abstract: The news form America which we publish today is hardly less important than the capture of NewOrleans. The Confederate army evacuated Yorktown on the 4th of May, abandoning a number of its guns, together with stores and ammunition, and retreated to Williamsburg, a few miles up the Peninsula. Here they seem to purpose making a stand, and Gen. McCLELLAN anticipates an obstinate contest.
lead_paragraph: From the London Times, May 17th.

abstract: Editorial sees future resources abundant despite war; Editorial sees abundant population and resources in future despite war
snippet: Editorial sees future resources abundant despite war; Editorial sees abundant population and resources in future despite war
lead_paragraph: Foreign financiers and political economists continue to be tenderly solicitous as regards the prospects of the United States Treasury, and predict all manner of evils and embarrassments springing from the expense of crushing the rebellion. As the answer to their conviction of our military failure is to be found in our catalogue of swelling and successive victories, so is the response to financial auguries engraved with unmistakable clearness on the lists of our Stock Exchange. Neither domestic treason nor foreign depreciation, neither the intrigues of Bears, nor threats of intervention, have succeeded in persuading the loyal people of America that their Government securities are worth less than their face in gold. In this state of affairs, we find from the inside and outside enemies of the nation a surprise which is only exceeded by their chagrin. Yet the matter is by no means so hard to explain as they would have us believe. So far as the Transatlantic theorists are concerned, their blunders really lie in a nutshell, and for this reason: Every calculation wherein they draw on European precedents to demonstrate our financial future is purely fallacious, because nothing in their history furnishes a parallel with our growth in population and resources.

abstract: FIRING THE SOUTHERN COTTON. -- The rebels begin to see that all their boasts about achieving success by fighting are tumbling to the ground. The wager of battle, which they so defiantly offered to the nation, is likely to result in their utter and irretrievable discomfiture. In their fury and stupidity now, they imagine they can work out Southern independence by the novel expedient of burning up all their cotton. They will thereby terrify the North into letting them go, and frighten the nations of Europe into recognizing their independence, and, if necessary, taking up the quarrel for them. Gen. LOVELL, the hero of New-Orleans, has issued an order upon the subject, which goes into the cotton and into rhetoric, in what cannot be characterized otherwise than as a decidedly "high old style." "If," shouts he to his fellow-citizens, "if you have fixed your undimmed eye upon the brightness that spreads out before you," &c., &c. -- what then? -- what if you have? Buckle on your bowie knives, plant yourselves sternly in the last ditch, and die as KIRBY was wont to expire? Not at present. But, shrieks he, wildly, "One sparkling, living touch of fire in manly action for one hour upon each cotton plantation, and the eternal seal of Southern independence is fired and fixed in the great heart of the world!" How so, General; if you have leisure, let us ask you, how so? We have not time at present to quarrel about the mixedness and incongruity of your figures of speech, or the violence of your manner; but really we would like to know how the eternal seal which you mention would befired and fixed in the great heart of the world by any such means as the burning up of the cotton crop? That, in itself, could not achieve Southern independence. It would assuredly achieve Southern bankruptcy, ruin and slave-abolition. For what other wealth has the South than its cotton, and what would be the use of keeping slaves to raise it if it be burned as soon as it is grown? Such a course would certainly not weigh a feather with the North, in inducing it to cease the war; for all considerations of cotton, or property, or Slavery sink into insignificance when compared with the determination of the people to restore the Union and uphold the Government. Such a policy could not induce England or France to intervene in behalf of the rebellion; for if the cotton were all consumed, and the universal desolation which Gen. LOVELL invites had spread over the South, what motive could there then be to recognize such a charred and blackened fragment of a country -- such a chaotic political and social jumble, such a horde of miscreants, as an independent power?

abstract: Public improvements discussed
snippet: Public improvements discussed
lead_paragraph: The work of improving the Central Park goes steadily forward, and the space included in its limits is being rapidly canverted from a rough, rocky, uncultivated tract, into the beautiful resort we have been led to expect from the improvements already made. The upper portion of the tract will shortly be made more sightly than heretofore. The portion between Eighty-sixth and Ninety-seventh streets, in length about half a mile, has, for a long time past, been covered with stone and other material, to be used in the construction of the new reservoir. This space has now, however, been mostly cleared of the obstructions, and the authorities will soon commence the work of beautifying it, in accordance with their plans.

abstract: The flight of the Rebel army of the Southwest from its fortified position at Corinth, looks like an abandonment of the campaign in the Gulf States, and the Mississippi Valley.
lead_paragraph: The flight of the Rebel army of the Southwest from its fortified position at Corinth, looks like an abandonment of the campaign in the Gulf States, and the Mississippi Valley. There were at Corinth all the fighting rebels from that vast region; they had there a good strategic position, with railroads ramifying from it all through the South; they were in a more favorable location for obtaining supplies than can be found between there and the Gulf of Mexico; and they were not within reach of those terrible gunboats of ours, which have lately furnished an excuse for so many rebel retreats and evacuations. It is very true that time was not increasing these facilities and advantages. The capture of New-Orleans, and the ascent of the Mississippi by our gunboats, cut them off from the supplies they had formerly received from Texas; the advance of Gen. CURTIS to the White and Arkansas Rivers, cut off their supplies from Northeastern Arkansas, while the naval and military operations on the northward and to the eastward of their position, had severed it from the grain-growing regions of Tennessee. All their railroad connections, too, were being destroyed one by one; and if our gunboats could not directly play upon Corinth, they were on the eve of opening upon Memphis -- after the fall of which the continued occupation of Corinth would be a military impossibility. Still, if these various movements weakened the strength of the rebel position at Corinth, they weaken still more the strength of any other position they may choose to take up south of Corinth. If they should attempt, as they have already attempted, to move down over the Mobile and Ohio Railroad, they find that POPE is already operating there; if they move over the only other line running southward, the Mississippi Central Railroad, they will find the terminus of that road in our hands; and if they stop at Jackson, in the centre of the State, as is given forth they will, they will learn, as indeed they already know, that Vicksburgh and the line of the short road running west from Jackson is ours, and that they are then in a worse plight than it would have been possible for the most consummate strategy to have brought them in at Corinth. It is hardly possible that they ever had an intention of stopping at Jackson; for there, even with the points at present in our possession, we could fall upon them in front and rear and on both flanks; and there, too, our gunboats, by ascending the Pearl River, could act upon them with destructive effect. Besides, though in the region between Memphis and Jackson there is cotton enough raised to clothe the whole South, there is not corn or bacon enough to supply a regiment of its troops. There can be little doubt that if, in evacuating Corinth, the rebels have moved southward, as the telegraph affirms, they have abandoned once and forever the Valley of the Mississippi. As to the assertion, made by some, that they will retire into the swamps of Mississippi and Alabama, and draw our army down there to be destroyed by miasma and gallinippers, such a theory can be held only by those who are illy informed about the strategic topography of those States, and of the nature of great military operations.

abstract: Yesterday at noon Commodore MONTGOMERY assumed command of the Philadelphia Navy-Yard. Sixteen years ago he landed in the streets of San Francisco, and hoisted the American flag in its square. It was Commodore MONTGOMERY who commanded the corvette Portsmouth when the Mexican war broke out.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday at noon Commodore MONTGOMERY assumed command of the Philadelphia Navy-Yard. Sixteen years ago he landed in the streets of San Francisco, and hoisted the American flag in its square. It was Commodore MONTGOMERY who commanded the corvette Portsmouth when the Mexican war broke out. In less than 24 hours after the receipt of the intelligence the Stars and Stripes were, by orders of the gallant officer, flying at San Francisco, Bodiga, Sonora, Sutler's Fort and San Jose. With 200 officers and men a district of over 200 miles square was occupied, and no flag was ever torn down of any hoisted at the above-named places, although at every other point, save Monterey, the Mexicans succeeded in lowering it. It was Commodore MONTGOMERY's promptness that relieved FREMONT, when, fatigued, hungry and penniless, he returned from his tour of Oregon, whither Mr. BUCHANAN sent him almost unprovided for. The Portsmouth, under MONTGOMERY's command, took all the prizes, save one, that were captured in the Pacific during the war. It is to be hoped, therefore, that Philadelphians will not think their new commandant an unknown man, in the blaze of victories that immortalize his younger cotemporaries. He relieves the "Cable Commodore," Capt. HUDSON, who may now be expected to get a ship or fleet.

abstract: failed to take time enough from his multifarious and arduous duties, to send to the Government at Washington the fullest possible account of his dealings with the Consul of the Netherlands at New-Orleans, and full proofs of the facts upon which he acted. We hope he has done this, in order that a true and full account of the whole affair may reach our Representatives abroad at the outset. We all know how the excitement in England in relation to the Trent was raised at once to fever heat by the preposterous stories of the enraged Englishmen on board her, which our friends could not contradict, because they had not yet had time to hear our side of the story. And so this act of Gen. BUTLER's, if the account sent by the Consul is to have time to work uncontradicted, may do us great harm. For we may rest assured that it is not a complaint to friends, who will judge most favorably of the facts and will hear us before they condemn. The foreign Powers have none of them shown themselves over and above friendly, and just now, when we have from them such frequent intimations of a desire to interfere in our matters, this affair may furnish a pretext which will be very gladly laid hold of.

abstract: Only the Senate was in session yesterday. A bill was introduced by Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, to enable slaves to establish a right to freedom under the act to confiscate the property of rebels, &c. A resolution was offered by Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, and laid over, providing for a Select Committee to investigate the official conduct of Adjutant-Gen. THOMAS. The resolution to compensate the crew of the gunboat Varuna, for the loss of clothing and other property in the fight below New-Orleans, was passed. The House bill to allow California an additional representative was passed. The bill legalizing the acceptance of volunteers by the President was called up by Mr. WILSON, who offered a substitute authorizing a further acceptance of volunteers, but limiting the whole number to 700,000, and providing for a premium of $2 for every soldier enlisted, and for the payment of two months' wages in advance. Mr. WILSON stated that the aggregate number of men now in service is estimated at 617,654, but we have a large number at home, on leave and sick, and the probable number of effective men in the field is 500,000. An amendment was adopted limiting the premium to the regular service. The bill was discussed until 1 o'clock, when the Tax-bill was again taken up, and debated until the adjournment. The proposed tax on coal was reduced.

abstract: The schooner Hannibal, (of Bangor,) Capt. WINTHROP, from Nassau, N.P., May 23, with logwood and cotton to C.C. DUNCAN, arrived yesterday. She left there the Confederate at amers Thomas L. Wragg, to sail for Charleston in a few days. The Wm. Seabrook, from Charleston, the Santee from a Southern port, just arrived with a cargo of cotton. The Confederate steamers Kate, Cecil and Nelly, sailed May 20, for Charleston. The Hannibal brings the following passengers, Mr. H. Galacar, lady and son; J. Cohen and lady; Miss E. Murphy, Miss N. Murphy, Miss J. Illing, E. Barnston, M. Dectel, J. Musgrove, Mrs. Ellen J. Hodgdon.

abstract: Gen. BANKS has already commenced his second campaign of the Shenandoah. He has moved across the Potomac and to Martinsburgh, and his advance seems to be pushing toward Winchester. JACKSON, in the meantime, appears to have commenced his second retrograde movement up the Valley, though as yet we hear of only a small detachment of his force. It does not seem possible, however, that he will be able to escape down the Valley as he did before. We have news this morning that our troops have repossessed Front Royal, from which they were driven a week ago. If they succeed in recapturing Strasburgh, JACKSON will be in a tight place -- particularly when he discovers that FREMONT is in his rear up the valley. It looks now as if his whole force would certainly and speedily be bagged; though it is quite possible if he finds there are no means of escape, that his command will break up and take to the mountains.

abstract: Pursuant to an extended public notice, the main hall of the Cooper Institute was thrown open last evening to any and all who might feel desirous of participating in the celebration of the first ...
lead_paragraph: Pursuant to an extended public notice, the main hall of the Cooper Institute was thrown open last evening to any and all who might feel desirous of participating in the celebration of the first anniversary of the day on which the Naval Brigade landed at Fortress Monroe. The country is somewhat familiar with the origin and progress of this noted corps, which was originated in this City by WASHINGTON ALLEN BARTLETT, who, upon the full organization of the same, became its Colonel. That gentleman was formerly a Lieutenant in the Navy, in which service he passed twenty-two years, earning an enviable reputation for efficiency and gallantry, until he was, with a host of other able officers, displaced by the famous "Examining Board," under the Pierce Administration. Lieut. BARTLETT's history was interesting in this connection previous to the outbreak of the existing rebellion, and became doubly so, after the organization of his brigade, whose mishaps and difficulties culminated in an accident at the Rip Raps, by which the Colonel nearly lost his life, and the subsequent transfer of the force to another commander and its final transposition into the ordinary service as the Ninety-ninth Regiment N.Y.S.V. The 31st of May, 1861, saw the brigade set foot as such, for the first time, on the soil of Virginia, and Col. BARTLETT deemed the recurrence of the day, this year, a befitting occasion for a reunion of its friends and ex-members, and all others whom sympathy or curiosity might attract to the scene.

lead_paragraph: We receive the important intelligence by way of San Francisco, that on the 7th ult., the French troops retired from before the city of Puebla, declining a battle with the Mexican forces which were drawn up to meet them. The news was conveyed to San Francisco by the steamer Orizaba, from Acapulco.

abstract: Our late disasters in the Valley of the Shenandoah are being removed, so far as it is possible to do so. Front Royal, the scene of the defeat of Col. KENLY and his brave First Maryland ...
lead_paragraph: Our late disasters in the Valley of the Shenandoah are being removed, so far as it is possible to do so. Front Royal, the scene of the defeat of Col. KENLY and his brave First Maryland Regiment, has been recaptured, apparently with as much fatality to the rebels as was suffered by us. A brigade of our troops, preceded by four companies of the Rhode Island Cavalry, entered the place on Friday morning, and drove out the enemy, consisting of the Eighth Louisiana, four companies of the Twelfth Georgia and a body of cavalry. The enemy, it appears, were taken completely by surprise, and had no time either to save or to destroy anything. A large amount of transportation fell into our hands, including two engines and eleven cars on the Manassas Gap Railroad. We captured six officers and one hundred and fifty privates, besides killing and wounding a large number of rebels. Our loss in this affair was but eight killed, five wounded and one missing. Several of our men who were taken prisoners at Front Royal a week ago, were recaptured by our forces. In addition to this decided success, we are gratified to announce that Gen. BANKS has once more advanced from Harper's Ferry, the Fifth New-York Cavalry having passed through Martinsburgh, and several miles beyond, yesterday morning. They encountered the rebel cavalry, and captured several prisoners, together with a wagon, muskets, ammunition, &c. It has been ascertained that Col. KENLY, of the First Maryland, was not killed, but is now at Winchester, wounded.

abstract: Editorial says recent successes have awakened British press appreciation of Union
snippet: Editorial says recent successes have awakened British press appreciation of Union
lead_paragraph: The recent successes of the National arms, culminating in the possession of New-Orleans, seem to be at last awakening in the English Press a True appreciation of the utter hopelessness of this rebellion; and, as a natural consequence, they appear to be already casting about for the discovery of some mode of cutting the gordian knot of this difficulty, very different from the mode which has been so long held in favor among them.

lead_paragraph: The members of the Twenty-eighth Regiment positively expected to leave for the seat of war yesterday, but in this all were disappointed. They were at the City Armory during the day, expecting to hear the order to fall in every moment, but owing to some delay in the arrival of accoutrements, it was not given, and at a late hour the Colonel dismissed the command until Monday morning, at which time, it is now said, they will surely take up their line of march. The regiment has a full complement of men, and every one is eager to be in the field. Annexed is a complete list of the officers of the Twenty-eighth Regiment:

abstract: CITIZENS OF PUEBLA: From the City of Cordova I had the honor to address all my fellow-countrymen, and explain the reason that brings the French arms to our soil, the causes that under these circumstances induced me to present myself among you, and the final object of my patriotic intentions. Now, however, that I find myself among you, it is very pleasing to be able to address you more particularly,if not to repeat what I have already declared, at least to congratulate myself as well as you, that under the protection of a friendly flag, you are in possession of your liberty, so that you can, without fear of new persecution or vicissitudes, enjoy your goods and social rights, and manifest your wishes to the end of contributing to the establishment of a moral, respectable and lasting Government.
lead_paragraph: CITIZENS OF PUEBLA: From the City of Cordova I had the honor to address all my fellow-countrymen, and explain the reason that brings the French arms to our soil, the causes that under these circumstances induced me to present myself among you, and the final object of my patriotic intentions. Now, however, that I find myself among you, it is very pleasing to be able to address you more particularly,if not to repeat what I have already declared, at least to congratulate myself as well as you, that under the protection of a friendly flag, you are in possession of your liberty, so that you can, without fear of new persecution or vicissitudes, enjoy your goods and social rights, and manifest your wishes to the end of contributing to the establishment of a moral, respectable and lasting Government.

abstract: GERMAN OPERA. -- A very satisfactory performance of "Martha" was given at the Stadt Theatre, in the Bowery, on Friday evening, by the German opera company, under the management of Mr. QUINT. The following was the cast: Martha, Mme. ROTTER; Nancy. Mme. FICHER; Tristam, Mr. GRAFF; Plunkett, Mr. LEHMANN; Lionel, Mr. LOTTI. The solo parts, which have generally been the weak part of our German opera troupes, were excellently sung, and the orchestra and chorus were better than usual. The house was crowded. In the absence of the opera from the Academy, the performances of this troupe present quite an agreeable substitute. MOZART's "Magic Flute" is to be given on Wednesday, Mme. ROTTER, an excellent prima donna from Germany, appearing as the Queen of the Night.
lead_paragraph: GERMAN OPERA. -- A very satisfactory performance of "Martha" was given at the Stadt Theatre, in the Bowery, on Friday evening, by the German opera company, under the management of Mr. QUINT. abstract: MORTALITY. During the week ending yesterday, there were 102 deaths in this city, from the following named diseases: Fatty degeneration of kidneys, old age, cyanosis, diarrhoea, unknown ...
lead_paragraph: MORTALITY. -- During the week ending yesterday, there were 102 deaths in this city, from the following named diseases: Fatty degeneration of kidneys, old age, cyanosis, diarrhoea, unknown, jaundice casualty, intermittent fever, measles, sprue, apoplexy, cirrhosis -- one each; inflammation of bowels, tuberculosis, drowned, inflammation of stomach, cholera infantum, bronchitis, marasmus, scarlet fever, croup, diphtheria, whooping cough, disease of the heart, palsy, hydrocephalus -- 2 each; premature birth, typhoid fever, dropsy, strangulated hernia -- 3 each; debility, 4; congestion of the lungs, inflammation of the lungs -- 5 each; convulsions, 12; consumption, 16; stillborn, 6. Males, 50; females, 52. Forty-six of those who died were five years old and under.

abstract: MORMONISM IN NEW-YORK A MAN WITH THREE WIVES. JACOB A. HANSON, alias ADOLPHUS O. W. GRAHAM, was taken into custody yesterday by Officer TAYLOR, of the Essex Market Court, charged with being the husband of three wives, all of whom, it is stated, are now living.
lead_paragraph: MORMONISM IN NEW-YORK -- A MAN WITH THREE WIVES. -- JACOB A. HANSON, alias ADOLPHUS O. W. GRAHAM, was taken into custody yesterday by Officer TAYLOR, of the Essex Market Court, charged with being the husband of three wives, all of whom, it is stated, are now living. In answer to the questions put to him by Justice OSBORNE, the accused said he was born in the West Indies; that he was 19 years of age, and at present a resident of Brooklyn. Two of his reputed wives were in Court yesterday afternoon, and appeared to enjoy the punishment inflicted upon their husband exceedingly. The facts of the case, briefly stated, areas follows: On the 22d of February last, the accused -- whose true name, by the way, is A.O.W. GRAHAM -- married a young lady by the name of HARRIET GLINN, of No. 66 Rivington-street. The acquaintance of the parties was very brief prior to the marriage, but GRAHAM was a man of genteel exterior, very prepossessing in his manners, and made loud professions of wealth and position. He dressed with scrupulous neatness, in the garb of a navy officer, and sometimes represented that be was a surgeon in the navy, at others that he was a passed midshipman. These pretences had the effect to induce Miss GLINN to consent to marry him. For a few days the pair lived happily together, but soon the supposed navy surgeon had occasion, as he said, to leave the City on official business. Instead of taking his departure, however, he left his young wife for the purpose of gaining the affections of another lady of this City, by the name of ROSANNAH LEDDY. After a short courtship he was married to the latter on the 15th of May ult. As soon as the ceremony was performed he took his new wife to the Astor House, where he engaged rooms, and lived in fine style for two weeks. He represented to the proprietors of the Hotel that he was a naval Surgeon, under the pay of the Government, but that he would have no money until the first of the month. He appeared like a gentleman, was dressed as a naval officer, and his story seemed so plausible that he was allowed to run up a large bill before it was ascertained that he was an impostor. Yesterday the character of the man became so evident that it was deemed advisable to take him into custody. When taken before the magistrate, he was confronted by two of his wives, both of whom made affidavits of the facts above mentioned. Another wife of his, it is stated upon good authority, is now living somewhere in the interior of this State. Several parties who have been swindled out of money by him, will make complaints to-morrow. Numerous persons in this City and Brooklyn have trusted him to large amounts, upon the strength of his representations that he was an officer in the navy. The fact is, that he was never connected with the naval department in any manner. Justice OSBORNE committed him to prison to await the action of the Grand Jury.

abstract: The evacuation of Manassas by the rebels was the signal for an outcry against Gen. MCCLELLAN, because he had not prevented it. And when Yorktown was evacuated, the same outcry was repeated. And men asked why he had not attacked the rebels, why he had not prevented their retreat, why he had not known of it before, and there were not wanting those who intimated that MCCLELLAN could not do anything except build fortifications, and that if we expected to have anything done on the east of our line, in the way of fighting, we should have to send for Gen. HALLECK to take the chief command.

abstract: The men belonging to this regiment were inspected and sworn into the service of the United States at the Arsenal, corner of White and Elm streets, yesterday. As each company was sworn in -- and it was made known to the men that they were regularly-accepted soldiers -- they testified their pleasure by loud cheers. To-day the uniforms, accoutrements and arms will be delivered to them. On Monday the regiment will positively leave for the seat of war.

abstract: Gen. SCOTT, the other day, in a single felicitous word, expressed most forcibly what he thinks of the present aspect of the rebellion. abstract: There is every indication that the ensuing Summer and Fall will see a vigorous revival in mercantile affaire. In the book-trade, which is as sensitive as a barometer to all outside influences, there seems, lately, to have been a marked change. For instance, Mr. CARLETON, of New-York, has sold five thousand copies of VICTOR HUGO's Les Miserables, and four thousand copies of Artemus Ward, in less than seven days after the date of their publication. This is doing well in spite of the war.

abstract: Music has had but a spasmodic existence during the past season, but nevertheless appears to be struggling resolutely to prolong it. Even opera is attempting to make another brief effort at life, which ...
lead_paragraph: Music has had but a spasmodic existence during the past season, but nevertheless appears to be struggling resolutely to prolong it. Even opera is attempting to make another brief effort at life, which we have every reason for thinking maybe successful. In other words, Mr. ULLMANN, who returned from Europe some ten days since, as we believe, is planning a short season, which will in all probability commence this week or the next. When the arrangements are completed, which only the cupidity of a few of our resident artists may probably prevent -- a cupidity which, we must say, is as ill-judged as it is at the present period ungracious -- we believe it will be found that he offers the public a more considerable degree of artistic novelty than any manager during the past musical year has done. Two prime donne, neither of whom have yet been heard in this City on the lyric stage, will probably appear. Although their names have not as yet been announced, we may hint that the one of them was the leading soprano in the opera at New-Orleans before the rebellion rendered that city unable to maintain such a costly amusement. Report speaks in the highest terms of her capabilities as a cantatrice, and although she has only been heard by us in a private drawing-room, we may frankly say -- judging by that occasion -- we believe report has done her no more than justice. The other is the wife of a prominent foreign artist, whose ability in her own profession has reaped a splendid pecuniary harvest during his tour through America. She is young, personally very charming, and has been studying for the operatic stage during the past two years. If the promise of success is borne out by her appearance at the Academy, she ought to be a valuable debutante to Mr. ULLMANN. We understand that D'ANGRI is to be contralto. It will be seen, that in female voices there is every promise of the troop Mr. ULLMANN is about to offer us being very rich. With male voices there is more difficulty, but we scarcely doubt that he will be able to overcome it, and will make another effort to tame that stray bird -- operatic success, -- while he meanwhile keeps the contract with RISTORI carefully buttoned up in the innermost recesses of his breast-pocket.

abstract: -- The ship John J. Boyd arrived here yesterday, 39 days from Liverpool, with [???] Mormons, bound for Utah. They will be landed at Castle Garden this morning. They are mostly English, Scotch and Irish, and among them are 139 children. There was very little sickness on the passage, and the passengers all look remarkably clean and healthy. The 400 Mormons who arrived in the ship Franklin, on Thursday last, were discharged from Castle Garden on Saturday, and most of them are probably now on their way to Salt Lake. They were principally from Denmark and Sweden.

abstract: PLYMOUTH CHURCH. Mr. BEECHER last evening delivered one of his radical appeals for justice to all men, and in connection therewith a scathing rebuke to all injustice and selfishness particularly as affecting ...
lead_paragraph: PLYMOUTH CHURCH. -- Mr. BEECHER last evening delivered one of his radical appeals for justice to all men, and in connection therewith a scathing rebuke to all injustice and selfishness -- particularly as affecting the inferior races, and especially that of the negro. He selected as his text the 40th verse of the 11th chapter of Hebrews: "God having provided some better thing for us, that they without us should not be made perfect." Christ, he said, did not suffer on the cross alone to save the Anglo-Saxon race, as some affected to believe, but he suffered that all mankind might have the road of salvation open to them; even including the negroes. He impressed upon the minds of his hearers the important truth that the world could not be elevated unless the inferior races were taken along too; that it was the duty of all men, but especially of Christians, to render justice to the ignorant and depraved of all races. In this connection Mr. BEECHER read an extract from the Newbern, N.C., correspondent of the TIMES, (E.S.,) wherein it is stated that Gov. STANLY had informed Mr. COLYER (who has been teaching the negroes to read since the advent of Gen. BURNSIDE into that State) that his instructions from Washington were to administer the laws of the State as he found them; consequently, under the laws of North Carolina, teaching negroes to read being a penal offence, Mr. COLYER would have to cease his philanthropic work. If, said Mr. BEECHER, the Government at Washington sanctions that decision of Gov. STANLY, the people have been deceived. He did not believe, however, that the Governor, in this respect, would be sustained. If the people of North Carolina had elected a Governor, then there might be some excuse for enforcing this law; but if the Government had the right and the power to force upon the people of that State a Governor, that Government had equally a right to order that the law referred to should not be enforced, and he believed it would be done.

abstract: The news from the Army of the Potomac, this morning, is of the most intensely exciting and important character. Another great battle has been fought, and another great victory has been won!
lead_paragraph: The news from the Army of the Potomac, this morning, is of the most intensely exciting and important character. Another great battle has been fought, and another great victory has been won According to the first brief telegram from Gen. MCCLELLAN, dated at noon yesterday, on the battle-field, the enemy made an attack upon the right of our lines at 1 o'clock P.M., on Saturday, in the midst of a terrible storm, which had flooded the whole valley of the Chickahominy. Gen. CASEY's Division, which was in the first line, gave way before the enemy, "unaccountably and disunitedly," as Gen. MCCLELLAN states. Temporary confusion was thus caused, during which some of our guns and baggage were lost; but the enemy were checked in a handsome manner by Gens. HEINTZELMAN and KEYES, and held at bay until, by great exertion, the divisions of Gens. SEDGWICK and RICHARDSON were brought across the river, when the enemy was driven back at the point of the bayonet, leaving the ground covered with his dead. This ended the conflict on Saturday. Yesterday morning the enemy attempted to renew it, but was everywhere repulsed. Many prisoners were captured by us, including Gen. PETTIGREW, of South Carolina, and Col. LONG. Our losses in killed and wounded are heavy, but nothing to compare with those of the enemy, which, Gen. MCCLELLAN says, must be enormous. During the progress of the fighting, several fine bayonet charges were made -- two by the Second Excelsior Regiment, yesterday. We may now expect the speedy evacuation of Richmond.

abstract: For a wonder, one  Sunday has passed without any startling sensation. So accustomed has the City grown to being electrified by some capital event every Sunday, issued in extra and proclaimed by the vociferous newsboy, that yesterday probably seemed to many tame and void in consequence. It was on a Sunday that the announcement of the raid of the Merrimac came, and almost every Sunday since has brought with it some new and stirring event -- such as the evacuaion of Yorktown, the capture of Norfolk, the destruction of the Merrimac, the repulse of our iron-clads on the James River, and the like; while only last Sunday we had the great scare of the repulse of BANKS, and the "wily and barbarous horde" moving on Washington! Though less exciting, it is, however, far more Sabbath-like that the blessed air should not be coined into dangerous shouts of bloody battles and glorious victories, and no sound more jarring than the church-bell be heard on that day which pre-figures the time when men shall study war no more.

abstract: -The anti-secession movements in North Carolina are sufficiently encouraging, even if some of the reports of Union manifestations turn out to be unfounded. But really the most significant evidence of the spirit of the Old North State, and one which is in no danger of exaggeration, is to be found in the turn of events with reference to the next State Governor. The Secessionists have put forward as their candidate KENNETH RAYNOR, a rabid rebel of the South Carolina stripe. The conservative anti-secession and (in posse) Unionist party, on the contrary, have chosen Hon. WILLIAM A. GRAHAM, (Mr. FILLMORE'S Secretary of the Navy,) one of the most active members of the recalcitrant Convention that have lately been kicking against the Richmond despotism. GRAHAM has the support and sympathy and will probably have the votes of the great majority of the State. Now, though not ostensibly or avowedly, these parties really represent the Confederacy on the one hand and the Union on the other. The whole tenor of their public discussion and discourse has this scope and no other, and it requires no great skill in reading between the lines to see that this is really the marrow of the whole matter. Among the significent indications to this effect is the following from the Raleigh Standard, the Democratic organ of the State, which, in urging the election of Mr. GRAHAM, says:

abstract: The Annual Regatta of the Club will come off on Thursday morning, the 5th of June, at 10 o'clock. There will be a prize valued at $125 for each class of yachts. The classes will be allowed time for measurement ...
lead_paragraph: The Annual Regatta of the Club will come off on Thursday morning, the 5th of June, at 10 o'clock. There will be a prize valued at $125 for each class of yachts. The classes will be allowed time for measurement as follows: The first class, one second per square foot; the second class, one and thirty-five hundredths seconds per square foot; the third class, one and seven-tenths seconds per square foot. This allowance shall be based upon the product of the multiplication of the extreme length, on or under the water-line, from fore side of stem to aft side of sternpost, by the extreme breadth, wherever found-both measures to be in feet and decimals.

abstract: We receive the important intelligence by way of San Francisco, that on the 7th ult., the French troops retired from before the city of Puebla, declining a battle with the Mexican forces which were drawn up to meet them.

The news was conveyed to San Francisco by the steamer Orizaba, from Acapulco.

abstract: NEW CLAIMANTS FOR CITIZENSHIP THE CHURCH PROPERTY NOT IN DANGER. Judge HILTON, of the Court of Common Pleas, presided in that wellknown and (as we say of a good-hearted, fat and jovial gentleman of ease) highly respected institution ...
lead_paragraph: NEW CLAIMANTS FOR CITIZENSHIP -- THE CHURCH PROPERTY NOT IN DANGER. -- Judge HILTON, of the Court of Common Pleas, presided in that wellknown and (as we say of a good-hearted, fat and jovial gentleman of ease) highly respected institution one day last week. It seems he had very little to do, for the only attendant awaiting the judicial fiat was a clerk, who, like the ball that the lamented late father-in-law of Col. FREMONT set in motion, was there "solitary and alone." The accomplished Judge, it may be readily supposed, was about to do, under the circumstances, what Dean SWIFT is said to have done in a somewhat parallel state of affairs. The Dean, after his debut in Ireland, was sent to take charge of a very flourishing Protestant parish. On the occasion of what is there called "a visitation," which is to some of the clergy of the Established Church a "visitation" in more senses than one, the Dean was obliged, from a paucity of reformed brethren in his neighborhood -- there being few petticoats or brogues on hand -- to borrow from a friendly Catholic priest a very numerous congregation, in order to satisfy the Bishop of the Diocese that the Evangelizing trade had been immensely effectual. On the Sunday after, however, the only "congregation" was ROGER, the clerk. "ROGER," says the pastor, "let us pray." And here we approach the point. Judge HILTON, it may be readily supposed, was just on the point of saying, "Mr. KENNEDY," ask the officer to adjourn the Court," when an apparition appeared -- angels escorted by N.J. JARVIS, Esq., the clerk. It was four sisters of the order of the Good Shepherd, clothed in conventual robes, mauve flowing garments, white linen bandages on their fair foreheads, and flowing veils. They came -- three of them, at least -- from Ireland to this City, to found an asylum, not for the reformation only, but for the reformation and restoration to reputable and pious character among decent men and virtuous women of the poor fallen creatures, whose poverty or ignorance, (or, may it be said, innocence,) has contributed to their unhappy fortune. In order to aid in saving these unfortunate girls, these ladies, having arrived here, became possessed of certain property near Yorkville, on which to found an establishment. It is necessary, in order to acquire a legal title to real estate in New-York, that the claimant shall be a naturalized citizen. In compliance with this enactment, it was that these good women presented themselves before His Honor, Judge HILTON, who, with all the suavity and consideration of a gentleman, and all the delicacy, which not only befits but adorns the Bench, yielded to the request at once.

lead_paragraph: Gen. Prim and suite, who arrived on Saturday last, were last night visited, at the Clarenden Hotel, by Mr. Stoughten and Mr. Camaeho, respectively Consuls in this City of Spain and Venezuela, and several prominent Spanish and American gentlemen. Gen. Prim and suite leaves ere long for Europe in the Don Antonio Ulloa, the Spanish war frigate in which they arrived from Havana.

abstract: PLYMOUTH CHURCH. Mr. BEECHER last evening delivered one of his radical appeals for justice to all men, and in connection therewith a scathing rebuke to all injustice and selfishness particularly as affecting ...
lead_paragraph: PLYMOUTH CHURCH. -- Mr. BEECHER last evening delivered one of his radical appeals for justice to all men, and in connection therewith a scathing rebuke to all injustice and selfishness -- particularly as affecting the inferior races, and especially that of the negro. He selected as his text the 40th verse of the [???] chapter of Hebrews: "God having provided some better thing for us, that they without us should not be made perfect." Christ, he said, did not suffer on the cross alone to save the Anglo-Saxon race, as some affected to believe, but he suffered that all mankind might have the road of salvation open to them; even including the negroes. He impressed upon the minds of his hearers the important truth that the world could not be elevated unless the inferior races were taken along too; that it was the duty of all men, put especially of Christians, to render justice to the ignorant and depraved of all races. In this connection, Mr. BEECKER read an extract from the [???], N.C., correspondent of the TIMES, (E.S.,) wherein it is stated that Gov. STANLY had informed Mr. COLYER (who has been teaching the negroes to [???] since the advent of Gen. BURNSIDE into that States [???] at his instructions from Washington were to [???] for the laws of the State as he found them; consistently, under the laws of North Carolina, teaching negroes to read being a penal offence, Mr. COLYER would have to cease his philanthropic work. [???] said Mr. PEECKER, the Government at Washington [???] that decision of Gov. STANLY, the people have been deceived. He did not believe, however, that the Governor, in this respect, would be sustained. If the people of North Carolina had elected a Governor, then there might be some excuse for enforcing this law; but if the Government had the right and the power to force upon the people of that State a Governor, that Government had equally a right to order that the law referred to should not be enforced, and he believed it would be done.

abstract: Only the Senate was in session on Saturday. A bill was introduced by Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, to enable slaves to establish a right to freedom under the act to confiscate the property of rebels, &c. A resolution was offered by Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, and laid over, providing for a Select Committee to investigate the official conduct of Adjutant-Gen. THOMAS. The resolution to compensate the crew of the gunboat Varuna, for the loss of clothing and other property in the fight below New-Orleans, was passed. The House bill to allow California an additional representative was passed. The bill legalizing the acceptance of volunteers by the President was called up by Mr. WILSON, who offered a substitute authorizing a further acceptance of volunteers, but limiting the whole number to 700,000, and providing for a premium of $2 for every soldier enlisted, and for the payment of two months' wages in advance. Mr. WILSON stated that the aggregate number of men now in service is estimated at 617,654, but we have a large number at home, on leave and sick, and the probable number of effective men in the field is 500,000. An amendment was adopted limiting the premium to the regular service. The bill was discussed until 1 o'clock, when the Tax-bill was again taken up, and debated until the adjournment. The proposed tax on coal was reduced.

abstract: Officer CARROL, of the Eighth Precinct, was very roughly handled yesterday morning, by a number of rowdies, in a groggery at the corner of Grand and Laurens streets, kept by a man named SHIELS. The officer, seeing the place open at 1 o'clock, and a number of well-known rowdies carousing at the bar, arrested the proprietor. A rescue was attempted by the rowdies, led by SHIELS' brother, in which the officer had his head and neck cut, but succeeded in arresting SHIELS and his brother. The latter was this morning held in $500 to answer, and SHIELS, the proprietor, held in $100.

abstract: A correspondent  of the Philadelphia Press, writing from Fort Monroe, sends to that paper a sensation fiction which will greatly rejoice the hearts and aid the schemes of the rebels. He states that two hundred and seventy-two negroes have been decoyed on board a bark which has been lying off the fort for some time, and carried off to Cuba to be sold as slaves. Unless matters are conducted there with a good deal less of method and rigor than we think prevails, this story is simply preposterous. No such thing could possibly take place. All the contrabands who have collected at the Fortress have been under military control, having a regular Superintendent, who keeps the list of them, regulates their hours of work and rates of pay, and has the same supervision of them that the Colonel of a regiment has of his men. To suppose that two hundred and seventy-two of these negroes could be carried away without his knowledge, is simply ridiculous.

abstract: Editorial on Stanly refusal to allow opening of Negro schools in North Carolina; Editorial on Gov. Stanly refusal to allow opening of Negro schools in North Carolina
snippet: Editorial on Stanly refusal to allow opening of Negro schools in North Carolina; Editorial on Gov. Stanly refusal to allow opening of Negro schools in North Carolina
lead_paragraph: -Our North Carolina correspondent, ina letter from Newbern, which we published yesterday, mentioned an incident connected with Gov. STANLY's entrance upon his official duties, which will not make a pleasant impression upon the public. Mr. V. COLYER, in his capacity as Superintendent of the Poor, has been engaged in establishing schools for the blacks of that vicinity. Gov. STANLY informed him, at his first interview, that his instructions from Washington were to enforce the laws of the State precisely as they stood before the outbreak of the rebellion, and these laws made the opening of such schools a criminal offence. Mr. COLYER has accordingly closed the schools.

abstract: The Orthodox yearly meeting commenced on last Thursday, the opposite society, commonly called Hicksite, having closed their session the day previous. During the progress of the yearly meeting a number ...
lead_paragraph: The Orthodox yearly meeting commenced on last Thursday, the opposite society, commonly called Hicksite, having closed their session the day previous. During the progress of the yearly meeting a number of distinguished speakers have been moved to unusual eloquence in denunciation, as they declare, of the unchristian strife which now marks our country's history; but for all that, appropriate as such doctrine is to the quiet non-resistant principle. Friends, there beat, and that too, evidently to the less disciplined observer, hearts as loyal under the breast linings of those shad-bellied coats, and precisely platted kerchiefs and three-cornered mantles, as beat in the bosoms of our fighting heroes. It is curious and interesting to see how an occasional touching of the subject by one Friend, will be but an opening for a dissertation upon the shocking consequences of pride and political preferences; how another, disapproving of "Friends meddling with what is so entirely out of the pale of recognition" more than as a relic of barbarism, will give the subject a thorough letting alone; and how another, such as RACHEL BARKER MOORE, will denounce the rebellion in no picked terms, and while giving all praise to our President for his long suffering patience, and the Cabinet for their wisdom in supporting him, touches up the consciences of the nation generally, with arrows of eloquence aimed at their torpid remorse as a "fast people." There is no manner of doubt that if Friend RACHEL had have had the ear of our "honest" Chief Magistrate, she would have labored with his patient spirit, to the end that he might not, heed the call to arms from her more impulsive countrymen; for she says, "We are a fast people; we do not love to stop and think:" and now that the mischief, if not played out, is well on to the close of the fifth act, she, in mildest terms, insinuates that bad we been a less rapidly disposed people, if we had indeed emulated the patient bearing of our amiable Chief Magistrate, who, she avers, "was placed in an exceedingly trying position," we might have settled the difficulty with our brethren without resort to deadly weapons.

abstract: The battle fought in front of Richmond on Saturday and yesterday, seems to have amounted to a general engagement.
lead_paragraph: The battle fought in front of Richmond on Saturday and yesterday, seems to have amounted to a general engagement. The corps d'armee of Generals SUMNER, HEINTZELMAN and KEYES -- all the organized army corps, though not all the troops, under Gen. MCCLELLAN -- were engaged, and probably by the whole rebel force at Richmond, for Gen. MCCLELLAN says that their numbers were greatly superior to ours. The information we have concerning the battle is meagre, but it is sufficient to let us know that our army has gloriously triumphed.

abstract: The Memphis Appeal, on the 17th of May, made an elaborate calculation of the military strength of the Southern States, which led it to the very comfortable conclusion that, within thirty days they would have in the field an "effective army of 500,000 men, as renowned for their courage as invincible in their purpose." Just about, judging from results. The Appeal further predicts that "this army will fall upon the invaders in two or more columns, drive them from the Confederacy, and thence proceed to precipitate itself into the very vitals of the North, carrying fire and sword into the country of the enemy." About ten days after this prediction, Memphis itself was evacuated.
lead_paragraph: The Memphis Appeal, on the 17th of May, made an elaborate calculation of the military strength of the Southern States, which led it to the very comfortable conclusion that, within thirty days they would have in the field an "effective army of 500,000 men, as renowned for their courage as invincible in their purpose." abstract: editorial criticizes Halleck for letting Confederates evacuate without his knowledge
snippet: editorial criticizes Halleck for letting Confederates evacuate without his knowledge
lead_paragraph: There is one lesson taught by the rebel evacuation of Corinth that should be remembered to the full vindication of Gen. MCCLELLAN in regard to the evacuation of Manassas. It will be recollected that the whole country was vocal with ridicule and censure from a class of our population, because MCCLELLAN had "let the enemy at Manassas get away from him." Although many miles distant, and never having approached Manassas even, much less endeavored to invest it, Gen. MCCLELLAN was expected to know to a hundred how many men the enemy had there, how many guns, how and where mounted, and what intentions their commanders had -- whether they meant to fight or run away. The fact that the leader of the Union army was disposed to approach cautiously the famous breastworks and redoubts of Centreville, was considered proof conclusive of a timid, hesitating disposition, afraid of "hurting" somebody or something, and wholly incompatible with the enterprise needed at the head of the army.
headline: {'main': 'Lesson Taught by the Evacuation of Corinth.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Lesson Taught by the Evacuation of Corinth.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -Capt. COLES, of the Royal Navy, whose name is associated with a plan of cupola shields, or deck turrets, for iron-clad vessels, has just had a taste of the narrow ness and perversity of that old-fogy affair, the British Admiralty. The success of the Monitor gave this Body of wise-acres a cupola-mania, and simply because Capt. COLES' plan embraced this feature, they immediately ordered that it should be applied to several ships. With a sense of justice particularly their own, however, they debarred the inventor from any practical supervision of the works that were to test the merits of his theory.

abstract: -- Gen. C.A. ARTHUR, who has had arduous labors for the last twelve months in equipping and securing transportation for more than 100,000 soldiers that have left this State for the seat of war, and who has been temporarily absent visiting the advance encampment of Gens. MCCLELLAN and MCDOWELL, looking after the condition and comforts of the volunteers from the Empire State, returned on Saturday evening. Gen. ARTHUR reports a prevailing good health and cheerfulness throughout the army, and a determination on the part of our soldiers to do their whole duty when their commanders give the orders. Gen. ARTHUR left the extreme front at a point 4 1/2 miles from Richmond, and from which he could see with the naked eye the rebel Capital.

lead_paragraph: The steamship Virginia, Capt. SNYDER, from Newbern, N. C., arrived at this port last evening, having on board 490 released prisoners. They appear in fine spirits, and are over-joyous to be once more so near their homes and friends, after being separated from them so long -- a majority having been closely confined in rebel factories and criminal prisons from ten to twelve months.

abstract: Editorial on report Arkansas is again in Union hands
snippet: Editorial on report Arkansas is again in Union hands
lead_paragraph: -- GOOD NEWS FROM AN UNEXPECTED QUARTER. -- We suppose it may be considered that the "fine old State of Arkansaw" is again back into the Union. Gen. CURTIS expelled the rebels from the northwestern part of the State; Gen. STEEL holds control, by means of the great batteaux fleet, of the river system in the northeastern section; FARBAGUT's fleet commands the southeastern line; and in the centre of the State a force under CURTIS has now seized and occupied Little Rock, the capital. Fort Smith on the extreme western verge of the State, is still in the hands of the rebels, but will doubtless surrender as soon as called upon by one of our gunboats. ALBERT PIKE's cannibals also are still hovering somewhere in that vicinity; but they will give us no more trouble. So that it may now be considered that we have absolute military control of the whole State. All that is required now is that the President select some "fine old Arkansaw gentleman," and make him Military Governor of the State, having first provided him with a good-sized Arkansas toothpick.
headline: {'main': 'ARKANSAS BACK TO THE UNION', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'ARKANSAS BACK TO THE UNION', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, petitions for the enlargement of the Oswego and Erie Canals and Locks were presented. Mr. SUMNER offered a resolution calling upon the Secretary of War for copies of the instructions of the Department to the Provisional Governors of Tennessee and North Carolina. They refer more particularly to the course of Gov. STANLY, in regard to teaching the colored people of North Carolina to read. The bill for the collection of taxes in insurrectionary districts was taken up, and all the House amendments agreed to excepting one. A resolution was adopted instructing the Committee on Public Lands to inquire into the expediency of reporting a bill to confiscate the public lands of Texas. At 1 o'clock the Tax bill was again taken up, and debated until past 5, when it was reported to the Senate -- which, however, adjourned without taking a vote on its passage.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, petitions for the enlargement of the Oswego and Erie Canals and Locks were presented. Mr. SUMNER offered a resolution calling upon the Secretary of War for copies of the instructions of the Department to the Provisional Governors of Tennessee and North Carolina. The bill for the collection of taxes in insurrectionary districts was taken up, and all the House amendments agreed to excepting one. A resolution was adopted instructing the Committee on Public Lands to inquire into the expediency of reporting a bill to confiscate the public lands of Texas. At 1 o'clock the Tax bill was again taken up, and debated until past 5, when it was reported to the Senate -- which, however, adjourned without taking a vote on its passage.

abstract: Gen. SIGEL is again inthe field. This will be his fourth campaign during the war. It was first LYON and SIGEL; then FREMONT and SIGEL; then CURTIS and SIGEL; now, from his location, we should judge it was likely to be BANKS and SIGEL. The first two of his campaigns were in SouthernMissouri last year; the third was in Western Arkansas this year; and the fourth -- SIGEL will soon let us know where it is. In all of his campaigns, SIGEL has proved himself to be not only a gallant soldier, but a most accomplished and scientific officer -- a master of military strategy, and of all the maneuvers of the field -- an indomitable, self-posses and modest man -- a loyal, intelligent Citizen. The whole country has followed him with admiration throughout his entire military career in the far West; and now that he takes the field in a new quarter, he will be watched with, if possible, a keener interest. Gen SIGEL has already performed some of the most splendid feats of the war. May his present campaign be still more brilliant.

abstract: The United States steam-transport Star of the South arrived here yesterday from Fortress Monroe, with 540 rebel prisoners, captured at the battle of Hanover Court-House. They are mostly North Caro-...
lead_paragraph: The United States steam-transport Star of the South arrived here yesterday from Fortress Monroe, with 540 rebel prisoners, captured at the battle of Hanover Court-House. They are mostly North Carolinians, and belonged to the Eighteenth, Twenty-eighth and Thirty-seventh Regiments from that State. abstract: The Tribune seems determined to be unhappy. If our armies meet with a check, it groans over the misfortune and calls lustily for negro aid. If they achieve a victory, it...
lead_paragraph: The Tribune seems determined to be unhappy. If our armies meet with a check, it groans over the misfortune and calls lustily for negro aid. If they achieve a victory, it deplores the lamentable fact that lives were lost in the effort. It croaks dismally over MCCLELLAN's splendid repulse of the enemy on Saturday and Sunday last, even though acknowledged to have been achieved against a "superior force," and glorifies the vigilant and wary generalship which led the enemy to make the attack during a violent storm and upon an inferior force. And here is the Tribune's summary of the case against our own army:

abstract: The Richmond Examiner is laying the flattering unction to its soul, that -- probably not having yet had a sufficiently strong dose of secession -- we are about to get up a little quarrel between the Eastern and Western States, and secede from each other. "The detestation for the Yankee," says our Richmond well-wisher, "is, we believe, as full and heart-felt at the West as at the South, only that the blood of the people of the latter section has stamped that hatred eternal, and made it lasting as the skies." The Examiner reminds us of the fox who, having lost his tail in a trap, tried to persuade his companions to have theirs cut off also; but it is not likely that the great West, where "the only fighting material of the Federal army is to be found" is going to be seduced from the loyalty which has already cost it so much blood and treasure, -- even though the Examiner should soothe and flatter it with the tongue of Belial himself.

abstract: We give in another part of this morning's TIMES, a very full and clear account of the brilliant engagement in front of Richmond, of Saturday and Sunday last.
lead_paragraph: We give in another part of this morning's TIMES, a very full and clear account of the brilliant engagement in front of Richmond, of Saturday and Sunday last. It cannot fail to be read with the deepest interest. Our Reporter was upon the spot, and describes what he saw, and his narrative leaves no room to doubt that the conduct of our troops merits the highest praise and is the sure precursor of final and complete success.

lead_paragraph: Sometimes mock sympathizers with suffering humanity are unexpectedly brought up by practical philanthropists with the direct and pertinent inquiry, "How much are you sorry?" And if a paper with subscriptions for relief is presented, it becomes an embarrassing debate in the consciences of the bogus humanitarians, whether they are really sorry to the extent of fifty dollars or only five.

abstract: WHY THE REBELS DO NOT SUCCEED. -- What remains of the rebel Press continues to heap up all manner of reasons and excuses for their long train of defeats and calamities. A straightforward avowal of palpable truths would be inconsistent with their character and history, while it would tend to crush into ashes the smouldering remnants of their cause. They, therefore, bewilder their readers and themselves by plunging into seas of sophistry, and accumulating mountains of irrelevant hypotheses, to mystify that which can be explained in the simplest manner. Their reasons, in fine, are as plenty as blackberries, but we doubt whether, by this time, even to the vitiated Southern appetite, they are half as palatable. We read that the celebrated CONDE, when about passing through Beune, was met at the gates by the civic authorities. After a salvo of prodigious compliments, the Mayor added: "To evince our joy, we wished to receive you with the reports of a numerous artillery, but we have not been able to fire the cannons for eighteen reasons. in the first place, we have none; secondly --" "My good friend," said the Prince, "the first reason is so excellent, I will excuse the other seventeen."

abstract: The Richmond Dispatch makes desperate efforts not to appear frightened at MCCLELLAN's gradual but sure approach to take possession of the City of Richmond, and tries to ridicule that gallant chieftain. "He will throw up dirt," says the Dispatch, "as soon as he reaches the proper point, and he will try to reach the heart of the city with the Spade." Well, we don't know but what the spade is, after all, the best implement for MCCLELLAN on this occasion; for if ever a man dug a grave, deeply and thoroughly, MCCLELLAN is digging the grave of Treason in Virginia. Not only that, but the spade will be a good emblem of the prosperity which the Union arms are about to exchange for the havoc and destruction to which the Old Dominion has been so long subjected by her self-appointed taskmasters. We have had enough of the ruthless clubs of war in Virginia; let spades henceforth be trumps.

abstract: COMMISSIONERS OF HEALTH -- THE SPANISH WAR STEAMER QUARANTINED. -- This Board, composed of the Mayor, Resident Physician, Health Commissioner. City Inspector, and the President of the Board of Aldermen and Councilmen, met, yesterday, being the first meeting under the operation of the Quarantine law; and henceforth unless circumstances should require more frequent meetings, they will assemble on Monday and Thursday of each week. The matter of the Spanish war steamer Don Antonio Ulloa was brought before the Board, and it being satisfactorily established that several cases of yellow fever had occurred on board prior to her departure from Havana, the following resolution was adopted:

abstract: A most pleasingdomestic drama was produced at Miss KEENE's theatre last evening. It is called "The Post Boy" and for quiet, intense portrayal of character, is equal to many pieces of more pretension, About two years.ago it was produced in London, and created a great sensation by the wonderful acting of Mr. JAMES ROGERS. Last night it was as great a success, owing to Mr. J. NICKINSON, who performed the same part of Joe Spurrit, the Post Boy. Miss ADA CLIFTON and Miss IONE BURKE also contributed to the favorable reception the piece met with. Undoubtedly it will hold the boards for sometime.

abstract: The Board of Councilmen held their regular meeting yesterday evening, the attendance being very thin. The usual reference was made of petitions and resolutions. The Mayor sent in a communication,...
lead_paragraph: The Board of Councilmen held their regular meeting yesterday evening, the attendance being very thin. The usual reference was made of petitions and resolutions. The Mayor sent in a communication, (which will be found in the official proceedings,) recommending that official courtesies be extended to Gen. PRIM, but with the proviso that such courtesies are not to be construed as an approval of the course of his Government, in organising and sending to Mexico the Spanish expedition, which has recently been recalled, and closing with these words: "Any well-founded objections we may have to the policy of Gen. PRIM's Government in this respect, should not be allowed to interfere with our duty of courtesy to a distinguished visitor."

abstract: Gen. PRIM visited the Brooklyn Navy-yard yesterday, at 1 1/2 P.M., and was received with full military honors. A detachment of 100 United States marines, all the officers of the Navy-yard and marine barracks, in full uniform, received him at the Lyceum, where Commodore PAULDING introduced him to the representatives of our navy. The General was shown through the various departments of the yard, inspected the process of iron plating on the steam frigate Roanoke, and expressed himself somewhat surprised at the rapidity with which Americans get up "iron-clads." He then went on board the receiving-ship North Carolina, the Captain of which, Commander MEADE, is a countryman of the General. The interview between them was of the most cordial character. The party adjourned to the wardroom of the "North," where refreshments were provided. An interchange of the most friendly sentiments took place between the distinguished Spaniard and our officers, Gen. PRIM frequently assuring the latter of the desire of Her Catholic Majesty to retain the most amicable relations with the Government of the United States. After a careful scrutiny of the novelties in the Navy-yard, Gen. PRIM returned to the City.

abstract: The achievement of Col. ELLIOTT, in cutting off the Mobile and Ohio Railroad, in the rear of the southwestern rebel army, is one of those brilliant episodes in the war, which, like BISSELL's canal at Island Ten, exact especial credit and acknowledgment for the performer. These Gen. HALLECK has frankly awarded. A forced march, with a handful of men, among swarming enemies, and without supplies; such elements of inauspicious promise, crowned with success beyond all expectation, certainly constitute in the aggregate a strong claim upon recognition and unstinted praise. Booneville is twenty miles below Corinth. The intervening country is peculiarly difficult, and, previous to the advance of ELLIOTT, was quite unexplored by the Union forces. To have traversed the distance in safety, and without casualty or repulse, was a miracle of daring and success.
lead_paragraph: The achievement of Col. ELLIOTT, in cutting off the Mobile and Ohio Railroad, in the rear of the southwestern rebel army, is one of those brilliant episodes in the war, which, like BISSELL's canal at Island Ten, exact especial credit and acknowledgment for the performer. These Gen. HALLECK has frankly awarded. A forced march, with a handful of men, among swarming enemies, and without supplies; such elements of inauspicious promise, crowned with success beyond all expectation, certainly constitute in the aggregate a strong claim upon recognition and unstinted praise. Booneville is twenty miles below Corinth. The intervening country is peculiarly difficult, and, previous to the advance of ELLIOTT, was quite unexplored by the Union forces. To have traversed the distance in safety, and without casualty or repulse, was a miracle of daring and success.

abstract: the great rebel army lately at Corinth has gone. Nobody knows -- not even Gen. HALLECK. If it has gone southward -- why don't he take Memphis? If it has gone westward -- if it has been broken up -- if it is in existence at all -- why is not the public mind relieved by the knowledge of the fact? The only thing we know certain, is that it has not gone to Virginia. But that does not help us much. Is there no intelligent contrabands, reliable deserters, or respectable refugees, to post us up? If Gen. HALLECK has not driven all reporters out of his lines, both he and we would have known all about it long ago. As it is, we must only concede that if BEAUREGARD and his hundred thousand men have not gone up in a balloon, they are somewhere on the solid earth. But where?

abstract: The grand Base Ball match between a selected nine from Philadelphia, and a picked nine from the Kinckerbocker, Eagle and Gotham Clubs, was played yesterday afternoon at Hoboken, and resulted in a
lead_paragraph: The grand Base Ball match between a selected nine from Philadelphia, and a picked nine from the Kinckerbocker, Eagle and Gotham Clubs, was played yesterday afternoon at Hoboken, and resulted in a victory for the Philadelphia nine. The latter played every position in a splendid manner, and their fielding and batting both elicited great praise. PRATT, as pitcher, and BOMEISLER, as catcher, proved themselves experts in their positions. MOORE on the first base, PAUL on the second, and JOHNSTON on the third, marked their play by a number of good catches. WILKINS, as short-stop, exhibited great activity, and made some superior catches on the fly. All of their out-fielders played creditably. CROASDALE and PAUL each made a capital home-run in the fifth innings, by powerful hits to the centre and left fields. Col. MOORE officiated as Captain of the nine in a judicious manner.

abstract: It is a marked characteristic of Gen. Mc- CLELLAN'S bulletins that they are wholly free from exaggeration, and that the full re- port magnifies rather than belittles the action
lead_paragraph: It is a marked characteristic of Gen. Mc- CLELLAN'S bulletins that they are wholly free from exaggeration, and that the full re- port magnifies rather than belittles the action they announce. The greatest artists best know the value of neutral tints; and Gen. MCCLELLAN would rather undertone than startle by vulgar glare or high lights -- wisely preferring that the public should grow up to the appreciation of the full measure of his victories rather than that disgust and distrust should come -- as they arc sure to come -- out of an over-colored report falsified by the event.

abstract: Brig.-Gen. SILAS CASEY, whose division broke at the battle of Chickahominy, is an officer of the reg- ular army, and a graduate of West Point. He en- tered the line after the expiration of his military.
lead_paragraph: Brig.-Gen. SILAS CASEY, whose division broke at the battle of Chickahominy, is an officer of the reg- ular army, and a graduate of West Point. He en- tered the line after the expiration of his military studies, on the 1st of July, 1830, and is consequently thirty-two years an officer. His first position was that of Second Lieutenant in the Seventh (old) Regiment of Infantry, from which he rose gradually, being promoted for the exhibition of "great soldierly qualities." He was appointed to the Colonelcy of the Fourth Regular Infantry in October, 1681, having been previously authorized to act as Brigadier-General of Volunteers. Gen. CASEY's reputation as a tactician was always of a high order, and many of his cotemporaries are astonished at the reverse which has suddenly befallen it. He is a native of Rhode Island, to which State his appointment is credited. In the Mexican war the old warrior gave a different account of himself. The rumor about a Court of inquiry being ordered to investigate the circumstances attending the late battle has not been confirmed.

abstract: editorial on Jackson retreat
snippet: editorial on Jackson retreat
lead_paragraph: If Stonewall JACKSON is not caught before he reaches Staunton, it will not be because there is not a big enough force in pursuit of him. One column, under BANKS and SIGEL, is after him, directly up the valley, FREMONT's column has joined the chase from the westward; and a detachment of MCDOWELL's corps comes from the outward, and rushes upon him. The hills and vallies of the wild region bordering on the Shenandoah, echo to the thunders of the columns as they sweep along, and give battle to such bodies of the flying foe as they may be able to overtake. Gen. FREMONT, at the present moment, seems to lead the van. He is reported to have defeated a detachment of JACKSON's army at Middletown, in Frederick County, and we have dispatches this morning from his headquarters at Woodstock, in Shenandoah County, more than fifty miles up the valley.
headline: {'main': 'The Second Flight of Stonewall Jackson.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Second Flight of Stonewall Jackson.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The annual meeting of the Grand Lodge was held yesterday afternoon, in the Apollo Rooms, Broadway. On the platform in the East the banner of the Grand Lodge occupied a prominent position, having
lead_paragraph: The annual meeting of the Grand Lodge was held yesterday afternoon, in the Apollo Rooms, Broadway. On the platform in the East the banner of the Grand Lodge occupied a prominent position, having on each side banners with the inscriptions " Faith, Hope, Charity, Wisdom, Strength and Beauty." At 2 o'clock the gavel in the East was sounded by M.W. Grand Master FINLAY M. KING, who called the body to order and the Lodge was opened in "ample" form. An impressive prayer to the Grand Artificer of the Universe was delivered by R.W. Brother SCHOONMAKER. Grand Chaplain. The Grand Master then proceeded to read his annual address. He congratulated the fraternity upon its successful career, which had remained undisturbed amid all the clash of warfare.

abstract: The Mayer, , vs. The St. Nicholas Insurance Company; Same vs. The Relief Fire Insurance Company; Same vs. The Exclusion Fire Insurance Company.  These cases came on for trial, and verdicts were
lead_paragraph: The Mayer, &c., vs. The St. Nicholas Insurance Company; Same vs. The Relief Fire Insurance Company; Same vs. The Exclusion Fire Insurance Company. -- These cases came on for trial, and verdicts were taken against all the Companies, under stipulation entered into between the counsel for the respective parties, that these actions should abide the event of the action against the Exchange Fire Insurance Company, which is now before the General Term of the Superior Court. It will be recollected that these actions are brought on policies issued by the various Companies, in the Crystal Palace, the particulars of which have been heretofore reported, on the 21st of January. Seven out of ten Companies refused to pay, on the ground that the City had no insurable interest, the building being vested in John H. White, as Receiver, and also on the ground that the risk was increased after the policies were issued.

abstract: The Board held their regular meeting yesterday afternoon. The usual reference was had as to petitions and resolutions. The sum of $40,000 was appropriated to the Commissioners of the new Courthouse
lead_paragraph: The Board held their regular meeting yesterday afternoon. The usual reference was had as to petitions and resolutions. The sum of $40,000 was appropriated to the Commissioners of the new Courthouse by an unanimous vote. The bill of D. Linn, keeper of the Eldridge-street jail, amounting to $647, was ordered paid. The Committee on County Offices reported the completion of the new Debtors' Jail, and a resolution to inspect it was adopted. The Mayor transmitted a communication, addressed to the Clerk of the Board, stating that he had signed a resolution to pay for advertising the Annual Report of the Board in 17 papers, amounting in all to $4,179 25, but protesting against the extravagance of the Board in ordering the publication in so many papers. The Mayor contends that the insertion of the document in three papers of the largest circulation would have been ample and saved to the City the sum of $3,360. The Mayor concluded by assuring the Clerk that he cannot hereafter give his sanction to any similar bill. The message was ordered on file. The Comptroller transmitted his regular report from which it appeared that the expenditures [???] to May 31, amounted to $1,554,262 72, and the balance unexpended. $3,771,939 20. The remainder of the session was occupied with the [???] of unimportant bills. A report in favor of discouraging the extra guard at the Eldridge-street jail after the 16th inst., was adopted. The bill of Dan. Linn, keeper of the Eldridge-street jail, for the employment of watchmen to protect the county jail from Jan. 1 to March 31, 1862, amounting to $540, was [???] and ordered paid. The Board, after transacting some routine business, adjourned for two weeks.
