abstract: On Monday the double-team trot, announced to come off on the Fashion Course, for a purse of $100, mile heats, best three in five, was decided in the pres- ence of a large assemblage of the regular habitues of
lead_paragraph: On Monday the double-team trot, announced to come off on the Fashion Course, for a purse of $100, mile heats, best three in five, was decided in the pres- ence of a large assemblage of the regular habitues of the track and the owners of fast horses in this locality. For the purse, which was offered by the manager of the Course, there were originally four teams entered, viz.: Panic and Jilt, named by D. TALLMAN; Belle and Alida, named by HIRAM WOODRUFF; Hawk and Buzzard, named by D. MACE, and Pug and Pauline, named by SAM MCLAUGHLIN. In consequence, however, of the well-known superiority of TALLMAN's team. Panic and Jilt, and the knowledge that their starting for the purse would assuredly have the effect of causing the withdrawal of the other teams, and thus spoil the race, TALLMAN very handsomely withdrew his entry, thus leaving the three other teams to contest for the purse. In consequence, however, of Belle and Alida, the team of HIRAM WOODRUFF, having been purchased by a gentleman for his own driving on the road, the starters were reduced to the teams entered by MCLAUGHLIN and MACE. The former, which comprises two handsome and well matched bay mares, Pug and Pauline, belong to a gentleman holding a high official position in the City; while Hawk and Buzzard, a black and a bay team, belong to Mr. WAYNE, of Hartford, Conn., and were driven in the two first heats by MCQUIVEY, and by HORACE JONES in the two last. D. TALLMAN handled the ribbons over Pug and Pauline, whose fine condition and free style of going in their preparatory brushes, at once made them the favorites in the betting. At the appointed hour the judges entered the stand and called up the horses for the first heat, the Hartford team having the pole.

abstract: The intelligence from the Department of the Shenandoah this morning is highly important, and indicates that the Government has come to the conclusion at last, that it is time to finish the
lead_paragraph: The intelligence from the Department of the Shenandoah this morning is highly important, and indicates that the Government has come to the conclusion at last, that it is time to finish the operations of "Stonewall JACKSON" in that region. The enemy's rear-guard was driven out of Strasburgh on Sunday evening by Gen. FREMONT, who pushed on after them as far as Woodstock, where a halt was made for the might, the enemy being only three miles distant. On Monday morning the pursuit was continued, and the enemy was driven from three positions, taken up by them to retard the advance of our troops. The flight of the rebels was a hurried one, as is evidenced by the fact that the roads and woods along the line of retreat are strewn with arms, stores and clothing. It is believed that JACKSON will be over, taken and forced to fight, or at least, that he must abandon his old "stamping ground" entirely. It will be seen from our dispatches that a portion of Gen. MCDOWELL's command has formed a junction with Gen. FREMONT.

abstract: Current scene, Baltimore
snippet: Current scene, Baltimore
lead_paragraph: A year ago, Baltimore had the reputation of being the most turbulent and disorderly city in the Union the City of Mobs and Monuments. Election riots were the common law of the municipality. The right of suffrage and the right of outrage went hand in hand, and bullets and ballots were inseparable. In February, 1861, more than a thousand arrests and committals disgraced the police record of this municipality. Its streets swarmed with ruffians stained by every crime, and familiarly known as "shoulder-hitters," "bullies," "Rip-Raps," "Plug-Uglies," and "Blood-tubs" -- scoundrels who gloried in having killed, in brawl and riot, "their man" -- their men -- their two, or three, or more political opponents, guilty of no worse offence than voting on "the wrong side."

abstract: The num-  ber of fugitive rebel Governors is rapidly increasing. The Governor of Louisiana (MOORE) and the Governor of Arkansas (RECTOR) are now added to the list. The first filed from his
lead_paragraph: -- The number of fugitive rebel Governors is rapidly increasing. The Governor of Louisiana (MOORE) and the Governor of Arkansas (RECTOR) are now added to the list. The first filed from his capital when our gunboats made him a visit on their way up the Mississippi from New-Orleans; but where he has absconded to, no man knows. The other decamped from his capital a few days ago when it was approached by the National detachment under Gen. CURTIS; and it is said that he has taken refuge in the capital of the beleaguered State of Mississippi -- the Governor of which, with his guest, will have to make tracks away from there, too, before long.

abstract: Judge SMALLEY, of the United States Circuit Court, on Saturday delivered a decision of great importance, in the case of The Grover & Baker and Wheeler & Wilson Sewing Machine Companies vs. Abraham Fuller, agent for the sale of the Williams & Orvis machines in this city. An injunction was ordered to issue, restraining the further sale of the Williams & Orvis machines, the feeding device being held to be a direct intringement of the complainants' patents. The case was severely contested, and occupied several days at the hearing, when a long argument was made for the defendants by Mr. Whiting of Boston, the Wm. H. Johnson, Batchelder, Ellithorp, and other machines being set up in defence, all of which were disposed of by the decision, and persons using the Williams & Orvis machines are declared to be [???] as well as those who make or sell them.

abstract: Editorial on Confederate govs. forced to flee their states
snippet: Editorial on Confederate govs. forced to flee their states
lead_paragraph: The letter of our correspondent at Newborn, throws a glare of light upon the doings and policy of the new Provisional Government. Gov. STANCY has addressed himself undividedly to the negro question. Not pausing with the closing of the African schools, he has given a large share of attention to the capture and restoration to their alleged owners of negro fugitives, and that, it would seem, with very slight, if any inquiry into the loyalty of the claimants. With the same sturdy devotion to the institutions of his native State, he has established a strict guard over departing vessels, to see that no contrabands effect a passage northward: while legal process awaits the return of certain shippers who are known to have carried away with them the [???] chattels. Having looked somewhat curiously into the transactions of the new State Administration, we are unable to find that any other subject has attracted the notice of the Governor. Questions financial, legislative, and judicial, are all postponed. His civil commission and the entire energies of the army which he indirectly controls, and which was sent to punish treason and restore North Carolina to the Union, are concentrated upon the rendition of fugacious blacks to disloyal proprietors; and in the expulsion from the State of Mr. H.H. [???], for no other crime apparently than his relationship with the author of the Impending Crisis, and his authorship of an advisory note, Gov. STANLY shows that his zeal for the strict administration of local law cools when the rights of non-slaveholding whites are concerned. It would be difficult, we imagine, for Gov. STANLY to lay his finger upon that section and [???] of the North Carolinian statute book which warrants him in banishing from the State the writer of a distasteful letter. In the Constitution of the United States it would be easy to find a passage which precludes the exercise of any such arbitrary authority.

abstract: Quartermaster HAVERTY, of the Eighty-eighth Regiment. N.Y.V., (Irish Brigade) telegraphed to the Editor of the Irish American, from "Camp at Liters Farm, Va., June 2," that the Sixty-ninth, (Col. ROBERT NUGENT,) and Eighty-eighth, (Col. HENRY M. BAKER,) N.Y.V., were engaged yesterday. Lieuts. KING and O'CONNER, and about thirty privates of the Eighty-eighth were wounded. One man in Company I, Sixty-ninth was killed. The two regiments are highly eulogised by Gens. MCCLELLAN and SUMNER for their decisive charges. I am busy trying to get rations across the Chickahominy, which is swollen by the rebels turning a canal into it."

abstract: Coroner RANNEY was yesterday engaged in holding an inquest upon the body of an unknown man, who was found under circumstances which warrant the belief that the deceased came to his death by foul means. A post mortem examination made by Dr. GALEN HUNTER, of the Coroner's office, showed a gun-shot wound in his head; the ball having entered the left side of the face, and escaped under the jaw upon opposite side. Deceased was about fifty-five years of age, and five feet six inches in height. The body was discovered by Officer CRAFT, of the Eleventh Precinct, floating in the water at the foot of Houston-Street, East River. When found he was dressed in a black frock coat, brown vest and pantaloons, white muslin shirt, calf-skin gaiters and black silk neck-tie. He had apparently been in the water about two weeks. The Coroner made diligent efforts to ascertain by whom, and under what circumstances, the shot was fired, but no satisfactory evidence could be obtained. It is the general impression, among those who have seen the remains, that the man was murdered and afterward thrown into the river. The body was taken to the dead-house of Bellevue Hospital, where it will be kept for identification as long as possible.

The Coroner made diligent efforts to ascertain by whom, and under what circumstances, the shot was fired, but no satisfactory evidence could be obtained. It is the general impression, among those who have seen the remains, that the man was murdered and afterward thrown into the river. The body was taken to the dead-house of Bellevue Hospital, where it will be kept for identification as long as possible.

abstract: In the Senate, yestrday, a communication was received from the Secretary of war, transmitting  the instructions given to the Military Governors  of Tennessee and North Carolina. A joint resolution allowing hereafter: premium of two dollars for every accepted recruit for the regular army, and allowing all soldier, to receive a month's pay in advance, was passed.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yestrday, a communication was received from the Secretary of war, transmitting the instructions given to the Military Governors of Tennessee and North Carolina. A joint resolution allowing hereafter: premium of two dollars for every accepted recruit for the regular army, and allowing all soldier, to receive a month's pay in advance, was passed. The joint resolution suspending payments in the Department of the West, was passed. The Tax bill was then taken up, and debated until 7 1/2 o'clock, when the Senate adjourned without final action on the bill.

abstract: Earl RUSSELL, in laying on the table a copy of the treaty concluded between the United States and this country for the suppression of the Slave-trade, made a few remarks which were very indistinctly heard in the gallery. He was understood to say that the present Government of the United States had shown great anxiety to adopt stringent measures for the extinction of that nefarious traffic.
lead_paragraph: Earl RUSSELL, in laying on the table a copy of the treaty concluded between the United States and this country for the suppression of the Slave-trade, made a few remarks which were very indistinctly heard in the gallery. He was understood to say that the present Government of the United States had shown great anxiety to adopt stringent measures for the extinction of that nefarious traffic. Their Lordships were aware that for some years past there had been great facilities afforded to persons at New-York to fit out slavers. Those slavers went afterward to Havana, and thence to the coast of Africa. Her Majesty's Government were fully informed of the names of the persons who fitted out those slavers, and they advised our Admiral and cruisers on the African coast on the subject. Owing however, to their using the American flag, those slavers were enabled to escape from search by our cruisers, and their operations consequently could not be checked. But President LINCOLN's Government had given orders for the entire suppression of the slave trade, and had also taken effectual steps to break up the practice of fitting out ships at New-York for the purpose of carrying it on. Besides these, as occasion required, other steps would be adopted for the effectual suppression of the slave trade. The present treaty had been negotiated between Mr. Secretary SEWARD and Lord LYONS; and he might take this opportunity of stating that it afforded the best evidence of the sincerity of feeling and purpose for the suppression of the slave trade, which, since the election of the present President, had characterized the Government of the United States. The treaty gave extensive powers of search to the cruisers of both nations, and he had now the honor to lay it on their lordships' table.

abstract: House yesterday voted to reconsider the slaves of rebels confiscation bill, which was rejected by a very close vote a fortnight ago. The majority for reconsideration was 21, the total vote being; for, 84; against, 65. It is not likely that the rejected bill will pass the House or become a law in its original form; but the necessity of some action in the premises is admitted on all hands. Probably not less than a hundred thousand slaves have been directly engaged in forwarding this rebellion; and leaving out altogether Slavery as the ultimate inducing cause of the revolt, it is very doubtful whether, in a military point of view, it could have attained anything like its present proportions without the labor and the aid of Southern slaves. It cannot be that this rebel live stock shall be protected and preserved for the future use of the rebels. It cannot be that we should neglect to inflict a just punishment upon the slaveholding traitors and usurpers who have plunged the country into this bloody war. Still, hasty action on a subject of such vast and enduring import is dangerous to all parties: and while justice should be inexorably administered, it should also be administered discreetly, and in such a manner as not to reflect unjustly upon those who may be innocent. There is no doubt of the correctness of the oft-made assertion, that a large part of the Southern people was forced into this rebellion. As things went, it was a virtual impossibility for them to resist it. When, then, the question of confiscation assumes a practical shape, these men should have an opportunity of proving their virtual innocence. Neither their civil rights nor their estates should be interfered with, without trial; and it is to be hoped that the bill which may pass Congress will make ample provision for this. It must not be forgotten that while the people of the South had a duty of fealty to the Government, the Government also had a duty of protection to them; and that the Government is morally as culpable for failing in its imperative duty as the loyal men of the South were for failing to do their whole duty. We do not say that when the protection due the Southern loyalists was for so long a time withheld, the latter were inexcusable for succumbing to the de facto powers. We only say that there was a joint culpability of citizen and Government. And as soon as the Government, by suppressing the rebellion, sets itself right toward the Southern people, the latter also should have an opportunity to set themselves right toward the Government. For convicted traitors -- for those who have willingly furnished slaves to aid the rebel cause, there should be punishment and confiscation severe and exemplary; but, as we already said, in providing for this, care should be taken that the innocent do not suffer with the guilty. We are glad to learn that the feeling of Congress is in favor only of judicious legislation on the question.

abstract: -- A deplorable tragedy occurred in Springfield, Mo., on May 21. Capt. John R. Clark, of Company F, Fifth Kansas Cavalry, being officer of the day, called, in company with one A.J. Rice, both in a state of intoxication, at the house of Mrs. Willis, a widow lady, to get their supper. Mrs. Willis refused to prepare it for them. This enraged the Captain and his companion, and they drew their pistols and attempted to force their way into the house through the guard who had been stationed to protect it. One of the guard shot the Captain through the body, killing him instantly. About the same time, Rice fired at the guard, missing him, but sending a ball through the head of Miss Mary Willis. She fell dead on the floor. Another of the guard fired at Rice, shooting him in the breast, and in acting what was thought to be a mortal wound. Mrs. Willis is a Union refugee from Arkansas, where she lost two sons assassinated by rebel guerrillas. Capt. Clark was a native of Sciota, Ohio, but moved to Grundy County, in this State, in 1836. He served in the Mexican war under Sterling Price, and was after ward twice elected Sheriff of Grundy County.
lead_paragraph: -- A deplorable tragedy occurred in Springfield, Mo., on May 21. Capt. John R. Clark, of Company F, Fifth Kansas Cavalry, being officer of the day, called, in company with one A.J. abstract: City Directory for 1862-3, published by J. LAIN & Co. has just been issued. It contains several thousand more names than any previous Brooklyn Directory -- a result which the publishers justly attribute, not to any marked increase in the population of the city during the past year, but to greater vigilance on the part of the canvassers. It is a source of great inconvenience to the citizens of Brooklyn, and one of which the compilers of the Directory justly complain, that many of the streets are irregularly and confusedly numbered and in several instances two or more streets are allowed to bear the same name. The Legislature has long since empowered the Common Council to remedy this defect, but they have thus far neglected to do it. Aside from the imperfection arising from this cause, the present Directory appears to be all that could be required, and to the Brooklynites, as well as others having business there, it is well worth the low price of $2, for which it is sold.

abstract: The thirtieth annual meeting of the New-Jersey Railroad and Transportation Company took place at the new shops in East Newark yesterday morning. There were about two hundred stockholders and their friends present.
lead_paragraph: The thirtieth annual meeting of the New-Jersey Railroad and Transportation Company took place at the new shops in East Newark yesterday morning. There were about two hundred stockholders and their friends present. Hon. WALTER RUTHERFORD presided, and Messrs. H.T. SOUTHMAYD and N.M. HALSTED acted as Secretaries. Among the gentlemen of note present were Hon. NEHEMIAH PERRY, Hon. D.S. GREGORY, Col. KRAN, of Elizabeth; E.Y. ROGERS, of Rahway; JOHN BLACK, of Burlington; N. THORP, of Rahway; L.A. SMITH, of Newark; J. MCDONALD, of Newark, and many others of note in the State.

No dispatch was received from Gen. MCCLELLAN's army yesterday. abstract: Editorial on Union gunboats being able to sail from Roanoke Island to Norfolk via inland river routes
snippet: Editorial on Union gunboats being able to sail from Roanoke Island to Norfolk via inland river routes
lead_paragraph: The passage of the gunboats Southfield and Port Royal from Roanoke Island to Norfolk, by the internal route, thus putting BURNSIDE and WOOL in direct water communication without the aid of the Atlantic, is an event which is not only notable as showing the progress of the campaign, but is of the greatest prospective importance, and adds new point to the question of completing that line of intra-coast navigation of which nature has given us the suggestion and the rough draft.

abstract: Yesterday morning, at 11 o'clock, the Twentyfifth Regiment, from Albany, arrived in this City, on its way to Washington. Landing at the foot of Canalsneel, it was marched to the Arsenal, corner of....
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning, at 11 o'clock, the Twentyfifth Regiment, from Albany, arrived in this City, on its way to Washington. Landing at the foot of Canalsneel, it was marched to the Arsenal, corner of White and Elm streets, where a substantial dinner was provided the men. It was expected that the regiment would have left during the evening; in consequence, however, of the inclemency of the weather, the departure was delayed till to-day. All of the men are armed with the Enfield rifle. Companies D and E declined leaving with the regiment, giving for a reason that they were composed exclusively of Germans, while the majority of the members of the regiment were Irish. Nothwithstanding this Col. BRIAN has very nearly [???] his full complement of men. [???] is a list of the officers:

abstract: Henry D. Brookman et al. vs. Sixty Barrels, , of Molasses. This case came up on exceptions to the Commissioner's report. The suit was brought to recover an alleged balance of freight and demur- rage on a charter party.
lead_paragraph: Henry D. Brookman et al. vs. Sixty Barrels, , of Molasses. -- This case came up on exceptions to the Commissioner's report. The suit was brought to recover an alleged balance of freight and demur- rage on a charter party. The Court decided in favor of the libelants for both freight and demurrage, and referred it to a Commissioner to ascertain the amount. To his report the claimants excepted, claiming, first, that the Commissioner had reported too large a balance of freight money due. The evidence before him was the same as that which was laid before the Court.

abstract: -- BEAUREGARD once compared himself to ALCIBIADES -- the point of resemblance being that the Athenian had on one occasion cut off a dog's tail, and that JEFF. DAVIS had cut off the tail of the report of the battle of Manassas by the little Creole. At present, he rather resembles the dog than ALCIBIADES; for whereas, before, it was only his report that was docked, he has just had his own caudal honors grievously abbreviated by Gen. POPE, who has curtailed his army by the nice figure of 10,000 men! It seems, too, by the latest accounts that his appendage has been taken off near the point where the tail of the Dutchman's dog was -- just behind the ears.

abstract: The prize schooner Lucy C. Holmes, of Charleston, S.C., in charge of Prize-master LAWTON COGGESHALL, arrived at this port yesterday. abstract: The Annual Meeting of the stockholders of the New-Jersey Railroad  Transportation Co., took place yesterday morning in East Newark.
lead_paragraph: The Annual Meeting of the stockholders of the New-Jersey Railroad & Transportation Co., took place yesterday morning in East Newark. WALTER RUTHERFORD presided, and about two hundred stockholders and their friends were present. The annual report was then read, and exhibited the affairs of the road in a highly prosperous condition. The following Board of Directors was elected unanimously: John S. Darcy, Dudley S. Gregory, Henry R. Remsen, Hamilton Fish, Geo. R. Chetwood, A.O. Zabriskie, Wm. Whitney, Alfred N. Dennis and Martin Howell. The only changes in the Board are to fill vacancies occasioned by death.

abstract: A month of considerable activity at the Customhouse has just closed. The receipts for May, like those of the few months preceding, give promise of a large revenue for the year.
lead_paragraph: A month of considerable activity at the Customhouse has just closed. The receipts for May, like those of the few months preceding, give promise of a large revenue for the year. Toward the latter partof the month the receipts were somewhat smaller than before, and symptoms of a decline in importations were apparent. The receipts at this season of the year are usually lighter than at other seasons -- the importations being smaller on the near approach of Summer, and the market being in a measure supplied by the goods already imported and placed in bond. The goods now imported are principally dry goods, hides, coffee, sugar and tea -- the revenue being in a great measure derived therefrom.

abstract: THEIR PART IN THE  WORK OF RECONSTRUCTION. The recent arrival from New-Orleans, of the Hon. JOHN E. BOU
lead_paragraph: -- THEIR PART IN THE WORK OF RECONSTRUCTION. -- The recent arrival from New-Orleans, of the Hon. JOHN E. BOULIGNY, will perhaps recall to the minds of some of our readers, suggestions made in these columns more than a year ago, in reference to acknowledgments due by Government to the people -- to the steadfast Union men of the South. We owe them much, not for their loyalty, because that is a sacred duty, the absence of which would deserve our just indignation, but for their noble conduct and splendid example, in steadfastly enduring the trials to which their fidelity in the midst of traitors subjected them, and accepting patiently, the evil consequences to themselves of blows necessarily struck at our foes, ofttimes through the bosoms of friends.

abstract: British press observations
snippet: British press observations
lead_paragraph: The Federals are working out the old metaphor, and eating up the South leaf by leaf, as a man would eat an artichoke. It is a pleasant occupation to one, not too hungry, leisurely inclined, and with plenty of time on his hands; but the artichoke is not a vegetable exactly adapted to a passenger who has but ten minutes for his dinner, and who has to make his way by the express train, which will not wait. New-Orleans was a very large leaf quietly pulled off and peaceably discussed, and now Yorktown is another, enjoyed with equal ease and comfort. To a military mind the evacuation of Yorktown will probably cause no very great astonishment. So long as the wholesome terror imposed by the Merrimac continued, Yorktown was a good strategic position. Directly, however, it began to be suspected that the Merrimac was not likely to repeat the achievement of Hampton Roads, there was a strong possibility of a fleet of ships-of-war and transports running by the river forts on the York River and the James River, and landing an army in the rear of the Confederate lines, thus cutting them off from Richmond, and putting them between two fires. NAPOLEON might possibly have been glad of an opportunity to annihilate, in two blows, a thus divided enemy; but it is not in accordance with what we know of Confederate tactics to seek any such dangerous opportunities. The Fabian policy has hitherto been the policy of the South. They have from the first been hoping that something might turn up. Originally they believed Europe would come in a mass to rescue King Cotton. Disappointed in that, they were convinced that the North would be divided, and then that the funds would fail. Now they are probably living partly upon the remnants of all these broken hopes, and partly upon the anticipation that the heats of Summer will melt away the hosts they cannot vanquish. Delay they think to be equal to victory, and to some extent they are doubtless right. But it is a policy which may be carried too far, and, bit by bit, they may give up so much that they may at last have nothing very much worth fighting for. The danger of being surrounded would, however, appear to be a sufficient strategic reason for their last achievement in abandoning their Yorktown lines.

abstract: editorial on Beauregard route
snippet: editorial on Beauregard route
lead_paragraph: The question with everybody for the last four days has been, Where is BEAUREGARD'S army? Swiftly, silently, and under cover, the great host stole away from Corinth; but whither it had gone, no man could tell. The whereabouts of at least a large portion of it is at last satisfactorily settled. Gen. POPE, by one of those brilliant Napoleonic movements which have placed his name first and foremost on the roll of Western Commanders, has taken prisoner ten thousand of its number, has captured fifteen thousand stand of arms, and is still in pursuit of, and scattering to the winds, that fraction of it which holds together. This is the glorious news which will make the eyes of the nation glisten this morning, and which will strike terror and dismay to the hearts of the infernal Southern traitors. The vaunting and insolent chivalry of the Cotton States is routed and disgraced. The General in whom the rebels most trusted is discomfited. An army of men who swore that they would contest every inch of Southern soil till they reached the last ditch, and then and there would fight till the last of them had been hacked to pieces, has ignominiously thrown down its arms, and resigned itself to the clemency of its captors. A General whose bluster has only been equaled by his falsehoods -- who, in his efforts to fire the Southern heart, has stopped at no perfidy, scrupled at no means, however atrocious -- has now fled frantically before the National army, anxious only to save his worthless life, and shouting to his deluded followers as he flees "to save themselves the best way they could." It is a fitting finale to the rebel campaign in the Southwest -- a campaign which to the rebels has been but a long series of disgraces and disasters, from the day when this same POPE took prisoner four thousand of them in Missouri last Winter -- down through the days and fields of Pea Ridge, Donelson, Bowling Green, Nashville, Columbus, Island Number Ten, Pittsburgh, Huntsville, New-Orleans, Pensacola, Corinth and other discomfitures too many and too pitiful to be enumerated. All that remains now is that POPS and HALLECK put the finishing stroke to their week's work by breaking up entirely the fleeing host, and clutching its leaders, when the whole military force of the great rebellion will be the shivering fragment of an army now facing death at the rebel capital.

abstract: The infantile display at the Museum has achieved a success. In spite of the tremendous fall of rain yesterday, the inhabitants of this and the adjacent cities literally flocked to see the babies.
lead_paragraph: The infantile display at the Museum has achieved a success. In spite of the tremendous fall of rain yesterday, the inhabitants of this and the adjacent cities literally flocked to see the babies. Thelittle ones were obliged by their contract to be there rain or shine, and many a poor youngster took his seat upon the platform with dampened socks, saturated jacket, wet trousers and soaking shoes. The premium babies were in high spirits, as were their parents, who, male and female, were in constant attendance all day long.

abstract: Editorial on Confederates' practice of destroying property and homes rather than yield them
snippet: Editorial on Confederates' practice of destroying property and homes rather than yield them
lead_paragraph: There is to be awarded to the rebels credit for a certain amount of dash and gallantry, which under favoring conditions earns them a plausible semblance of success. The chase after Gov. BANKS, the assault upon Gen. CASEY, are specimens of this particular school of courage. An adversary weak in numbers and experience, and free from all apprehension of attack, is fallen upon, routed, and driven for miles, until reinforced and enabled to make a stand; when the pursuit ceases, the victors take to flight, and the net product of the enterprise is defeat and dispersion. There is impulse but no momentum. The moment the force which inspired the movement ceases to act, the movement ceases, and reaction ensues. It is a consciousness of this halt in the valorous gait of their warriors, which persuades the leaders of the insurrection to place small reliance upon the success of their cause if it be left to the arbitrament of arms. They are well assured that ultimate military superiority is out of the question. They have never been able to set foot upon Northern soil; mile by mile they see their own soil restored to the Union. The odds of the contest are all against them. If the war continues they must be ruined.

abstract: We are happy to announce that Brig-Gen. Innis N. Palmer, reported killed in Saturday's battle before Richmond, is probably safe.
lead_paragraph: -- We are happy to announce that Brig-Gen. Innis N. Palmer, reported killed in Saturday's battle before Richmond, is probably safe. A private letter from one of his friends in Washington, states such to be the latest report, but does not say whether or not he was wounded or fell into the hands of the enemy. The last positive intelligence we have in regard to him, left him in the thickest of the fight, heroically exerting himself to rally the suffering and broken troops whom be commanded in Gen. Casey's Division. All the correspondents from the battle-field concur in flattering mention of his gallantry and self-sacrificing exposure. They also agree in the statement that he was missing when the fight was over, which suggests the fear that he was taken prisoner.

abstract: Unequaled as have hitherto been the trotting performances of the celebrated Ledger team, throwing far into the shade every record of last time previously made under similar conditions, Mr. BONNER, on Tuesday last, accomplished a feat which far surpasses any thing he had before accomplished with his matchless horses, and which would appear incredible were not the fact witnessed and vouched for by gentlemen whose names are a guarantee of their reliability. After the race on the day above-named, between Lady Emma and Jilt, on the Fashion Course, Mr. BONNER having in his heavy four-seat wagon, drawn by Lantern and the Flatbush mare, three other gentlemen, Mr. C.A. DANA, (late of the Tribune,) Mr. PALAMENICO and Mr. C.J. FOSTER, of Wilkes' Spirit, drove the first half mile of the track in the extraordinary time of one minute and seven seconds. The start was a little beyond the quarter-pole, and Lancet soon breaking up and running, he was kept going at the top of his speed, the Flatbush mare trotting steadily and magnificently alongside him. Passing the judges' stand, Lancet was urged to his fastest running pace by the whip, the mare trotting squarely throughout, and the half mile was made in the above unprecedented time of 1 min. 7 sec. When, in addition to this tremendous speed, the weight carried is considered, (the collective weights of the four gentlemen exceeding 600 pounds,) the performance stands unparalleled.

abstract: An adjourned meeting of this Board was held last evening in the County Jail, President CROOKE in the Chair. The Penitentiary Committee reported on the recent explosion at the Flatbush Almshouse, by which several lives were lost, that the accident was owing to an improper construction of the boiler, so that the flues could not be properly cleaned, and that this defect was being remedied under direction of the Superintendents of the Poor. The report was adopted and placed on file. A communication was received from the Commissioners of Excise showing that they had granted 1,214 licenses during the year ending May 1, and that the total receipts amounted to $36,420. Referred to the Committee on Accounts. The Committee on Accounts reported that the Sixth Monthly Report of the Commissioners of the Volunteer Relief Fund was correct, and the same was placed on file. The members amused themselves for a couple of hours by voting for a Keeper of the Penitentiary, made vacant by the resignation of HIRAM HELMES, but with arriving at any result. After the transaction of some routine business the Board adjourned for two weeks.

abstract: Hon. Gen. LANE, of Kansas, is to speak in the Cooper Institute this evening. Those who have never listened to this greatest of Western orators will now have an opportunity to hear him never before offered in this City. His topic will of course be the present rebellion -- against which LANE has fought and spoken during the past year and a half, with a vigor equaled by few other Western men. His popularity in the West is unbounded; and as a soldier in the war of freedom in Kansas, and again last Summer in Missouri, he did service known only to those who know the country and the people amid whom he served. For daring, [???] and force "JIM LANE" is everywhere known, and we hope the great hall of the Cooper Institute will be crowded to-night.

abstract: The Coroner's inquest upon the body of the First Mate, JOHN PAUL PIERSON, who was stabbed on Saturday last by a seaman named JOHN WILLIAMS, was concluded yesterday. The jury, in their verdict, said that "deceased came to his death by a stab-wound at the hands of WILLIAMS." The accused was thereupon fully committed to await the action of the Grand Jury. In answer to the usual questions put to him by the Coroner. WILLIAMS stated that he was 21 years of age, born in Ireland, and resided in Liverpool. As to the question of his guilt, he stated that he was advised by his counsel to say nothing. It transpired during the progress of the investigation that the deceased knew that WILLIAMS was drunk, when the latter came aboard the ship; that when he did not obey the orders which were given by PIERSON, the latter struck him three or four times, and then turned around to the bystanders and said, "During all my experience on a ship, I have never before struck a man." Shortly after this the accused told one of his shipmates that he should "put a knife into PIERSON the first chance he had."
lead_paragraph: The Coroner's inquest upon the body of the First Mate, JOHN PAUL PIERSON, who was stabbed on Saturday last by a seaman named JOHN WILLIAMS, was concluded yesterday. abstract: Board of Education.  At a regular meeting of this Board, last evening, the report of the Finance Committee, in favor of appropriating $18,918 for erecting a new Primary School-house in the Twelfth Ward, was adopted.
lead_paragraph: Board of Education. At a regular meeting of this Board, last evening, the report of the Finance Committee, in favor of appropriating $18,918 for erecting a new Primary School-house in the Twelfth Ward, was adopted. The School Officers of the Seventh ward were authorized to purchase lots Nos. 68 and 70 Monroe-street, on which to erect a Primary School-house, at an expense of $13,500.

abstract: Col. LOUIS BURGER has been most active in recruiting for this regiment, and has nearly raised it to its full standard. None of the men have, as yet, been mustered into the service of the United States, neither has any definite time been arranged for so doing, but it is supposed that in a few days the men will be sworn soldiers of the Government, and receive marching orders from their Colonel.

abstract: Yesterday closed an unusually interesting session of Friends' Yearly Meeting. The afternoon was set apart for the reading of the epistles from corresponding yearly meetings.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday closed an unusually interesting session of Friends' Yearly Meeting. The afternoon was set apart for the reading of the epistles from corresponding yearly meetings. It appears that the subject of First-day Schools is exciting increased interest throughout all of them. Some highly interesting facts were elicited from JACOB and ELIZABETH HAVILAND, who have lent the most zealous effort in the behalf of Mission Schools along the Western border of this State. They gave instances where the privileges to be met with in these humble educational institutions, directed as they are by the firm yet gentle discipline of Friends, have been seized upon with avidity by the indigent searcher after instruction, and have been seen to produce results the most profitable. Children are not alone the pupils who receive instruction in these schools. The laborer wipes the sweat from his honest brow and repairs to them, as a little child, when working hours are done. The mechanic forgets, at Betting sun, his toil and tools, and hastens to the Mission that is working to cultivate that longing which he feels for nobler effort, for higher ends and intellectual enjoyment. At the business meeting the Tract Society's report was read, and from which some new facts were disclosed which much interested Friends. It is a new thing to see the plain garb of a Quakeress passing to and fro in by-ways of iniquity and distress, or standing at the doors of their residences distributing the little prints so carefully selected to reach the needs of the recipients, yet this rather unusually demonstrative custom is gaining ground; and strange as it may appear, the class who do not as a general thing accept with becoming grace these free offerings at the hands of the pharisaical, eagerly crowd about such distributors.

abstract: editorial says Negro prejudice delayed bill far too long; editorial says prejudice against Negroes delayed bill far too long
snippet: editorial says Negro prejudice delayed bill far too long; editorial says prejudice against Negroes delayed bill far too long
lead_paragraph: some months ago, in his Annual Message to Congress, declared that if there was any good reason why Hayti and Liberia should not at once be recognized by the United States, he was not aware of it, it may safely be assumed that he will have no hesitation in at once giving his sanction to the bill to that effect, which has at last passed both branches of the National Legislature. It is a tardy act -- we will not say of justice -- but of common sense. Liberia has grown to a condition of stability, and has been declared entitled to respect, under the law of nations, by France, Great Britain, Belgium, Prussia, Brazil, Lubec, Bremen, Hamburg, Portugal, and the Kingdom of Italy. Hayti has already had an independent existence of two generations, and has been acknowledged and treated as a nation by every Government in the world except our own. We now send Ministers Plenipotentiary to several nations, whose united intercourse with the United States is not a tithe of the commercial importance of that of either Hayti or Liberia. It is only just to say that this inconsistency has long been lamented, and many of our most enlightened statesmen and merchants have for years urged the measure whenever there appeared to be any prospect of even a hearing from those in authority. Twelve years ago HENRY CLAY wrote: "I have thought for years that the independence of Liberia ought to be recognized by our Government, and I have frequently urged it upon persons connected with the Administration, and I shall continue to do so if I have suitable opportunities." The one barrier all along in the way has been that despicable and disgraceful prejudice, which would deny the black race even the poor recognition of humanity. This prejudice was again made to do service in opposing the passage of the bill for the recognition of Hayti and Liberia, by the fag-end of the negrophobists in Congress; and, characteristically enough, the meanest and most malignant speeches against it were made by Northern men. The bugaboo of the equality of blacks with whites (assumed as being contemplated by this measure,) was again trotted out; and poor Mr. Cox, of Ohio, tried his best to terrify the House into a rejection of the measure by the picture of a negro in Court dress. It is not to say very much to say that Congress had common sense enough not to be influenced by such wretched puerilities. At the same time it is gratifying that the spirit of the age has been at length recognized in this act of tardy justice.

abstract: AN OLD GAME REVIVED. A man named HENRY CASS, was brought before Justice STEERS yesterday, charged with swindling SARAH ANN CONNOLLY out of the price of nine pieces of French calico.
lead_paragraph: AN OLD GAME REVIVED. -- A man named HENRY CASS, was brought before Justice STEERS yesterday, charged with swindling SARAH ANN CONNOLLY out of the price of nine pieces of French calico. Mrs. CONNOLLY has a fancy store at No. 394 Fourth-avenue. In February last, the accused went to complainant's store, and bought the calico in question. He directed that the goods be sent to his office in Broadway, and he would then pay for them. A messenger was accordingly sent to the designated No. with the bundle. CASS met the man at the door, took the goods from him, and said that his wife wished as much more of the same article; he therefore directed that it be brought to him immediately, when he would pay for all at the same time. The messenger did as requested, but of course the accused was missing when he returned to the appointed place, and nothing more was seen of him until yesterday. He was committed in default of $500 bail.

abstract: The man who was found in the water at the foot of Houston-street, with a gun-shot wound in his head a full account of which was published in yesterday's TIMES has been identified.
lead_paragraph: The man who was found in the water at the foot of Houston-street, with a gun-shot wound in his head -- a full account of which was published in yesterday's TIMES -- has been identified. It turns out that his name was BERNARD LEWIS, the well-known and skillful artist, who, for a long time past, has been employed as the scene-painter at LAURA KEENE's Theatre. He has been missing since the 20th of May last. On that day he was seen by several of his friends riding around the City in a carriage, in a state of intoxication. When last seen alive, he was at his bankers, in company with three rough-looking men. While at the latter place, he drew the sum of either $70 or $700 -- which of the sums is not known -- and soon after left with his companions; before leaving, however, he gave one of the men an order for a hat. He was identified by his clothes, the body having been previously interred in Potter's Field, as that of an unknown man. It is believed that the wound made by the ball in his head was of itself sufficient to produce death, and the theory of those who have investigated the matter, is that the deceased was induced by others to go to the foot of Houston-street at a late hour of the night; that he was then shot, robbed of his money and other valuables, and then thrown into the water, the murderers hoping in this way to hide all the evidence of their crime. This supposition is strengthened by the fact that no money or other property was found upon his person, although it is known that he carried a heavy gold watch and chain, a diamond pin, and it is also thought a large amount of money. Miss LAURA KEENE is taking a very active part in the endeavor to unravel the mystery, and bring the murderers to punishment, if it be a fact that the man has died by foul means.

abstract: The People ex rel. Roberts vs. Thomas et al. -- The plaintiffs claiming to be Trustees of the Welsh Presbyterian Church, in Eleventh-street, brought this action to have the defendants removed from the position of Trustees, which it is alleged they have unlawfully usurped. The question at issue is whether certain votes cast at the election of Trustees, in March last, were legal or not.
lead_paragraph: The People ex rel. Roberts vs. Thomas et al. -- The plaintiffs claiming to be Trustees of the Welsh Presbyterian Church, in Eleventh-street, brought this action to have the defendants removed from the position of Trustees, which it is alleged they have unlawfully usurped. The question at issue is whether certain votes cast at the election of Trustees, in March last, were legal or not.

abstract: column, to the Report of the Military Committee of the House of Representatives upon the offer of the State of New-York, in regard to the enlargement of the Canals. The Committee is decided in its recommendation that the National Government shall accede to the New-York proposition. The expense to the National Treasury is but $3,500,000 at the utmost; the return, free access to the lakes for all the gunboats needed for the defence of the Northern frontier; free passage through the canals for all troops, munitions, or boats belonging to the General Government. The equivalent for the expenditure so palpably outweighs the outlay, that it seems hardly possible Congress will hesitate to adopt the views of the Committee.

snippet: editorial says Stanly wants to maintain slavery and existing state laws
lead_paragraph: We are glad to hear that President LINCOLN does not sustain the action of Gov. STANLY in closing the schools for freed negroes and in returning fugitive slaves to rebel owners. If our information from Washington is reliable, he has expressed his disapprobation of both these acts, and will direct Gov. STANLY not to interfere with these schools, nor to use the authority or power of the General Government for the return of these fugitives.

lead_paragraph: Hon. JAMES H. LANE, Senator from Kansas, addressed a large audience, last night, at the Cooper Institute. The "Emancipation League," of which WM. C. BRYANT, Esq., is President, held its first public meeting on that occasion, and Gen. LANE, inaugurated a series of Thursday night lectures on the themes suggested by the present aspect of the rebellion.

abstract: editorial speculates on their chances of taking Memphis
snippet: editorial speculates on their chances of taking Memphis
lead_paragraph: The chances seem to be ten to one that Memphis is not yet taken. The news of its capture was brought to HALLECK'S headquarters by "a man" who asserted that the city surrendered on Friday last. But since the arrival of this solitary individual, "ten refugees" have come in, who left Memphis on Monday of this week, and bring with them the local papers of that day, which papers do not mention the surrender of the city The averment of one man must, by the ordinary rules of testimony, be regarded as invalid when directly contradicted by the averment of ten men, particularly when the latter are backed up by a Memphis editor. Moreover, there was a meeting of the citizens of Memphis, held on Sunday last, at which resolutions were adopted that "the city never should yield to the enemy voluntarily." Wonder if the citizens of Memphis thought that anybody was going to ask them to surrender "voluntarily." That is not the way things are done in war. Cities and armies usually surrender quite involuntarily, and when the alternative of surrender is destruction. The fact, however, that the Memphians adopted the resolution mentioned, is good proof that if the city has not yet surrendered, it is on the eve of doing so. The usual course of the rebel cities and hamlets on the Mississippi River toward our naval officers now ascending that stream, has been to send to our fleet, as soon as it came in sight, a deputation headed by the mayor, who asserted that the place never would surrender; and after this, the next thing we learn is that a small party of our soldiers had gone ashore, taken possession of the place, and administered the oath of allegiance to the recalcitrant municipal functionaries. There is no doubt that this is pretty nearly the programme that will be carried out in Memphis.

abstract: By the Persia, which arrived at this port yesterday, we have three days later from Europe. Our European letters and selections, and translations from our files, will be found in their appropriate place.
lead_paragraph: By the Persia, which arrived at this port yesterday, we have three days later from Europe. Our European letters and selections, and translations from our files, will be found in their appropriate place. The anxiety relative to news from America was daily becoming more and more intense among the commercial classes of England, and false rumors were in constant circulation. In regard to the capture of the British steamer Bermuda by one of our blockaders, Mr. LAYARD declared in the House of Commons, on the 23d ult., that the case had been referred to the Law Officers of the Crown. The case of the Emily St Pierre was being discussed in the Liverpool papers, and there was evidently little disposition to give her up. The London Times thinks the details of the capture of New-Orleans put the surrender of the city in a light more favorable to the defenders. A similar tone is assumed by that portion of the Paris Press under Secessionist influence; though the importance of the National victories at New-Orleans and Yorktown were generally fully recognized. The Common Council of London resolved to present Mr. PEABODY with the freedom of the City. An interesting discussion on the experiments at Shoeburyness, brought out declarations from several members of Parliament to the effect that the great Armstrong Gun is practically a failure. The Continental news, with the exception of the revelations of French designs in Mexico, is not of marked importance. It is stated that Gen. PRIM will be authorized to return to Mexico as Spanish Ambassador. The sales of Cotton for the week, in the Liverpool market, had been 33,880 bales, at a general decline. Breadstuff's and Provisions were dull. The latest quotations for Consols is 93 1/2@93 5/8. American Securities had a better tone.

abstract: If our readers could like to learn some of the schemes by which our kind friends in England undertake to violate the blockade, we recommend to them to read Judge BETTS'
lead_paragraph: If our readers could like to learn some of the schemes by which our kind friends in England undertake to violate the blockade, we recommend to them to read Judge BETTS' decision condemning the ship Cheshire and her cargo, which we publish in another column. The vessel sailed from Liverpool bound, as she claimed, on a voyage either to Nassau, or Halifax; and with so much uncertainty about her own destination, it is not at all remarkable that she should have found herself one morning off the port of Savannah. She was boarded by one of our vessels there, and her captain stated that he had only looked in to see if the blockade was still continuing. If it was, of course he had no thought of going into the port; but if by any falling of the sky or otherwise, the blockade had been broken, he proposed to be early in Savannah to catch Whatever larks could be found there.

abstract: -- The Navy Department has just taken steps for a very important, addition to our naval arm -- having issued proposals for the construction and complete equipment of fifteen gunboats; speed not less than thirteen knots, to be delivered within four months. The confidence which has led the Department to make this large addition to the navy, in this particular build of war-ship, is fully justified by the magnificent service which our gunboats have rendered in every theatre of naval action, both on the Western waters and along the Atlantic and Gulf coasts. The "gunboats" have long been the terror of the rebels, who make them the scapegoat for all manner of discomfitures and defeats; and indeed they hardly now pretend to resist where these potent opponents are at hand. Though nothing is better demonstrated than that wooden walls are powerless against iron sides, it would be quite to overshoot the mark to claim that there are not an infinity of services to which wooden war vessels may be put. It was wooden ships, wholly unaided by ironclads, that fought their way up to New-Orleans against forts, chains, obstructions, rafts, fire-ships and what not -- performing one of the most brilliant naval enterprises on record. We shall find abundant use for the fifteen gunboats which the Navy Department has ordered.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, a bill for the establishment of National armories was introduced by Mr. GRIMES, of Iowa. The bill providing for a Government for the Territory of Arizona was taken up and debated. Mr. SUMNER, of Massachusetts, moved to postpone its consideration, and take up the resolution for the expulsion of Mr. STARKE, of Oregon; but the motion failed, as it was decided by the Vice-President that such a course would throw the Tax bill over. The Tax bill was then taken up, and debated until the adjournment. An amendment was offered by Mr. SUMNER and adopted, which provides that every person claiming the services or labor of persons held as slaves shall be taxed $2 per head for every person so held.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, a bill for the establishment of National armories was introduced by Mr. GRIMES, of Iowa. abstract: returned from Europe yesterday, after an absence of nearly six months. He was received with a welcome which indicated a general recognition of the important service he has rendered the country by his unofficial, but intelligent and influential representation of its interests abroad. Since public opinion began to play so important a part in the control of National affairs, recognized diplomatic Ministers have ceased to be the only organs of international sentiments. Men are wanted abroad not only to inform other Governments of our views and purposes, but to enlighten and guide public sentiment concerning us. It is no longer Ministers, Secretaries and men in office whose intelligent friendship or just appreciation is alone important to us, -- every merchant and banker, every prominent manufacturer, every editor and political or social leader -- every man, in short, who influences public opinion, has become an important element in the governing forces of every free nation, and is to be addressed and consulted in the guidance of public affairs.

abstract: Arguments relative to the restitution of the ship Emily St.Pierre to the Federal Government were being carried on pro and con., in the columns of the Liverpool journals, and, while it was urged by ...
lead_paragraph: Arguments relative to the restitution of the ship Emily St.Pierre to the Federal Government were being carried on pro and con., in the columns of the Liverpool journals, and, while it was urged by some writers that the demand of the American Government for the restitution ought to be complied with, it was maintained by others that the demand could not be legally sustained.

abstract: MARY RILEY, a poor Irish emigrant girl, arrived in this City not long since, on her way to her friends in the State of Ohio. She expected to find, upon her arrival here, either a ticket for a passage to her place of destination, or the money with which to defray her expenses thither -- which her friends at the West had assured her should be here when she arrived from Europe. For a week or more she has been at Castle Garden, under the supervision of Mr. CASSERLY, the well-known agent of the Commissioners of Emigration. Yesterday morning, however, her money failed, and upon being questioned she frankly stated what her expectations were, and that she was only waiting for a letter from her sisters in Ohio, which would contain the necessary means to permit her to proceed onward. At the same time, she produced a letter that she had received about a week before at Castle Garden, and which she said she had been unable to read. Mr. CASSERLY read the letter, and from it he learned that a certificate for MARY's passage from New-York to her friends in Ohio had been sent. The letter was addressed to the care of Messsrs. KNOUTH, NACHOD & KUHNE, No. 28 Broad-street, and from them it had been sent to the girl at Castle Garden soon after her arrival in the City, but it contained no ticket or certificate of passage. Mr. CASSERLY at once dispatched Sergeant MCPHERSON, of the Castle Garden Police, to the store of the above firm. He was referred to their confidential book-keeper. The latter individual, upon being presented with the letter in question, admitted that he had opened it. When asked what he had done with the ticket or certificate of passage that the letter contained, he became very impudent and abusive to the officer. After much delay, however, the certificate was produced from an out-of-the-way place, but the book-keeper would give no satisfaction whatever for having detained the document, or for having broken open the letter. Mr. CASSERLY, upon being informed of these facts, at once made application to the United States authorities to have the party dealt with according to law. The story was related at the United States District Attorney's office, and Mr. ANDREWS, the Assistant District-Attorney, immediately sent Deputy Marshals PLEL and HUNT in pursuit of the bookkeeper. The latter was brought up, and after hearing the statement of the accused, the Assistant District-Attorney concluded it was not a case wherein he had jurisdiction to act; he was also of the opinion that it was no violation of the United States law for a person to break open a letter addressed to his care for another. Mr. CASSERLY thought otherwise, and says he is determined to break up the system of swindling emigrants, that is at present practice [???] by various parties in this city, who, when an emigrant arrives in here bound to the Western States, will take every means in their power to sell them tickets, for which they get from 30 to 40 per cent. commission. This case will be investigated to-day in a Police Court.

abstract: We have a dispatch from Gen. McCLELLAN's headquarters, dated last evening, which states that the storm of Wednesday was very severe in the vicinity of Richmond.
lead_paragraph: We have a dispatch from Gen. McCLELLAN's headquarters, dated last evening, which states that the storm of Wednesday was very severe in the vicinity of Richmond. The water in the Chickahominy rose to an unprecedented height, and railroad and telegraphic communication was for some time suspended. The rebels opened fire yesterday morning from five different points opposite New-Bridge, with a view to prevent its reconstruction, but they were driven away by three of our batteries, after a hot fire of two hours. A report has been received from Richmond that all the available conveyances in the city were impressed into the service of carrying the rebel wounded from the battle-field of Saturday and Sunday, and that many of the public and private buildings had been turned into hospitals. All accounts go to confirm the belief that the rebels suffered terribly. A dispatch from Gen. MCCLELLAN, which we publish, corrects an error in his first dispatch, relating to the battle, as transmitted by telegraph. He calls it the "Battle of Fair Oaks." We also have a stirring address from Gen. MCCLELLAN to his soldiers, from which it will be seen he expects soon to meet the enemy in a decisive battle.

abstract: -- The plaintiffs who occupied the ground floor of the store No. 561 Broadway, in this City, brought this action to recover damages alleged to have been sustained by injury to their stock in trade, consisting of chandeliers, gas-fixtures, &c, by reason of the negligence of the defendant. The defence set up that defendant contracted with the owners of the premises to repair the second story of the store and to alter the stairway, to both of which the plaintiffs assemed, and that plaintiffs have sustained no injury. John E. Develin, for plaintiffs, John K. Hackett, for defendant.

abstract: A stated meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday at 1 P.M. Hon. ROYAL PHELPS, First Vice-President, occupied the Chair, owing to the absence of the President, PELATIAN PEEIT, Esq., on account of ill health. Previous to the regular ...
lead_paragraph: A stated meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday at 1 P.M. Hon. ROYAL PHELPS, First Vice-President, occupied the Chair, owing to the absence of the President, PELATIAN PEEIT, Esq., on account of ill health. Previous to the regular business, Mr. PHELPS took occasion to return thanks to the Chamber for his seventh reelection, to his friends for their support, and especially to Mr. A.A. LOW for his personal defence, which was all the more acceptable on account of the issue of the secret circular, already noticed.

lead_paragraph: The United States steam transport Philadelphia, Capt. HENRY BARTON, from Pensacola May 25, and Key West May 30, in bailast, to Col. D.D.TOMPKINS, arrived yesterday. The Philadelphia tools from New-York, on her outward trip, 116 bullocks and 80 sheep, and all were landed in good condition by Commissary JAMES STARR and assistants. She has had fine weather all the passage home.

abstract: The United States vs. The Ship Chesire and Her Cargo The United States ship-of-war Augusta captured this vessel at sea, off the harbor of Savannah, Dec. 6, 1861. She and her cargo were sent by ...
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The Ship Chesire and Her Cargo -- The United States ship-of-war Augusta captured this vessel at sea, off the harbor of Savannah, Dec. 6, 1861. She and her cargo were sent by the captors to this port, and were here libeled, Dec. 23, for condemnation as prize of war. On Jan. 17, 1862, Joseph Battersly intervened as a neutral and British subject, by Thomas Stone, who represents himself to be a passenger on the ship and her supercargo for the voyage. Joseph Battersly also alleges that he is part owner of the cargo.

abstract: The conqueror of Solferino has apparently found his Moscow in Mexico. The news received through San Francisco a few days since is confirmed by an arrival at Key West.
lead_paragraph: The conqueror of Solferino has apparently found his Moscow in Mexico. The news received through San Francisco a few days since is confirmed by an arrival at Key West. The French have really been beaten back from the Mexican capital. Defeated and surrounded, they have retreated by forced marches upon Vera Cruz, where, in the presence of yellow fever, they will make curt stay enough, if transports be at hand to carry them out of the country. The Mexicans have vindicated not only their patriotism and courage, but their eminent claim to the rank of an independent and self-sustaining nation. They have also settled with some degree of accuracy the fact that JUAREZ is the proper exponent of the National will, and chosen organ of popular self-government.

abstract: The Allied expedition to Mexico, the entire legacy of which has, at length, fallen to France, is still the subject of prolonged and serious discussion by the French Press of all shades of opinion. Some of the Paris journals are loud in their remonstrances against the part the French army is new made to play in this singular enterprises. Others steady uphold the Imperial policy, an liberate its opponents in round terms. The most prominent of the former class is our Union friend, the Opinion Nationale, which, after citing the clauses of the London Convention, that state the objects of the triple alliance to be the procurement of protection for the persons and property of their subjects, and disclaim all intention of [???] with the free choice of the Mexicans in [???] their own form of government proceeds to [???] the origin of the difficulty that has arisen, [???] all, a letter from Havana to the [???] which says that England and Spain withdrew on the pretext that the presence of ALMONTE in the French camp altered the conditions of the London Convention totally, and that he and the other Mexicans with him manifested pretensions that they had no idea of supporting. The reply of the French Commissioners excluded the idea of any forcible intervention by France to change the form of government, and yet they refused to dismiss ALMONTE and broke off all further relations with JUAREZ.

abstract: MELANCHOLY ACCIDENT   TWO YOUNG LADIES  INSTANTLY KILLED BY LIGHTNING   On Sunday night, about 12 o'clock, during the terrific storm of thunder  and lightning which passed over the city, two young ladies ...
lead_paragraph: MELANCHOLY ACCIDENT -- TWO YOUNG LADIES INSTANTLY KILLED BY LIGHTNING -- On Sunday night, about 12 o'clock, during the terrific storm of thunder and lightning which passed over the city, two young ladies -- Miss MARY PILLSBURY and Miss CLORA GOODWIN -- were instantly killed by lightning, in their bed, at the two-story brick house which stands alone on the island, opposite the steamboat landing. The two ladies had retired to bed a few minutes before the approach of the storm, and it is supposed that they had not gone to sleep when the fatal accident occurred. The head of the bed, in which they were lying together, stood near a gable window. The lightning struck the house between two chimnics, and the fluid appeared to have divided into three different forks, and to pass in different directions. The fork which killed the ladies passed in at the window near the bed. There was a feather mattress upon a straw one, and the flued passed under the feathers and set the straw on tire. A right cup worn by one of the ladies was torn into shreds, and the face and neck of the wearer somewhat marked. The other fork or division of the fluid passed down a wooden water conductor, which was completely shattered. The third passed down a chimney-flue to the lower story, and, coming out near the fire-place, shot diagonally across the room, breaking a looking-glass into a hundred pieces. The shock was, of course, distinctly felt by all in the house, and some member of Mr. PILLSBURY's family opening the door of the room occupied by the girls, the fire in the bed was discovered and immediately extinguished.

abstract: If it had been  proposed any time the yast five years to add another to the Thirty-nine Articles, all good Britons would undoubtedly have desired that the new article should he implicit faith in the Armstrong gun.
lead_paragraph: If it had been proposed any time the yast five years to add another to the Thirty-nine Articles, all good Britons would undoubtedly have desired that the new article should he implicit faith in the Armstrong gun. It mattered not that this projectile has been rejected by every other nation except England: is not that all the more reason why Britons should hold on to it? It mattered not that nobody could be found who had seen the experiments with this gun, or had any practical knowledge of its working -- it is the nature of faith to be independent of sight, and with all Englishmen the exhaustless and universal merits of the Armstrong gun were a matter of pure faith. Well, this faith has just received a very severe shock, and that, too, in the House of Commons.

abstract: An "Eman  eipation League" was organized last evening at Cooper Institute, by a public meeting collected for the purpose of hearing a speech ...
lead_paragraph: An "Emancipation League" was organized last evening at Cooper Institute, by a public meeting collected for the purpose of hearing a speech from "Gen. JIM LANE," of Kansas. A constitution, a list of officers, prepared and appointed in advance, (by whom it was not stated,) were read by a gentleman introduced as Col. MCKAY, after which Gen. LANE addressed the audience in favor of emancipating and arming all the slaves immediately. One of the articles of the constitution of this new league pledges it to resist the retention of any Slave State in the Union, unless it will first pass an act of emancipation.

abstract: The machinery of the Society carrying on its operations in the old mansion at the corner of Broadway and Astor-place, moves some what more smoothly than formerly since the virtual resignation of cer- ...
lead_paragraph: The machinery of the Society carrying on its operations in the old mansion at the corner of Broadway and Astor-place, moves some what more smoothly than formerly since the virtual resignation of certain influence, the zeal of which outstripped its methodical action; and the working spirits, those who have the real interest of the poor at heart, are discreetly using the power and means which the contributions of a generous public place at their command to relieve distress. There are still some unpleasant features existing which trammel the full exercise of judicious management, but it is probable they will disappear when the novelty of position wears away and new points of attraction, already dividing the attention of the holders thereof, promise the distinction craved.

abstract: GARD's army will have a very important bearing on the great question of cotton supply. Had that army retreated slowly, fighting its way foot by foot through Mississippi. Alabama and Georgia, or westward through Arkansas, Louisiana and Texas, there is no doubt that the military authorities would have destroyed all the cotton, tobacco and sugar on the line of retreat. But if the rebel army is broken up, the fragments of it will have quite enough to do to save themselves without running from county to county and from plantation to plantation applying the torch to the little stores of cotton. The great bulk of the cotton in the rebel States is still on the plantations, in accordance with the act of the rebel Congress forbidding its accumulation in the cities or at the usual shipping points. Very little of this has as yet been burnt: and if the rebel forces really are defeated, and if our armies occupy the railroad lines and our navy commands the rivers, and if martial law is, as it will be, declared over the repossessed States, it will be a dangerous thing for rebel marauders or planters to attempt to burn cotton anywhere within their bounds. If after these events happen, the rebel planters do not promptly send forward their cotton to market, it will, doubtless, he promptly sent forward for them. Some people seem to think that because vast stores of cotton have not been sent forward from New-Orleans and Nashville, since we captured those cities, that it is never going to come forward. But is has not come from these cities simply because it was not there. Back of these cities, and between them and the stores of cotton, was a cordon militaire, through which the staple could not pass. Now that this is broken, we may anticipate that the cotton will, as speedily as possible, be sent to market. There is yet over a million of bales in the States we obtain control of by the rout of BEAUREGARD's army. And there is little doubt that this will be in the mills of Manchester and Lowell before the end of Summer.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC SUMMER SEASON. It will be seen, by reference to our advertising columns, that Mr. ULLMANN will, in all probability, arrange a brief Summer season, beginning upon Wednesday next, at the Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC -- SUMMER SEASON. -- It will be seen, by reference to our advertising columns, that Mr. ULLMANN will, in all probability, arrange a brief Summer season, beginning upon Wednesday next, at the Academy of Music. This Summer season will be naturally operatic, and we may promise the lovers of operatic music a succession of novelties, if not in opera, at least in the cantatrivi of opera, which ought to insure him success. We believe that the prices will be, as he assures the public, within the reach of all classes.

abstract: The new County Jail, which has been in process of erection for two years past, in Ludlow-street, adjoining the Essex Market Police Court, is now completed, and was, yesterday, opened for the inspection of the Board of Supervisors, under whose direction it was built. Invitations were issued by the Board to various City officials, citizens and members of the Press, to assist them in the inspection of the building, and among those who availed themselves of the courtesy we notice Judges WHITE, BARBOUR and MONCRIEF, of the Superior Court; Recorder HOFFMAN and Judge MCCUNN, divers members of the Common Council and Board of Education, and a large number of private citizens. At the close of the inspection the party partook of a collation that had been provided for the occasion, at which all present expressed themselves entirely satisfied, and even delighted with the manner in which the jail had been constructed.
lead_paragraph: The new County Jail, which has been in process of erection for two years past, in Ludlow-street, adjoining the Essex Market Police Court, is now completed, and was, yesterday, opened for the inspection of the Board of Supervisors, under whose direction it was built. abstract: --We are glad to learn that provision has been made by Government for the prompt payment of our soldiers taken captive by the rebels in different engagements, who are now returning to this City. There has already been some complaint on account of dilatoriness and difficulties in this matter. Some of our gallant men, severely wounded on the field, and taken prisoners by the rebels a year ago, who have patiently upheld the honor of the Stars and Stripes during a long and dreary confinement in the dungeons of the South, find, when they come to New-York, that it is almost impossible to obtain the pittance that is their due. Perhaps this was unavoidable heretofore, on account of the fact that the regimental rolls were often missing or imcomplete, that parties were difficult of identification, and that the machinery generally was not in working order. It will not occur, however, in the future. Gen. BROWN, commanding at this military post, has received instructions from Washington to muster for payment the fourteen hundred prisoners lately arrived, and now arriving in this City from the South; and they will obtain their money as soon as the muster rolls can be completed. We hope that not an hour will be lost in completing these rolls, and delivering to the soldiers their dues. In most instances the sums owing the men range from fifty to a hundred dollars; and, small though the individual amounts are, they will be a great assistance to many a poor soldier's family. Let the Government be as prompt in doing its duty to the men, as they were in offering their lives to the Government.

abstract: An accident occurred Thursday morning between 3 and 4 o'clock, near Rhinebeck, on the Hudson River Railroad, by which the locomotive A.F. Smith, and eight cars were broken to pieces, and pitched over the embankment into the river. The accident was caused by a tree, which had fallen from the bank above, and extended across the track. The engineer and fireman did not see the obstruction until nearly upon it and had just time to jump into the river and escape to the shore by swimming, when the train struck the tree with great force, carrying it along nearly twenty rods tearing up the track and scattering the rails and ties in all directions, when the engine, followed by the tender and eight cars pitched over the embankment into the river. In its [???] the engine turned completely over, and now lies bottom upward. abstract: A WOMAN DROWNS HERSELF, AND CHILD. -- Between 4 and 5 o'clock on Wednesday afternoon, as the Jersey City ferryboat Colden was crossing the river, coming toward New-York, an unknown woman, with a child in her arms, jumped overboard from the stern of the boat, and both were drowned. The woman was seen by the driver of an express wagon, on the boat, to let down the chain, and sit down upon the edge of the deck, and, after looking around, slide off into the water. No alarm being given, the boat was not stopped, and the pilot and hands knew nothing of the occurrence until arriving at New-York. Neither the woman or child were seen after they struck the water. When the boat left Jersey City the woman was noticed sitting in the cabin crying. She had on a red plaid shawl and knit hood.

When the boat left Jersey City the woman was noticed sitting in the cabin crying. She had on a red plaid shawl and knit hood.
