abstract: The ladies of the New-York Educational Union have established, at No. 334 Sixth-avenue, a resort (it would be well to say home, were not the word so hackneyed) for children whose fathers have been killed in battle, or are prostrated by camp-contracted disease. The institution is intended to meet many wants. First, that of the care-worn, war-made widow, who is thankful to leave her little one under the kind auspices of Mr. and Mrs. DAVIS, the Superintendents, while she seeks perhaps for the first time a day's employment. Again, it is a refuge for the young girl of intelligence and capacity, who would fain accept instruction to fit her to combat unwonted trials in a commercial sphere; and a home for the little girls and boys, some of whom wear garments of mourning that should be looked reverently upon by every loyal American, especially those who in tranquility of luxurious homes, entertain but faint visions of the battle-field. The enterprise is of late conception, and has been scarcely two weeks in operation. The moving spirits at work in it are nerved on by the knowledge that sixteen thousand families of our New-York soldiers are reduced to the extremity of applying to the relief fund of the City for aid, and that their multitude of little children must feel the heaviest pressure of poverty. They must either be left to the chance and often demoralizing associations of the street, or have a place provided for their accommodation, while their care-takers are necessarily absent. The ladies who have visited these families have discovered that in many cases the heads of them have returned from the war debilitated and suffering, so that they are confined to their beds a home, thus increasing the weight of care upon the household, while they are unable to relieve any necessity. Such cases the ladies are especially mindful of, and supply with whatever their resources may afford in the way of food or clothing. The main feature of the organization, however, is to edicate the children whose early career of peaceful acquirement has been interrupted by the breaking up of their family circle; so that, after they have completed a certain course of study, they may be of use to society and to those they hold most dear. It is nut at all a design of the institution to separate the little ones from their natural guardians, and it is the privilege of parents to take them home every night, or to leave them one week and have them spend the Sabbath at homo to be welcomed again by their adopted guardians on Monday morning. This is certainly a considerate plan, when it is remembered that the children of our volunteers are quite a different class, far more hopeful and full of character than the habitual dependers upon charitable assistance. The little band now collected in this institution is one for whom our professed patriotic citizens should be proud to interest themselves. The refined, the intellectual, the beautiful are here, not only in the first promising loveliness of childhood, but in the full bloom of youth and inspiration of usefulness. Donations of articles both useful and attractive have been received, to swell the little stock that is displayed for safe in aid of the general fund. Ladies will find it repaying to step out of their usual shopping routes to purchase some of these pretty concerts, which are held at prices proportionate to the economist's purse. Many sacrifices have been made by Rev. Mr. DAVIS and his philanthropic wife, so that any offices of kind support in the matter of furnishing necessary comforts for their charge, will be more than duly acceptable. The house now occupied, though not just fitted for its present use, is large, and will requite much to make it the home-place that is intended. Many ladies of distinguished benevolence are associated in the rising progress of this praiseworthy movement, and it is destined to the success it deserves. Our discriminating President subscribes himself its foster-father, and some names in our own and neighboring city, Brooklyn, award it countenance of no meagre character.

abstract: Lady Suffolk and Kitty Wink afforded, a week since, an opportunity to the sporting men of this City to test the correctness of their judgment and back the same by their money.
lead_paragraph: Lady Suffolk and Kitty Wink afforded, a week since, an opportunity to the sporting men of this City to test the correctness of their judgment and back the same by their money. The result, as chronicled in the TIMES was, that Lady Suffolk was the winner -- her friends pocketing liberal quantums of that article, the love of which is the root of all evil; while the equally sanguine admirers of Kitty Wink were obliged to go home comfortless, and with slim pocket-books.

abstract: The annual regatta of the New-York Yacht Club came off yesterday, and, though devoid of the interest which has attached to previous races, on account of the absence of the best yachts, neverthe- ...
lead_paragraph: The annual regatta of the New-York Yacht Club came off yesterday, and, though devoid of the interest which has attached to previous races, on account of the absence of the best yachts, nevertheless afforded a fine day's sport to all who participated. The day was fair, and the breeze all that could be desired. But, out of eighteen vessels that entered, only twelve sailed the course, and among these we missed the ever-welcome America, Maria, Julia, Una, and a host of other favorites that were wont to gladden the eyes of yachtsmen. All were anxious to see how the Maria would sail in her new schooner-rig, and, though pleased with her appearance at the start, were much disappointed as she gave up the race, when reaching Robin's Reef stake-boat, and deprived the contest of its most interesting feature.

abstract: WOMAN'S MISSION TO WOMAN THE MISSINGLINK SOCIETY. The Association bearing this attractive title is auxiliary to the New-York Bible Society. Its managers are all ladies, who employ only their own sex, whom they call Bible-readers, to visit the homes of the degraded, and exert what power they possess to elevate them.
lead_paragraph: WOMAN's MISSION TO WOMAN -- THE MISSINGLINK SOCIETY. -- The Association bearing this attractive title is auxiliary to the New-York Bible Society. Its managers are all ladies, who employ only their own sex, whom they call Bible-readers, to visit the homes of the degraded, and exert what power they possess to elevate them. The Bible is read, its teachings explained,and a copy of it given or sold to the family. This enterprise has now progressed for one year, and promises well for the future. One of the visitors reported the condition of one thousand families, whose spiritual necessities she had tried to relieve in the short space of three months. She had also exerted much influence in getting the children sent to the public and to the Sunday Schools. It is a cherished feature of the Society to appeal directly to the wife and mother, and through her to the husband, by teaching her how she can make her house attractive to him; to elevate the tastes of the children, and instruct them in their share of household unity and peace. These younger members are often make the most powerful instruments of reform, for the rude nature may listen unawares to good lessons in the innocent prattle of a beloved child when it would treat with scorn a remonstrance from an older and less pure source. These welders of the missing link in homes made desolate by absence of moral law, are exposed to every disgusting contact, having nothing to protect them but the mantle of purity which their mission throws about them. Each of the ladies who superintend the affairs of the Society, choose and regulate the sphere of movement for one especial visitor, the whole result of their work to be placed before the meeting which is convened once a month. A pleasant offset to the sterner aspects of duties connected with the Association, is to be arranged in the "Mothers' Tea Drinkings," which are in contemplation.

abstract: We observe that BEAUREGARD, amid the multiplicity of his business during the last days of his stay at Corinth, found time to consider the future a little, for it is said that he sent dispatches to the officer commanding at Mobile, directing him to hold that place at all hazards, "as it would be the base of important operations in prospective." This raises an interesting field of inquiry. What were the important operations in prospective which he had in his mind? Gen. HALLECK, perhaps, could conjecture with more probability than we, who are not military men, and are so far off. But what seems to us the most "important operation" for BEAUREGARD, as he and his scattered forces flee before POPE, the rebel-catcher, who does not seem at all to resemble that Pope of whom BUNYAN spoke, as being stiff in his sinews and rusty in his joints, is for him and the other ringleaders to get out of the country; and for this "important operation in prospective," Mobile seems to us as available a "base" as is to be found along the Southern coast. It is one of the few ports still remaining to the rebels where they have any vessels left, and those are necessary to such an important operation. But unless this operation is speedily put in execution, we fear it will be too late. If FARRAGUT gets ready to bring his gunboats and mortar vessels around there, the operation will prove a difficult one. If BEAUREGARD can get to Mobile before him, he had better undertake it at once, for it will be much easier performed while only our blockading squadron lie off the port. We hope our Secretary of the Navy will instruct, the officers of our blockading squadron to be especially careful not only to catch all the vessels, but also as to whom they allow to depart. And it any peaceful passengers are discovered upon the vessels which may be caught making their escape from rebeldom, to have them carefully examined by those who can defect a military bearing under civilians' clothes. The captured of some of those fleeing traitors might not bring the navy so much prize money, unless, indeed, some one could be found who would buy them at their own valuation, but it would afford a satisfaction to the country which would be better than prize money to whoever should have the good fortune to accomplish it.

This raises an interesting field of inquiry. What were the important operations in prospective which he had in his mind? Gen. HALLECK, perhaps, could conjecture with more probability than we, who are not military men, and are so far off. But what seems to us the most "important operation" for BEAUREGARD, as he and his scattered forces flee before POPE, the rebel-catcher, who does not seem at all to resemble that Pope of whom BUNYAN spoke, as being stiff in his sinews and rusty in his joints, is for him and the other ringleaders to get out of the country; and for this "important operation in prospective," Mobile seems to us as available a "base" as is to be found along the Southern coast. It is one of the few ports still remaining to the rebels where they have any vessels left, and those are necessary to such an important operation. But unless this operation is speedily put in execution, we fear it will be too late. If FARRAGUT gets ready to bring his gunboats and mortar vessels around there, the operation will prove a difficult one. If BEAUREGARD can get to Mobile before him, he had better undertake it at once, for it will be much easier performed while only our blockading squadron lie off the port. We hope our Secretary of the Navy will instruct, the officers of our blockading squadron to be especially careful not only to catch all the vessels, but also as to whom they allow to depart. And it any peaceful passengers are discovered upon the vessels which may be caught making their escape from rebeldom, to have them carefully examined by those who can defect a military bearing under civilians' clothes. The captured of some of those fleeing traitors might not bring the navy so much prize money, unless, indeed, some one could be found who would buy them at their own valuation, but it would afford a satisfaction to the country which would be better than prize money to whoever should have the good fortune to accomplish it.

abstract: A spirited scrimmage occurred in Huntsville, Ala., a few days since, between Col. LEW. HARRIS, of one of the Ohio regiments, and Col. DAVIS, a law partner of JERE CLEMENS, and formerly an earnest Union man, but more recently an officer in the rebel ...
lead_paragraph: -- A spirited scrimmage occurred in Huntsville, Ala., a few days since, between Col. LEW. HARRIS, of one of the Ohio regiments, and Col. DAVIS, a law partner of JERE CLEMENS, and formerly an earnest Union man, but more recently an officer in the rebel army. The meeting took place at the quarters of Major MCCOOK. Some champagne was opened and the discussion of the state of the country presently grew warm. The Alabama Colonel told the Ohio Colonel he was a liar, with the customary qualifying epithet, and Ohio told him that if he were not the guest of Major MCCOOK, he would knock him down, Alabama begged Ohio not to have any scruples of that Sort, and repeated the epithet. So at it they went. Fair play was shown, and Ohio soon made his word good, knocking Alabama down and giving him a severe belting when he was down. Ohio's damage consisted chiefly in a badly-torn shirt. Alabama received a pair of black eyes and enlarged rose and mouth. JERE CLEMENS met the Ohio officer a few days afterward and told him he had inquired into the particulars of the affray, and that his partner (DAVIS,) had been served exactly right. DAVIS afterward acknowledged that he had got no more than he deserved. This little circumstance has contributed largely to the popularity of the Ohioan in Huntsville.

abstract: -- The great battle of last Saturday and Sunday has been designated by the Press as the "Battle before Richmond," the "Battle of the Chickahominy," of "The Pines," of "The Seven Pines," and by various other names. This is already producing confusion in the public mind concerning the affair. Gen. MCCLELLAN, in his brief dispatch to the Secretary of War correcting his first report from the field, designates the engagement as the battle of "Fair Oaks," and in his address to the soldiers of the Army of the Potomac, he repeats that designation. This will, consequently, be the name by which the battle or battles of the last day of May and first day of June, 1862, shall be known -- "The Battle of Fair Oaks.
lead_paragraph: -- The great battle of last Saturday and Sunday has been designated by the Press as the "Battle before Richmond," the "Battle of the Chickahominy," of "The Pines," of "The Seven Pines," and by various other names. abstract: -- It will be seen by our law reports this morning that a portion of the cargo of the prize Hiawatha, which was, reported as missing on its discharge from the vessel, has made its appearance. The result, even as thus far developed, shows the importance of the action taken by the Court in the matter, to which we called attention some days since. The Prize Commissioners report that they have since recovered about $13,000 worth of the missing property, but that there is as much more still missing, which, newever, they have hopes of recovering also, at least the greater portion of it. The number of missing packages is 261, besides 33 bales of cotton. That there should have been a deficiency of $26,000 in a cargo valued at about $150,000, was a somewhat startling development. We trust that the deficiency may be reduced as much as the Prize Commissioners hope it will. And when the whole matter is brought to a conclusion, we may have something further to say in the matter.

abstract: editorial speculates on capture of Memphis; Editorial on possibility of getting cotton now that Beauregard has been routed
snippet: editorial speculates on capture of Memphis; Editorial on possibility of getting cotton now that Beauregard has been routed
lead_paragraph: When BEAUREGARD had started southward from Corinth, the immediate fall of Memphis was seen to be inevitable. When Memphis was ours, the whole line of the Mississippi River, and the whole of the Great Valley, was in our military possession. Above that place our descending gunboat fleet had reduced every stronghold from New-Madrid to Fort Pillow. Below it, our ascending fleet had battered down or brought to terms every rebel fort and city from the Delta and from New-Orleans to the mouth of the Arkansas River. And both of these fleets were pressing hard upon the city. Beside our upper and lower river fleets, there was advancing upon it an overwhelming military force from Gen. HALLECK's army. Either of these naval or military detachments was capable of capturing the city; -- acting together, resistance on its part was useless. The most convenient National force to Memphis of late, has been the upper naval flotilla. The only obstacles to its southern advance were two or three unreduced rebel earthworks, some distance above the city on the left bank of the river; and into the principal one of these our mortar-boats have been showering bombshells for the past two months. We have news this morning that this work (Fort Pillow, or Wright) has been reduced, and that both it and Fort Randolph, ten miles below, are in possession of our troops. These were the only defences of any moment, unreduced, known to exist above Memphis. So that there is little doubt that yesterday afternoon or this morning, our fleet appeared before the great rebel city of the Southwest, and demanded, and probably received, its capitulation. It was understood that our upper fleet was not to advance upon it until our fleet below was ready to cooperate. So that it is not unlikely that the citizens of the last rebel city on the Mississippi, on looking up the stream this morning behold the Stars and Stripes floating in the breeze, and, on looking down the stream, behold the same resistless banner approaching from that direction. We have already had abundance of threats that the inhabitants would burn the city before they would surrender; and here, as elsewhere, we have heard plenty of gammon about dying in last ditches. But a hundred rebel towns, -- and one of them the capital of Tennessee, -- which had vociferated the same nonsense until they were hoarse, -- have capitulated when they saw they could not help themselves; and the fact that Memphis has roared louder, if possible, than any other place, is only a sign that it is prepared the quicker to devour its own words.

abstract: After many delays, the Twelfth Regiment N. Y.S.M. formed regimental line on Union-square at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, in order to leave for Washington. A large crowd was present to witness ...
lead_paragraph: After many delays, the Twelfth Regiment N. Y.S.M. formed regimental line on Union-square at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, in order to leave for Washington. A large crowd was present to witness the departure. Shortly after 11 the order to march was given, and the regiment, preceeded by a platoon of policemen, moved down Broadway. Along the route the men were frequently cheered, and attracted much attention by their fine, healthy appearance. Arriving at Pier No. 1, the Twelfth left for Washington by way of Amboy. Annexed is a list of the officers:

abstract: By the steamship City of Washington, which passed Cape Race last evening, we receive advices from Europe four days later than by the Persia. It was announced by the London Post ...
lead_paragraph: By the steamship City of Washington, which passed Cape Race last evening, we receive advices from Europe four days later than by the Persia. It was announced by the London Post that the Emily St. Pierre, rescued from her prize crew, would not be given up by the British Government. The surrender of Norfolk and the destruction of the Merrimac were regarded as the retirement of the South from the contest by water. A slight advance is reported in the Liverpool Cotton Market. Breadstuff's and Provisions were unchanged. Consuls were quoted at 93 1/2@93 5/8.

abstract: The Prize Commissioners handed into the Court to-day their report in reference to the cargo of the bark Hiawatha. The report states the order directing the appraisal and sale of the cargo, and that the cargo was discharged by the Marshal from the vessel into Wheeler's store in Brooklyn before the order was made directing them to superintend the discharge. It also states that there were 39 bills of lading of the cargo on file in the District Court; that the contents of 18 of the bills of lading have been found in full and appraised by them, and that the contents of two others were previously discharged from custody by order of the Court. That at the commencement of their examination there was found to be a large deficiency in almost every bill of lading, by reason whereof this Court on the application of the Prize Commissioners, and  at the request of the Marshal, made an order directing an investigation; that they have discovered and recovered a large amount of the property, the value whereof exceeded $13,000, but there are still deficiencies in [???] of the bills of lading, but the Commissioners have reason to believe that some portion of that will yet be recovered; that there were also on the manifest 33 bales of cotton, for which there was no bill of lading, and which could not be found, and of which they cannot therefore give even an approximate value. And they annex to their report a statement showing the portion of the cargo which they found to be appraised at $124,180 00, and the portion still missing to be 261 packages, estimated as worth $12,664 07, besides the cotton.

abstract: A dispatch from Gen. McCLELLAN'S headquarters, dated yesterday, states that everything continued very quiet.
lead_paragraph: A dispatch from Gen. McCLELLAN'S headquarters, dated yesterday, states that everything continued very quiet. Two deserters came into our camps to the morning, who reported that Gen. Jo. JOHNSTON was seriously, if not mortally wounded in the groin in the late battle, and that Gen. SMITH was in command of the rebel army. The entire rebel loss is stated by these deserters to be about ten thousand in killed, wounded and missing. Matters in the city are in a terrible condition of uncertainty.

abstract: On Thursday, the remains of Col. RIKER, who fell at the battle of Fair Oaks, while gallantly leading on his regiment, arrived in this City. On Sunday, the body will lie in state in the Governor's Room, City Hall, from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M., at which hour the funeral will take place. A military escort, under command of Gen. SANFORD, will accompany the procession to Greenwood. This evening, at 8 o'clock, the friends of Col. RIKER, will hold a meeting at the Everett House.

abstract: of Fair Oaks, and other Virginia fields, are now arriving here daily. Six hundred came in last evening, and were sent to the different places previously chosen for the purpose in this City. These wounded and sick men will all be taken care of by the Government, aided by the Sanitary Commission, and by the efforts of professional and other benevolent persons in the City. Still there is much that private beneficence and attention can do for them. They need comforts, delicacies, attentions, underclothing, and a thousand other things. Any one who has had sickness in the house, and knows those things that the sick and suffering need, can do daily a little work that will relieve much suffering. Any woman, any lady, with a little leisure, a needle, and a kind heart, can make herself of service. If she has no other time, let her work for the suffering soldiers on Sundays. It is no harm, but rather a positive virtue, to ply the needle or kindle the fire on the holy day for such a purpose. Most of these private benefactions had better reach the soldiers through the Sanitary Commission, which is in need of constant renewals of labor, supplies, and money. It depends upon private contributions for the means of carrying on its great work. The public have well supported it hitherto; but it needs much more at present, when such large numbers of sick and wounded are daily thrown upon its care. Let no woman waste any time while this war lasts. The sex cannot fight, (not in regiments, we mean,) but they can serve their country equally effectively, otherwise.

abstract: Editorial cites time it took to effect British social revolution to show that Union reconstruction will be slow process
snippet: Editorial cites time it took to effect British social revolution to show that Union reconstruction will be slow process
lead_paragraph: No Government of modern times excites more of the admiration of historians and philanthropists than that of Great Britain. In it is recognized the most intelligible and unchangeable of constitutions, uniform and liberal laws, a strong, permanent Executive, and yet the freest and most prosperous of subjects. No nation is more steady in its power, more progressive in its policy, or more bright in the glory of contributing its vast energies and influences to the elevation and well-being of the human race. And yet the English people were once infected with the vice of slaveholding -- and, what will be considered perhaps most astounding to our Utopian friends of the Abolition school, Slavery was never abolished in England, neither by military proclamation, by legislative enactment, nor by Executive edict.

abstract: the vicinity of Charleston are becoming very threatening. There had been a sharp engagement with the rebel batteries, some four miles from the city, at Stono Inlet; and it is given out, in the news from there this morning, that our forces had virtually invested the city. Charleston, we fear, like so many other rebel cities, is to be taken by a flank or rear movement. The local papers there stated, some time ago, that every other means of defence which Southerners had invented having failed to defend the cities of the South, the authorities of South Carolina had resolved to build a prodigious granite wall across the harbor in front of the city. They will find that a poor defence; for if our ships or soldiers cannot climb over the wall, there is no doubt that they will get around it some way. Besides, do they think that our great naval rams cannot batter down walls? Why, that's the very thing that battering-rams were first invented for. And then again, let them remember the walls of Jericho, and how they fell. The Yankees will adopt that dodge over again with the walls of Charleston -- if all other means fail.

abstract: Editorial on British press attitudes
snippet: Editorial on British press attitudes
lead_paragraph: The progressive falsification of all their favorite theories and prophecies respecting this great rebellion, is, at last, producing its effect upon European censors, who are not less unwilling than most men, to acknowledge themselves mistaken. Even the London Times is mournfully compelled to admit the strength and resolution of the National Government, and to perceive the inadequacy of the means wherewith traitors have sought its destruction. For a long time did that ingenuous journal entertain the conviction that we could never raise an army, but if we unfortunately did so, there was consolation in the certainty that it would never fight, and whether it fought or not, there remained a cheering reflection in the impossibility of its ever being paid. On these little points, the London Times, as well as a great many other newspapers and people, has lately changed its opinions with a celerity nearly as ludicrous as the celebrated summer-sault of the New-York Herald in April, 1861.

abstract: THE PETROLEUM OIL ORDINANCE. -- The Common Council, it will be remembered, at the meeting held on Monday evening last, adopted a stringent ordinance, almost prohibiting the traffic or distillation of Petroleum Oil within the city limits. At the same time the subject matter of the ordinance was referred to the Joint Fire Department Committee to investigate the nature of this kind of oil, and recommend such changes in the ordinance as they might deem best for the interest of all parties. A meeting of the Committee was called for Friday evening, at the City Hall; but, notwithstanding the large amount of capital invested in the business in this city and a direct invitation for all interested in the business to appear before the Committee at that time, when their side of the case would be heard, only one member of the Committee, Alderman BELKNAP, made his appearance during the whole evening. At 9 o'clock the gentlemen interested in the oil trade, who had met at the Committee room by invitation, as above stated, resolved, so long as they had got together, to do something toward giving a fair expression of their grievances. A meeting was therefore organized by electing Mr. J.G. WILLIAMS Chairman, and Mr. J. WALES Secretary. After some desultory conversation as to the importance of united action in an effort to secure a remodeling of the ordinance, so that the right of all might be conserved, Mr. PAGE moved that a Committee of five be appointed to draft petitions, obtain signatures, and present the case of the oil-dealers in a succinct manner to the Common Council Committee on the first opportunity offered. This motion was adopted, and the Chairman appointed the following named gentlemen on the Committee: Messrs. Richardson, Wales, Stearns, Irvine and Ketchum. The meeting then adjourned until 3 o'clock Tuesday afternoon next, at No. 34 Pine-street, New-York, at which time it is expected there will be a large attendance of oil-dealers. The dealers in petroleum say that it will be impossible for them to comply with the ordinance as it now stands, and that the authorities have acted upon erroneous information as to the character of petroleum. This they propose to show if the Committee will afford them an opportunity.

abstract: By the steamship North America, which arrived off Cape Race yesterday, we receive advices from Europe one day later than by the City of Washington. The Defence Commission, appointed by...
lead_paragraph: By the steamship North America, which arrived off Cape Race yesterday, we receive advices from Europe one day later than by the City of Washington. The Defence Commission, appointed by the British Government to inquire into the relative efficiency of iron-plated vessels and fortifications, had unanimously reported that fortifications cannot be dispensed with -- that they must continue to form an essential feature in the defences of the country. The House of Commons was engaged in an inquiry into the relations between England and the Nationals and Confederates Cotton had advanced 1/4 d. for American varieties, and the market closed buoyant, with sales for the week of 47,000 bales. Bread stuffs had also advanced, but Provisions continued dull. American securities were steady. Consuls were quoted at 93 5/8 for money.

abstract: Editorial discusses terms Puritans and Cavaliers in describing settlers of Massachusetts and Virginia
snippet: Editorial discusses terms Puritans and Cavaliers in describing settlers of Massachusetts and Virginia
lead_paragraph: A favorite device with the Secessionists and their sympathizers is that which seeks to identify loyal men and rebels, respectively, with the Roundheads and Cavaliers of the time of the STUARTS. The object of insisting upon this analogy is quite obvious, but consideration will show that it must fall far short of logical demonstration,. It is highly desirable for the traitors to hold Unionists up to the world as gloomy ascetics who hate innocent pleasure, and try to oppose all who disagree with their fanatical dogmas; and equally so to represent themselves as gay, dashing, high-spirited fellows, overflowing with honor and redolent of chivalrous sensibility. Such are the ideas suggested to most people, now-a-days, by the terms Puritan and Cavalier. Let us see how far the application is appropriate to the cases in point.

abstract: THE POLICE AMONG THE BULLS AND BEARS OF WALL-STREET. It will be remembered that several days ago, the TIMES gave an account of the arrests made by the Police of several street brokers, who were charged with having illegally blockaded the street in the neighborhood of Exchange-place and William-street.
lead_paragraph: THE POLICE AMONG THE BULLS AND BEARS OF WALL-STREET. -- It will be remembered that several days ago, the TIMES gave an account of the arrests made by the Police of several street brokers, who were charged with having illegally blockaded the street in the neighborhood of Exchange-place and William-street. The arrests were made at thattime upon the complaint of three or four brokers, who have offices in the vicinity. They alleged that it was the daily habit of large numbers of men, who claim to be street brokers, to gather in crowds, upon the side-walk, and in front of their offices, thereby obstructing the way, and preventing customers from entering their places of business. When complaint was made to Mr. KENNEDY, Superintendent of the Police, he immediately determined to put a stop to the nuisance, and for this purpose he directed that a patrolman should be stationed at that place during business hours, with instructions to arrest all parties who were found obstructing the sidewalk, or in any way interfering with the rights of those engaged in a legitimate business. Pursuant to these directions the officer upon that post, yesterday, arrested Mr. THOS. DENNY, a very respectable and inoffensive gentleman, and a member of the Stock Exchange. The policeman showed very little regard for Mr. DENNY's position or feelings; but on the contrary, dragged him through the crowded streets to the Tombs, in a very rude way. When the magistrate had heard the com-plaint, and Mr. DENNY's reply thereto, he instantly released the accused party, and reproved the officer for the ungentlemanly course that he had pursued.

abstract: The eyes of the whole country are now fixed upon our army before Richmond. A battle is imminent there which may take rank with the most stupendous battles ever fought on the globe.
lead_paragraph: The eyes of the whole country are now fixed upon our army before Richmond. A battle is imminent there which may take rank with the most stupendous battles ever fought on the globe. Seldom, in the history of the world, have more numerous hosts confronted each other than those which are now on the eve of measuring steel upon the narrow strip of land between the Chickahominy and the James. Never an army went into the field so magnificently appointed as ours; never one supported by such vast supplies of unequaled artillery, and aided by such extraordinary scientific appliances; never was there an army composed of such splendid stuff; never one possessed of a finer mettle; and we would fain hope that the event will show that never was there one led to glory by a greater commander. The issue involved in the contest is the grandest, -- the old issue of Freedom which has been "bequeathed from bleeding sire to son" all through the long ages -- which our grandsires and their children fought for, and which has been given to us to do battle for once again, and then, as a sacred gift, hand down to our posterity. A fiercer or bloodier foe never entered the lists for mortal combat than that now fronting our army, and ranged under the black banner of Slavery and rebellion. This is his last desperate chance, and he knows it. To fail here is to lose not only his capital but his cause; while for us to succeed now is to secure freedom, peace and unity; not to this generation alone, but it is to make any future triumph of Slavery and disunion forever impossible.

abstract: quite a respectable naval fleet, as well as an eminently respectable mercantile fleet, from our domestic enemies and foreign friends in this war. The last week has been a peculiarly rich one, two British iron steamers were brought into this port during the past week, which had been nabbed in their attempt to pierce our paper blockade; and the sailing ships, schooners, sloops, brigs and barks, from the British West India islands and from rebel ports, have been so numerous that it is hard work to keep track of them. During the last war (1812) the British lost 354 merchant ships, 610 brigs, 520 schooners, and 130 sloops, besides 67 armed vessels carrying 878 guns; and we took vessels enough from them to form an entire navy of large size, and guns enough to supply them all. We are comparatively deficient in our captures of guns so far in this war; but should & last another year, we would certainly obtain as many ships from the English, now that they are friends, as we formerly took from them when they were.

abstract: Died in Hartford, Conn., on the evening of the 5th inst., Rev. CHARLES A. GOODRICH, aged 71 years. The deceased was son of Rev. SAMUEL GOODRICH, of Connecticut, and a brother of SAMUEL G. GOODRICH, (Peter Parley,) who died two years ago in this City.
lead_paragraph: -- Died in Hartford, Conn., on the evening of the 5th inst., Rev. CHARLES A. GOODRICH, aged 71 years. The deceased was son of Rev. SAMUEL GOODRICH, of Connecticut, and a brother of SAMUEL G. GOODRICH, (Peter Parley,) who died two years ago in this City. C.A. GOODRICH, like his brother S.G. GOODRICH, devoted his life to literary pursuits. He was the author of GOODRICH's History of the United States, one of our best standard school books, and several other valuable historical and religious works in general use. The reverend author was naturally a very gifted man and a most accomplished scholar. His mentalorganization was active, though of that sensitive nature which caused him to shrink from rough contact with the world. Mr. GOODRICH's love for his fellow men was refined, charitable, and of the most enlarged order. After a life spent with the single view to elevate mankind, the good man is now gathered to his fathers, and another of those bright lights that have adorned New-England is put out.

abstract: The rain fall steadily from the commencement on Tuesday night, in consequence of which the ground soon became thoroughly soaked, when the water that fell subsequently was thrown into the...
lead_paragraph: The rain fall steadily from the commencement on Tuesday night, in consequence of which the ground soon became thoroughly soaked, when the water that fell subsequently was thrown into the creeks, causing the Delaware and Lehigh to rise rapidly. At an early hour last night these streams were considerably swollen, but it was not supposed they would attain any great height. As morning approached, however, it became evident that the freshet would be a heavy one, and preparations were made by persons owning property and those residing along the rivers to save what they could from the flood and remove their families and furniture to places where they would be more secure. The loss on lumber alone at this place will probably reach $25,000 to $30,000. This, however, is mere guess work, as it is impossible at present to count the losses occasioned by this disastrous freshet.

abstract: All the work which can be done to her on the stocks, planking, &c., is finished, and she will be reported ready for floating into the stream when the caulkers have got through with her. The Lackawanna is a "single banked" frigate, 262 feet long over all, 235 feet long on load line, extreme breadth of beam 33 feet 3 inches, depth of hold 17 feet 10 inches, tonnage 1,000 tons, and proportionate draft of water. She has been constructed under the superintendence of Naval Constructor DELANO, who has built some of our crack vessels. The masts, of which she will have three, are preparing for her in the spar department. The machinery of the Lackawanna will be about the most perfect of any got up for the Navy Department. It is now nearly complete, and consists of two horizontal back acting engines, with cylinders 42 inches in diameter and 30 inches stroke. There are three of MARTIN's patent boilers, which are now the only ones, we believe, used in the service. The propeller is a fixed brass one fully 15 feet diameter, and 17 feet 6 inches mean pitch. The condenser is SEWELL's patent, similar in all respects to that used in the gunboats recently built. The engines, with their accompanying attributes, will be taken over to the Navy-yard when the Lackawanna is launched. She is in ship-house No. 2, and was put on the stocks late last year, some months before the Ticonderoga's keel was aid. The latter vessel will not be complete for some months.

abstract: The ship Idaho, of Boston, Capt. HOWE, from Ship Island on May 12, in ballast to U.S. Quarter  master, arrived here yesterday. She reports that on May 27, lat. 328, Ion. 76 , she spoke United States...
lead_paragraph: The ship Idaho, of Boston, Capt. HOWE, from Ship Island on May 12, in ballast to U.S. Quarter master, arrived here yesterday. She reports that on May 27, lat. 32°, lon. 76°, she spoke United States sloop-of-war Marion, from Key West for Boston on April 12. While lying at Ship Island Roads, and during a northerly gale, came in contact with ship Great Republic, carrying away bowsprit and cutwater, split plank-shear, broke rudder and sprung aleak; was obliged to have a steam-pump put on board to keep her free. The Idaho is bound to Boston, but put into this port in consequence of the steam-pump giving out.

abstract: Editorial on military strength of North and South
snippet: Editorial on military strength of North and South
lead_paragraph: The recent flurry occasioned by the bold dash of the rebels upon Gen. BANKS has been the occasion of a movement of troops which displays in a most striking manner the difference between our situation and that of the rebels. After a year of war carried on upon a scale of unprecedented magnitude, in which we had put mightier armies on foot than this continent has ever seen before, the Government had given orders to receive no more volunteers, and thus alone had checked the rush of our people to the camps. But now, at the call of a sudden emergency, on every hand spring up new hosts of armed men, where all was quiet but a few days since, and the roads again begin to shake beneath their tread as they pour forward, showing that the "frozen loins" of the "populous North" have not yet lost their fruitfulness, and that a year of the privations and burdens of war has but whetted their zeal and fired the patriotism of those who are proud to be the sons of the North. And yet we are that people whom taunting Southrons so loudly proclaimed to be an unmilitary people, who thought of nothing but material things, and took more naturally to peddling and to the petty cheats of small traffic than to anything else. They have learned by this time that when "the lawful tap of the drum" resounds through our valleys and over our plains, it summons to the ranks fighting men, of whom any General might be proud, and whom any foe must respect.

abstract: Hon. WILLIAM A. RICHARDSON, of this city, received yesterday, from Major-Gen. BETLER, a fac-simile of the Ordinance of Secession adopted by the Convention which voted the State of Louisiana out of the Union.
lead_paragraph: -- Hon. WILLIAM A. RICHARDSON, of this city, received yesterday, from Major-Gen. BETLER, a fac-simile of the Ordinance of Secession adopted by the Convention which voted the State of Louisiana out of the Union. The document is sketched in ink on drawing paper, and is dedicated to HENRY PEYCHAND, Esq. As a specimen of chirography, the work is highly creditable to the artist, who, if we may judge from the spelling, had not received the advantages of even a common school education. The memento is embellished in the most elaborate manner, with pelican and lone star flags, and as if to idealize the grand result which each day's events now betoken, the words "United States of America" are supported by a stack of arms on one side and the implements of agriculture on the other -- the one to defend the Union, the other to feed her armies. The ordinance is signed by A. MOUTON, as President, J. THOS. WHEAT, Secretary, and one hundred and eleven members of the convention.

abstract: A meeting of the friends of the late Col. RIKER, of the Anderson Zouaves, who gloriously fell whilst leading his regimentat the battle of Fair Oaks, was held last evening at the Everett House...
lead_paragraph: A meeting of the friends of the late Col. RIKER, of the Anderson Zouaves, who gloriously fell whilst leading his regimentat the battle of Fair Oaks, was held last evening at the Everett House. GEO. W. MORTON, Esq., called the meeting to order, and nominated Ex-Recorder TALLMADGE as Chairman, and Councilman LENT as Vice-Chairman. Mr. CHARLES L. FROST acted as Secretary. Several officers of the Anderson Zouaves, now on here in charge of their lamented commander's body, were present. After some remarks from Ex-Recorder TALLMADGE, Lieut. BRADLEY -- who participated in the battle of Fair Oaks, as aid to Col. RIKER -- was called upon, Lieut. BRADLEY gave a long and interesting account of the share taken in the engagement by the Anderson Zouaves, with special reference to Col. RIKER's conduct on that occasion. From the Lieutenant's statement, it would seem that the regiment and its Colonel behaved magnificently all through the fight; the coolness of the Colonel, in the most trying situations, being absolutely marvelous. As showing this Lieut. BRADLEY incidentally remarked that the Colonel was not struck whilst waving his sword, as he never drew his sword at all, but was quietly smoking a cigar most of the time. Lieut. BRADLEY declared he never saw a Colonel so beloved by his soldiers as was Col. RIKER. The speaker was warmly applauded at the conclusion of his remarks.

abstract: Senator SUMNER has  brought forward in Congress resolutions denouncing the policy of President LINCOLN in appointing Military Governors for the reclaimed rebel States. Mr.SUMNER declares...
lead_paragraph: -- Senator SUMNER has brought forward in Congress resolutions denouncing the policy of President LINCOLN in appointing Military Governors for the reclaimed rebel States. Mr.SUMNER declares that it is unconstitutional and subversive of the public liberties, He claims for Congress the exclusive right of governing these States, though he does not describe the means and machinery by which that authority should be exercised.

abstract: Dispatches from Washington
snippet: Dispatches from Washington
lead_paragraph: The following very interesting document reaches us from the State Department at Washington, which it seems to have reached instead of the Department at Richmond, for which it was evidently intended. It is a most curious and important disclosure of the utter hopelessness of the rebel cause abroad. Mr. SEWARD causes it to be published because, as no mode of communicating with the rebel Government has yet been established, this seems the most speedy method of bringing the interesting facts embodied in this dispatch to the President of that concern. We hope he will be edified by its perusal:

abstract: PICKPOCKETS IN STAGES. The stages in NewYork, and especially those running principally upon Broadway, have recently been made the resort of a well organized and skillful set...
lead_paragraph: PICKPOCKETS IN STAGES. -- The stages in NewYork, and especially those running principally upon Broadway, have recently been made the resort of a well organized and skillful set of pickpocket, who ply their trade with impunity, upon passengers of all grades, if the victims do not happen to be well informed in regard to the habits and practices of the numerous thieves who infest the City. Not a day passes, but that we hear of some person who has been unfortunate enough to lose money in this way. In most cases, however, the guilty parties escape, for the simple reason that there cannot be sufficient evidence brought against them to secure a conviction. The operators in this business, are of both sexes, and apparently of all ages and conditions in life. Some are exceedingly well dressed, and appear like well-bred ladies and gentlemen; others are poorly clad, and pretend to be proper objects of charity. The Police authorities assert that there is a thoroughly organized gang of these pickpockets in the City, the leaders of which, have, by dint of much pains and labor, reduced the business to a system, and that some of the most adroit pocket-robbers in the country are connected with this band. Each one has his particular branch of business to attend to. Some of them exhibit the most skill in taking a person's pocket-book in a crowd, while others can more successfully operate in a stage or car. They much prefer a stage to a car however, from the fact that in the latter vehicle they are liable to be observed by the conductor, and, if caught in the act, their escape is more likely to be prevented. On Saturday afternoon last one of this gang was caught by Officer BODINE, of the Fifteenth Precinct, and yesterday morning the accused was taken before Justice KELLY, where, after examination, she was committed to prison. The prisoner gave her name as ADELAIDE IRWIN; she says she is a native of this State and nineteen years of age. She and the complainant, HELEN MCNAUGHT, were the only persons in the stage at the time. The accused very adroitly picked the pocket of her victim of a porte-monnaie containing $7, and soon after left the stage. Mrs. MCNAUGHT, who, by the way, has been recently victimized twice in the same manner, at once missed her money, and gave chase. After running about a block the thief was caught, while in the act of throwing away the porte-monnaie, the money having already been abstracted. Several persons are now in the City Prison upon the charge of picking pockets in stages, and the Police are daily adding to the list of offenders. It is thought that the authorities have obtained sufficient information to enable them to break up this systematic nuisance.

abstract: I give you this name with  much pleasure, since you desire to look upon me as an old friend, and because I believe also that we have the same heart and the same ideas. You are right in...
lead_paragraph: I give you this name with much pleasure, since you desire to look upon me as an old friend, and because I believe also that we have the same heart and the same ideas. You are right in believing that I follow with much interest the events now accomplishing where you are. I think as you do, that besides this question of Slavery, which will shortly be a weight the less upon the heart of every good man, a stain removed from the forehead of modern civilization, the debate now closing beyond the Atlantic will have its rebound in Europe, and that it is also universal Democracy which triumphs this moment in America, with the Gospel of which it is but the application socially, whether Democracy so believe or not. I wish you in advance good fortune and courage in the work to which you have devoted yourself, the success of which can alone make your people and ours friends. Since you sometimes see Gen. MCCLELLAN, tell him that the wishes of all generous souls are with him. * * * *

abstract: There is an ominous pause in the movements of our Army in front of Richmond. It is now a week since the rebel attempt, with an overwhelming force, to break our lines was...
lead_paragraph: There is an ominous pause in the movements of our Army in front of Richmond. It is now a week since the rebel attempt, with an overwhelming force, to break our lines was repulsed and punished with dreadful slaughter, but also, it must be remembered, at very serious cost to ourselves. Gen. MCCLELLAN's order, issued immediately after that sharp engagement, indicated a purpose on his part to push forward speedily, and force his way into Richmond. The terrible storm of Wednesday last so swelled the streams he has to cross as to delay the movement for four or five days, -- and it may be that this is the only reason why that movement is delayed.

abstract: Through the kindness of the friends of the orphan in this City a spacious and commodious home has been erected in Forty-ninth-street, and has now been occupied for more than a year. At first the Managers were content to finish the building only so
lead_paragraph: Through the kindness of the friends of the orphan in this City a spacious and commodious home has been erected in Forty-ninth-street, and has now been occupied for more than a year. At first the Managers were content to finish the building only so far as was necessary for immediate use. But they find themselves now constrained, both for the preservation of the edifice and for the proper care of the inmates, to proceed to a further expenditure of about $8,000, which sum will place the building in very complete order.

abstract: By the steamship North America, which arrived off Cape Race on Saturday, we receive advices from Europe one day later than by the City of Washington. The Defence Commmission, appointed by the British Government to inquire into the relative...
lead_paragraph: By the steamship North America, which arrived off Cape Race on Saturday, we receive advices from Europe one day later than by the City of Washington. The Defence Commmission, appointed by the British Government to inquire into the relative efficiency of iron-plated vessels and fortifications, had unanimously reported that fortifications cannot be dispensed with -- that they must continue to form an essential feature in the defences of the country. In the House of Commons notice had been given of an inquiry into the relations between England and the Nationals and Confederates. Cotton had advanced ld. for American varieties, and the market closed buoyant, with sales for the week of 47,000 bales. Breadstuffs had also advanced, but Provisions continued dull. American securities were steady. Consols were quoted at 93 [???] for money.

abstract: We yesterday published brief dispatches from the West, announcing that Memphis had surrendered to our Upper Mississippi flotilla, and was in quiet possession of our forces. It appears now,...
lead_paragraph: We yesterday published brief dispatches from the West, announcing that Memphis had surrendered to our Upper Mississippi flotilla, and was in quiet possession of our forces. It appears now, however, that this possession was not gained without a furious naval struggle, which will take rank as one of the most desperate of the war. Capt. DAVIS, commanding the flotilla, telegraphs to the Secretary of the Navy that he arrived on the evening of the 5th, at a point about a mile and a half above the city, and the next morning discovered the rebel fleet, consisting of eight rams and gunboats, lying at the levee. He engaged them at 6:30 A.M., and the engagement terminated at 7, in a running fight. The result was the destruction and capture of seven of the rebel fleet, and the escape of the eighth through her superior speed. Capt. DAVIS says he was ably supported by our fleet of rams, under command of Col. ELLET, who was severely though not dangerously wounded in the action. The Mayor of the city surrendered the city immediately after the engagement, and a National force, under Col. FITCH took possession.

abstract: A NEW ENTERPRISE. -- A New-York firm has recently put up extensive buildings on Long Beach, near Greenport, to manufacture oil and guano out of the fish known as "bunkers," which swarm the coast of Long Island. The buildings for carrying on the business consist of a main building, 40 by 50 feet a guano house, 30 by 70; office and store-house, 30 by 70; engine-house, 30 by 35; dwelling, 18 by 35; stable, 18 by 25; oil-shed, 30 by 50. A large wharf had been constructed, which is to be connected with the buildings by a railway. The engine is to be 40 horse power. Some of the retired whaling captains of Orient and vicinity have organized a company to catch the kind of fish required, and will soon have five vessels engaged in the business. This is but the commencement of a new enterprise, which will eventually give employment to a large number of people on Long Island.

abstract: The work of "restoring the Union" in Tennessee is making steady and satisfactory progress. Gov. JOHNSON'S administration is marked by firmness and prudence. He aims...
lead_paragraph: The work of "restoring the Union" in Tennessee is making steady and satisfactory progress. Gov. JOHNSON'S administration is marked by firmness and prudence. He aims to conciliate Union men by showing them that, in spite of the war, the National Government has no thought of interfering with their rights or of doing anything but restore to them the right of self-government under the Constitution of the United States. At the same time he treats with just and relentless rigor all who persist in waging war upon the Government, and who make themselves active partisans of the rebellion long after they can plead anything like coercion or constraint in excuse therefor.

abstract: The capitulation of Memphis, which was seen to be inevitable after the evacuation of Corinth and the fall of Fort Pillow, is now authentically announced. The city surren-...
lead_paragraph: The capitulation of Memphis, which was seen to be inevitable after the evacuation of Corinth and the fall of Fort Pillow, is now authentically announced. The city surrendered on Friday morning last to our naval fleet, after the latter had destroyed or captured, in a brisk fight, the whole of the rebel gun-boats which had remained as its last defence. It was surrendered to our forces by the very man, the Mayor of the city, who, only five days before, had presided over a meeting, at which the speakers breathed forth fire and vengeance against the Union army; and at which, among others, that notable resolution was passed: "That we will never yield while we can defend, and will never voluntarily surrender this city into the hands of the enemy." The city does not appear to have been given to the flames, as the howling rebel dervishes of that locality have asseverated every day for the last eighteen months that it should be, if our forces ever managed to reach it. The cotton-bale barricades, which were originally erected in the streets by the immortal Gen. PILLOW, and behind which every man, woman and slave was to fight, and to fight until the last armed inhabitant expired, had long ago been removed; and the other terrible devices for our destruction, which the local Press have conjured up, do not seem to have been brought into requisition. A small military force -- for we believe there were only two regiments of troops accompanied the fleet -- quietly took possession of a city which, by last census, had a population of twenty-five thousand, -- the largest city in Tennessee, the largest between St. Louis and New-Orleans, the last rebel stronghold on the Mississippi River, and a point to resign which was to give up not only the whole of the territory beyond the Father of Waters, but was virtually to close the campaign in the Southwest. Not a gun was fired in its defence -- not a rebel life was laid down to save it. The rebel troops, we suppose, must have decamped; for they did not fight. The rebel Generals, and among them Peacock PILLOW, who "would rather die a thousand deaths than see Memphis in the hands of the enemy," all took to their heels, we imagine; for not a General, dead or alive, is mentioned as a captive. The rebel Governor and Legislature, who, when chased from Nashville, took up their quarters in Memphis, have fled to some other place of temporary safety; and to find it they must have absconded from Tennessee. The rebel newspapers of Memphis, which seemed to be printed with sulphur instead of ink, doubtless now exhibit that discretion which for them is the safer part of valor. If rebel brag has not already become so ridiculous that nothing could add to its absurdity, this denouement at Memphis would cap the climax. Nashville had spoken strongly, and had blustered fiercely as to what it would do: New-Orleans had boasted of its power and impregnability, and had warned us what tearful things we might expect if ever we came there; 'Norfolk, and a score of other rebel cities now in our possession, had previously declaimed loudly enough as to their determination to fight the invader to the last; Charleston, Savannah, and Richmond, even now, while we are thundering at their gates, keep up a show of spirit. But of all the cities of rebeldom, captured or to be captured, not one has approached to Memphis in the ferocity of its threats against us, in its ear-splitting screams of defiance, in the uproarious, obstreperous shrieks, yells, and whoops of murder and madness, in case the Yankees should dare to set foot within its sacred streets. If it can be that Memphis has surrendered to a few gunboats and a few hundred Union soldiers, peacefully and without firing a shot, it would not now surprise us to see Charleston succumb as soon as Gen. HUNTER, from his headquarters at Port Royal, bids it do so; or to behold the South Carolina fire-eaters transformed into lambs, and hailing with shouts of rapture the Star Spangled Banner.

abstract: Rev. Dr. WILLIAMS repeated yesterday morning, in his Church in Amity-street, the discourse recently delivered by him at Providence, before the Home Missionary Society of the Baptist Church. It...
lead_paragraph: Rev. Dr. WILLIAMS repeated yesterday morning, in his Church in Amity-street, the discourse recently delivered by him at Providence, before the Home Missionary Society of the Baptist Church. It was a very able, interesting and instructive sermon Its leading purpose was to urge the fact that all great national changes, all wars, rebellions and social transformations, however dreadful they may seem to us, are really the means by which Providence works out His own purposes, and that those purposes always involve the advancement and upbuilding of His Church, and the establishment and diffusion of His truth. He illustrated this principle by copious and learned references to history, both ancient and modern, and then urged its application to the war in which we are now engaged for the maintenance of the Government against rebellion. Whether we can see the successive steps of His Providence in this war, or not, it is nevertheless certain that God presides over every event which marks its progress, and will, by its agency, accomplish his own righteous designs. Dr. W. specified several respects in which the beneficial effects of the war upon the National character can already be traced. It has rebuked and checked the prevalent overweening fondness for lucre, by showing that there are aims and objects infinitely more worthy of labor and sacrifice than more wealth It has fastened the attention of the nation upon foundation principles -- upon the precepts of justice and of right, which are indispensable to all national prosperity. It has deepened and quickened the public sense of the real sacredness and obligation of an oath, by holding up to reprobation the infusions perjury of which the South has been guilty. The doctrine of the old Jesuits, that an oath might be taken with a mental reservation, which should annul its obligations whenever they came in conflict with the Order, has worked their ruin and exposed their organization to the scorn and contumely of the world forever. But it has been fairly paralleled and fully equaled in guilt by those who, year after year, in high places of public trust, have sworn allegiance to the Constitution of the United States, with the mental reservation that they would disregard the oath whenever it came in conflict with the minor claims of the several States. This infamous perjury is working out its proper fruits. It has covered the rebellion with curses as with a garment, and they will cling to it and its authors forever The war is developing and strengthening the spirit of National unity, by showing all parts and all the people of the Nation how essential they are to each other -- by leading them all to common toils, common sufferings and common sacrifices for the common good. Men of all races -- men from the Scheldt and the Shannon -- meet together on the battle-field and shed their blood under the same flag, and fight for the same blessings common to them all of order, of liberty, of law; and so they come to have a stronger and a more pervading sentiment of the identity of their national interests, and the unity of their public duties. Dr. WILLIAMS dwelt upon each of these points with great force and eloquence, and spoke also at some length of the bearings of the war upon Slavery, which has always been our reproach abroad and at home. Our fathers regarded it as an evil, and by studied circumlocution shunned its recognition in the Constitution, hoping and believing that it would prove ephemeral. But the South, misled by sophistry and a false view of their own interest, have sought to make it permanent, and, according to the avowal of their own Vice-President, have made it the cornerstone -- the very basis and foundation -- of their new Confederacy. To recognize a nation with such a basis -- resting upon an open and ostentatious denial of God's own declaration that of one blood He has made all the nations of the earth, on a flagrant and blasphemous denial of the rights and humanity of any class of men, said Dr. W., would be an infamy not to be thought of for a moment in this age of civilization and Christianity. The North could better afford to wage war upon it for a century -- to see every one of her cities and towns laid in ashes, and her people driven to the mountains for refuge, than assent to the incorporation of such a principle into the Constitution of the nation. But the progress of events proves that they are not called to make any such sacrifice. Every day indicates that this great question is to be solved much more speedily and with much less suffering than we could have predicted. Without any violent or sudden uprooting, the advance of our armies loosens the bonds of Slavery, and the longer the war continues, the greater the number of the slaves set free: -- and for the nation to return men, thus enfranchised, to bondage again, would be an infamy not to be for a moment thought of. The apostolic precept to slaves, not to despise their masters, but, it they may have freedom without violence or wrong, to "use it rather," -- to prefer freedom to Slavery if they can secure it without violence or sin of their own, must be the guide of our conduct now. We should shun the violent and sudden changes which would involve society in anarchy and ruin: -- but we can never wisely or justly regard Slavery as equally desirable with freedom, nor fail to "use" the latter "rather" than the former, if the providence of God shall open the way. These views were enforced with characteristic fervor and force by the preacher, who took occasion in passing to question seriously the wisdom of deporting the enfranchised slaves, saying that Spain did herself most serious wrong in expelling the Moors, and to urge the duty of raising them, by culture, by the influence's of education and of Christianity, to a fitness for their new responsibilities and duties. He referred, also, to the fears that our armies would become our masters, and that, as the result of this war, our Republic would degenerate into a despotism, and said the intelligence, the principle, the home attachments and religious character of the great body of our troops, afforded a sufficient protection, under God, against this peril.

abstract: Editorial on British opinion of US public debt; Editorial on British opinion of public debt
snippet: Editorial on British opinion of US public debt; Editorial on British opinion of public debt
lead_paragraph: The market for the Government Funds, it will be observed from our Stock and Money review, made a further advance last week of one per cent., partly on the general buoyancy of the Stock Exchange, but mainly from the increasing public confidence in and favor toward this leading class of securities. They have also been strengthened by the official contradiction of the various exaggerations through partizan speeches in Congress and otherwise as to the present magnitude of the Public Debt. This contradiction derives the more importance from the fact that the precise figures and classification of the Debt are published in answer to a formal resolution for such a report passed by the House of Representatives a few days ago. It was not volunteered for effect by the Secretary. The resulting average rate of interest paid by the Government is not less gratifying than the comparatively moderate cost at which this great War has been conducted. Both are alike creditable to the Administration of the Government and the prompt and generous confidence of our loyal people who have taken up the whole of the War loans, without the slightest reference, to or reliance upon the foreign markets. Indeed, while this process has been going on, our own market has taken back from England a large share of the old 5 and 6 per cents of the United States, heretofore held abroad; especially the 5 per cents of 1874, upon which heavy profits have been made by American parties in London, like Messrs. GEORGE PEABODY & Co., who bought the stocks as offered on the London Exchange and resold them here upon a rapidly advancing market.

abstract: We observe that Com-  modore FOOTE continues to be pestered with invitations to celebrations in his honor. These are, no doubt, weil meant but the movers...
lead_paragraph: -- We observe that Commodore FOOTE continues to be pestered with invitations to celebrations in his honor. These are, no doubt, weil meant -- but the movers must surely be altogether forgetful of the condition of the gallant sailor that has necessitated his temporary retiracy. Commodore FOOTE was severely wounded at the taking of Fort Donelson, and the wound was much aggravated by his long refusal to take rest from the arduous duties of the campaign on the Western waters. Finally, however, it became obvious that if he was ever again to be able to serve his country as he wished to, the one imperative condition was that he should allow himself sufficient repose for his wound to heal and his physique to regain its strength. Accordingly he retired to Cleveland, where he has a brother, under whose care he is now recuperating. It is said that he weighs but one-half what he did previous to the fight at Fort Donelson, so reduced is his system. The heart of the gallant sailor is, however, firmly set on resuming the work he so nobly began on the rivors of the West; and the whole country wishes to see him again on board his flag-ship, leading his victorious gunboats up the waters where rebellion shows itself. But in order that he shall ever be able to do so, the first condition is that he shall have the undisturbed benefit of his present repose. We hope, therefore, that those who are disposed to disturb it by intentions of Iionizing Commodore FOOTE will reflect that their kindness, though well meant, is untimely and calculated to defeat the object they, in common with the whole country, have in view.

abstract: Editorial sees omen of doom for Confederate leaders whose namesake ships have been destroyed by Union
snippet: Editorial sees omen of doom for Confederate leaders whose namesake ships have been destroyed by Union
lead_paragraph: -- In the early days of the war, the rebels used to put great stress upon omens, auspices and portents. Like the ancient Romans, they drew auguries from historic coincidences, the identity of names, places, dates, and what not; and from every sign in the heavens, on the earth, or in the news of the day, they prognosticated the success of the rebellion. Curiously enough, at that time, the omens were nearly always favorable to them, as were also the events which followed or preceded the omens. The first auspice adverse to the rebels was when the pirate ship Jeff. Davis was dashed against the rocks, and went to the bottom of the sea. That clearly foreshadowed the coming doom of the arch-usurper JEFF. DAVIS; and though, prior to this event, everything had gone in his favor, immediately after it the tide turned against him, his kingdom began to break up, and now his ship of State is dashing among the breakers, and will inevitably soon sink to the bottom of the bloody sea on which he launched it. The word "Sumter" at first was a name to conjure with; for at Fort Sumter the first success of the rebellion was achieved; but the vessel which the rebels soon after baptized by that name, has been driven in disgrace from the high seas by our cruisers, and is now skulking in the harbor of Gibraltar, under the protection of British guns -- indicating that through some of the knaves may save their necks, it can only be by skulking from their own country and seeking the protection of foreign Powers. Manassas was their next great success, and after it they named their tremendous iron ram, but in the naval engagement below New-Orleans the ram was shivered to atoms and consumed by the fire of the Union guns -- the augury from which occurrence is too palpable to require a priest to set forth. And so it has been with every sign, as well as every event, for the last half year. Every wind has been adverse to the rebels; every rebel cloud has been densely black; every fowl and frog has croaked dolefully; and the entrails of every rebel beast have smelt only of decay. The latest sign of the fate awaiting the prominent rebels of the Southwest, comes in the news of the great naval battle on the Mississippi River, which we give this morning. In that engagement, the General Beauregard was blown up and burned -- auguring a fearful doom for the little Creole. Already he, as well as the gunboat of his name, has been pretty well and pretty highly blown up; and he is now only awaiting the cremation which is sure to come; after which he will float down the stream of time a charred and contemptible wreak. The Gen. Sterling Price had "one wheel carried away." Poor Gen. PRICE! He was a good vessel originally, built of sound timber, and designed by nature for most excellent uses. We hope that the rebellion will still leave him one wheel with which to propel himself through this devious world; and if he is of no other service, he can be laid upon the shores of the Republic, high and dry, a melancholy warning to others. The Jeff. Thompson was set on fire and blown up -- a fit fate for the cutthroat and marauder of the Missouri swamps. The Gen. Van Dorn escaped; but, at last advices, two rams were in hot pursuit of him, who will doubtless ere long get their horn into his heart. Thus nearly every prominent rebel has had his doom foreshadowed; and in every case the event is following close upon the heels of the sign. Will not the deluded rebels see that even the gods are against them?

lead_paragraph: In response to an advertised call, a meeting of Pennsylvanians was held yesterday afternoon, at the Astor-house, for the purpose of effecting some permanent organization for the care of sick and wounded soldiers belonging to Pennsylvania, arriving at this port. Gov. CURTIN was expected to be present, but was detained by ill health. Mr. S.B.H. VANCE acted as President, and M.G. HART and L. HARWOOD as Secretaries.

abstract: ARREST OF SUNDAY LIQUOR DEALERS.--The following named persons were arrested on Sunday, upon the charge of selling liquors on that day, in violation of law: John Shiel, No. 159 Seventh-avenue;...
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF SUNDAY LIQUOR DEALERS.--The following named persons were arrested on Sunday, upon the charge of selling liquors on that day, in violation of law: John Shiel, No. 159 Seventh-avenue; John Battles, No. 44 Amity-street; Loutz Brannigan, No. 521 Sixth-avenue; Michael Regan, No. 1,385 Broadway; Frank A. Gould, No. 754 Broadway; Joseph Wills, No. 81 Fourth-avenue; Henry Murbeck, No. 4 Lawrence-street; and James Corcoran, No. 177 East Thirty-second-street. The above were all taken before Justice QUACKENBURGH and held to [???] in the sum of $100 each, to appear before the Grand Jury. In addition to these, twelve violators of the Sunday law were taken to the Tombs Police Court, and dealt with in a similar manner. At the Essex Market Court there were about a dozen parties committed for the same offence. The Police have very explicit instructions to deal with all parties who are caught in the act of violating the Sunday law.

abstract: From the descriptiongiven of the woman who drowned herself and child, by jumping overboard from the Jersey City ferry-boat Colden, on Wednesday last, there is no doubt but she was a Welch woman, named JANE MORGAN living in Williamsburgh, who had been on a visit to some friends living in Bright-street, Jersey City, where she remained three days. She started, as they supposed, to return home. Her husband deserted her a short time since and went West, which -- making her disconsolate, she being in destitute circumstances - no doubt led her to commit the act of self-destruction at the same time destroying her babe. The child was about nineteen months old.

abstract: The regular meeting of the Board of Councilmen was held yesterday. The Mayor returned without approval a resolution authorizing the Comptroller to purchase the lot No. 195 Elizabeth-street for an engine company. A Committee of Conference with the Board of Aldermen was appointed, with reference to the ordinance appropriating $500,000 for the relief of the families of volunteers. The Committee on National Affairs was instructed to prepare and present resolutions of condolence with the family or J. LA FAYETTE RIKER. Resolutions of thanks, as passed by the Board of Aldermen, to Archbishop HUGHES, were unanimously concurred in. A communication was received from the Mayor, with reference to the official reception of Gen. PRIM, which will be found in the official proceedings. It is the same communication which was received at the last meeting, then noted, but not acted on. The session was, with the above exceptions, devoted to routine business of no public interest.

abstract: -OPERATIONS INSOUTHWESTERN VIRGINIA. -- FREMONT has now reached Harrisonburgh, the furthest point up the Shenandoah Valley that was reached by Gen. BANKS; and Stonewall JACKSON has retreated as steadily before him as he did before BANKS, and a good deal more hastily. It seems utterly impossible to overtake that old rebel hypocrite and knave. He was within a few miles of Staunton last Saturday, and has probably reached that place by this time, and from there he most likely has taken the railroad to some point east of the Blue Ridge. Harrisonburgh, where our forces were last Saturday, is but twenty miles from Staunton. FREMONT was getting minor and indecisive fights out of JACKSON, and was expecting hourly that the latter would make a grand stand. Judging from his antecedents, however, it is unlikely that he will do anything of the sort.
