abstract: An official statement from the Treasury Department shows the Federal debt, on the 29th of May, to be $491,448,984. In this statement it appears by the Department books that one hundered and forty-six...
lead_paragraph: An official statement from the Treasury Department shows the Federal debt, on the 29th of May, to be $491,448,984. In this statement it appears by the Department books that one hundered and forty-six millions of Demand Notes are already out. A fair deduction insight with propriety have been made for "notes on hand," in the vaults of Sub-Treasurers, &c. -- say twenty millions.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a resolution was introduced by Mr. SUMNER and laid over, directing the Post-Office Committee to inquire into the expediency of providing for an air-line railroad between Washington and New-York. A bill to provide for an increase of medical officers in the volunteer service was introduced. The joint resolution relating to the imprisonment of soldiers in the Penitentiary of the District of Columbia was passed. The Senate, at 1 o'clock, resolved itself into a High Court of Impeachment, for the trial of Judge HUMPHREY's, of Tennessee, for treason, and the members of the House of Representatives were introduced in due form; but it was finally concluded to postpone the trial until the 26th inst., notice in the meantime being published in the papers of Washington and Nashville. The bill from the House to prohibit Slavery in the Territories, was passed, 28 to 10. The Pacific Railroad bill was ordered to be printed, with the amendments. The bill prescribing an additional oath for grand and petit jurors was passed. The Senate then went into Executive session, and on the opening of the doors adjourned.

abstract: Editorial on loss of Mississippi River possibly annihilating Confederacy
snippet: Editorial on loss of Mississippi River possibly annihilating Confederacy
lead_paragraph: If we were to concede all that the obstinate Secessionists assert, and all that their sympathizers of the British Press claim in their behalf, to wit: that "the South can never be subjugated," there are still certain conclusions reached in the progress of the Union arms, that destroy all hope of the "South" ever existing as an independent nation. One conclusion reached is, that the Mississippi River can never be closed against the free commerce of the Northwest. For a brief season it has been thus closed. A hostile local population for a while held that river from New-Orleans to the Belize, with a gunboat force of no contemptible number of bottoms and weight of metal. They held two of the best built forts on its banks that the abundant resources of the National Union constructed; and these defences were supported by an army more numerous and formidable than that with which Gen. JACKSON, 50 years ago, annihilated an attempted invasion of the British, under PAKENHAM. From New-Orleans to Cairo, equally formidable preparations were made to control the navigation of the river. Every bluff was crowned with earth works and columbiads, and islands became as floating batteries to command the approach from North to South. Vast armies garrisoned these positions, as at Columbus, Island No. 10, and Memphis. Looking at these facts from an English stand-point, and remembering the experience of the English in their essay upon the Mississippi River, it is, perhaps, not surprising that the English Government, and its allies here, regarded the dislodgment of such naval forces, batteries and armies, as impossible, especially when sustained by a unanimous local population, possessing resources, courage and will.
headline: {'main': 'The Southern Confederacy Annihilated by the Loss of the Mississippi River.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Southern Confederacy Annihilated by the Loss of the Mississippi River.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Yesterday afternoon the Presbyterian Church in One Hundred and Twenty-seventh-street was crowded with the friends of the late Col. RIKER, who were present to hear the funeral oration delivered...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon the Presbyterian Church in One Hundred and Twenty-seventh-street was crowded with the friends of the late Col. RIKER, who were present to hear the funeral oration delivered over the body. The members of Mechanic Hook and Ladder Company, of which deceased was an honorary member, were present. The time fixed for the funeral ceremonies was 3 o'clock, but long before that hour the small church was thronged to excess; indeed, so great was the number of the people present that the sidewalk in front of the building was impassable.

abstract: JEFF. DAVISlately put forth a pretty little programme, according to which the war is to last for the next twenty years; and our Government, anxious to accommodate him, has begun seasoning some new material against that protracted spell. General Order No. 59, just issued by the War Department, directs that a camp of instruction for fifty thousand men -- cavalry, artillery, and infantry, in due proportion -- is to be immediately formed near Annapolis, Md., under command of Maj.-Gen. WOOL. We presume this fifty thousand to be the new enlistment of that number of three years volunteers authorized by the War Department a month ago -- an altogether different affair, from the three months State militia lately summoned to the Capital. They will form a reserve corps d'armee, whence reinforcements will he drawn to fill up voids made by battle or disease, and thus the regiments in the field be kept at a plenum. The corps could not possibly be under better organizing hands than those of the veteran General who has just assumed command of the Department.

abstract: Ten days ago the rebels had two first-class armies in the field--one at Richmond, the other at Corinth. The work assigned to each was of about equal importance to the existence...
lead_paragraph: Ten days ago the rebels had two first-class armies in the field -- one at Richmond, the other at Corinth. The work assigned to each was of about equal importance to the existence of the so-called Southern Confederacy. One was to hold and defend the rebel Capital, and check the march of Gen. MCCLELLAN through Virginia; the other was to hold the Mississippi Valley and the Mississippi River, and bar the progress of Gen. HALLECK into the Cotton States of the Gulf. To defeat or disperse either of these armies was to change entirely the aspect of the campaign. If the army of the Southwest was defeated, the area of the Confederacy would be reduced to about one-fifth of its original size, and the number of States which the rebels controlled, even partially, would be reduced to four or five. If the army of Virginia was defeated, the whole of that State, inclusive of the rebel Capital, would fall into our hands; and if the military leaders chose to continue the war any longer, it would be seen by the world and by themselves to be a hopeless struggle for an impossible object.

abstract: A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening, Alderman VAN BRUNT in the chair. A communication was received from the Mayor, returning without his approval the resolution adopted on the 26th ult., declaring the contract made with HENRY W. PARSONS, for repairing the lamps in the Western District, null and vold, and directing the Board of Contracts to advertise for proposals for repairing the same until the 1st of June, 1863. The Mayor thinks to release a contractor simply because he secured an unremunerated job, would be setting a bad precedent. Also a resolution, adopted at the same meeting appointing a Committee of five to proceed to Albany to collect money from the State to refund the city for advances made, amounting to $75,000, to equip volunteers at the commencement of the war, and to distribute the same, when collected, to the wives, &c., of the volunteers in the field. The Mayor makes no objection to the object for which it is sought to appropriate the money, but he thinks that sending a Committee to proceed to Albany, would involve an unnecessary expense, and that it is a duty properly pertaining to the Comptroller, who, when the money has been appropriated by the State, can obtain the same at the expense of a few post-age-stamp; also the resolution deciding that the streets of the city shall be repaired by contract, and that proposals for each Ward be advertised for separately, such a method, in the opinion of the Mayor, would be impracticable, while to advertise for each district of the city separately would be perfectly practicable. The communication was laid on the table and ordered printed. The Corporation Counsellor communicated the following recent decisions at a General Term of the Supreme Court, affecting interests of the city: The case of the People ex rel. Thomas Hunt against the city, involving the regularity of the assessment for the Hamilton-avenue bridge, decided favorably to the city and the assessment affirmed. A warrant for the collection of the assessment should therefore be ordered to issue; the case of Curtis against the city, involving the regularity of a tax sale and the liability of the city to refund money received from the purchaser at such sale, has been decided favorably to the city, and the judgment below reversed. The case of SPOONER against the City, involving the right of the Common Council to discharge the Evening Star as one of the Corporation newspapers, has been decided favorably to the city, and the judgment of the City Court reversed. The suit of GERALD's executors against the city, to recover a balance of award for lands taken in the opening of Van Ruren-street, upon the ground of negligence on the part of the city in collecting the assessment, has also been decided favorably to the city, and the non-suit obtained in the trial in the City Court has been sustained on appeal. That portion of the Counsellor's communication referring to Gowanus Bridge was referred to the Assessment Committee and the balance to the Law Committee. The Special Committee, composed of the Eastern District Aldermen, to whom was referred the subject of an Armory for the Eastern District, reported in favor of purchasing the building at the corner of Fifth and South Fourth streets, known as the Odean. The report was adopted. A resolution was adopted declaring the Health Committee, with the Mayor, a Board of Health, and requesting that their services be at once resumed for the season.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Mr. ULLMAN is about to step into the ring of musical management once again. His career as an operatic manager has been extraordinary enough.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Mr. ULLMAN is about to step into the ring of musical management once again. His career as an operatic manager has been extraordinary enough. Here he has culminated, and there his pecuniary affairs have been in decadence. Now, he has made money, and immediately after he has failed to pay both his artists and outside employes. At one moment up, and at another moment down, he has been the veritable JACK in the box of musical speculators. If we are not mistaken, his last speculation was an unsuccessful one. Consequently, we should not be astonished if his present attempt was to make a veritable hit. In the first place, his prices are reduced to the same popular sum which we had opera for at Castle Garden many seasons since -- so many, indeed, that, being youthful, we prefer being excused from remembering the exact period. In the next place, be offers to us a plethora of attraction. There are two new prima donnas besides Miss KELLOGG and Mme. D'ANGRI -- the last of whom is, with the exception of ALBONI, the greatest contralto that has ever visited this country. These novelties are Madame COMTE BORCHAID and Madame HERMANN. The first of these was the leading soprano at New-Orleans, and we should judge, from her success when she song at Boston last year, and our personal knowledge of her vocalism, will prove a decidedly profitable engagement. Madame HERMANN, although announced to make her first appearance "upon any stage" in our Academy, is not altogether a novice to the operatic scenes. She has recently appeared at Cincinnati and other of our Western cities, and we argue from what we have heard of her, will confirm the reputation she acquired there. In addition we have BRIGNOLI, SUSINI, -- whose recent concert tour has not proved a success, demonstrating the fact that individuals may be very excellent vocalists and at the same time very unsuccessful musical managers -- with Signor AMODIO, the brother of the late baritone. Signor ABELLA is to be the conductor, and we understand that THEODORE THOMAS once more will assume the position of leader in the orchestra. But opera is not the only thing which Mr. ULLMANN offers to the public for the limited price he announces in his advertisement. He also gives us GOTTSCHALK. This alone ought to make the six operatic evenings which he announces for such a minimum admission indisputably attractive, inasmuch as the public have heretofore paid twice as much to hear GOTTSCHALK without opera. The last attraction is HERRMANN, the Prestidigitateur, who will prestidigitate at the conclusion of the opera. The sale of tickets commences to-day.

abstract: It is still mysterious  enough where the great bulk OF BEAUREGARD'S army can have gone. We suppose it must be allowed that he had at least a hundred thousand...
lead_paragraph: -- It is still mysterious enough where the great bulk OF BEAUREGARD'S army can have gone. We suppose it must be allowed that he had at least a hundred thousand men at Corinth. Now, suppose Gen. POPE captured ten thousand of these rebels; suppose ten thousand deserted and fled to their homes, or to the woods; suppose thirty thousand have gone to Richmond, (and, if any were sent there, the single circuitous line of railroad could hardly have carried more than that since the day Corinth was evacuated,) and there are still sixty thousand men of BEAUREGARD's army unaccounted for. It is unlikely that the regiments of Gen. PRICE's command disbanded, or that the men deserted; for the bulk of his troops belonged in Missouri, and it would have been impossible for any number of them to have retraced their steps in that direction, without our immediately knowing it. The troops of Gen. VAN DORN were mostly from Arkansas, and they could not have crossed the river to get to their homes. POLK's troops were from Louisiana and Mississippi; and those from Louisiana, at least, could not have got into their State without first taking the oath of allegiance. BRAGG's troops were from Alabama and Florida; HARDEE's mostly from Georgia, with a few from South Carolina; and, unless those from the latter-mentioned States have been sent eastward toward Virginia, it is hardly conceivable that any very great part of BEAUREGARD's army can have deserted. It is easy to talk about an army a hundred thousand strong breaking up, and the men flying in confusion everywhere; but rarely, if ever, in the military history of the world has an army broken up in such a way, and there is not a shadow of proof that the rebel army of the Southwest has done so. If such a host were disbanded in Mississippi at present the men would be fighting, if not feasting upon, each other before a week.

abstract: Why is the Herald so anxious to induce the rebel leaders, civil and military, to fly into Mexico? For months it has kept up the cry, with most suspicious iteration; and the nearer we come to cutting off all the avenues of flight in that direction, the more loudly does it call on them to make their way into Mexico, while means of escape is yet left. The Herald, no doubt, thinks this is all in the legitimate line of backing its friends; but does it really suppose that the motive of the advice is not also pretty plain? Loyal men have no desire that DAVIS, FLOYD, BEAUREGARD, COBB, and the rest of the traitor crew, shall escape into Mexico. We have quite another disposal to make of them much nearer home.

abstract: editorial on Ashby
snippet: editorial on Ashby
lead_paragraph: -- Gen. FREMONT telegraphs officially that the notorious rebel cavalry officer, Gen. ASHBY, was killed at the late fight near Harrisonburgh. ASHBY has figured very prominently during the whole war in the Shenandoah Valley, and in Gen. BANKS' campaign he was specially conspicuous. Every day, almost, we heard of a new skirmish with "ASHBY's Cavalry," and if half the number of his troop reported at different times to be killed were really and truly slain, he must either have had an immense force under him, or the continually thinned ranks of his regiment must have been very promptly recruited. Every day he was routed; twice a day his men scattered in confusion; and three or four times a day he and they again appeared in full feather. ASHBY's Cavalry formed JACKSON's rear guard in his various retreats; they constituted his advance guard in his different forward movements; they turned up on each flank, and they appeared everywhere. It is to be hoped that now that the force seems to he pretty well broken up, and its commander killed, we will hear no more of them or him. Exit ASHBY!

abstract: Gen. FREMONT has at last overtaken JACKSON and compelled him to fight. The battle took place on Sunday, the 8th, at a point about eight miles beyond Harrisonburgh, on the road to Port Republic.
lead_paragraph: Gen. FREMONT has at last overtaken JACKSON and compelled him to fight. The battle took place on Sunday, the 8th, at a point about eight miles beyond Harrisonburgh, on the road to Port Republic. JACKSON chose his position where his force was almost completely masked by dense woods, but he was driven out of it, our dispatches state, with heavy loss. We give elsewhere very full telegraphic details of the affair.

abstract: It may be permitted to assume that, with the destruction of the flotilla at Memphis, by Col. ELLET'S fleet of rams, the last batch of rebel floating things has been finally done for.
lead_paragraph: It may be permitted to assume that, with the destruction of the flotilla at Memphis, by Col. ELLET'S fleet of rams, the last batch of rebel floating things has been finally done for. If all the accounts we have received of Confederate fleets be true, we should certainly have to credit them with a naval activity perfectly unexampled. Some individual, of a statistical turn of mind, would do the State a service to sum up the gross total of the "eleven gunboats." "the seven rams," and the "thirteen iron-clads" that have figured at nearly every point we have gone to. Those rebel fleets seem to possess the elastic vitality of Odin's warriors in Valhalla, who, though slain outright every morning, returned each night to drink mead from the skulls of their enemies.

abstract: It will be seen, from a reportelsewhere, that the Pennsylvanians resident in this City will hold a mass meeting at the Astor House, on Friday evening. It is designed to form a permanent association for the care of sick, wounded and disabled Pennsylvania volunteers arriving at this port. Gov. CURTIN has given his sanction to the movement, and has promised to be present and address the meeting. It is to be hoped that all resident Pennsylvanians will attend, and lake their friends with them, so that the plan so ably carried out by the representatives of New-England may be emulated by the sons of the Keystone State.

abstract: The Summer conge which Lord LYONS is about to take out in the form of a three months' visit to England is not so purely a private matter but that we may see a certain public importance in the return, for a season,...
lead_paragraph: The Summer conge which Lord LYONS is about to take out in the form of a three months' visit to England is not so purely a private matter but that we may see a certain public importance in the return, for a season, to his own Government of one who has played so important a part in the international transactions in which the United States has been engaged the past year as has the British Minister Plenipotentiary to Washington. Lord LYONS, both from his position and his disposition, knows better, probably, than any individual whatever outside of the Administration the interior history of the rebellion and of the great crisis through which the United States has passed; and he can hardly fail to communicate information to the members of his own Government that will have an important influence if not on their action yet on their views respecting American affairs. With regard to the action of the British Government we have no occasion to complain: it assumed at the outset an attitude of neutrality, and it has honestly and unswervingly adhered to that neutrality. But we have not the same satisfaction with the views of the members of that Government touching our affairs. From the time that Earl RUSSELL, Her Majesty's Secretary for Foreign Affairs, formulated his theory of the American contest as a "struggle for empire on the one hand and for power on the other," down to the late strangely perverse, speech of the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Mr. GLADSTONE, -- the British official mind appears to have viewed the American war through a false medium or from an angle of vision that has persistently distorted the true relations of things.

abstract: Thomas Costello, Jr. vs. Philip McCaffrey. -- This action was brought to recover $700 alleged to have been loaned by the plaintiff to defendant. The defence set up that the money usually belonged to Thomas Costello, an uncle of the plaintiff, who having failed in business and being largely indebted to defendant, agreed to secure in debt on condition that the defendant would lean him his credit, and purchase his cattle at the Bull's Head market. The defendant also swore that the $700 was sent to him by Costello, through Thomas Costello, Jr., with request that he would use it in purchasing cattle. But defendant, as claimed, finding that by the new arrangement Costello was getting deeper and deeper in his debt, concluded to keep the money, and give Thomas Costello credit for it on the old account. The evidence was conflicting, and the Judge charged the jury that the simple question was, who told the truth, plaintiff or defendant.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Costello, Jr. vs. Philip McCaffrey. -- This action was brought to recover $700 alleged to have been loaned by the plaintiff to defendant. The defence set up that the money usually belonged to Thomas Costello, an uncle of the plaintiff, who having failed in business and being largely indebted to defendant, agreed to secure in debt on condition that the defendant would lean him his credit, and purchase his cattle at the Bull's Head market. The defendant also swore that the $700 was sent to him by Costello, through Thomas Costello, Jr., with request that he would use it in purchasing cattle. But defendant, as claimed, finding that by the new arrangement Costello was getting deeper and deeper in his debt, concluded to keep the money, and give Thomas Costello credit for it on the old account. The evidence was conflicting, and the Judge charged the jury that the simple question was, who told the truth, plaintiff or defendant.

snippet: Editorial speculates on summer campaign
lead_paragraph: Of the course the rebels will pursue, in any given case, there is but little indication furnished by what they say. The whole history of the war consists of a series of practical contradictions to-day of what the rebels had asserted yesterday. Did they build at any point a formidable series of fortifications, plant a prodigious army behind them, and then swear before heaven and earth that they would never leave these works while there was a live rebel left to defend them: -- the next thing generally heard was that they had fled to some other point, where the same Chinese motions would be gone through with. Did the rebels in any city proclaim, in terms of uncommon ferocity, that, rather than surrender, they would give the place to the flames and themselves to the sword: -- the usual corollary has been that our troops or gunboats would advance upon the city, and, after a little mouthing, it would surrender. So frequent have been the exhibitions of this kind of thing on the part of rebel armies, rebel States, rebel cities, and military and civil rebel functionaries of all sorts, that we have come to regard rebel bluster and bullying as something to be received only with contempt. In the beginning of the war, a prominent South Carolina official said that the whole Yankee character might be summed up in three words: "bluster and backdown;" but it would seem from the military history of the past year, that he was exactly describing the character of his own people.

abstract: In the Senate, yeasterday, the bill providing for an increase in the Volunteer Medical Department was reported from the Military Committee. A resolution was adopted asking the Secretary of War to inform the Senate whether any claims have been made by citizens of the United States for the destruction of property by the National Army, etc.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yeasterday, the bill providing for an increase in the Volunteer Medical Department was reported from the Military Committee. A resolution was adopted asking the Secretary of War to inform the Senate whether any claims have been made by citizens of the United States for the destruction of property by the National Army, etc. A bill providing for the purchase ofthe hospital known as the Douglas Hospital was referred. The bill donating lands for the benefit of Agricultural Colleges was passed after being amended so as to limit the number of acres to be taken from any one State to 1,000,000. A copy of the Treaty with Great Britain relating to the Slave-trade, with the accompanying correspondence, was received from the President, and referred to the Committee on Foreign Relations. A memorial from citizens of Utah, asking for admission to the Union as the State of Deseret, was presented, and referred to the Committee on Territories. A resolution was adopted instructing the Committee on Foreign Relations to inquire whether any further legislation is necessary for the proper control of the contingent expenses ofthe State Department. The bill making further appropriations for civil expenses for 1862-63 was passed, after being amended so as to include $7,500 for a Commission and Consul-General to Hayti, and $4,500 for like offices to Liberia. The bill amending the Fugitive Slave law was taken up, but pending its consideration the Senate adjourned.

abstract: LOOK OUT FOR MANTILLA THIEVES. MARY MURRAY was yesterday taken into custody upon the charge of having stolen a black silk mantilla, valued at fifty-five dollars, from the store of Mad. FLORA PINCHON, of No. 56 Bleecker-street.
lead_paragraph: LOOK OUT FOR MANTILLA THIEVES. -- MARY MURRAY was yesterday taken into custody upon the charge of having stolen a black silk mantilla, valued at fifty-five dollars, from the store of Mad. FLORA PINCHON, of No. 56 Bleecker-street. The accused attended the Cremorne Gardens on Monday night, and was caught with the mantilla upon her person. It was identified by several parties beside the proprietress. Justice KELLY held the prisoner to bail in the sum of $300. It is alleged that there is a large class of cloak and mantilla thieves, who have recently plied their trade with great success in the neighborhood of Canal and Bleecker streets. The Police have been informed in respect to their plans, and all shop-keepers, who have suffered on account of this gang, are requested to report their losses without delay, either to Police Headquarters, or to the Captains of the different Police Precincts.

abstract: US suppression of slave trade discussed in Parliament
snippet: US suppression of slave trade discussed in Parliament
lead_paragraph: In the House of Lords, on the 20th inst., Lord BROUGHAM rose to call the attention of the home Lord, the Secretary for Foreigh Affairs, to an apparent omission in the recent Convention with the United States. That Convention was in many respects the most important event that had occupied during the period of his sixty years' warfare against the American Slave-trade, in as much as [???] the right of search. Since the Slave-trade had been made a crime of great atrocity by an act which he had had the happiness of passing through Parliament fifty-one years since, nothing had happened that was more gratifying to him than the recent Convention, whereby the Northern States of America, to their great honor, yielded the right of search, without which the former laws were almost nullities. That concession would, he hoped, speedily put an end to the atrocious traffic. The right of search was conceded within so many leagues of the coast of Africa, and within 30 leagues of the coast of Cuba, but the Island of Porto Rico was more than thirty leagues distant from Cuba, and the consequence would be, if the right of search remained limited to a space of thirty leagues from the Cuban coast, that slavers would land their cargoes at Porto Rico, and send the slaves over to Cuban at their leisure. He must say that nothing could be more fair than the conduct of the American Government since the present unhappy disruption took place, and he would ask the noble Earl whether he thought in would be possible to arrange some modification of the Convention which should include Porto Rico within the limits of the right of search. He also wished to know whether the Government intended to take any action with respect to a vessel recently fitted out at Liverpool, and afterward captured with 600 slaves on board. He was informed that the brother of the Captain was ostensibly a shipping agent to Liverpool.

abstract: It is  now pretty evident that the Richmond authorities, in their sham negotiations for the re  lease of Col. CORCORAN, have been simply ex- permenting with the Government.
lead_paragraph: -- It is now pretty evident that the Richmond authorities, in their sham negotiations for the re lease of Col. CORCORAN, have been simply ex- permenting with the Government. They have annexed half a dozen different conditions for his release -- each of which has been acceded to at Washington, and each of which, when granted, they have perfidiously shuffled off. Their last condition was that the privateersmen should be given up. This was an exacting demand. These men, are, under our laws, pirates and felons and not a fair exchange for prisoners of war. Our Government was, however, exceedingly anxious to secure the liberation of the gallant soldier, strained a point of law and acceded to the demand. The privateersmen, accordingly, were sent up to City Point, where our flag of truce and accompanying officers waited some days, till finally it became evident that there was really no serious intention of releasing Col. CORCORAN, and they returned to Fortress Monroe.

abstract: The Committee of Pennsylvanians resident in this City, charged with the duty of forming a permanent organization for the relief of the sick and wounded Pennsylvania volunteers arriving at this port, met last evening at the Astor House.
lead_paragraph: The Committee of Pennsylvanians resident in this City, charged with the duty of forming a permanent organization for the relief of the sick and wounded Pennsylvania volunteers arriving at this port, met last evening at the Astor House. Mr. S.B.H. VANCE presided. Mr. S. NEWELL reported that Gov. CURTIN had been conferred with, and would aid the movement in every way. Committees were appointed to seek a location for the hospital, to report a plan for a permanent organization, to attend to correspondence, printing and other incidental business. The mass meeting will be held at the Astor House on Friday evening.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Opera, with a soprano new to the City, GOTTSCHALK, with some of his most attractive compositions for the piano, and HERRMANN, with his [???] to wind up the evening, all at one-half the lowest price for which we have ordinarily had opera alone, of late years, naturally produced last night one of the most crowded audiences we have lately had at the Academy. Indeed, the debut of Madame COMTE BORCHARD would alone have insured this result and as we have heard GOTTSCHALK play, and expressed out opinion respecting had many times previously in the most favorable of manners, while we have puzzled our brains [???] or prestidigitation of HERRMANN at least twice as often, we shall in the present case confine our remarks to the appearance of Madame BORCHARD and [???] "Lucretia Borgia" [???] has been, for some reason or other, so long since this opera has been given at the Academy, that we consider it an excellent choice for the first appearance of a new vocalist, while the company was not only as good as could be collected at present in the States, but was undeniably one of the best with which during the last few years we have had "Lucretia Borgia" given in New-York. Setting aside the debutante of the evening as Lucretia, we had the [???] of D'ANGRI, the finest we have ever heard on this side of the Atlantic. BRIGNOLI as Gennare, and the Duke by SUSINI, who although scarcely so fine in voice as he was on his first arrival here, is indisputably always an available artist. It is true that we have had these artists together before during the present season. Generally, however, they have appeared to operas requiring a larger operatic staff; consequently, their excellent was less positively felt. Signor [???] conducted the orchestra, which was led by [???].  , displays sentiment rather than [???] strongest and most [???] is remarkably appropriate [???] qualification in her school of singing, which is generally too much given to embroidery. In the second act, in the duet with her husband -- represented by SUSINI -- she displayed much energy in conjunction with her finish and precision of style. SUSINI was also in better voice than he has recently been, and both artists deserved more applause than they received from one of the most crowded, but certainly the coldest audiences we have had the pleasure of forming a part of during the last dozen of brief seasons. BRIGNOLI sang well -- possibly the character was a comparative novelty -- possibly he wished to demonstrate that the recent want of success he has proved as a concert manager had no effect upon him. The "Brindisi" of D'ANGRI was of course one of the principal points of the evening, and was actually warmly applauded into an encore. It would be needless for us to dwell at greater length upon the performance, save to say that the management had the common sense not to give too much GOTTSCHALK and HERRMANN, thus permitting it to leave the house before 11 1/2 o'clock.

abstract: -The British Parliament is to have another grand palaver over the American question before the close of the session. Sir L. PALK has given notice that he intends to introduce the subject, and our old friend LINDSAY has also given notice that he means to "inquire into the relations of England with the Federal, and also with the Confederate States of America." If they do not hurry up the matter, we fear that, so far as the "Confederate States of America" are concerned, it will be a post-mortem inquisition.

abstract: The revelation of Confederate Commissioner ROST, writing from Madrid to the Government at Richmond, is certainly one of the most valuable, as it is one of the most amusing, ...
lead_paragraph: The revelation of Confederate Commissioner ROST, writing from Madrid to the Government at Richmond, is certainly one of the most valuable, as it is one of the most amusing, developments of the diplomatic history of the rebellion. The valuable part of Mr. ROST's disclosure is the Spanish Minister's distinct conviction and assurance to him that the Emperor NAPOLEON "considered the disruption of the Union and of its rising navy as a great misfortune to France." The relations between the Governments of France and of Spain are believed to be of a most confidential character. And so clear and unreserved a declaration of the Emperor NAPOLEON's sentiments in regard to American affairs as the above, made by Mr. CALDERON COLLANTES, the Spanish Minister of Foreign Affairs, is entitled to serious attention. Standing alone, the fact might not have much weight. But when there is so much in French history and so much in French policy to make reasonable the Emperor's aspiration for the preservation of the American Union, so remarkable a speech as that of the Spanish Minister must receive credence. If there was in the mind of the Spanish Government a shadow of doubt as to the Emperor's views, the Minister would have given utterance to no such language; for the interview, as reported by Mr. ROST, gives evidence of the courtly kindness with which the rebel Commissioner was treated, and the manifest effort of the Spanish Minister to make his communications to Mr. ROST as agreeable as possible.

abstract: -THE ELEVENTH NEW-YORK MILITIA. -- A correspondent takes us to task for having recently held up a certain New-York regiment to "public contempt as cowards." In the first place, we did not do it. A telegraphic correspondent at Harper's Ferry reported some remarks of a General and his Aid-de-Camp who were in temporary service there, concerning one of the militia regiments which recently volunteered from this city. The General very unjustly, and evidently in a fit of passion, characterized the regiment as cowards, because it refused to submit to a violation of the contract made with it by the authorities; but we need not say that, as it is not forbidden us to differ with Generals, we did and do most heartily dissent from the opinion of this one, and utterly condemn the application of any such epithet to such a body of men as the Eleventh New-York Militia. It is a regiment of the best military material, of the very best mettle, and of the most self-devoted patriotism -- which is unnecessary to be said when we say it is a German regiment. The Government has had the offer of its services ever since the war began; and now that it has been accepted, there is little danger of its flinching at the calls of duty. The regiment, or its gallant Colonel, or its friends, need not be afraid that the imputation will rest upon it for one moment.

abstract: Gen. BURNSIDE has lately paid a back-door visit to Fortress Monroe by way of the intra-coast channel. We assume that the General's visit to headquarters, and his intercourse with the Washington authorities, had reference to an important movement imminent. BURNSIDE has not yet "cut the great artery" of rebel communication with the South. The time is at hand when the army of the rebellion now before Richmond will seek to make it escape over this line to the far South. Let BURNSIDE look after this bit of surgery, and if he needs any more tools for the operation, let them be furnished.

abstract: It is really amusing to see the effect upon the London Times of the capture of NewOrleans. The events of that desperate seafight seem to have thrown the Thunderer into ...
lead_paragraph: It is really amusing to see the effect upon the London Times of the capture of New-Orleans. The events of that desperate seafight seem to have thrown the Thunderer into a state of doubt and confusion quite remarkable to witness. But the same determination never to admit that any possible good could come out of our Nazareth; the same utter blindness to any valor or skill or determination on the part of our officers and soldiers is just as apparent as heretofore. Thus, for instance, it quotes that expression of one of our Commanders, that "it was a contest of iron hearts in wooden vessels, and iron-clad with iron beaks, and the iron hearts won;" of which it says that "this Commander goes so far as to declare, in his very pardonable exultation, that the victory was nothing less than a victory of wood over iron;" and it declares that if that statement "were an actual description of the affair, the story would be almost beyond comprehension or belief."

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Africa at Halifax, we receive advices from Europe two days later. She left Liverpool on the 31st ult., and Queenstown on the 1st inst.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship Africa at Halifax, we receive advices from Europe two days later. She left Liverpool on the 31st ult., and Queenstown on the 1st inst. The news is not specially important. Mr. LINDSAY, in the British House of Commons, had given notice that he should call attention to the relations of England with the Federal, and also the Confederate States of America, on the 27th of June. It is stated that the French army at Rome was about to be reduced to a single division. The session of the Spanish Cortes had been extended, on account of the Mexican question. It was understood that Gen. PRIM was to return home, and that Gen. SERRANO would go to Mexico as Ambassador. The Turks are reported to have gained a great victory in Montenegro. There are no later reports of the Liverpool cotton market than were received by the previous steamer. Breadstuffs were advancing, but Provisions continued dull. American securities were steady.

abstract: The United States vs. One Trunk Marked S. M., containing Pearls,  This was an action to forfeit the goods on account of an attempt to smuggle. The evidence for the prosecution was that of Cus-...
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. One Trunk Marked S. M., containing Pearls, &c. -- This was an action to forfeit the goods on account of an attempt to smuggle. The evidence for the prosecution was that of Custom-house Inspectors, who testified that they attended when the steamer Champion arrived from Aspinwall on May 14, 1862. One of the passengers was named Solomon Miguel. His baggage consisted of two trunks, a box, a case and a package. One of the Inspectors asked Miguel what his baggage contained, and he said, "Nothing but his clothes." The baggage was examined, and in the trunk was found pearls, laces, linens, silks, &c. The silks were found in the cover of the trunk; a package of pearls was found in the pocket of a pair of white pantaloons, and another in a shirt. The Inspector opened the pearls and asked what they were, and Miguel said they were nothing but some shells he had picked up on the shore, and were valueless. The lace was between the clothes. The goods were landed under the usual passenger's permit.

abstract: PRESENTATION TO COMMODORE PAULDING AT THE BROOKLYN NAVY-YARD A GOVERNMENT COMPLIMENT. A few days since Commodore H. PAULDING, now in command of the Navy-yard, Brooklyn, was ...
lead_paragraph: PRESENTATION TO COMMODORE PAULDING AT THE BROOKLYN NAVY-YARD -- A GOVERNMENT COMPLIMENT. -- A few days since Commodore H. PAULDING, now in command of the Navy-yard, Brooklyn, was the recipient of a compliment from the Government of Nicaragua, the equal of which has been but twice extended to the officers of our army or navy. The action of Commodore PAULDING, while in command of the Home Squadron, in arresting the proceedings of WALKER, the "Gray-eyed Man of Destiny," was severely commented on by papers in the influence of the filibusters, but was subsequently approved by the United States Congress, which allowed him, as a special favor, to receive the testimonial awarded by a grateful Government for the services he had rendered.

abstract: The rebels now threaten that they will burn Richmond. Well, against whom is it that this dreadful menace is directed? We suppose it must be considered a threat against themselves. A year ago they were threatening to burn New-York, to burn Boston, to burn Washington, and every Abolition city in the North. Now they propose to change tactics, and burn their own cities. They see that they cannot force our fingers into the fire, and they propose to stick their own fingers in. In this case, who will be burnt but themselves?

abstract: -- The House of Representatives on Tuesday last, on motion of Mr. CONKLING of this City, postponed the bill creating the office of Solicitor of Customs at this port until next December. We are inclined to look upon this postponement as being practically a killing of the bill. But whether it is or not, we are glad that Congress refused to pass it now. We should have been somewhat surprised if they had done so. The facts of the case tell so strongly against the bill, as our readers are well aware, for we have done what we could to make those facts public, that we can hardly believe that Congress could overlook them or pass the bill in face of them, and the report of the Committee which accompanied the bill was so full of blunders that it must have damaged the prospects of its passage more than it helped it. And so the bill is postponed, and for some months longer the ancient landmarks remain, and the law business of the United States in this District remains in the hands of the Attorney for the United States. We are thoroughly satisfied that this course is the best for the Government, and best for the citizens who are interested in revenue causes, and that the remedy for whatever causes of complaint may have existed and may have led to the action in this direction, is to be found in quite a different quarter.
lead_paragraph: -- The House of Representatives on Tuesday last, on motion of Mr. CONKLING of this City, postponed the bill creating the office of Solicitor of Customs at this port until next December. And so the bill is postponed, and for some months longer the ancient landmarks remain, and the law business of the United States in this District remains in the hands of the Attorney for the United States. abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. DIXON, of Connecticut, introduced a resolution, which was laid over, declaring that all acts or ordinances of secession are null and void, and that the relations of any State to the Union are not changed, whatever may be the forfeitures and penalties to which individuals may be subjected. A bill was introduced for the better government of the navy.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. DIXON, of Connecticut, introduced a resolution, which was laid over, declaring that all acts or ordinances of secession are null and void, and that the relations of any State to the Union are not changed, whatever may be the forfeitures and penalties to which individuals may be subjected. A bill was introduced for the better government of the navy. Papers and document were presented in support of the claim of Deseret to be admitted as a State. The bill in relation to the appointment of lieutenants in the marine corps was passed. The bill to establish Provisional Governments in rebellious States, in certain cases, was reported back from the Judiciary Committee, with a recommendation that it be passed. The bill to amend the Fugitive Slave law was postponed for the consideration of the Pacific Railroad bill, which was considered, and the amendments ordered to be printed. The bill providing for additional medical officers in the volunteer service was debated at considerable length and passed. The bill from the House for the relief of Gen. GRANT, giving him an allowance of $1,000 for a check for that amount lost several years ago, was debated until the Senate went into Executive Session.

abstract: Yesterday the great double-team trotting match for $1,000, mile heats and repeat, to wagon, came off on the Fashion Course, Long Island. The teams belong to two of our leading citizens, are well known...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday the great double-team trotting match for $1,000, mile heats and repeat, to wagon, came off on the Fashion Course, Long Island. The teams belong to two of our leading citizens, are well known on the road, and the match was to decide the question of their relative superiority of speed. The day was fine, but the track, owing to the heavy rains of the preceding day, was not in good condition for making fast time. The attendance was numerous and highly respectable, -- many of our leading merchants and civic functionaries being present.

abstract: Another battle has taken place in the Valley of the Shenandoah, in which the losses are heavy  this time between JACKSON's forces and the advance of Gen. SHIELDS' Division, which has been...
lead_paragraph: Another battle has taken place in the Valley of the Shenandoah, in which the losses are heavy -- this time between JACKSON's forces and the advance of Gen. SHIELDS' Division, which has been pushing on from Luray to the support of Gen. FREMONT. The advance, is appears, had reached the Port Republic Bridge, across the Shenandoah, on Sunday night, but neglected, for some reason, to destroy it, though the rebels were known to be in force on the other side. JACKSON made the attack on Monday morning, the day following the battle with Gen. FREMONT, and a desperate fight took place for the possession of the bridge -- our forces seeing, when too late, the importance of destroying it. The enemy came on in overwhelming numbers, and our advance was finally compelled to retreat, which it did in good order, until it reached the main body, when JACKSON again turned and continued his flight, burning the Port Republic bridge behind him. It will be seen by reference to a map, that Gen. FREMONT's army is on one side of the Shenandoah, and Gen. SHIELDS' on the other.

abstract: This great sporting event, the most important of any of the season, comes off on the Fashion Course this day. It is the first time that the principal of handicapping, or the art of equalizing the speed of...
lead_paragraph: This great sporting event, the most important of any of the season, comes off on the Fashion Course this day. It is the first time that the principal of handicapping, or the art of equalizing the speed of various horses by the apportionment of different amounts of weight to be carried in the race, has been applied to trotting. It will prove a must exciting affair, as the horses engaged are all of very high class Panie and Widow Machree, having shown the fastest trotting time in public, are each handicapped to carry a wagon and driver weighing 270 pounds; Gen. McClellan has to carry 250 pounds; Gen. Butler, 240 pounds, and West Philadelphia, 230 pounds.

abstract: Editorial sees eventual Confederate retreat to Atlantic cotton states
snippet: Editorial sees eventual Confederate retreat to Atlantic cotton states
lead_paragraph: There is an inconsistency in rebel military movements which, at first glance, is puzzling. Their army of Virginia, and their late army of the West, evidently were not governed by the same controlling considerations. Indeed, the inconsistency of their respective operations would seem to indicate that the rebel leaders have no policy, or that, if they have one, they are without the courage to maintain it at all points alike. Some weeks ago JEFF. DAVIS evidently was disposed to retire gracefully from Virginia for some more Southern field of defensive operations. The Confederate Congress, already struck with panic, made good its retreat before the rebel army had begun to retire. The Virginia rebels took alarm at this, and remonstrated fiercely against the retrograde movement, which they had clearly reason to anticipate. Their complaints, naturally enough, were tinged with the States' Rights heresy on which secession rests its foundation-stone, and it was broadly hinted that, if the war was to be carried to the Gulf States, and Virginia abandoned to the Union army, her sons would remain at home. They were willing to fight and starve on the "sacred soil;" but upon a transfer of the struggle to a new and more Southern field, they would have no part or lot in the matter. The "right of secession," destroying all unity in Government, was held to mean the right of the troops of each State to abandon the common cause whenever its management fails to suit individual State policy; and secession was in danger of destroying itself by a general mutiny in the rebel camp, if the Jeff, Davis policy of retiring to the Cotton States should be attempted.

abstract: The Brooklyn Navy-yard presents to-day an aspect of bustle and activity hardly surpassed, if it is equaled, by any naval depot in the world. On entering the premises the Marine Garrison, the Reservoir...
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn Navy-yard presents to-day an aspect of bustle and activity hardly surpassed, if it is equaled, by any naval depot in the world. On entering the premises the Marine Garrison, the Reservoir Building, the Naval Lyceum, the Roll-caller's Office, and the Drill Ground, are seen to swarm with human beings; piles of shot and shell, cannon of every shape and pattern, and gun-carriages of all conceivable designs, make the Ordnance Department look like the rendezvous of all naval artillery. The ship-houses and constructing departments, notwithstanding the "iron-clad" mania, are still well studded with hugh spars and other materials for wooden walls. Even the riggers find plenty of work to do, and the sailmakers have put more canvas through their hands within the last six months, than would make a vast awning for the whole Navy-yard. In the stream there is a perfect fleet of vessels, from the tiny yacht to the burly seventy-four. The following is a brief account of the chief men-of-war in the hands of the operators

abstract: Editorial on role of female secessionists in war
snippet: Editorial on role of female secessionists in war
lead_paragraph: -- The undue annoyance which the secesh demonstrations of the women and ladies of the Southern cities carries to the souls of our Union soldiers, really springs from one of the noblest characteristics of American civilization. With us the status of women is much higher than it is in any other country on the globe. If there is any question of the equality of the sexes, it is only because it is a part of every good American's creed that there is a divinity in women that places equality out of the question. It is possible that there is, if anything, an excess of deference and devotion to the sex, which is not without its social inconveniences and its compensatory disadvantages.

abstract: Those unfortunate beings known as rebel privateers are certainly entitled to the most profound commiseration, for they have dared and suffered more in the cause in which they embarked, and received less, by way of recompense, than any other of the agents whom the Confederate leaders have inveigled into supporting the rebellion. All of their craft which escaped the perils of shipwreck have long since fallen into the hands of National cruisers; prizes which they captured, with the exception of those given to the flames, have either reverted to their rightful owners or been sold for the benefit of the Confederate Government; and to add to their miseries, the crews which were taken prisoners fretted for weeks in the cells to which they were commuted, doubtful whether the halter would not speedily end their sufferings. All the interest which the rebel Government exhibited in their fate was to insist that they should be regarded as prisoners of war, and to force the National authorities to this concession, Cols. CORCORAN, WILCOX, and others, were held as hostages. That point was yielded; but meantime, the Confederate "navy" had been annihilated, nearly all the seaports had passed beyond the control of the rebels, they, had no farther use for seamen, and could not afford to waste the small capital which they had in National prisoners by exchanging them for those whose services they did not need; so these privateers, who had passed through such strange mutations of hope and fear, were heartlessly permitted to gaze upon the stricken fields of the South from the deck of their prison-ship in the James River, and then, as our dispatches this morning informs us, were sent back to Fortress Monroe, convinced that all expectations which they may have cherished of seeing their homes and families, were utterly groundless. Such treatment as this might make loyalists rebellious. In the bitterness of their hearts the privateers have doubtless already taken innumerable oaths; now let them take another, --the oath of allegiance, -- and become loyal citizens.

abstract: All evidence tends to prove the the defeat of JACKSON by Gen. FREMONT, on Sunday last, was a very severe one. JACKSON left his dead and a great part of his wounded on the field on his retreat the night after the battle.
lead_paragraph: All evidence tends to prove the the defeat of JACKSON by Gen. FREMONT, on Sunday last, was a very severe one. JACKSON left his dead and a great part of his wounded on the field on his retreat the night after the battle. Not less than five hundred dead were found, and two of their guns were left behind, which were taken possession of by our forces. Our army advanced early on Tuesday morning in line of battle, but finding no enemy, proceeded by column over the country to Port Republic, when the bridge was found to have been burnt by the rebels, as reported in yesterday's TIMES. Our reports from Gen. FREMONT's army are silent in reference to the fight between JACKSON and Gen. SHIELDS' advance, which indicates that nothing was known of it on the other side of the Shenandoah. Ere this the two armies have probably formed a junction, and are well on their way to Staunton, if they have not already reached there.

abstract: Col. ALBERT W. DRAKE of the Tenth Connecticut, cried at his home in South Windsor, Ct., on Thursday noon.
lead_paragraph: -- Col. ALBERT W. DRAKE of the Tenth Connecticut, cried at his home in South Windsor, Ct., on Thursday noon. He was a graduate of Yale College, and at the breaking out of the rebellion was practicing law in Hartford. He volunteered in Company A, (Rifles.) First Connecticut Volunteers, and was appointed First Lieutenant of the Company, in which office he exhibited all the qualities of a soldier and gentleman. On the return of the three months' volunteers his health was somewhat impaired, and the wishes of a widowed mother prevented him from immediately reenlisting. Subsequently he was able to accept the Lieutenant-Coloneley of the Tenth, and fought with it at Roanoke Island, where its Colonel, RUSSELL, was killed. He was promoted to the Coloneley, but his constitution could not stand the hardships which he was called upon to endure, and he was compelled to return home, hoping soon to be able to join his command, though his fellow-officers saw that he had settled consumption. His age was 27 years. In 1858 he represented South Windsor in the Legislature.

abstract: John W. Roof, the  plaintiff's assignee, was appointed a Deputy Collector of Assessments by Mr. Devlin, Street Commissioner.
lead_paragraph: John W. Roof, the plaintiff's assignee, was appointed a Deputy Collector of Assessments by Mr. Devlin, Street Commissioner. Roof qualified, but was prevented by injunction from entering upon his duties. Mr. Devlin's right to the office of Street Commissioner being contested, Roof presented himself to Mr. Taylor, Collector of Assessments, but was informed by that official that the duties of his office would continue to be performed by Mr. Libby, the incumbent, against whom no proceedings of ouster were instituted by Roof.

abstract: The address of Hon. OWEN LOVEJOY, before the Emancipation League, at Cooper Institute, last evening, attracted a most appreciative audience, who listened for two hours and a half to one of ...
lead_paragraph: The address of Hon. OWEN LOVEJOY, before the Emancipation League, at Cooper Institute, last evening, attracted a most appreciative audience, who listened for two hours and a half to one of the most original and effective speeches ever delivered on the subject. The speaker argued that the destruction of Slavery is essential to the perpetuity of the Union, and embellished his remarks with wit, humor and illustration, as well as argument and eloquence. He was most cordially received.

abstract: Our Quebec correspondent mentions that that city is full of rumors of the speedy arrival in Canada of a large body of troops from Great Britain; the only point in dispute being whether it is 24,000 or 40,000 that are to arrive. The Canadians are nothing, if not excitable. The canard probably arose from the fact that there are two or three little outstanding naval matters between the United States and England --  such as the Emily St. Pierre and Bermuda. Our friends across the line are making up their minds, in advance, that John Bull is going to try the game of bluff once again, and foresee a renewal of the Trent panic, reinforcements in Canada, &c. We think they are mistaken. We have faith that John Bull will act fair and square in regard to these matters. He could hardly afford to act unfairly on the strength of either 24,000 or 40,000 men.

abstract: Certainly the art  of capturing rebel cities reached ultimate simplicity in the negotiations that have been opened for the possession of Galveston.
lead_paragraph: Certainly the art of capturing rebel cities reached ultimate simplicity in the negotiations that have been opened for the possession of Galveston. In place of the vast armadas such as humbled Port Royal or New-Orleans, a single United States frigate quietly enters that far-off Texan port, drops anchor, and requests the surrender of the town. It is what the French would call a "purely moral demonstration," pointed, however, by the significant announcement that the Santee was but the avant courrier. "In a few days," said Capt. EAGLE, "the naval and land forces of the United States will appear off the town of Galveston to enforce its surrender." Do as you please; surrender now or surrender then, when it will be worse for you. In the meantime, twenty-four hours are given for reflection. The Southern rebels would not be what we so well know them to be if the first reply had not been a blustering message that they "would not give up on a mere paper bombardment." The next step was a delicate feeler adroitly put through their friends, the foreign Consuls, who wanted to know of the Captain if he would not "fix upon some point that might be respected in the bombardment, as a place of refuge for foreign subjects?" The Captain could not comply with the little request -- "impossible to tell what direction the shot and shell will take!"

abstract: Report on Congress proceedings; Bryant and Repr. O Lovejoy speak at Emancipation League meeting, Cooper Institute, NY

lead_paragraph: The announcement that OWEN LOVEJOY, of Illinois, would address the Emancipation League at Cooper Institute, last evening attracted an audience which a little more than half filled the room. The platform was crowded with citizens of note, among whom were PETER COOPER, EDGAR KETCHUM, Alderman DAYTON, Dr. HART and WM. CULLEN BRYANT. abstract: A very large crowd of interested persons both colored and white, yesterday collected in the delightful park adjoining the Colored Home, at the foot of Fifty-sixth-street, and at 2  o'clock exercises and ...
lead_paragraph: A very large crowd of interested persons both colored and white, yesterday collected in the delightful park adjoining the Colored Home, at the foot of Fifty-sixth-street, and at 2 1/2 o'clock exercises and reading of reports were commenced in the Chapel. Those who wished attended these exercises, which were very interesting. Scriptural reading, singing and prayer preceded the reading of the reports, which duty devolved upon Rev. Mr. McDonald. A collection was then made, which was followed by singing of good old hymns, the sentiments of which were congenial to the aged men and women, whose bent forms seemed to rise into new youth as they joined their feeble voices with these their friends, who come once a year to impart cheerful pleasures to their ever peaceful nome.

abstract: Editorial notes rise in immigration from Europe despite war
snippet: Editorial notes rise in immigration from Europe despite war
lead_paragraph: Immigration to this port from Europe is quite brisk at present. Within the last week over three thousand immigrants have been registered, and the total number for the year, so far, is in round numbers twenty-five thousand. Up to the same time last year the figures were about a third higher than this year; but, curiously enough, last year the immigration opened brisk in the early Spring, when Europe did not believe there was going to be war here, and fizzled out in Summer when a great war was inevitable; while this year immigration opened very dull in the Spring, when our military prospects looked comparatively dull, but since the news of our victories and of the prospective termination of the war have had time to react and influence Europe, it is going on quite briskly. When the war is over, it is believed we will see such a rush from Europe, and particularly from Germany, as was never seen before. The Germans, as well as other Europeans, have learned a great deal about our affairs and our institutions during the past year. They have learned of our civil freedom, notwithstanding the outcries of the tory Press; they have learned of the immense extent of our country and its limitless resources; they hare seen the prosperity of these Free States, even in time of a war almost without parallel for its magnitude -- a phenomena unknown in any other country since wars were fought. They have also begun, or soon will begin, to learn of the Homestead law, and the provisions for securing to every man -- not only life, liberty and the freedom to pursue happiness -- but also the means of gaining an independent livelihood. The common people of Europe do not suffer from the ignorant prejudices that affect the aristocratic and snobocratic classes. They do not rejoice over the collapse of democracy; they do not think any the less of this Government because it is fighting for unity, for the rights of the majority, and for its own existence.

abstract: A Sub-Committee of the Joint Fire Department Committee, consisting of Aldermen STRONG, BELKNAP and GREENE, yesterday visited, officially, all of the oil establishments in the Western District of the city, and to-day the same Committee will visit the similar establishments in the Eastern District. Nothing especially new or interesting was added to the stock of knowledge already obtained by the Committee by the investigation yesterday, except as to the extent of the petroleum oil business. The Committee visited the different places in the order as annexed. Mr. KETCHAM's establishment is on Smith-street, near Ninth-street. Here there are about five stills, of the capacity of about twenty barrels each, and kerosene, naptha and lubricating oils are manufactured. The works are of large capacity, but there is only a small stock at present on hand, and but little doing. The Empire Works, on Smith-street, adjoining the above, is a similar establishment, but no oil is being turned out here at present. There are five stills, and the buildings are large and airy. Proceeding to Red Hook Point, the Committee first visited the storage-sheds of SETH ROBBINS, on Van Brunt-street. Here are six open sheds, each 20 feet wide by 100 feet, in which are now stored between two and three thousand barrels of petroleum. There is a storage capacity here for about 20,000 barrels, but the yard is not kept in very good condition. STEARNS' yard, on Van Brunt-street, was next visited. Here are three large one-story well-ventilated brick buildings, each about 200 feet square, with a storage capacity of about 15,000 barrels. Between six and eight thousand barrels of petroleum and kerosene are now on storage. NEWCOMB's American Kerosene Oil Works, corner of Ferry and Sullivan streets, were next visited. Here are five stills, and kerosene, naptha and lubricating oils are manufactured. The stock is light at present, and no manufacturing is going on, except to till orders. At the Phenix Oil Sheds, foot of Sedgwick-street, the Committee found 3,000 barrels of kerosene on storage, and 15,000 barrels of pork in sheds one story high. Adjoining the above, is another range of storage sheds, occupied by SETH ROBBINS, in which are stored at present several hundred barrels of petroleum. The yard is in a filthy condition, and petroleum was found on the ground in puddles. The next and last place visited was the Shin-bone Stores, at the foot of Little-street, near the Navy-yard, and owned by Mr. RUGGLES, and the place complained of to the Common Council by the Commandant of the Navy-yard. These are brick storehouses, 30 feet high, and about 150 feet square, containing at present about 3,000 bales of hay, and a large quantity of staves. Directly on the opposite side of the street, and near the water, Mr. RUGGLES has two storage sheds, each 20 by 100 feet, in which are stored at present 200 barrels of petroleum. With the exception of the last place, the manufactories and store-sheds are in isolated positions, so that in case of fire no damage, under ordinary circumstances, would be likely to occur to property in the vicinity. And the only danger to be apprehended is from burning oil floating off upon the water, and communicating fire to the shipping and buildings along the docks in the vicinity. The Committee make a tour of inspection through the eastern section of the city, to-day; and to-morrow the Joint Committee will hold a meeting, receive a report from Mr. CHILTON, the chemist, as to the character of petroleum oil, compare notes, and, if possible, report to the Common Council, on Monday evening next, the result of their investigations.

abstract: It would certainly disappoint the country if it were to wake up some of these Summer mornings and discover that the rebel army at Richmond had quietly and adroitly retreated ...
lead_paragraph: It would certainly disappoint the country if it were to wake up some of these Summer mornings and discover that the rebel army at Richmond had quietly and adroitly retreated from that place, and moved off to some other previously prepared position in Southern or Southwestern Virginia, where our army would again have to repeat the tedious operation of advance and siege, which retreat might, perhaps, when it suited the rebels, be again followed by another and still another retrograde movement -- and each of them without any decisive result. The war in the Southwest, and throughout the Cotton States, is now so far advanced that the public expects the whole rebellion will be brought to a close by the capture or destruction of the rebel army at Richmond, without its being permitted to effect its escape to any point further South. It is known that something like this was the programme of Gen. MCCLELLAN when he first moved the National forces down to the Peninsula: by a series of military and naval movements to encircle and circumvent the rebel army at Yorktown, and bring the rebels and the rebellion to a speedy end on that narrow neck of land. That programme is, of course, now impossible. The rebels made good their retreat from Yorktown; they effected their retreat from Williamsburgh; and now, before the gates of their Capitol, though they vow that from there they never will retreat, there are not wanting indications that their leaders are already preparing for it. We have seen lately too many of the most solemn asseverations of the rebels falsified, to lay much practical stress upon any that they may now make. Where they may retreat to -- whether toward Lynchburgh, to the mountains of North or South Carolina, or to the States of the far South -- is a question of comparatively little moment. Wherever they may go -- if they succeed in going anywhere -- the fact will tend to prolong greatly the war, and to embarrass operations.

abstract: After a great deal ofplanning and experimenting, the Park Fountain in front of the City Hall was completed yesterday, and the water turned on, to the amazement of some and amusement of many gaping citizens. The fountain is in the centre of the basin, and consists of a white marble column about fifteen feet high, with three basins different sizes -- the largest at the bottom, the whole [???] with what very much resembles a pine apple around which two dolphins are entwined in a most ungraceful attitude, and from their mouths spirits the limpid Ridgewood into the upper basin, and from this it sweeps over to the second and from thence to the third basin, and so along down into the general reservoir. Above all extend an iron pipe -- which revolves by the force of the water -- and from this extend several smaller pipes, from which the water is squirted in every conceivable direction. Surrounding the base are four large marble vases filled with [???] pond lillies, from the petals of which proceed jets of water toward the centre column. The structure itself is a pretty one, but the jets are not well arranged.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a resolution to admit to the floor gentlemen claiming to be Senators from Deseret was laid over. A resolution presented by Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, to turn over ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a resolution to admit to the floor gentlemen claiming to be Senators from Deseret was laid over. A resolution presented by Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, to turn over Gen. BUCKNER to the civil authorities for trial for treason, was debated at considerable length, but was finally postponed until to-day. During the debate the course of the rebel authorities with reference to Col. CORCORAN was canvassed. A resolution was adopted calling upon the Secretary of State to inform the Senate what amount of money has been paid to Maine and Massachusetts for yielding to the Ashburton Treaty, and what has been done with the money stipulated to be paid for certain lands by Great Britain. The House bill for the relief of Gen. GRANT was passed. The Pacific Railroad bill was taken up, and Mr. LATHAN, of California, made a speech in favor of its passage. The debate was continued until the Senate went into Executive session.

abstract: The army circles in this vicinity were thrown into commotion yesterday by the receipt of a private telegraphic dispatch announcing the temporary suspension of the Adjutant-General of the army, LO- ...
lead_paragraph: The army circles in this vicinity were thrown into commotion yesterday by the receipt of a private telegraphic dispatch announcing the temporary suspension of the Adjutant-General of the army, LORENZO THOMAS. He is said to have been the means, intentional or otherwise, of furnishing the enemy with important information. It is not asserted that he did so directly; but that some female members of his family wormed valuable secrets out of him, and made them known to the rebels. The immediate cause of his suspension, however, arises from his having dismissed some officers in Gen. HALLECK's command without the authority of the President. For this a Court of inquiry is now in session, investigating the charges against him. Gen. THOMAS is a native of Delaware, and entered the service, after graduating at West Point, on the 1st of July 1823, as a [???] in the Fourth (old) Regiment of [???]. He was on duty with Gen. SCOTT, in [???] this City, before the rebellion [???] out.

abstract: The first regular United States mail from New-Orleans for the post fourteen months arrived in this City last night. The mail was quite a heavy one letters from our soldiers ...
lead_paragraph: The first regular United States mail from New-Orleans for the post fourteen months arrived in this City last night. The mail was quite a heavy one -- letters from our soldiers to their Northern relatives, letters from citizens to friends from whom they have long been cut off, letters on business and on the subject of renewing commercial relations, beside newspaper files in abundance. For over a year the great commercial city of the South has been isolated from the world -- excepting what little intercourse it was able to keep up through privateers, through vessels running the blockade, and by way of Texas and Mexico. The tens of thousands of letters and newspapers that used to be conveyed weekly from that city to this, and back again from this City to that, ceased coming and going when the blockade was declared. During all that time, also, the foreign commerce of New-Orleans has had no existence, and its inland traffic has been almost extinct. The hundreds of steamboats that from there traversed the Upper Mississippi, the Missouri, the Tennessee, the Ohio and the Cumberland -- as well as the hundreds of ships that carried the products of the Mississippi Valley to the world, were all transferred to more profitable waters, or were laid up; and the formerly crowded harbor of the Crescent City has been desolate. Now that the Southern Metropolis is again under the old flag of its prosperity -- now that ships are again beginning to go in and produce to come out -- now that the prospect is bright for an immediate resumption of internal commerce with all the cities on the banks of all the tributaries of the Mississippi -- now that there is intercommunication of thought with the city and the world -- we hope soon to see New-Orleans arise from its ashes and become again, what it was of old, the Queen City of the South.

abstract: Editorial on evolution and importance of African Negro in US
snippet: Editorial on evolution and importance of African Negro in US
lead_paragraph: Of all topics now engaging the thoughts of gods and men, the American negro is unquestionably the chief. From the lowest place in the scale of human existence, he has reached the highest; and even yet the interest in him seems unabated. To what new honors he is reserved -- to what remarkable career he is predestined -- it would be a rash prophet that would attempt to foretell. But the evidences are abundant that he is the central figure of the nations -- the unit of existence around which "the rest of mankind" parade themselves as mere cyphers.

abstract: -- It is hardly necessary to direct attention to the important and interesting chapter of Mexican matters contained in our correspondence from the City of Mexico and Vera Cruz, and the accompanying translations of documentary pieces published elsewhere. The whole world now sees the wrong of the French invasion, and it is the general belief that the Emperor, when he receives intelligence of late events, will order his forces to withdraw and throw SALIGNY overboard. Yet, should he determine to prossecute the invasion and send further forces, such a feeling will be aroused in Mexico, and so much determination will be manifested, that the Mexicans, now that they know their own strength and have confidence in their capacity to cope with the French soldiers, will render the affair infinitely more difficult of settlement than NAPOLEON had conceived. Our advices are to a much later date than anything that has yet been published.
