BUTTERFIELD'S Staff, who was taken prisoner at Hanover Court-house and afterwards paroled, furnishes the following partial list of the National prisoners, wounded, now in hospital in Richmond. All the well prisoners are sent to Salisbury, N.C. Lieut. PERKINS states that the rebel authorities seem disposed to treat the wounded prisoners with attention, but their medical staff is insufficient, to care for their own wounded and sick. He also speaks in the highest terms of Dr. MARSHALL, of the Sharpshooters, who was taken prisoner at the same time with himself. He worked day and night incessantly, renovating the hospital and making quite a change for the better in all the arrangements for the care of the sick and wounded. The following is the list referred to:

abstract: The first orders of the authorities now paramount in Memphis, will be found in our columns to-day; and we trust and believe the good sense of our people will render clear to them the wisdom of ...
lead_paragraph: The first orders of the authorities now paramount in Memphis, will be found in our columns to-day; and we trust and believe the good sense of our people will render clear to them the wisdom of obedience to a power they are unable to resist. The fortune of war, in placing the city of Memphis in the power of the Federal Government has been kind in this, in placing us under the immediate control of officers of that Government whose political opinions, if we may judge by their past record, are not of the fanatical order, and whom the polish of education and natural inclination have rendered urbane, polite and kindly in disposition.

abstract: For the second time, a first appearance in Italian opera came off on the present season. It was a veritable debut, inasmuch as Mme. HERRMANN has not previously made her appearance in a regular opera, although we understand she has occasionally sung in public during her husband's recent tour in the States. The opera selected for the occasion was DONIZETTI's "Figlia del Reggimento," and Mme. HERRMANN, of course, took the part of Maria. She is a petite person, with a charming face and a winning style of acting, which struck us as being unusual in one so new to the footlights. Her voice has a compass of about two octaves, and is a light mezzo soprano -- French in its class. It is, however, remarkably sympathetic, and would, but for the nervousness she very evidently displayed, at once have made her a favorite. In the Duo with Tonio in the first act, she sang very agreeably, although we cannot but object to Tonio's style of conduct towards a new soprano on her first appearance on the stage of the Academy. If he had been so treated when he first appeared by an established soprano, we very seriously question whether the operatic world would have ever been blessed by the knowledge of a BRIGNOLI. On the other hand, we have to compliment SUSINI on the natural kindness his displayed, which makes us the more pleased to record the fact that he was in excellent voice, and sang even better than he has done on the two preceding nights of the season. In the second act Madame HERRMANN acted the part admirably, and sung the music with a nerve and spirit which confirmed the agreeable impression she had already produced, displaying great archness in the "Music Lesson." In the "Ricci Valse," which she sung at the finale of the opera, she more than confirmed our opinon of her merils, and demoustrated the fact that she possessed infinitely more power then we had at first imagined.

abstract: Mr. HAYS, the animal painter, has on his easel, nearly completed, a picture six feet by three, "Stampede of the Bisons," intended as a pendant for his ...
lead_paragraph: Mr. HAYS, the animal painter, has on his easel, nearly completed, a picture six feet by three, "Stampede of the Bisons," intended as a pendant for his "Herd on the Move," which was on exhibition at a studio reception during the past Winter. The scene of the latter picture was laid in the valley of the Upper Missouri, where the bison is still found in his best estate, and where it is not uncommon to see herds from fifty to one hundred miles in length, and covering a breadth as far as the eye can reach. Headed by the sturdiest and most valiant bull, the heard moves slowly, ponderously, feeding over the illimitable prairies or rich bottom lands of the rivers.

abstract: Gen. SHEPLEY, the Military Commandant and Acting Mayor of this city, summoned the bakers to appear before him this morning. This was owing to the numerous complaints made to him by poor people, who were compelled to pay to some bakers at least double the tariff price fixed by the city ordinance. The interview with the bakers was a highly interesting one. He told them, one and all, that while he held his present position, not only the starving poor, but every other class should be protected from imposition; that any baker who hereafter violated the ordinance regulating the weight and price of bread, he would punish to the extent of taking possession of his establishment and the stock of flour on hand, working it with bakers from the army, and distributing the bread gratuitously to the starving poor. Before closing the interview, Gen. SHEPLEY told the bakers that he was as desirous of protecting their interests as those of the consumers; that he did not make the ordinance regulating the price and weight of a loaf of bread; that if the ordinance was unfair or unjust, he would take great pleasure in laying before the Council a remonstrance from them, with the view of having it amended or repealed; but so long as it was the law, he would hold every one to its strict obedience. This explanation seemed to satisfy the bakers, and they all departed in much better spirits than when they entered the Mayor's office. -- Delta.

abstract: Henry M. McLuvid vs. Andreu Whitlock el al  This action was brought to test the validity of a sale of a livery stable, in Brooklyn, by the defendants Ryers  Wilton, to the defendant, Whitlock, alleged ...
lead_paragraph: Henry M. McInvid vs. Andreu Whitlock el al This action was brought to test the validity of a sale of a livery stable, in Brooklyn, by the defendants Ryers Wilton, to the defendant, Whitlock, alleged to have been made with intent to hinder delay and defraud the creditors of Byers & Wilton. It was claimed, on the trial, that the properly transferred was worth about $3,000 but that it was sold to Whitlock for $1,050. It was alleged that Whitlock had a mortgage on the property for $700, and, learning that Byers & Wilton were involved and unable to pay the mortgage, by threats induced Byers to sell him his interest in the property for a small consideration, and induced Wilton to sign a bill of sale of his interest in it, with a secret understanding that Wilton should continue a partner, in such a manner that his creditors should suppose he had no interest remaining.

abstract: BOLD AND EXTENSIVE ROBBERY. -- A bold robbery was perpetrated Thursday morning at the store of R.B. KASHOW, NO. 58 Montgomery-street, Jersey City. A young man named JULES MOGON, who had been employed there for the past six weeks, decamped with a large number of watches and articles of jewelry amounting in value to nearly 2,000. Soon after the opening of the store he went as usual to the safe to get out his work, when being unobserved he extracted the articles mentioned and left. The police got upon his track shortly after, but as yet he has escaped their vigilance. Most of the watches stolen belonged to parties who had left them at the store for repairs.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill appropriating $150,000 for new Post routes was passed. A bill to carry into effect the treaty recently negotiated with Great Britain relating to the Slave-trade was reported from the Committee on Foreign Relations. The House bill prescribing an oath of office,  c., was debated, but not acted upon.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill appropriating $150,000 for new Post routes was passed. A bill to carry into effect the treaty recently negotiated with Great Britain relating to the Slave-trade was reported from the Committee on Foreign Relations. The House bill prescribing an oath of office, c., was debated, but not acted upon. The Naval Appropriation bill was considered, and a number of amendments were adopted. A long debate occurred regarding the location of the Naval Academy, which resulted in an understanding that the permanent place for it will be at Annapolis. The bill was not disposed of when the Senate adjourned for want of a quorum.

abstract: -- It is one of the many pleasing forms of John Bull's multiform insular conceit to fancy that his pure and calm reason is in striking contrast with what the London Times lately called the "febrile and fickle" disposition of the Americans. May be so; but, oddly enough, we have lately had an example of a British flurry that strongly belies the claim. It will be remembered what a panic the tidings of the combat between our iron-clads in Hampton Roads, together with our reduction of the Southern forts, produced in England. The walls of all the fortifications in Great Britain forthwith tumbled down, as did those of Jericho before the blast of the rams' horns. The subject was taken into Parliament, and occasioned an excited debate in which it was universally agreed that fixed defences were henceforth useless against floating batteries; wild propositions for "a hundred Monitors" were made, and the work on the fortifications at Spithead was put a stop to as worthless. John Bull, in fact, was precipitated into a regular panic, and COBDEN may find in this episode matter for another chapter to his late brochure on the "Three Naval Panics of England." A couple of months' reflection, however, has somewhat toned down the excitement. The Commissioners on National Defences have been incubating the matter, and have come to the conclusion that they were altogether too hasty. It's their opinion that the "expense of providing for the defence of Spithead by ships alone would far exceed that of forts and ships combined." Hence the work on the fortifications at Spithead is to be resumed, and thus our cool and imperturbable Britons tacitly confess they were quite carried off their feet by these American maritime experiments. Now it is a little curious that these things did not at all disturb our balance. We also had fortifications and harbor defences in process of construction -- but we did not delay work for a day; for, though we saw the vast importance of iron-clads, it was also understood perfectly well that stationary fortifications would continue to be an important and indispensable element in a complete system of defences. After this fortification flurry, our British friends would do well to say no more about the "febrile and fickle" Americans.
lead_paragraph: -- It is one of the many pleasing forms of John Bull's multiform insular conceit to fancy that his pure and calm reason is in striking contrast with what the London Times lately called the "febrile and fickle" disposition of the Americans. May be so; but, oddly enough, we have lately had an example of a British flurry that strongly belies the claim. It will be remembered what a panic the tidings of the combat between our iron-clads in Hampton Roads, together with our reduction of the Southern forts, produced in England. The walls of all the fortifications in Great Britain forthwith tumbled down, as did those of Jericho before the blast of the rams' horns. The subject was taken into Parliament, and occasioned an excited debate in which it was universally agreed that fixed defences were henceforth useless against floating batteries; wild propositions for "a hundred Monitors" were made, and the work on the fortifications at Spithead was put a stop to as worthless. John Bull, in fact, was precipitated into a regular panic, and COBDEN may find in this episode matter for another chapter to his late brochure on the "Three Naval Panics of England." A couple of months' reflection, however, has somewhat toned down the excitement. The Commissioners on National Defences have been incubating the matter, and have come to the conclusion that they were altogether too hasty. It's their opinion that the "expense of providing for the defence of Spithead by ships alone would far exceed that of forts and ships combined." Hence the work on the fortifications at Spithead is to be resumed, and thus our cool and imperturbable Britons tacitly confess they were quite carried off their feet by these American maritime experiments. Now it is a little curious that these things did not at all disturb our balance. We also had fortifications and harbor defences in process of construction -- but we did not delay work for a day; for, though we saw the vast importance of iron-clads, it was also understood perfectly well that stationary fortifications would continue to be an important and indispensable element in a complete system of defences. After this fortification flurry, our British friends would do well to say no more about the "febrile and fickle" Americans.

abstract: About 3  o'clock yesterday afternoon, Mr. PETER C. REAL, of No. 256 Broadway, was shot by a woman named MARY STEWART, alias Mrs. Mary Real, with a pistol, and almost instantly killed.
lead_paragraph: About 3 1/2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, Mr. PETER C. REAL, of No. 256 Broadway, was shot by a woman named MARY STEWART, alias Mrs. Mary Real, with a pistol, and almost instantly killed. The affair occurredjust outside of Mr. REAL's place of business, upon the landing of the second flight of stairs. The particulars of the murder, so far as we have been able to gather them, amid the great excitement cousequent upon the affray, which existed in and around the premises, are as follows: For a long time past, Mr. REAL, the deceased, has been paying his addresses to MARY. She and her friends allege that they were married several months ago. He, and those who know him best, on the contrary, assert that such is not the fact, but insist that there was never any intimacy exiting between them, except a brief and in every respect honorable courtship, which was finally terminated by the mutual consent of the parties. The friends of the deceased allege that a short time since she approached him with a dagger which she had secreted about her person, and with which she attempted to stab him to the heart, and would have done so but for the timely interference of some friends. The difficulty between them, it seems, grew more and more serious, until yesterday afternoon, when the woman stated to several of her friends that affairs between herself and REAL had become so grievous that she could no longer bear up under the great grief and misery which he had brought upon her. Fired with the passions of disappointed love, jealousy, and revenge, she went to a gunshop on Broadway, between 1 and 2 o'clock in the afternoon, bought a pistol, had it loaded by a friend, and, thus armed, she repaired to the store of the deceased, situated on third floor of No. 256 Broadway. She found him lying upon a sofa in a room where, at the time of her entrance, there were several other persons. A some what lengthy interview took place between them, which terminated in loud and angry words upon both sides. At last he was induced to go with her outside the glass door, to the landing at the top of the stairs. Immediately thereafter, a scuffle ensued on the stairs, and the report of a pistol brought several persons who were in the vicinity to the scene of the conflict. After the shot was fired the wounded man was at once aided by the woman, and one or two others, to get back to the sofa in the store, where he expired in about ten minutes afterward. The only words he uttered were, "I'm killed -- I'm dead." The woman, MARY, was at once taken into custody by a Policeman, and conveyed to the Fifth Precinct Station-house, where she was confined in a close cell to await the result of the Coroner's inquest. Deputy Coroner Dr. ROBINSON last evening made a post-mortem examination of the body of deceased, of which the following is the result:

abstract: Dispatches from Washington; Editorial on current and future effects of Civil War on real estate, especially in NYC; Editorial on present and future effects of war on real estate, especially in NYC
snippet: Dispatches from Washington; Editorial on current and future effects of Civil War on real estate, especially in NYC; Editorial on present and future effects of war on real estate, especially in NYC
lead_paragraph: The superabundance of money, in the open market, at the cheap rate of four or five per cent, per annum, has already made itself felt upon the prices of all dividend securities in Wall-street, and the current excitement among buyers at the ordinary figures has scarcely been exceeded since the speculative times of 1852-'53, when the progress of our railway system rapidly stimulated the entire stock market. The present extent of the advance in dividend share and first mortgage values is equal, on the average, to fifteen per cent. on the prevailing rates in February last, when the financial policy of the Government was defined by the establishment of the National currency. That the improvement will not stop at this point seems quite clear, from the course of affairs in Wall-street for a day or two past. Of course there will be a stopping point, as well as a point of diversion for the surplus means or capital of the country centering in New-York into other than stock channels. Under such prospects, the course of real estate in this City, whether in vacant lots or improved property, becomes a question of immediate interest.

abstract: According to the revelations of Mr. Roving Commissioner ROST, the Emperor NAPOLEON considers the "rising navy of the United States as a great misfortune to France." The official communication which Mr. WELLES has handed in to Congress will hardly tend to allay his uneasiness. The Secretary of the Navy, who is not of that type of mind that forgets nothing and learns nothing, fully and frankly accepts the revolution that has taken place in naval warfare; henceforth vessels for fighting purposes must be heavily plated with iron, if they are not built entirely of that material. It is for Congress to decide, says Secretary WELLES, whether the Government will promptly take the initiatory steps "to place our country in the front rank of maritime Powers."

abstract: Editorial on reported Confederate offer of purse for assassination of Union Gen. Butler
snippet: Editorial on reported Confederate offer of purse for assassination of Union Gen. Butler
lead_paragraph: having failed in the great field operations of war -- having failed almost totally in their efforts at guerrilla warfare -- are now publicly advocating secret assassination as a last resort in their struggle for Slavery and independence. The open combat on the field of battle between the chivalry and mudsill, which the chivalry sometime so hotly panted for -- the assault on the highway, by the skulking chivalry, upon the wayfarer or quiet settler -- both these are now to give way to the stiletto, the cup of poison, or the bloody razor, in the hands of the chivalry. They have been for some time advertising their purposes in this matter, and singling out persons for the stab in the dark. The individual whom the chivalry are at present stimulating each other to assassinate, is Gen. BEN. BUTLER, of New-Orleans. A proposition has been made in a journal published at the Capital of Mississippi, the organ of the State Government, that a purse of $10,000 (probably Confederate shinplasters) "be made up and offered for the head of the modern Nero -- the brutal, beastly and sanguinary savage, Gen. B.F. BUTLER -- or to any one who will take his life by any means whatsoever;" and, not tired of piling on epithets, the would-be rebel thug goes on to say that "it is our plain duty to rid our country and the world of this horrid, hideous monster, by any means that can be commanded." The Charleston Mercury, in writing of the same General, urges: "let no quarter to BUTLER be the sworn resolve of every Southern man;" and adds, "if he venture not upon the field of battle, (by the way, he has met the chivalry there once or twice already,) let poison or the knife do its secret but deadly work." If the rebels do really mean to immolate Gen. BUTLER, or any of the other persons whom they name in that connection, they certainly have a curious way of going about it. They advertise the fact in all the papers, proclaim it to the prospective victim and to the whole world; and, what is noticeable, the urgent parties do not, in any case, propose to do the deed themselves, but wildly implore some one else to do it in their behoof. Political assassinations arc usually concocted and done secretly, and by persons, who, themselves, have smarted under wrongs until they became unendurable. But the rebels, in this, as other matters, have quite an original mode of procedure. We do not believe that the thing will be done. It will all end in threatening, as so many other rebel heroics have ended.

abstract: The Court of Inquiry convened, yesterday, at the Office of Capt. RADFORD, at the Brooklyn Navyyard, to investigate the circumstances under which ...
lead_paragraph: The Court of Inquiry convened, yesterday, at the Office of Capt. RADFORD, at the Brooklyn Navyyard, to investigate the circumstances under which the Emily St. Pierre was taken from Prize Master (Acting Master United States Navy) STONE, who is held to await the action of the Court. The officers of the Court are Commander RAFFORD and Lieut. FLAG, of the Receiving ship North Carolina. There are also four of the Emily's crew attending the Court. They say that the disaster to the price was caused by the crew put on board not having been provided with arms. It is not thought that a Court-martial will be deemed necessary. The chief facts elected from the witnesses examined yesterday do not differ materially from the statements already published. The recall of the Court of Inquiry will be made known to the Navy Department immediated on its adjournment.

abstract: Where is Gov. HARRIS, of Tennessee? Has he lied beyond the State he rules? Has he at last taken refuge at Jackson, in Mississippi, to which so many other fugitive Governors have lately wended their steps? When he fled from Nashville, hatless and on horseback, he said that he was only leaving his capital temporarily -- in otherwords, that his flight was a great strategic move, after the rebel style of tactics. But from Memphis he never could be driven, by all the hordes of Lincolndom. We should like to know if he did flee from it before the noise of our rams' horns, or whether he is, incognito, skulking around some of the groggeries, or in some of the negro shanties, or under some of the beds of that town. Let the new Provost-Marshal examine closely. HARRIS would be worth catching.

abstract: By the arrival at this port of the steamer British Queen, we have received our Mexican and Havana correspondence, containing details of the recent important events in Mexico, including the battle of Amazoc, near Puebla, in which the French were defeated and forced to retreat to Orizaba. Gens. [???] and BERRIOZABEL commanded the Mexican troops in this affair. Two battalions of French Zouaves skirmishing as light infantry began the attack. These covered two strong colums of infantry supported by rifled cannon. The Mexicans waited till their enemies were within 50 yards, and then fired. The French fled whilst the Mexicans charged; but other French columns renewed the attack, and a second time they fled, leaving a number of dead who were shot in the back. Again the Mexicans charged, and had they had cavalry would have destroyed the invading army. The French did not renew the attack on the front, but sent a strong column against the fortifications of Guadalupe. They were here also repulsed, and a reinforcement of Mexicans coming up, an attack was made on their right flank. The French at once fell back upon Orizaba. Their loss is estimated by a friendly authority at 600 or 800 soldiers in the fight and by sickness. Another fight subsequently took place near Orizaba, between the Reactionists, supported by the French, and the Liberal forces, the result of which is claimed by both sides as a victory. It may, therefore, be regarded as a drawn battle. The French forces, it is understood, were to remain at Orizaba until they could receive instructions from their Government. Meantime, JUAREZ is making every effort to fortify the approaches to the Capital, and expresses the determination to defend it to the last.

Their loss is estimated by a friendly authority at 600 or 800 soldiers in the fight and by sickness. Another fight subsequently took place near Orizaba, between the Reactionists, supported by the French, and the Liberal forces, the result of which is claimed by both sides as a victory. It may, therefore, be regarded as a drawn battle. The French forces, it is understood, were to remain at Orizaba until they could receive instructions from their Government. Meantime, JUAREZ is making every effort to fortify the approaches to the Capital, and expresses the determination to defend it to the last.

abstract: -- Mr. EDWARD C. HERRICK, for many years Librarian of Yale College, died at New-Haven, Conn., on June 11. Mr. HERRICK was the son of Rev. CLAUDIUS HERRICK, of New-Haven, and was born in the year 1811. After receiving a thorough preliminary education, he engaged in mercantile pursuits in New-Haven, and in 1843 was elected Librarian of the College, and, until 1852 continued to discharge the duties of that position as well as those of Treasurer. Mr. D.C. GILMAN, in 1852, relieved him of the librarianship, and since that time Mr. HERRICK has given himself up entirely to the responsibilities of the treasurership. Although his multifarious duties pressed upon him heavily, and completely engrossed his attention during business hours, he found time to make extensive acquisitions in nearly every department of natural science. In entomology, practical astronomy, history and bibliography, he was thoroughly and accurately versed, as the numerous communications on all these subjects, which have been published from time to time in the American Journal of Science, prove. His loss to the institution with which he has been connected for twenty years, will be irreparable.

abstract: The ship Colombo. Capt. STEWART, arrived yesterday from Port Royal, bringing advices to the 7th inst. She has a cargo of cotton, and brings sixty-five passengers. She has no news of importance, except that intelligence has been received at that place that the National gunboats had taken possession of Stone Creek, and capture all the batteries on it and the Union troops were within four miles of Charleston. Capt. STEWART reports that on the 8th inst., when off Charleston, he heard very heavy firing on the direction of that city.

abstract: ANOTHER CHILD FOUND DROWNED. -- The body of a male child, apparently about eighteen months old, was picked up in the bay, by a powder-boat, on Saturday morning, and brought into the canal dock, Jersey City. It being evident that death was caused by drowning, Coroner GARNEY deemed an inquest unnecessary, and ordered it buried. This is the second child of about the same age found drowned in [???] bay below Jersey City, within the last three days.

abstract: The Senate only was in session yesterday, the House having adjourned over from Friday until Monday. A message was received from the President, transmitting to the Senate a memorial in behalf of the State of New-York, in favor of the enlargement of certain canals and locks. The bill from the House, providing that officers and volunteers shall be paid according to the pay-rolls, was passed. A bill for increasing the revenue, by the reservation and sale of town sites on the public lands, was introduced and referred. The Naval Appropriation bill was further debated, and finally reported to the Senate, and laid aside informally. The Senate soon afterward went into Executive Session, and, when the doors were again opened, adjourned.

abstract: Maria M.C. Wetmore vs. Daniel Holsman, Charles Frederic Wetmore and Katharine Holsman Wetmore, an Infant. This action was brought by the plaintiff, a young married lady, to be...
lead_paragraph: Maria M.C. Wetmore vs. Daniel Holsman, Charles Frederic Wetmore and Katharine Holsman Wetmore, an Infant. -- This action was brought by the plaintiff, a young married lady, to be relieved from the operation of a trust deed executed by her while an infant to the defendant. Daniel Holsman, (her brother,) and one William H. Kissam, who was also her guardian, in contemplation of marriage with the defendant C.F. Wetmore. The instrument in question conveyed to the trustees all the estate, real and personal, of Maria M.C. Holsman, (now Mrs. Wetmore,) in trust, to receive and pay over the rents and profits to her during her lifetime, and after her death to her husband, if he should survive her, for the term of his life. After the death of both parties, the estate was to go to the plaintiff's lineal descendants, if she left any; otherwise it was to go as she should devise it. There was also an authority given the trustees to borrow money for the purpose of improving the property, if done with Mrs. Wetmore's concurrence. The circumstances of the execution of the trust deed, as gathered from the pleadings, and the testimony of the plaintiff herself, were as follows:

lead_paragraph: CITY MORTALITY. During the week ending yesterday there were 82deaths in this city, males, 45; females, 37. The diseases were as follows: Congestive fever, lockjaw, pleurisy, unknown, spine, apoplexy, typhoid fever, croup, measles, scrofula, diarrhoea, and puerpera, one each. Cancer, paralysis, dysentery, dropsy, premature death, disease of the heart, whooping cough, diphtheria -- 2 each. Drowned, hydrocephalus, and disease of the kidneys -- 3 each; scarlet fever, 4; marasmus and debility, 5 each; inflammation of the lungs, congestion of the brain, congestion of the lungs, consumption, 6 each, convulsions, 7; still-born, 5. Forty-two of those who died were 5 years old and under.

abstract: Mr. YANCEY, after safely evading all the perils to which he has of late months been subjected by sea and land, now rests his uneasy and traitorous head at Montgomery, Alabama, as we learn from some correspondence...
lead_paragraph: Mr. YANCEY, after safely evading all the perils to which he has of late months been subjected by sea and land, now rests his uneasy and traitorous head at Montgomery, Alabama, as we learn from some correspondence which has recently passed between him and certain inhabitants of that place. Six of his Montogomery fellow-citizens, it seems, bought and presented to Mr. YANCEY a black horse, fifteen hands and two inches high, eight years old, cost four hundred and fifty dollars -- which black horse, in the highly metaphorical minds of its donators, "is supposed to represent, in some faint degree, those high moral attributes which have adorned your (YANCEY's) character as the leader of the great movement for Southern independence." Mr. YANCEY accepts the horse with gratitude; and to the categorical statement of the beast's height, age and cost, made by those whe presented it, Mr. YANCEY poetically adds, that it "has the eye of the hawk, the spirit of the king eagle, the chest of the Iion, is swifter than the roebuck and stronger than the buffalo," and must consequently be a horse altogether without a peer, and quite worth the $450 (we should like to know if the money was Confederate shinplasters) which it cost. As the letter accompanying the charger was dated on the 19th of May, and Mr. YANCEY's reply thereto was dated the next day, the 20th, it looks from the minute description of the animal's qualities and characteristics given by Mr. YANCEY, that it had hardly come into his possession before he committed the grievous fault of "looking his gift horse in the mouth."
headline: {'main': 'Mr. Yancy on a Black Horse.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Mr. Yancy on a Black Horse.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: IMPORTANT ARRESTS A NEW SYSTEM OF THIEVING. For several weeks past, the various Express Companies of this City, and also numerous private parties in the upper Wards, have been extensively victimized by a trio of thieves who rode about in a butcher's cart.
lead_paragraph: IMPORTANT ARRESTS -- A NEW SYSTEM OF THIEVING. -- For several weeks past, the various Express Companies of this City, and also numerous private parties in the upper Wards, have been extensively victimized by a trio of thieves who rode about in a butcher's cart. Their plan was to follow up the Express wagons, as they went their rounds through the City, for the purpose of delivering parcels, and when the messenger left the wagon, one of the thieves would hastily seize a bundle therefrom, toss it into his cart, and drive rapidly off with his plunder and confederates before the Express messenger had time to discover his loss. The several Express Companies have, they say, been defrauded of a large amount of property, by means of this system. On this account, they have been compelled to employ an extra man to each wagon, for the purpose of guarding the packages left in the vehicle. This was something the thieves were quite unprepared for, and they were necessarily compelled to change their tactics. In many instances, since the expressmen have taken this precaution, the thieves have entered private residences immediately after the departure of the real messenger, and under pretence of having left the wrong bundle, 'hey have claimed and carried away the property. When too late, the owners discovered that the packages were surrendered to thieves. Several policemen in the up-town wards made ineffectual attempts to arrest these swindlers, and at last the matter was placed in the hands of Officer IRVING, of the Twentieth Precinct, who for several days has been upon their track. Early on Friday evening, the three culprits were seen in their butcher's cart, on the corner of Thirty-third-street and Eighth-avenue by Officer IRVING, who cautiously approached them, and jumping into the vehicle, seized two of the occupants and held them fast. The third one speedily ran away, but was soon caught by Policemen ANDERSON and HOPKINS. They were all taken before Justice QUACKENBUSH, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, where after an examination they were held to await the action of the Grand Jury. The names of the accused are WASHINGTON SMITH, JOHN DRUMGOLD and JOHN SHERIDAN.

abstract: Editorial on report Union soldiers counterfeited Confederate money while prisoners in Tuscaloosa, Ala
snippet: Editorial on report Union soldiers counterfeited Confederate money while prisoners in Tuscaloosa, Ala
lead_paragraph: We always look with suspicion upon any statement, from rebel sources, of any misconduct on the part of our soldiers in the regions of rebeldom. But we regret to have come across one well-authenticated case of such misconduct, which has been narrated by the perpetrators of it, and which we cannot therefore doubt. It seems that some of our soldiers, having been taken prisoners and carried to Tuscaloosa, Alabama, were guilty, while there, of the heinous offence of counterfeiting, and not only that, but counterfeiting Confederate shinplasters; and the guilty man who narrated the fact actually told it with a grin, and said that "the boys" made about $300 in this way, and that the money which they manufactured went off better than the genuine article. We can readily believe this latter fact. If any ordinarily cute Yankee could not make a better looking article than the wretched shinplasters of which we have seen specimens, he would not be worthy of the name.
headline: {'main': 'Counterfeiting Bad Money.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Counterfeiting Bad Money.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Editorial on favorable condition of US securities and European reaction; Editorial on favorable condition of US securities and on European reactions
snippet: Editorial on favorable condition of US securities and European reaction; Editorial on favorable condition of US securities and on European reactions
lead_paragraph: Many people beside Mr. ADDISON have observed that a man who is furnished with arguments from the mint, will convince his antagonist much sooner than one who draws them from reason and philosophy. The popular prejudice runs with the axiom that figures cannot lie; and with the other, that money, like water, will find its level. We have long been satisfied that, in our domestic quarrel, we have both reason and philosophy on our side; but the invidious world is, after all, most forcibly impressed by the golden rhetoric we are so fortunate as to be able to furnish. While convinced, therefore, that our cause is essentially a noble and just one, and that in its success are involved the highest interests of liberty and of progress, we need not despise the persuasive logic of a heavy purse, which kind Providence and our own industry happily allow us to display.

abstract: editorials on bill
snippet: editorials on bill
lead_paragraph: It looks as though the same soil on which the bloody drama of civil war was opened, eighteen months ago, was also destined to witness its final act. The intense, interest with which the public formerly looked toward South Carolina, has for a long time been fixed upon other regions where stupendous operations have been going on; hut there is now again a prospect of action in Charleston Harbor, and in the vicinity of Fort Sumter, and public attention is eagerly turned in that direction. The recent reconnoissance as far as Pocotaligo, in the southeastern part of the State -- the naval reconnoissance up to and beyond Georgetown on the northeastern coast of the State, and the movements of our land and naval forces at James Island, in the immediate vicinity of Charleston, seem to indicate that Gen. HUNTER is preparing for decisive work. The point aimed at appears to be Charleston, and the other movements may be only to distract the enemy's attention. If Gen. HUNTER is able to approach the city in the direction he is now pursuing, be will thus avoid all the forts and other formidable rebel defences in Charleston harbor. At latest accounts he had advanced on the island, till he approached almost within rifled cannon shot of Gov. PICKENS' head -- that is to say, if that "insensible-to-fear" functionary still resides at the executive mansion in which he took up his residence for the war. Whether Gen. HUNTER really means to take the city or not, we do not know. We think it doubtful whether he has troops enough to hold it. We believe that there is quite a large rebel military force in and around Charleston. The rebels know the anxiety with which the nation looks for the capture of Charleston; they know the preparations HUNTER is making for its capture; they have had ample time to concentrate all available troops there; and Charleston we believe to be one of the few rebel cities the possession of which will be fiercely contested. The fact that they have been so quiet about what troops they have there, is a hint not without significance. If our gunboats could get up to the city, it would be easily enough held and controlled; but they would first have to pass Forts Sumter, Moultrie, Pinckney, long lines of land batteries, and other defences. We hardly think that this will be attempted until one or more of our iron-clad vessels can be sent down to operate in that quarter. But Gen. HUNTER is bold and daring; and may very likely take the country and the rebels by surprise by some movement that will place the city and all its defenders entirely at his mercy.

abstract: Blackwood's Magazine, for June, contains a letter addressed to Capt. COLES, R.N., by a gentleman at Baltimore. Capt. COLES lately addresed a letter to the London Times, in which he...
lead_paragraph: Blackwood's Magazine, for June, contains a letter addressed to Capt. COLES, R.N., by a gentleman at Baltimore. Capt. COLES lately addresed a letter to the London Times, in which he spoke of his "mortification at finding that America, instead of England, should have the palm of floating the Monitor, which is to dictate the reconstruction of navies to the world." The Baltimore correspondent of the eminent Captain thereupon consoles him with an attempt to prove that the mortification should be ours, as we were hoaxed in the matter by Capt. ERICSSON. The proof given is, that Blackwood, for December, 1860, in an article on iron-clad ships, contained three diagrams of Capt. COLES' "shield," with a broadside view of a shield-frigate; and it is taken for granted that Capt. ERICSSON must have seen these diagrams, and thereupon conceived the idea of the Monitor. Why, asks the writer, (forgetting that the same question might just as fairly be put to Capt. COLES,) why did not Capt. ERICSSON build his Monitor years ago, seeing that he claims to have put his plans before the Emperor of the French in 1855? Neither Capt. COLES nor Blackwood has had the fairness to show why the former, whose invention is said also to date from 1855, has not yet constructed a cupola ship. It does not seem to have occurred to either that the question of originality may be decided in much the same manner as a writer in the June number of the United Service Magazine speaks of the invention of the "ram," and the rival claims of Sir GEORGE SARTORIOUS and Mr. NASMYTH.

abstract: The steamer Fulton, having on board sick and wounded soldiers, arrived here yesterday afternoon, from Fortress Monroe. The New-York and Pennsylvania men were conveyed to the Park Barracks...
lead_paragraph: The steamer Fulton, having on board sick and wounded soldiers, arrived here yesterday afternoon, from Fortress Monroe. The New-York and Pennsylvania men were conveyed to the Park Barracks those belonging to the New-England and Western States were taken to the New-England Association Rooms, No. 194 Broadway; while the worst cases were kept on board the ship, and will be taken to the hospital on David's Island to-day. abstract: At 10 o'clock yesterday morning, Coroner COLLIN commenced the inquest in the case of PETER C. REAL, who was murdered at No. 256 Broadway, on Friday afternoon, by his alleged wife, a pretty full account of which we published in yesterday's TIMES.
lead_paragraph: At 10 o'clock yesterday morning, Coroner COLLIN commenced the inquest in the case of PETER C. REAL, who was murdered at No. 256 Broadway, on Friday afternoon, by his alleged wife, a pretty full account of which we published in yesterday's TIMES. The first witness examined was WILBUR F. BROWN, who testified that he resided at No. 36 Bedford-street, and was an employe at the store No. 256 Broadway, where the murder was committed. That at about twenty minutes past 3 o'clock on Friday afternoon, a lady, (here the witness identified the prisoner as the person referred to,) entered the store, and engaged in conversation with Mr. REAL. They stood and talked about five minutes, when the deceased took his hat and coat, and went out of the door. He saw a motion made by the deceased, as if to grasp the prisoner, just outside of the door, at the head of the stairs. The door was a glass one, but it was closed. Witness then lost sight of the parties, and supposed they had gone down stairs. Soon after he saw a flash and heard the report of a pistol; the prisoner and the deceased then came to the door together, and with the aid of two other persons the deceased was helped to a sofa in the room, where he died in a few minutes after; witness saw the prisoner on Friday morning, at nine o'clock, at the store, and he heard the deceased speak of the prisoner, but not as his wife; the deceased also stated to witness that he had met a lady on the cars in New-Jersey that morning, and was with her when he was accosted by the prisoner, who suggested to the lady that he, Real, was her lawful husband. The lady with whom the deceased was walking was Miss Van Name, daughter of Mr. Van Name, of No. 214 Broadway, under Barnum's Museum.

abstract: -- Mr. VINCENT COLYER, Superintendent of the Poor of Newbern, N.C., sails in the steamer for Beaufort to-day. Mr. COLYER is very desirous of establishing his schools for the neglected while children in every city or town of any importance which may be occupied by our troops. His school in Newbern has already over fifty children, and is in most successful operation. The cost of maintaining such schools is as nothing compared with the good that is effected. Any of our citizens who approve of this mission can send their subscriptions to Mr. FRANK W. BALLARD, No. 2 [???] Wallstreet, New-York, by whom they will be duly acknowledged. Gen. BURNSIDE is a subscriber to the amount of $50.

abstract: PRIVATE WATCHMAN DANGEROUSLY STABBED -- ARREST OF THE OFFENDERS. -- About 2 o'clock yesterday morning a serious affray occurred in William-street, during which a private watchman named ISADORE -- alias Izzy -- FELLEMAN, was dangerously, and is believed fatally, stabbed. The statements as to the origin of the difficulty are conflicting, and in the present stage of the affair, is quite impossible to ascertain the precise facts. The version which is given by the wounded man and Police Officer DONNELLY is, that the two were [???] their beats between Pearl and Duane streets, in William-street, when they discovered a cellar door open. The policeman called to [???] for matches, in order to procure a light, to [???] them to see to fasten the door. The [???] had to matches, but proposed to go into [???] in the neighborhood, and obtain some. [???] accordingly went to a place Kept by EDWARD ULRICK, in the basement of No. [???] William-street. FELLEMAN States that as, [???] as [???] entered the saloon he was fiercely [???] by [???] Germans, named PHILIP DENNIG, THOMAS LEPENCHE and ULRICK, the proprietor, who beat [???] and during the scufile he was stabbed with a knife in the hands of one of his [???], but [???] of the three inflicted the wounds with the [???] is unable to say. He received several [???] in the [???] and three or four upon other [???] his person. Those in the abdomen are very serious. The three were immediately taken into custody by officers DONNELLY and MOORE, and yesterday they were brought before Justice OSBORN, at the Tombs, and [???] to await the result of FELLEMAN's injuries. The latter was conveyed to the New-York [???], where he now lies in a critical condition. The statement made by the prisoners before the Justice was, that FELLEMAN began the assault on them, that he used very [???] and insulting language to them, and batted has [???] violently against DENNIG's breast before anything was done by them. They further say that the whole affray happened on the sidewalk, and not in the saloon, as asserted by FELLEMAS. They deny having stabbed him, and insist that whatever they did do was done strictly in self-defence.

abstract: DANIEL SHAY, a lad 14 years of age, was yesterday captured for having robbed his uncle, TIMOTHY SHAY, of No. 38 Trinity-place, of the sum of $72. Officer RODE, of the Twenty-seventh Precinct, caught the young offender with $63 of the stolen money in his possession, which was fully identified by and restored to the owner. He made a full confession of his guilt.

abstract: PATRICK HOGAN was arrested yesterday charged with picking the pocket of Mr. WM. W. RUNYON, a gentleman who is at present a guest at Lovejoy's Hotel. RUNYON was looking at some soldiers in the Park when he, felt something pulling at his vest pocket, and at once discovered HOGAN with his $50 gold watch in his hand, just ready for an escape. An alarm was given and a Second Precinct officer took the offer der into custody, Justice OSBORN committed him in default of $500 bail.
lead_paragraph: PATRICK HOGAN was arrested yesterday charged with picking the pocket of Mr. WM. W. RUNYON, a gentleman who is at present a guest at Lovejoy's Hotel. abstract: Argument in favor of the passage of a Pacific Railroad bill, by Congress, is out of place at this late day. The country long ago settled down in the conviction that the measure ought to be and must be adopted.
lead_paragraph: Argument in favor of the passage of a Pacific Railroad bill, by Congress, is out of place at this late day. The country long ago settled down in the conviction that the measure ought to be and must be adopted. It may be doubted whether any other proposition agitating political circles during the last twenty years, commands to-day the unanimity of support which, in all the loyal States, is accorded to the project of binding the Atlantic and the Pacific together with a band of railroad iron. The only difference of opinion has grown out of the conflict of competing routes, or applies to the details of means for carrying the great enterprise into effect.
headline: {'main': 'Who Block the Pacific Railroad?', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Who Block the Pacific Railroad?', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Advices from Europe, a week later, are received by the arrival off Cape Race of the steamships Bavaria, from Southampton on the 4th, and China, from Liverpool on the 8th inst.
lead_paragraph: Advices from Europe, a week later, are received by the arrival off Cape Race of the steamships Bavaria, from Southampton on the 4th, and China, from Liverpool on the 8th inst. There is little political news of importance. Cotton had advanced 1/8d.@1/4d. in the Liverpool market. Breadstuffs were again dull, and Provisions were tending downward.

abstract: This evening VERDI'S "Trovatore" will be produced at the Academy for the first time during the present season -- or rather the present and last dozen, more or less, of seasons. It will give Mme.BORCHARD the opportunity of appearing in the part of Leonora, which, we understand, is one of her greatest characters. It also gives us a new debutant in the person of Signor AMODIO, brother of the late baritone, whose role as the Count di Luna he will undertake. The memory of his brother will insure him a kind reception, but may possibly prove injurious to his chance of making a positive success. Let us hope that he will overcome the prejudicial fact to himself, as a vocalist, that his brother was a public favorite. Madame D'ANGRI will fill the part of Azucena, and BRIGNOLI will, in all probability, not allow Signor SERIGLIA a chance to make a second appearance as Manrico. To-morrow evening Miss KELLOGG, Madame D'ANGRI, BRIGNOLI, SUSINE BARILI and Signor AMODIO will appear in the "Linda di Chamounix," also given for the first time in 1861-'62. It may be noticed that upon his second appearance Signor AMODIO again appears in one of his brother's finest parts Madame HERRMANN will also make her third appearance, in a scene from " L'Elisir D'Amore." This is positively announced as the last night of the season, (!) but it may be observed that a Grand Gala Night is underlined for Wednesday next. This is to be the benefit of Mr. ULLMANN, and will, we understand, offer us any possible amount of opera, from all sorts of operas, in a musical olla podrida, varied by slices of GOTTSCHALK and HERRMANN. However,as we have previously mentioned, the "star" upon this night will be HERRMANN, who proposes demonstrating the manner of working his ring trick for Mr. ULLMANN'S special advantage, as well as that of those who are curiously inclined toward the magic art. If it benefits the former to a corresponding extent with the profit it has produced to the prestidgitateur, we confess that we shall: consider him a lucky man.

abstract: The Senate only was in session on Sunday, the House having adjourned over from Friday until Monday. A message was received from the President, transmitting to the Senate a memorial in behalf of the State of New-York, in favor of the enlargement of certain canals and locks. The bill from the House, providing that officers and volunteers shall be paid according to the pay-rolls, was passed. A bill for increasing the revenue, by the reservation and sale of town sites on the public lands, was introduced and referred. The Naval Appropriation bill was further debated, and finally reported to the Senate, and laid aside informally. The Senate soon afterward went into Executive Session, and, when the doors were again opened, adjourned.
lead_paragraph: The Senate only was in session on Sunday, the House having adjourned over from Friday until Monday. abstract: Editorial on public debt; Editorial on national currency; Editorial on public debt and national currency
snippet: Editorial on public debt; Editorial on national currency; Editorial on public debt and national currency
lead_paragraph: The actual cost of the war, as recently shown by the official exhibit of the progress of the public debt, agreeably surprised many of the most influential friends of the Government, who had indulged the vague rumors of much larger figures, while it disappointed the factious opponents of the Administration in Congress who had industriously given these rumors currency. The success of the Nationalcirculation, of lawful tender, established in February, as a valuable auxiliary to the management of the Public Debt and the conduct of the Treasury, has also afforded the highest satisfaction to the country, besides already vindicating the practical good judgment of its advocates in Congress and the skill with which it has thus far been employed by Secretary CHASE. The wonderful financial success of the Government in respect to both these important subjects, under the present administration of the Department of the Treasury, will undoubtedly afford its distinguished head a ready and powerful influence in both Houses of Congress in favor of any amendment or extension of the policy and measures established by the Acts of July 17 and February 25, including an increase of the National Circulation and Treasury deposits authorized by the last-named Act.

abstract: We publish elsewhere an abstract, asextended as the heavy pressure on our columns will allow, of the very interesting and important Memorial of Mr. S.B. RUGGLES to the President, on the subject of adapting our State canals to the purpose of national defence. The document was transmitted by Mr. LINCOLN to Congress on Saturday, asking for the subject the consideration its "obvious and unquestionable importance" demands -- a consideration which the "large amount of valuable statistical information collected and presented in the Memorial" will greatly facilitate. Mr. RUGGLES' main effort in this elaborate paper is to nationalize our canals, historically, statistically and naturally; and to show the fundamental importance of our agricultural inferior States as the "granary of the Union," furnishing the certain means of export with which to buy duty-paying imports in return. It shows conclusively -- 1. That if necessary we can fight John Bull on the Lakes; 2. That at any rate we can and will feed him. Coming from Mr. RUGGLES, we need not say that this paper is distinguished by all that breadth of treatment and consummate skill in dealing with and vitalizing large masses of statistical details, that so eminently characterize his mind. Its arguments, suggestions and revelations cannot fail to excite the liveliest interest both in Great Britain and the Canadas as well as here at home. We trust Congress will make time to give the subject the attention its great importance demands.

abstract: No intelligence from Gen. McCLELLAN'S army reached us yesterday, owing to an interruption of the telegraphic communication between Washington and Fortress Monroe.
lead_paragraph: No intelligence from Gen. MCCLELLAN's army reached us yesterday, owing to an interruption of the telegraphic communication between Washington and Fortress Monroe. On Saturday night wereceived dispatches, which were published in our Sunday edition, announcing extensive movements on the part of the enemy's forces, the meaning of Which were yet involved in mystery. Large bodies of men had been moved down from the neighborhood of Mechanicsville Bridge and Richmond, and were apparently being concentrated in the vicinity of the late battlefield. Our pickets, on Friday, were driven in from Old Church by a large force of rebel cavalry, and on the same day the rebels made a demonstration on the right [???] of our army at Tunstall's Station, apparently with the intention of interrupting our railroad communication. They were forced to retreat, however, without effecting their object. A letter from one of our special correspondents, published this morning, gives information which indicates that another great battle is near at hand, if it has not already been commenced. The two armies are face to face in such close proximity that it seems impossible long to avoid a collision.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday petitions were presented for the enlargement of the Erie and Owego Canals, and for a Bankrupt law. The Naval Appropriation bill was taken up at 1 o'clock, and debated at considerable length. An amendment, proposed by Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, providing that slaves shall not be employed in the Navy-yards, was rejected -- 18 to 17. With regard to the location of the Naval Academy, a Commission was provided for to settle the matter, the appropriation of $25,000 for repairs at Annapolis being adhered to, and the Senate subsequently rejected the proposition for a Commission, thus apparently permanently settling the location at Annapolis. The bill was then passed. A long discussion occurred in regard to the hour of daily meeting, in which the propriety of an early adjournment was considered. It was finally resolved that on and after the 19th of June the Senate will meet at 11 o'clock.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday petitions were presented for the enlargement of the Erie and Owego Canals, and for a Bankrupt law. The bill was then passed. A long discussion occurred in regard to the hour of daily meeting, in which the propriety of an early adjournment was considered. It was finally resolved that on and after the 19th of June the Senate will meet at 11 o'clock.

abstract: On Sunday morning Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER lectured his people upon the sin of covetousness, under which general head he included certain sins of shopping, picture-buying, house-building, and so on, reserving an especial rap for the benefit of the city railway companies, who, in addition to whatever individual rapacity they may possess, are open to a very serious charge in regard to the treatment of drivers and conductors.

abstract: A solemn and instructive occasion was enjoyed on Sunday morning by the inmates of the City Prison. By appointment with the Chaplain, Rev. Mr. GAMP, some ministering Friends, who are deeply interested in visiting our model benevolent and correctional Institutions, occupied the time usually devoted to Church service. ELIZABETH COMSTOCK, PHEBE B. HATHAWAY, GRACE and HENRY DICKENSON, each made brief and truly impressive remarks; but the main interest of the occasion centered in the visit of these Friends to the cell of WILLIAM HENRY HAWKINS, who is condemned to be hung on the 27th of the present month. As the keeper opened the inner door of the cell and announced to the colored occupant the request of the Friends to sit with him a little while, he arose from his pallet, and, in lieu of chairs, invited them to be seated thereon. Chairs were soon supplied by the keeper, who had perceived the lack, and who, in consideration of the close atmosphere, expressed a willingness to permit his prisoner to leave his cell for the corridor during their stay. The prisoner appeared to have no choice in the matter, and bore himself with quiet dignity, remaining standing by his pallet while the others sat. First, HENRY DICKENSON addressed him in language calculated to prepare his mind for the more moving appeals that were to be made in his behalf by the sympathetic soul of woman. An unbroken silence followed the brief address, when, after some moments, the eloquent expressions of ELIZABETH COMSTOCK, given in a voice deeply subdued, filled the narrow cell with tones which [???] have penetrated to the hidden recesses of [???] in the heart of its occupant, whom she [???] our poor brother." Her [???] also healing on their wings, for she laid before him the encouraging promises which are held out even at the "eleventh hour." Another silence ensued, sufficiently long to allow the words spoken, to lay hold upon the mind of the criminal, who made no outward demonstrations of feeling but maintained a modestly respectful and attentive demeanor.

abstract: We have further rebel reports of the preliminary operations of our forces against Charleston. A dispatch from Augusta, Ga., dated the 12th, informs us that a sharp engagement took place on James Island, on Tuesday afternoon, which continued until dark, the occasion being an attack on our forces, to present them from occupying a certain piece of wools.
lead_paragraph: We have further rebel reports of the preliminary operations of our forces against Charleston. A dispatch from Augusta, Ga., dated the 12th, informs us that a sharp engagement took place on James Island, on Tuesday afternoon, which continued until dark, the occasion being an attack on our forces, to present them from occupying a certain piece of wools. The rebels put down their loss at from fifty to sixty men, principally Georgians, among whom is Col. WILLIAMS, of the Forty-sixth Georgia Regiment, mortally wounded.

abstract: Immense preparations are being made throughout all the cities, towns and villages of the loyal States for such a celebration of the coming Fourth of July as has never been witnessed in the history of the country. We do not hear, however, that New-York, the Metropolis of the Union, has yet done anything for, or even begun thinking of a fit observance of the natal day of the Republic.
lead_paragraph: -- Immense preparations are being made throughout all the cities, towns and villages of the loyal States for such a celebration of the coming Fourth of July as has never been witnessed in the history of the country. We do not hear, however, that New-York, the Metropolis of the Union, has yet done anything for, or even begun thinking of a fit observance of the natal day of the Republic. Why this languor and indifference? Why are our City Fathers not bestirring themselves? Where are the preparations for our military reviews, our processions, our orations, our illuminations? We have but one suggestion to make about the observance. It should be as unlike as possible the customary celebrations of the occasion, with as little as may be of the fuss, fizz and firecracker sort of demonstration, of the tinsel show and highfalutin eloquence traditionally associated with the Fourth of July. There is real ardor and patriotic enthusiasm in the community to make wholly unnecessary all exaggerated mock-heroic, patriotism. We would have it an original, genuine and spontaneous manifestation, worthy of the superb events that have crowded the year since the last Fourth of July. But for this end forethought and deliberation are necessary; and the City authorities, societies and the whole community should now be busy planning and preparing.

abstract: The Board of Councilmen held their regular meeting yesterday, but the entire time was occupied with discussions upon unimportant matters. A report, in favor of compelling the Harlem Railroad Company to remove the T rails from Centre, Broome and Grand streets, and from the Fourth-avenue, and substituting the grooved rail, caused a great deal of discussion, but was finally adopted. Nearly an hour was consumed in the discussion of a resolution permitting the erection of a stand on the sidewalk adjacent to the Post-office, for the sale of prints and papers; and the entire session, with the exception of these two matters, was devoted to routine and unimportant business.

abstract: Capt. DAVIS, the flag-officer of the Western river fleet at Memphis, in his official report of the naval battle that resulted in the surrender of that place, gives great credit to Col. CHARLES ELLET, Jr., the commander of the Ram Fleet, which did such remarkable service in the engagement.
lead_paragraph: Capt. DAVIS, the flag-officer of the Western river fleet at Memphis, in his official report of the naval battle that resulted in the surrender of that place, gives great credit to Col. CHARLES ELLET, Jr., the commander of the Ram Fleet, which did such remarkable service in the engagement. This is the first naval fight in which ram met ram; and though there are no absolutely new principles in the science of naval warfare illustrated by it, it is important as initiating a kind of fighting which is not unlikely to be largely practiced in the future; and it is interesting as showing the great practical utility of aquatic rams. Prior to the arrival of ELLET's ram fleet, the battle of the gunboats was an affair which promised to be of dubious result. The swift craft of the rebels dodged the shot of our ponderous and clumsy ironclad scows, and poured in an occasional fire with damaging effect. If, finally, they had been repulsed, they would have steamed off to some other point, (for they were swifter than our vessels,) and given us more trouble and further fight elsewhere. In fact, the rebel fleet was just in the act of seeking temporary safety by flight, when, (says a Western correspondent):

abstract: The forces under the command of Brig.-Gen. WRIGHT, crossed from Edisto Island to Seabrook's Point on the 29th, 30th and 31st May. The Sixth Connecticut was the first regiment landed and were thrown out as an advance. They had a skirmish with the rebel pickets on Sunday morning, June 1, and at the second attempt, drove the enemy across the river and obtained possession of the bridge.

abstract: Editorial on how Southern image has been tarnished
snippet: Editorial on how Southern image has been tarnished
lead_paragraph: The present war has changed many of the opinions of the world. It has effectually exploded the notion that Cotton is King. That supposed monarch is dethroned, and his own infatuated followers are now consigning the object of their idolatrous worship to the flames. No one commodity of commerce has ever before had such potent sway as Cotton, and cotton has failed to sustain the vices and violence of a stupendous insurrection against republicanism and civilization.

abstract: The steamship Ariel, from Aspinwall on the 8th inst., arrived at this port yesterday, with the mails, passengers and treasure from California. She brings intelligence of the wreck of the British screw steamer Mutine at the entrance of the harbor of Navidad, near Manzanilla, on the coast of Mexico.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Ariel, from Aspinwall on the 8th inst., arrived at this port yesterday, with the mails, passengers and treasure from California. She brings intelligence of the wreck of the British screw steamer Mutine at the entrance of the harbor of Navidad, near Manzanilla, on the coast of Mexico. She had on board about $1,500,000 in treasure, which, with her guns, would be saved by the Clio, which vessel had gone up to her assistance from Acapulco. No lives were lost. The Mutine was bound into the little port of Navidad for the purpose of smuggling off silver. There is little news of consequence from the United States of Colombia, but what little there is indicates that the country is about as far from peace as ever. An official bulletin, issued at Bogota, on the 16th of April, states that in Guasco, State of Cundenamarca, there was a fight on the 14th, between the Liberals and Conservatives, the latter losing two hundred prisoners. The Liberals claim the victory. It is expected that there will be trouble in Panama relative to the Guardia-Murrillo Treaty, entered into some time ago between the Governor of the State and the agent of the Mosquera Government. There is no news from Central America, and from South America the intelligence is not important. Full details will be found in the letter of our correspondent.

abstract: We are still at anchor in the Stono river, near Legreeville, a pretty little village of planters' houses on John's Island, about three miles from the sea, and eight from Charleston. It has long been used as a Summer resort for the wealthy cotton lords of these innumerable islands, but has been deserted since December last, the residents having foolishly imagined that we would follow up the great advantage gained at Port Royal.

abstract: The last night at Wallack's was an appropriate climax to nine months of brilliantly successful management, and a well-deserved tribute to the Treasurer's personal popularity.
lead_paragraph: The last night at Wallack's was an appropriate climax to nine months of brilliantly successful management, and a well-deserved tribute to the Treasurer's personal popularity. Of all the officials having to do with the theatrical business, Mr. Moss is acknowledged to be the unexceptionable model, whether in his relations to the player or the play-goer. He finds his account in this enviable reputation once a year at least, when he is invariably compelled to receive such a benefit as a great many more obtrusive people don't get once in a life-time. The entertainment offered on his behalf on Monday was, in our opinion, the very best that had been advertised anywhere for a twelve-month. "The Little Treasure" and "Rural Felicity" were given, and between the pieces Mr. WALLACK -- the Veteran himself -- delivered his annual speech, gratulatory of the past and hopeful of the time to come.

abstract: Editorial on possibility of British-French intervention
snippet: Editorial on possibility of British-French intervention
lead_paragraph: A judicious sifting of the public and private advices received from Europe during ten days past, presents, in an unpleasant light, the possibility of European intervention in the American question. So obstinately is the progress of the National arms ignored, and the value of National victories disputed; so steadily, in spite of evidence plain as sunlight, is the opinion of the irrepressibility of the South adhered to; so captiously is the entire military, civil and financial policy of the North discussed, as to render it plain, beyond demonstration, that France and England are busily arguing themselves into a meddlesome, and even belligerent temper toward the American Government. And this is not the impulse, as we very well know, of mere unfriendly prepossessions. The British and the French people have been severe sufferers because of the American war. Every day of its prolongation has added a new pang to the existence of the laboring classes, and a new peril to the existence of government and civil order; until it has become a question of capital moment, whether or not it is incumbent upon Europe to perish passively in deference to a vague and perhaps Quixotic principle of international law. The discussion of this thesis has recently, more urgently than ever before, engaged the attention of the French and British Cabinets. And the impression conveyed by the sources of information to which we have referred, tends strongly to encourage the conviction that interference, looking to the pacification of our difficulties, has been favorably considered by both Governments, and might at any moment have been propounded. And if the homeward mission of Lord LYONS have any diplomatic significance, it may not be extravagant to accept the popular interpretation, which ascribes it to the friendly desire of his Lordship to prevent any precipitate action of his Government upon the subject.
headline: {'main': 'Intervention The Position of France and England.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Intervention The Position of France and England.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: YOUNG MEN'S CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION OF COLUMBIA COLLEGE. The first annual sermon before this Association was delivered at the Church of the Ascension, in Fifth-avenue, on Sunday evening, by Rev. ALEX. H. VINTON, D.D., who took for his text the following, from the First Epistle of John: "I have
lead_paragraph: YOUNG MEN's CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION OF COLUMBIA COLLEGE. -- The first annual sermon before this Association was delivered at the Church of the Ascension, in Fifth-avenue, on Sunday evening, by Rev. ALEX. H. VINTON, D.D., who took for his text the following, from the First Epistle of John: "I have written unto you, young men, because ye are strong." The aim of the discourse was to point out how the strength of young manhood could be so employed and directed as to secure the happiness of the individual, and confer the greatest blessings upon the world. Youth was the period of the passions -- pride, self-will, the lust of the flesh and the lust of the eye -- and according as those passions obtained the mastery or were kept in subjection, would the individual become a drivelling slave or a rational man. Some compensating power was needed to control the energies and passions of youth, and turn them to good. That compensating power was conscience, and hence the need of constant enlightenment of conscience. This enlightenment came not from within, but from without -- it came from above -- it was revelation. The peculiar influences that surrounded young men in this country, where everything is precocious, where the child is the man, where the tendencies are to encourage rather than to check the pride and self-will of young manhood, where the spirit of independence is instilled into the individual from childhood, made it especially necessary that the compensating power of conscience should receive a full development and enlightenment. In political life, above all, was there a need of this power. Every American was born a politician, and every fierce politician had two consciences -- one for himself and one for his party -- which, being mutually destructive of each other, were equivalent to no conscience at all. Political ambition, without the compensating power of conscience, tempted a man to huckster away his country's liberties and union, for his own advancement. Our politicians had need to learn that "God ruleth: let the nations tremble." They must learn that a nation, no more than an individual, could disregard moral law with impunity. The indispensable necessity of an enlightened conscience, as a guide and restraint to the individual in all the avocations of life, was forcibly urged by argument and illustration, and the speaker closed his discourse by picturing to the minds of his hearers the various stages in life and the calm and peaceful death of a man whose career had been guided by an enlightened conscience and the precepts of Christianity.

abstract: News from Ottago, New-Zealand, to April 4, represent that the gold washings were not yielding so largely as for the previous two months. In January the yield was 65,464 ounces; February, 61,946; March, 43,359; or say in three months nearly three millions and a half of dollars. The natives were opposed to prospecting their lands, which were thought to be very rich in gold. The total exports of gold from Ottago since the discovery last year, up to March 28, amounted to a million and a half pounds sterling.

abstract: Prior to the occu  pation of New-Orleans, the rebels there threatened that if our troops ever did get to the city, they would find a ghastly enemy with whom it would be hard work to cope  that Yellow Jack was ready to devour us.
lead_paragraph: Prior to the occupation of New-Orleans, the rebels there threatened that if our troops ever did get to the city, they would find a ghastly enemy with whom it would be hard work to cope -- that Yellow Jack was ready to devour us. He had already been seen around the purlieus of the city, and was only waiting for the arrival of Northmen to gorge his maw with Yankee blood. But now the local newspapers are compelled to record the fact that our soldiers are extremely healthy, that Yellow Jack cannot be discovered, and that "there has probably never been a similar body of men in any locality so free from disease." It looks now as if Yellow Jack would not occupy New-Orleans until our men are ready to evacuate it.

abstract: A FATAL ACCIDENT IN THE CENTRAL PARK  On Saturday last, as Mr. THOMAS P. SHERLOCK and his wife were riding in a one-house conveyance through the grounds of the Central Park, the horse suddenly took fright and at once became unmanageable. The result was that both of the occupants of the vehicle were thrown out, and Mr. SHERLOCK was so seriously injured by the fall that he aled on Monday afternoon,
lead_paragraph: A FATAL ACCIDENT IN THE CENTRAL PARK. -- On Saturday last, as Mr. THOMAS P. SHERLOCK and his wife were riding in a one-horse conveyance through the grounds of the Central Park, the horse suddenly took fright and at once became unmanageable. The result was that both of the occupants of the vehicle were thrown out, and Mr. SHERLOCK was so seriously injured by the fall that he aled on Monday afternoon, at his residence, No. 617 Seventh-avenue. His skull was fractured to such an extent as to render him insensible from the time of the accident until his death. His wife was also very much injured. She, however, appeared at the inquest held by Coroner RANNEY yesterday, and testified that her husband was a temperate man; that he had been in the habit of driving horses for the last twenty years, and that his death should be attributed wholly to the fact that the horse, which her husband hired at a livery stable up town, was a very wild and vicious one. Subsequent evidence, however, revealed the fact that the horse was very kind and gentle, and entirely safe for any person to drive, except upon occasions when he became frightened. The deceased was about 50 years of age.
