abstract: loyalty of Adjutant-General THOMAS appears to be exposed to intermittent attacks -- every few months some fresh assailant laying at the door of that official a charge of communicating directly or indirectly with the enemy, and betraying to them the plans of the War Department. Gen. THOMAS occupies a position of peculiar trust. From the very nature of his duties, every detail of our military plans and conduct is familiar to him; and it is doubtless because he is in a situation to know everything, and because the rebels seem to learn everything, that he has been gratuitously selected as their source of information. To those who know Gen. THOMAS, his steadfast fidelity to his country, his laborious zeal in behalf of the army, his untiring industry and unsparing sacrifice of his personal comfort, it would be idle to address unfriendly charges or to propose any vindication. The truth is, the Government possesses no more devoted and faithful servant. There is nothing in his private relations, nor is there anything in his public career upon which to found the least imputation upon his fidelity, for so often has the subject been forced upon the notice of the Administration, and subjected to inquiry, that if there were the slightest semblance of truth in the accusations, it would have been brought to light. It is quite time these malicious tattlings were silenced; and that Gen. THOMAS should be refreshed with some show of gratitude, in place of the steady current of slander to which he has been persistently subjected.

It is quite time these malicious tattlings were silenced; and that Gen. THOMAS should be refreshed with some show of gratitude, in place of the steady current of slander to which he has been persistently subjected.

abstract: editorial again questions Beauregard whereabouts
snippet: editorial again questions Beauregard whereabouts
lead_paragraph: ARMY. -- Is or is not the great rebel army lately at Corinth still a coherent mass? Taking all the circumstances into account, there never was, in the military history of the world, an army of such magnitude concerning whose movements and whereabouts the opposing commanders were so completely in the dark. Although such a host could not have been removed from Gorinth in a day nor in a week, Gen. HALLECK knew not it had evacuated until, by accident, Gen. POPE discovered that the rebel bird had flown, and that a few rebel pickets were keeping our mighty army at bay; and, though twenty days have elapsed since that event, we have yet nothing clearer than a lot of disjointed statements locating it here, there and everywhere. The 10,000 men said to have been captured by POPE is ascertained to have been a highly exaggerated statement of that dashing General's achievement, and though our cavalry were reported to be everywhere "in hot pursuit," and though POPE is now announced to be forty miles south of Corinth, it has not yet been ascertained where a single one of the rebel divisions has gone to. The possible lines of retreat for them were very few, and we know that they must have gone southward, and then probably east. But how far south, and to what point or points in the east? Information on this subject is awaited for by the public with the greatest anxiety. We have no doubt that if HALLECK had not expelled all correspondents of the Press from his lines, they would have informed us, and him too, long ago, of the location of every brigade of the rebel army.

abstract: I have been busied for the past few days in studying out the situation here as altered by the battle of the 31st. It would not be prudent to tell what new dispositions have been made of troops, but I may at least call attention to the fact that the lines heretofore intrusted to the single division of CASEY are nowguarded by a force adequate to the importance of the position. Brigades are now encamped where regiments were before, and divisions hole the ground that brigades were thought equal to occupy. In spite of assertions to the contrary, I am satisfied, by personal examination, that our lines are not so far advanced as they were before the affair at Fair Oaks, though the difference is too trifling to be ascribed, even by the rebels, to anything more than a prudent selection of the strongest position. Another advance on their part could hardly result in even a temporary advantage, and if they failed in an attack with every circumstance in their favor, they are hardly likely to attempt another with our position so strengthened as it has been.

abstract: interesting letter from Mr. J.J. CISCO, throwing light upon the admirable working of the allotment system, as carried out by the Commissioners. Messrs. DODGE, ROOSEVELT, and BRONSON, will be found in another column. A fraction less than half a million dollars has been transmitted, mainly by New-York regiments, to their friends and families at home, being so much saved from the harpies, and speculators, and camp-followers, who fasten themselves upon the army, and live upon the prodigality of the soldier. The statement of Mr. CISCO not only reflects great credit upon the Commissioners, but unconsciously shows with how much patience and indulgence the Assistant-Treasurer has conducted his dealings with a class unaccustomed to business ways, and therefore trying sadly the nerves of the methodical man of affairs.

abstract: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, June 17. The War Department has dispatches from Gen.  McCLELLAN'S headquarters, dated 4 o'clock this afternoon. No especial movement had taken place. Our cavalry yesterday paid another visit to Ashland surprised a party of rebels a that point, and drove them off, and captured some property.

abstract: Editorial on need to relieve hunger and distress of captured Confederates
snippet: Editorial on need to relieve hunger and distress of captured Confederates
lead_paragraph: Famine seems to be following in the wake of war. From every part of the South which has been conquered by our arms comes up the cry of poverty, starvation and distress. In some places the country has been ravaged by the rebel troops; in others the supplies on hand have been carried off for the use of the rebel army; in others nothing has been planted on account of the political and social perturbations; in others the able-bodied men have gone off and joined the rebels, leaving the women, children, and incapables, to our mercy and charity; in other places the want is but the result, in an aggravated form, of the usual shiftlessness of the Southern "poor whites."

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. Monday at this house was a night of novelty. The opera "II Trovatore" was comparatively new; that is to say, it has not been offered to the public during the last twelve months. It was the first appearance of Madame BORCHARD in Leonora, and her third appearance in New-York. Signor AMODIO made his first appearance in this City as
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Monday at this house was a night of novelty. The opera "Il Trovatore" was comparatively new; that is to say, it has not been offered to the public during the last twelve months. It was the first appearance of Madame BORCHARD in Leonora, and her third appearance in New-York. Signor AMODIO made his first appearance in this City as the Conde di Luna, and another tenore replaced Signor BRIGNOLI. The audience, which was the largest of the present season, was very good natured. It evidently came to enjoy itself. When the opera could not begin, it accepted Prestidigitation in its place. As BRIGNOLI did not sing, they took SBRIGLIA with the most polite indifference -- they relished la BORCHARD, and they applauded AMODIO, while they gossiped and chatted between the acts in a way that GOTTSCHALK alone could still for a time. Seriously, Signor SBRIGLIA proved a very acceptable Manrico, and, we may remark, sang his recitatives with something approaching to care and taste -- qualities which we had began to forget the existence of in Italian recitative -- at any rate, among Italian tenori. Mme. BORCHARD, in our opinion, was much finer in the role of Leonora than she had been in that of Lucretia Borgia. Whether it is that the character of her voice weds VERDI's music better than it does DONIZETTI's, or whether it was that we had become better acquainted with it, it seems to us younger and fuller than it had previously done, and we must candidly rank her amongst the best Leonoras we have had in New-York. And now we have to speak of the real debutant of the night, the brother of AMODIO. His voice is younger and nobler in its timbre than his brother's, but is certainly not yet so full, round and large in its volume, while he very evidently sings with more care, and in some instances with more judgment. "Il Balen," in the second act, was well rendered by him and at once sealed his success. We ought not to omit all allusion to the Azucena of Madame D'ANGRI. She was not in such good voice as usual, but sang her music with passion and feeling -- a virtue for which we ought ever to be thankful.

lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the House amendment to tho bill increasing the volunteer medical force, abolishing the office of Brigade Surgeon, way agreed to. A new Conference Committee was ordered on the till providing certain bounties, ect. Mr. CHANDLER, of Michigan, offered a resolution, which was laid over, declaring that the amount of legal tender notes already authorized shall never be increased. The Pacific Railroad bill was then taken up and considered until the adjournment. The bill was amended so as to fix the commencement of the road on the one-hundredth parallel of latitude, within the Territory of Nebraska.

abstract: Editorial on ways to capture Charleston
snippet: Editorial on ways to capture Charleston
lead_paragraph: -- The late operations in the rear of Charleston, by way of Stono Inlet and James Island, are without doubt designed to secure important results against the time when the grand assault on the original home of secession treason comes off. We hardly presume, however, that it is expected in this way to capture Charleston; and indeed we hardly know that it is the way in which the country would have it captured. When the time comes for the assault on Charleston, we trust that it will not be by any back-door passage. We trust the invading and avenging force will take the self-same route by which the Star of the West attempted to carry food to ANDERSON's starving band, and was assailed and driven back in the attempt. We trust it will pass up directly under Fort Sumter -- if need be, laying it in ruins, and, at whatever cost, restoring the Stars and Stripes over the citadel where first they were lowered to traitors fifteen months ago. Not till these acts of justice have been performed, would we have the naval and military force of the Union pass up to take possession of that wretched and half-ruined town.

abstract: Commencement
snippet: Commencement
lead_paragraph: The regular Commencement exercises of this sterling old College at New-Brunswick, N.J., were held, yesterday, in the Second Dutch Reformed Church, Rev. Dr. FORSYTH presiding. The exercises were opened with prayer, the church being crowded with an assemblage composed of the friends of the students, and many from Princeton, (Nassau Hall,) the Commencement of which takes place next week. Although the address before the Alumni, which precedes the regular Commencement, was not to be delivered until 4 P.M., the streets were thronged, at an early hour, with the friends and relatives of the graduates, and, before the doors were opened, admission, except by favor, was almost impossible. The church, one of the largest in the City, the Second Reformed Dutch Church, was crowded to its utmost capacity. Soon after 4 o'clock, the procession of the students was formed on the campus, moving toward the church to the music of a fine band. At the church, Rev. Dr. FORSYTH presided, the societies of the College, the "Peithessophian", and "Philoclean" being fully represented, as they were the recipients of the honor paid them in the address by Prof. J.A. HART, of the Girard College in Philadelphia. The large and elegant church was crowded with a gay and interested throng, who were well repaid for the endurance they had exhibited in passing many hours of patient waiting, by the address of the learned and eloquent orator. The speaker took as his text, or rather as the subject of his theme, "The Bible as an Educating Power among the Nations." Prof. HART was introduced in a few but pertinent remarks, by Rev. Dr. DEWITT, of New-York.

abstract: Among several measures destined to engage the attention of the Thirty-seventh Congress at its second session, is the bill providing for the admission of Western Virginia into the Union. The subject has not been neglected at the present session.
lead_paragraph: Among several measures destined to engage the attention of the Thirty-seventh Congress at its second session, is the bill providing for the admission of Western Virginia into the Union. The subject has not been neglected at the present session. In the House, the Territorial Committee reported a bill defining the Blue Ridge as the eastern boundary, and requiring the immediate abolition of Slavery. The Senate Committee recommended an acquiescence in the boundaries fixed by the Wheeling convention, namely, the Alleghanies on the east, and the New River at the south; and instead of immediate, proposed gradual emancipation. Why the House bill should be unpalatable we can very well understand. While convinced of the necessity of abrogating Slavery, the Western Virginians are wise enough to recognize the policy of making the change very slowly and with every possible security to the interests of both blacks and whites, and they are not at all indisposed to accept that splendid douceur which Congress has promised to any Slave State initiating a system of gradual manumission. Nor is the easterly boundary selected to the liking of the new State. It takes in the Valley of Virginia, separated geographically as well as by every interest and institution, from the Trans-Alleghany region; the people having no community of feeling or sentiment, and cherishing old jealousies, and bestowing upon each other opprobrious nick-names as the expression of inveterate dislike. The social antagonisms which prohibit any marriage of the valley region with the west, are too well appreciated by the representatives of Western Virginia to encourage a support of the House measure, which we are not at all surprised to learn has been dismissed as impolitic by the Senate Committee upon Territories.
headline: {'main': 'The Admission of Western Virginia.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Admission of Western Virginia.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The first merrymaking of the institution on Sixth-avenue, devoted to the interest and education of our soldiers' children, came off Monday evening at Mozart Hall. The only bad feature in all the admirably managed affair, seems to be the inadequate size of the room for the throng of enthusiastic visitors; and as the attraction is to be kept up for a week, increasing in interest each night, by the introduction of some novel feature, this drawback will be felt, especially in the matter of misshapen hoops, the amplitude of which is disrespectfully annihilated if any attempt is made to take up more than their share of room. Above the main entrance are arranged, in evergreen letters, the name of the society under whose auspices the affair exists, viz.: "The Ladles' Educational Union." Pretty ovals, in evergreen, illuminated with brilliant artificial flowers, frame the honored portraits of GEORGE and MARTHA WASHINGTON, and also the patriotism-inspiring figures of our heroes and Generals, in the midst of which, just above the stage or musician's stand, beams the honest face of the President. The banner of our Union waves here, there and everywhere, in folds, in festoons, crosswise and drooping, large, small and medium sized. The brilliant season tickets, which are quite artistic, were a gift of Madame DEMAREST. DELMONICO has made himself memorable by donations in his line, and some of our first hotels have expressed an intention of contributing of their store as the festival progresses. TIFFANY, DOUGLAS & SHERWOOD, with others, were liberal in providing decorations. Along one side and end of the room are the tables, loaded with small mountains of delicious strawberries, with the accompanying cream; adjacent is the hot coffee stand, and opposite are tastefully arranged toy and fancy tables. Best among these stands is a small table upon which lie, in massing modesty, a little sheet, all gotten up in regular newspaper style, called "The Volunteer." It has been doing its work of advertising the benefice of which it is a marked feature, and contains reading matter of much interest to volunteers' families and friends -- and who is not a friend to the Volunteer?

abstract: Yesterday the rebels in position opposite our left opened quite a brisk cannonading upon our line, endeavoring, apparently, to shell us out of our camp bordering on the railroad and neighborhood, but with no other success than interrupting several dinner parties in the woods. Their shells flew about in all directions, but no casually occurred in consequence.
lead_paragraph: HOOKER's Division, CAMP AT FAIR OAKS, Va., Wednesday, June 11, 1862.

abstract: RELIGIOUS SERVICES IN THE JERSEY CITY ALMSHOUSE. The Catholic clergy of Jersey City have sent a memorial to the Common Council, complain ing that they are not allowed exclusive charge of the Catholic children in that institution, but that the inmates ...
lead_paragraph: RELIGIOUS SERVICES IN THE JERSEY CITY ALMSHOUSE. -- The Catholic clergy of Jersey City have sent a memorial to the Common Council, complaining that they are not allowed exclusive charge of the Catholic children in that institution, but that the inmates are classed together and receive instruction from the clergy of all denominations, both Protestant and Catholic. They ask to have a separate service, and the organization of a separate Sunday School for the Catholic children. The memorial was referred to the Committee on Alms. Considerable excitement exists in regard to the matter, and some difficulty is anticipated in its settlement.

abstract: As a general rule, when counterfeiters wish to make a successful business, in putting off their spurious bills in this City, they select Saturday evening, or some other evening, when, owing to circumstances, the butchers, shop-keepers and tradesmen of all classes, are too busy with their customers to spend much time in scrutinizing a bank bill presented to them or to examine the Bank-Note Detector with the same care they would upon ordinary occasions.
lead_paragraph: As a general rule, when counterfeiters wish to make a successful business, in putting off their spurious bills in this City, they select Saturday evening, or some other evening, when, owing to circumstances, the butchers, shop-keepers and tradesmen of all classes, are too busy with their customers to spend much time in scrutinizing a bank bill presented to them or to examine the Bank-Note Detector with the same care they would upon ordinary occasions. Yesterday, however, was an exception. At an early hour in the morning, counterfeit $5 bills upon "The Manufacturers' Bank of Troy," this State, were put into circulation simultaneously in all parts of this City and Brooklyn. The fact that the spurious notes are excellent imitations of the genuine, in every respect except one, aided the members of the gang very materially in their efforts to swindle the public. The only difference which could be discovered between the good and bad $5, notes of this bank, even by brokers and others who are adepts in the business, is, that in the genuine, the red ink, with which the word "Five" is printed, is of a darker color than that which is put into the counterfeits. But this difference is so slight that no person would ever be able to detect it unless experienced in the business, or unless his attention were particularly called to it. It is believed that a large amount of this money was put off in different parts of the City before any suspicion was raised against the bills; indeed, they were taken without objection for several hours after the gang commenced to operate.

abstract: The important order has atlast been issued  the time for trifling with the Government has passed. Gen. BUTLER has been concillatory, has waited patiently a long time, hoping that the citizens of New
lead_paragraph: The important order has atlast been issued -- the time for trifling with the Government has passed. Gen. BUTLER has been conciliatory, has waited patiently a long time, hoping that the citizens of New-Orleans or its constituted authorities would come forward and take the oath of allegiance, but up to this moment such has not been the case; an apathetic spirit it has prevailed, such as seizes upon the body after a lung sickness by fever, and I think, the reaction will be health. Let this be as I may, we are soon to know here who are enemies and who are friends The proclamation promulgating this result does not coerce the citizens to take the oath; it assumes the higher ground that it is an honor to be enrolled among the loyal citizens of the Union. The moral effect of this proclamation cannot be too much appreciated; but the document, which I inclose, speaks for itself.

abstract: At a late hour yesterday afternoon, a notice was received at the Coroner's office, from Capt. THORNE, of the Fourth Precinct Police, that a woman named CATHERINE CURRAN, had just died at No. 279 Waterstreet, under cicumstances which warranted the belief that she had been poisoned.
lead_paragraph: At a late hour yesterday afternoon, a notice was received at the Coroner's office, from Capt. THORNE, of the Fourth Precinct Police, that a woman named CATHERINE CURRAN, had just died at No. 279 Water-street, under cicumstances which warranted the belief that she had been poisoned. Coroner RANNEY went immediately to the place and held an inquest upon the body. A post-mortem examination was made by the Coroner's Deputy, and from the stomach of the deceased there was taken a large quantity of fluid which is believed to be a mixture of alcohol and burning-fluid. In order to be more certain, however, a portion of the liquid was put into a bottle, sealed up, and sent to a noted chemist of this City, for the purpose of analyzation.

abstract: Advices from Gen. McCLELLAN'S army to yesterday afternoon have been received. There has been no movement of importance. Col. AVERILL'S ...
lead_paragraph: Advices from Gen. MCCLELLAN's army to yesterday afternoon have been received. There has been no movement of importance. Col. AVERILL's scout to the Mattapony, mentioned yesterday, had been unsuccessful in finding rebel guerrillas, but a bridge was destroyed, and a number of wagons and carts, loaded with rebel supplies, were captured, together with several important prisoners. A successful reconnaissance had also been made to Charles City Court -- house, where some of the stock captured by the rebels in their recent raid on the right wing was recaptured.

abstract: Among the passengers by the Ocean Queen which arrived from New-Orleans, yesterday, was PIERRE SOULE, formerly United States Minister to Spain, and one of the leading spirits of the rebellion. He was sent on here by Gen. BUTLER by orders from Washington.
lead_paragraph: Among the passengers by the Ocean Queen which arrived from New-Orleans, yesterday, was PIERRE SOULE, formerly United States Minister to Spain, and one of the leading spirits of the rebellion. He was sent on here by Gen. BUTLER by orders from Washington. ADOLPHO MAZUREAN, a wealthy merchant of New-Orleans, and also a leading rebel, accompanies him as a prisoner. On the arrival of the Ocean Queen, Deputy-Marshal BORST was dispatched to escort the prisoners to the United States Marshal's office in Chambers-street. Mr. SOULE has been quite ill since he left New-Orleans, and appears very low-spirited. He is accompanied by a negro servant named "Jule," who says he is a free man, and has been employed for seven years past by Mr. SOULE, who pays him regular wages. The prisoners were allowed the freedom of the ship during the passage from New-Orleans, but SOULE was not allowed to hold private communication with anyone.

abstract: The time has passed by when we Americans are very much exercised one way or another by what English critics have to say as to our affairs; and only some decided novelty in the ...
lead_paragraph: The time has passed by when we Americans are very much exercised one way or another by what English critics have to say as to our affairs; and only some decided novelty in the form in which the criticism comes, can, at this day, attract attention. The stereotyped abuse and misrepresentation of the haut ton journals and Tory orators we have grown pretty well accustomed to; but when Lord BROUGHAM opens his mouth to speak on the American war, we prepare to hear him with the respect which years and the wisdom brought by years claim, and with an interest arising from the fact that hitherto Lord BROUGHAM's voice has not been much heard as to the American question. The distinguished octogenarian has, however, taken the opportunity in his inaugural address at the opening of the Social Science Congress to express himself at some length on the question, and so much of his discourse as bears on the United States will be found reproduced in another column.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill for the better government of the navy was reported back from the Naval Committee. Mr. GRIMES, of Iowa, ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill for the better government of the navy was reported back from the Naval Committee. Mr. GRIMES, of Iowa, offered a resolution, which was laid over, that, in the opinion of the Senate, it is right for the Government to call loyal persons within he rebellious States to its armed defence. A joint resolution, adjourning Congress on the 30th inst., was laid over. A bill relative to further enlistments in the army was introduced by Mr. HALL and referred to the Military Committee. A bill to prevent Members of Congress and other Government officers from taking considerations or procuring contracts, was referred. The resolution introduced on Tuesday, to prevent a further issue of legal tender Treasury notes, was referred to the Finance Committee. A bill remodeling the Courts of the District of Columbia was referred to the Judiciary Committee. The Pacific Railroad bill was then considered until the adjournment.

abstract: Commencement
snippet: Commencement
lead_paragraph: The unexpected arrival of ZULOAGA, COBOS and their friends, in this city, shows that there is another complication in Mexican politics. It seems that ZULOAGA insists that he is the true President of Mexico, and is not inclined to abdicate in favor of ALMONTE, an act which would involve the trampling under foot of all legitimacy in Government, a principle upon which is based his power, and which is the principal support of his banner. This line of conduct will deprive the French of a great number of supporters, and serves to show how unpopular is their intervention when these leaders deem it necessary to exhibit to all the world their repudiation of the alliance. The conduct of the Spanish Government also makes another complication, for the last intelligence from Madrid informs us that O'DONNELL not only eschewed the idea of withdrawing the Spanish troops from Mexico, but intimated his intention of sending reinforcements; this was said at the very time when nearly all the expedition had returned to Havana. What, then, is the policy of the Madrid Government on the subject, or have they any? Is there to be a fresh expedition? These and many questions arising from the recent events, are in every one's mouth.

abstract: It would be an interesting inquiry to one whose bump of comparison was large, and who had a taste for statistics, and was not ...
lead_paragraph: It would be an interesting inquiry to one whose bump of comparison was large, and who had a taste for statistics, and was not appalled by immense quantities, to consider which was the biggest lie that the rebels have told. The mind wanders off into a labyrinth at the mention of the question. Was it one of the lies they have told about us or about themselves? Was it a lie military or a lie civil, a lie financial or a lie clerical? Was it one of the "solid and profound" lies, or was it some light and airy statement just tripping off the tongue or the pen employed on weightier themes? From whose mouth did it emanate? From JEFF. DAVIS, or FLOYD, or BEAUREGARD? Are we to look for it in State papers or military bulletins, or editorial rhapsodies? All these are questions which naturally arise, but we must turn over their consideration to some future essayist for the columns, perhaps, of the Atlantic Monthly. We can promise that if his article prove a dull one, it will probably be because the writer will be overpowered with the embarrass des richesses. He will have so many flowers of mendacity among which to cull his nosegay, that he will hardly know which to gather first.

abstract: Editorial on anti-polygamy bill passed by US Congress
snippet: Editorial on anti-polygamy bill passed by US Congress
lead_paragraph: A bill prohibiting Polygamy in the Territories of the United States has passed both houses of Congress by overwhelming majorities. In the Senate only two votes -- those of the Senators from California -- were cast against it. Mr. MCDOUGALL, on behalf of himself and colleague, explained that their objections to the measure rested solely on the ground of its impolicy at the present time. That the purpose of the bill is entirely right, and commends itself to every true friend of morality and civilization, will scarcely be questioned anywhere outside the circles of Mormondom. This subject has been fully discussed in our columns heretofore, and the necessity of some legislation to remove the foul blot of Polygamy repeatedly urged. A National Republican Convention has also declared war against the institution, as one of the "twin relics of barbarism." The duty of the Government to exert its power for the extermination of this great social evil is almost universally recognized, and we may consider that question to have passed beyond the field of discussion.

abstract: JUNE EXHIBITION OF THE BROOKLYN HORTICULTURAL SOCIETY. The annual June exhibition of the Brooklyn Horticultural Society was opened yesterday afternoon, with a larger and better display of fruits, plants and flowers, than ever before presented to the public for inspection by this Society.
lead_paragraph: JUNE EXHIBITION OF THE BROOKLYN HORTICULTURAL SOCIETY. -- The annual June exhibition of the Brooklyn Horticultural Society was opened yesterday afternoon, with a larger and better display of fruits, plants and flowers, than ever before presented to the public for inspection by this Society. The florists and horticulturists from different parts of this and the neighboring States have been largely drawn upon to render the exhibition as attractive and interesting as possible. The Society, to meet the increasing wants, of the public, has, with commendable liberality, engaged the whole of the Academy of Music for this exhibition, and the articles on exhibition are placed upon the floor that covers the stage and parquet. When balls are given in this house Dodworth's Band furnisties the music. There are on the different tables over ore hundred varieties of the strawberry alone, of all shades and colors, from which fact some idea of the extent of the exhibition can be inferred by the reader. The strawberries vary in size from the small meadow sweet to those so large that one would almost be enough to satisfy the appetite of the most voracious berry eater. The special premium of $10 for the best quart has been awarded to FRANCIS DRILL, of Newark. Mr. BURGESS, of Glen Cove, FULLER and others, of Brooklyn, have tables of this delicious fruit. Messrs. [???] & TELLER, A.G. BURGESS, of Brooklyn, and P. BREMIERS, of New-Jersey, as usual, have on exhibition a splendid display of cut flowers and flowers in pots, A. BRIDGMAN, of Broadway, New-York, has a table, containing twenty varieties of the gloxania; G.A. MESSELBERG, a fine lot of fuschias; Mrs. A. HENDERSON, a monster Scotch thistle, five feet high: D. FOULIS has a large and beautiful assortment of pelargoniums; Mr. PARSONS, OF Flushing, L.I., has a table of small and rare oak planks with leaves of variegated color, among which is particularly noticeable the Quercus Loretti. Mr. PARSONS also has altheas and a Japan gingko tree on his table; a mammoth squash preserved front the Boston Exhibition of 1861, and a Canada crooked-neck squash are to be seen on one of the tables. Mrs. JAMES HUMPHREY, as usual, makes an imposing display with some very beautiful variegated fuschias, wild and hot-house flowers. Mr. BURGESS, of Brooklyn, contributes a lot of sweet-williams and cut roses. Messrs. E. & G. MARSHALL, of Poughkeepsie, some luscious grapes; also, DAVID FOWLIS and JAMES [???], of Brooklyn, make contributions of the same kind of fruit; JOHN YOUNG, a fine lot of cherries; G. MARC, of Astoria, a plate of peaches; S.N. SIBBELL has the best single dish of strawberries; G. M. BALDWIN the second best; Mrs PACKER contributes a tree upon which both oranges and lemons are growing finely; J.A. MESSELBERG receives a premium for the best exhibition of cut flowers, P. BRUME, of Lewellyn Park, a premium for the second best lot of cut flowers. PHILIP ZEN exhibits [???] splendid baskets and boquets of flowers, also a lot of Gloxanias; J. [???], hand [???]; A.C. [???], of Brooklyn, two tables [???] with moss basket plants, and has been awarded the [???] premium of $10. There are rustic [???], apparatus for hosting green-houses, [???] on horticulture, names for preserving flowers -- a Boston not on, and last, but not least, a "What is it," which all should see. The attendance last evening, we are gratified in being able to say, was large. The exhibition will be open this and to-morrow afternoon and evening.

abstract: We acted on motives which, however unintelligible they may seem in America, were perfectly comprehensible to ourselves.
lead_paragraph: We acted on motives which, however unintelligible they may seem in America, were perfectly comprehensible to ourselves. We thought it unworthyof a great nation to allow our view of international law, and the duties it involves, to be warped and distorted by the pleading of a merely material interest The fact that the cotton of the South was very needful to us made the war more distressing, but furnished, in our view, no valid ground for intervention. Past injuries, if we did not think fit to resent them when the Union was strong and united, we thought it below our dignity to resent in the moment of its weakness and adversity. Future security we preferred to look for rather in the good feeling which our conduct seemed to us peculiarly calculated to produce than in availing ourselves of the temporary weakness and heavy misfortune of a kindred people. In this point only we confess we see some reason to believe that we may have been mistaken. We do not believe that, had we pushed to the utmost the advantages circumstances threw in our way, we could have been the objects of more bitter hostility, not only among the ignorant and misguided but among many of those whose education and information should have taught them better. We may possibly live to repent our generosity. We may possibly live to find that our moderation has been displayed toward those who have no power to appreciate it. It might have been wiser to take security for ourselves, instead of putting so much confidence in the fairness and good feeling of others. If this fact be established, the error is still reparable. The North cannot see that we have done anything to entitle us, we do not say to gratitude or good will, but to abstinence from hatred and reviling. A change of policy on the part of this country would very speedily alter their opinion and convince them of that which they seem now unable to conceive, that they have been treated by England as they never have treated her, and as, if she had thought more of her own interest, and less of their misfortune, she never would have located them.

abstract: comes from Philadelphia to the effect that Secretary STANTON has again called on the Governors of States to know how many men they can at once supply to reinforce the army. We greatly doubt that any such requisition has been made. It is but a fortnight since the Secretary of War countermanded the call for the State militia, to which a hundred thousand men responded on the word. "We presume that what Mr. STANTON is now looking [???] the last quota of fifty thousand men the enlistment of which, for three years or the war authorized six weeks ago. These, as we have before noted, are to fill up regiments, and from in a reserve corps. Owing to recent misunderstanding, however, this member has not yet been filled up. Let it be done to forthwith, If a hundred thousand more are really wanted, let Mr. STANTON distinctly say so, and they will be forthcoming.

abstract: An expedition down the river pass reached here without a shot being fired. The tug Spitfire captured the rebel steamer Clara Dobson to-day, in the Bayou Lareux. She had 100 bales of cotton on board, said to be worth $60,000. She has started for Memphis with a prize crew on board.

abstract: It is a bright, beautiful Sabbath morning, and we are marching out to our devotions to the music of grander anthems than ever echoed through church aisles. Our organ-pipes are great-ribbed, loud-lunged cannon, and the octaves that issue from their bur- nished throats would probably astonish any of the audiences that on bright Sundays are accustomed to gather around the porches of your City churches, to hear the music within.

abstract: PIERRE SOULE COMMITTED TO FORT LAFAYETTE. Yesterday, at 12  o'clock, United States Mar- shal MURRAY received a telegraphic dispatch from Washington, directing him to commit PIERRE SOULE and ADOLPH MAZUREAU, who arrived as prisoners in the Ocean Queen from New-Orleans, on Wednesday, to the custody of the commandant of Fort Lafayette The prisoners were immediately informed of the Government orders, to which they expressed no sur
lead_paragraph: PIERRE SOULE COMMITTED TO FORT LAFAYETTE. -- Yesterday, at 12 1/2 o'clock, United States Marshal MURRAY received a telegraphic dispatch from Washington, directing him to commit PIERRE SOULE and ADOLPH MAZUREAU, who arrived as prisoners in the Ocean Queen from New-Orleans, on Wednesday, to the custody of the commandant of Fort Lafayette The prisoners were immediately informed of the Government orders, to which they expressed no surprise or objection, and they were soon on their way to the Fort in a carriage, guarded by two Deputy Marshals. Mr. SOULE was quite ill on Wednesday night, suffering severely from an attack of neuralgia in the head, but he was much better yesterday morning, and called for all the newspapers, including the New-York Tribune. He expressed great indignation at an editorial article in the Herald censuring Gen. BUTLER for not hanging him instead of sending him North, and was anxious to learn the author, not appearing to be aware that a man named JAMES GORDON BENNETT claims to be the sole editor and proprietor of that sheet. Mr. SOULE says that he opposed the secession of Louisiana up to the last moment, and was Corporation candidate of New-Orleans for a seat in the Convention -- the Corporation being at that time opposed to secession. He was beaten, however, by 65 votes. After the secession ordinance passed, he says he submitted to the will of the people and went with his State. As to the part he has taken in the rebellion since that time he volunteers little information. He thinks it will be a long time before the rebellion will be subdued. His fellow prisoner, MAZUREAU, formerly High Sheriff of New-Orleans, is an open, bold, and somewhat blustering and bravado rebel, who seems to glory in the insignificant part he has played in the farce. He is not a man of very dangerous parts, physical or mental, and is probably as high up in the world now as he will ever get, unless the Government should by and by stoop to elevate him a little higher by means of a pully and weight.

abstract: Various rumors have recently been circulated in reference to an alleged over-issue of Indiana State Bonds. My connection with Bonds of that State commenced by my receiving them in the regular course of business, as collaterals for advances made and money loaned on faith of those instruments; afterwards, to secure money borrowed, 1 bypothecated some of them, and when it was deemed
lead_paragraph: Various rumors have recently been circulated in reference to an alleged over-issue of Indiana State Bonds. My connection with Bonds of that State commenced by my receiving them in the regular course of business, as collaterals for advances made and money loaned on faith of those instruments; afterwards, to secure money borrowed, 1 bypothecated some of them, and when it was deemed necessary that a number of them should be retired. I cooperated in effecting that result with the legally authorized, agents of the State of Indiana. The idea has been in some way conveyed to the public that these Bonds were fraudulently circulated, and the charge has been made that authorities of Indiana, knowing the Bonds were improperly issued, took no steps to expose parties through whose agency they reached the public. The result is, that the Grand Jury have been induced, as I understand, upon an unsworn and informal communication, without any complaint or charge before a Magistrate, to investigate those matters, and as these proceedings are secret, and they receive only testimony from the prosecution, and no accused party can be heard before them, it is not impossible that on the imperfect, or misrepresented state of facts presented to them, they may find an indictment against those to whose hands the alleged illegal Bonds have come, and thus attempt to implicate me.

abstract: Commencement
snippet: Commencement
lead_paragraph: A maze of tulle, laces, flowers, female loveliness, gossamer bonnets, and lively young gentlemen in silk gowns, adorned Niblo's Theatre yesterday morning, on the occasion of the Annual Commencement of the New-York University. From the stage, the vast area of variegated colors, and the constant flirting of a thousand fans, bore no slight resemblance to a garden of rare exotics moved by a gentle breeze -- a resemblance which was none the less striking from the delicious fragrance which wafted nasal-ward. The usual supply of bouquets rewarded the oratorical efforts -- a supply which the bouquet man was alacritous to furnish, and which he was much chagrined to see did duty to reward a variety of aspirants for Demosthenean fame.

abstract: MENT ITS OWN ARTIST. -- The bill authorizing the new emission of Demand Notes will, it is confidently anticipated, pass through Congress without difficulty. It should not pass, however, without a provision strongly recommended by the Secretary of the Treasury. The business of engraving and printing the notes should be reserved to the Government itself, and not farmed out to companies who realize enormous profits on the currency. One-half the profit on the printing of one hundred millions of notes would furnish the Treasury with an establishment complete in every particular for engraving and printing bonds, certificates of debt, and these notes, in style far more elegant and secure than those executedby the American Bank Note Company. It is notorious that upon the present Government bills dies are used which had been previously and currently used upon bank notes, and, we are credibly assured, those very dies have been perfectly reproduced upon counterfeit bills. It is of the highest importance to a currency now a permanent part of the financial machinery of the country, that the work should be as near perfection as possible, and that all the designs should be peculiar to the Government scrip. This can be easily and cheaply effected, by the Government coining its own paper as it coins the precious metals. Let some member, who has a trifling regard to economy and to the protection of the public and the Treasury against wholesale counterfeiting, see that the bill is amended so that the notes shall be engraved and printed in the Treasury building.
lead_paragraph: MENT ITS OWN ARTIST. -- The bill authorizing the new emission of Demand Notes will, it is confidently anticipated, pass through Congress without difficulty. It is of the highest importance to a currency now a permanent part of the financial machinery of the country, that the work should be as near perfection as possible, and that all the designs should be peculiar to the Government scrip. abstract: At 4  o'clock yesterday afternoon, building No. 290 Grand-street fell with a tremendous crash, burying five men beneath the ruins. Lot No. 211, owned by Mr. PETER WARREN, of No. 295 Bayard-street, was being excavated, for the purpose of erecting a new building. The workmen had shored up building No. 209 with the usual appliances, and had built a wall
lead_paragraph: At 4 1/4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, building No. 290 Grand-street fell with a tremendous crash, burying five men beneath the ruins. Lot No. 211, owned by Mr. PETER WARREN, of No. 295 Bayard-street, was being excavated, for the purpose of erecting a new building. The workmen had shored up building No. 209 with the usual appliances, and had built a wall underneath to sustain it. By throwing sand upon the east side of the wall, the pressure became so great as to force it out, producing the fall of the structure.

abstract: With a grand flourish, the Emancipation League paraded the name of Senator WILSON as the orator who would address them at Cooper Institute on last night. It being ascertained that Mr. WILSON could not come, they advertised Rev. Dr. CHEEVEE and Mr.
lead_paragraph: With a grand flourish, the Emancipation League paraded the name of Senator WILSON as the orator who would address them at Cooper Institute on last night. It being ascertained that Mr. WILSON could not come, they advertised Rev. Dr. CHEEVER and Mr. O.A. BROWNSON. The fame of these gentlemen attracted exactly 216 persons to Cooper Institute, 41 of whom occupied the platform. As the clock told the hour of 8 1/4, the audience aforesaid manifested, in the usual manner, signs of impatience, whereupon Mr. HART advanced to the desk, and apologized for the non-appearance of Mr. WILSON, on the ground of public duty; for the absence of Mr. BROWNSON, because he had not promised to come: and for the absence of Dr. CHEEVER, who is in "delicate health." He then read the following letter from Senator WILSON:

abstract: Editorial on death; Buckle, Henry Thomas
snippet: Editorial on death; Buckle, Henry Thomas
lead_paragraph: The death of Mr. BUCKLE will perhaps come home with more personal grief to his readers on this side the Atlantic than to his British fellow-countrymen. The whole form of his genius was essentially democratic, and here was something in his bold, aggressive nature, his contempt of tradition and routine and his catholic sympathies, that won strangely on our transatlantic temper. The next volume (the third) of his History of Civilization, was moreover to have been occupied with the United States, and if he had been spared, it was his intention this Summer, to have paid a visit to our country, as he thought to find here the best illustrations of the laws of the distribution of knowledge. It is perhaps allowable, therefore, to indulge a feeling of grief that cold obstruction should have fallen on this bright genius who has imported science into History, and from whom we had reason to expect so much.

abstract: The rapid completion of the tremendous preparations which McCLELLAN has made for the discomfiture and confusion of the rebels before Richmond, authorizes a belief that hardly a week will pass before a great battle shall have decided the event of the war. Of the reinforcements received and dispositions made by the Union General, it is improp-
lead_paragraph: The rapid completion of the tremendous preparations which MCCLELLAN has made for the discomfiture and confusion of the rebels before Richmond, authorizes a belief that hardly a week will pass before a great battle shall have decided the event of the war. Of the reinforcements received and dispositions made by the Union General, it is improper to speak. It is enough to know he heads an army numerically and physically the strongest in the New World, that in point of artillery and munitions he has vastly the advantage of the enemy; and that there is to be no such thing as a "siege of Richmond," and especially is there to be no such thing as defeat. Gen. MCCLELLAN will attack the rebels in their encampments, drive them back with artillery and the bayonet, and enter the rebel Capital close on the heels of their broken and flying columns. To effect this, our gallant General conceives himself abundantly competent, a faith, we have reason to know, shared to the fullest extent by his officers and men.

abstract: At the regular meeting of the Board yesterday, a resolution previously introduced by Alderman FROMENT, providing for a Joint Committee of both Boards to consult with the Comptroller and provide rules and regulations to prevent fraud in the distribution of the last appropriation for the relief of families of soldiers, was called up. Alderman GENET could not see the use of appointing a Committee of the two Boards for such a purpose, when, by the provision of the ordinance appropriating the money, the same men who would be on the Committee (with their associates in the two Boards,) were the men who were to distribute the money. It was merely appointing men to be guardians of their own honesty. On motion the resolution was referred to the Committee on National Affairs.

abstract: The War Department has received the important information, through a dispatch from Gen. MORGAN, dated the 18th in st., that Cumberland Gap, leading into East Tennessee. has been occupied by the National forces. Gen. MORGAN states that after great difficulty he reached a position near
lead_paragraph: The War Department has received the important information, through a dispatch from Gen. MORGAN, dated the 18th in st., that Cumberland Gap, leading into East Tennessee. has been occupied by the National forces. Gen. MORGAN states that after great difficulty he reached a position near the Gap, and at 1 o'clock on the morning of the 18th he advanced to the Gap to attack the rebel forces, but was just in time to learn that their rear guard had left about four hours before his arrival.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the House bill to change the port of entry of Brunswick, Geo., was passed. A motion to take up the resolution fixing the time of adjournment, was lost, 22 to 14. The bill defining the pay and emoluments of officers of the army was considered, and the amendment of the House striking out the section deducting ten per cent. from the pay of officers of the Government, etc., was concurred in. The Pacific Railroad bill was then debated until the adjournment. An amendment offered by Mr. COLLAMER, of Vermont, providing for the reservation of a certain amount of the bonds until the road is completed, was adopted.

abstract: ANNUAL REGATTA OF THE BROOKLYN YACHT CLUB. The annual June regatta of the Brooklyn Yacht Club took place yesterday afternoon, and was in all respects a very satisfactory affair. There were nine boats entered, and the contest was for a marine
lead_paragraph: ANNUAL REGATTA OF THE BROOKLYN YACHT CLUB. -- The annual June regatta of the Brooklyn Yacht Club took place yesterday afternoon, and was in all respects a very satisfactory affair. There were nine boats entered, and the contest was for a marine glass, first prize, and a silver pitcher for the second prize. The route of the boats was from the stake-boat at the Club-house, Gowanus Bay, to a stake-boat off Bay Ridge to station-boat off Robbins' Reef Light-house, and back three times, making in all a distance of about twenty-five miles. A steamboat chartered by the Yacht Club for the use of their invited friends, and hundreds of smaller craft accompanied the boats in their movements, and at times the most intense interest was manifested by the spectators, as the contest between different boats became sharp. There was a fair wind, and the boats were, as a whole, managed well, and made very good time. The boats entered were as follows:

abstract: troops are truly and actually in possession of Cumberland Gap at last. On Wednesday morning, at 1 o'clock, while all New-York and all the country were asleep, four brigades of our gallant Southwestern soldiers took up their line of march, amid darkness, solitude and the wild mountains, for the famous Gap -- the key of East Tennessee. They arrived there probably in the gray dawn of the morning -- for they had not a very long march to make -- expecting to find the foe; but they found that the foe had fled, and that this important position was ours without a battle.

abstract: Public attention has been scarcely awakened yet to a question now in process of decision--the most important which has ever affected our Republic in its foreign relations.
lead_paragraph: Public attention has been scarcely awakened yet to a question now in process of decision -- the most important which has ever affected our Republic in its foreign relations. We allude to the policy which the Emperor of the French will adopt in regard to the Mexican imbroglio. On his decision will rest momentous consequences to this Nation and to the world, for years to come. By that will be determined whether America shall enter the stormy sea of European politics -- whether foreign interests and monarchical schemes shall find a foothold on this Continent and on pur own borders -- whether the most vigorous military Power of the world shall erect a Protectorate, supported by bayonets, close by our frontiers, ever ready to interfere in our domestic difficulties, or to take advantage of our misfortunes -- or whether Mexico and the North American Continent are to be left to their former isolation, and to work out, in their own way, the Republican idea and their peculiar doctrines. To us, it is a question only second to that of our rebellion -- to the world, it is equally momentous. With Europe, the decision may be the beginning of wars and revolutions and complications which shall last for a generation. It is not to be wondered at, that the European Revolutionists are in the highest excitement over the question. They know well the trembling nature of a Revolutionary throne -- how fatal may be a single blunder to NAPOLEON's dynasty. They can see no horn of the dilemma which shall not weaken the skillful ruler, whose good fortune, thus far, has been equal to his prudence.

abstract: editorial sees Missouri enacting emancipation policy
snippet: editorial sees Missouri enacting emancipation policy
lead_paragraph: It is evident that Slavery cannot exist for any length of time in the State of Missouri. The mere fact that the question is being agitated all over the State seals the doom of the institution. Slavery can neither continue to exist in the midst of protracted war, nor of hostile agitation. The State Convention of Missouri last week gave reluctant consideration to the President's compensated-emancipation message; and responded that practical action on the proposition was at present uncalled for. But this week an "Emancipation Convention" has sat at the State Capital, at which 195 delegates were present, who represented twenty-five counties, or nearly one-fourth of the area of the State. By this Convention, resolutions were adopted recommending the gradual emancipation of the slaves in the State, and the acceptance of the aid tendered by the general Government. The mere fact that such a Convention could be held in Missouri, indicates the marvelous change that has taken place in the condition of that State since two years ago -- at which time such a meeting, at such a place, would probably have cost the life of every man who attended it. The growth of public opinion in a State like Missouri, is extremely rapid; and opinion hardly gets formed on any topic, ere it is overtaken by public action upon it. If twenty-five counties were represented in the Convention now, we may expect that all the counties in the State will be represented next year, and that the same year will see the question authoritatively submitted to the vote of the people.

abstract: Editorial on Union's iron-clad navy
snippet: Editorial on Union's iron-clad navy
lead_paragraph: OUR IRON-CLAD NAVY. -- The European journals exhibit great anxiety to learn the progress of our new iron-clad navy. This curiosity, though natural, is hardly fair; for both France and England take the utmost pains to envelop all their iron naval constructions in the densest secresy. We shall not enlighten them, except so far as to tell them that, such is the present activity of the Government, we shall, before the end of the present year, and probably before the rebellion is completely crushed, have a larger and more powerful iron-clad navy than either France or England, or than France and England combined. Since the passage through Congress of the Appropriation bill for this purpose, every muscle has been strained at our Navy-yards and foundries, both public and private. Mailed warships, of every form -- gunboats, batteries, monitors and rams, fitted, some for sea service, and others for harbor defence -- are now being constructed at New-York, Brooklyn, Greenpoint, Philadelphia, Troy, and in Connecticut. The revelations contained in the intercepted private letter of Mr. Rebel Roving Commissioner ROST, show conclusively that NAPOLEON, in his own words, "fears the rising navy of the United States." If he knew with what rapid strides it is "rising," his fear would probably amount to a panic. As for England, while Parliament clatters and their old-fogy Admiralty wrangles with Capt. COLES, our foundries and dock-yards resound with the lusty music of a hundred trip-hammers and riveting-tools. How the wefts of the Future are woven in with those iron strands! Who knows to what service they will be put? One thing we know -- the Power possessing the strongest iron navy holds the empire of the seas, and seizes the hegemony of the nations. With the end of this war the United States passes from the gristle state into the man, and our iron ships are the Thor's hammer in our hands.

abstract: No dispatches were received from Gen. M'CLELLAN'S Headquarters yesterday, but our correspondence, Editorial and other, will be found to contain very fall details of events up to and including the 18th. At that time the opinion was
lead_paragraph: No dispatches were received from Gen. M'CLELLAN's Headquarters yesterday, but our correspondence, Editorial and other, will be found to contain very fall details of events up to and including the 18th. At that time the opinion was entertained that a collision could not long be delayed, and that it might be precipitated at any moment. A dispatch from Fortress Monroe, in mentioning the arrival of a steamer from White House, states that skirmishing had been going on on the 19th, and that the rebels had assumed a more menacing attitude, and would probably try to bring on a general engagement in front of their defensive works, in order to bring our troops within range of their batteries. It is quite likely, however, that Gen. MCCLELLAN intends to take the initiative, and to choose his own battle ground.

abstract: The present condition of military affairs in front of the rebel capital can hardly last for any length of time. The Union army, under the skillful guidance of Gen. McCLELLAN, is daily taking up new positions more menacing to the enemy, and closer to their lines. It is
lead_paragraph: The present condition of military affairs in front of the rebel capital can hardly last for any length of time. The Union army, under the skillful guidance of Gen. MCCLELLAN, is daily taking up new positions more menacing to the enemy, and closer to their lines. It is daily enlarging its numbers, daily increasing in strength, spirit and warlike efficiency. Powerful outlying Union detachments on the rebel flank and rear are steadily getting into more suitable positions for joint action or for cooperation. And so far advanced now are matters on our side, for the decisive event, that it is not overstretching the fact to say that all things are ready. At latest advices Gen. MCCLELLAN had moved his headquarters across the Chickahominy to a point within about four miles of Richmond, and more than four-fifths of his entire army were also on the rebel side of the same river. It now remains only that he at once make an overwhelming assault on the enemy's lines, or that, by a steady and sure advance for a short distance further, he bring to bear upon them that tremendous artillery which, heretofore, has never failed of success.

abstract: Some comments have been made in France on the frequent charges of cowardice which pass back and forth between American regiments, and upon the discussions in Congress on the merits, and especially
lead_paragraph: Some comments have been made in France on the frequent charges of cowardice which pass back and forth between American regiments, and upon the discussions in Congress on the merits, and especially the demerits, of Generals and soldiers in the field. In a Government like that of the Empire, where the military element takes the first rank, and where the freedom of the Press and of speech is not understood as in the United States, these indelicate criminations and recriminations must indeed provoke a feeling very near akin to disgust. So thorough is the esprit de corps of the French army, that such a thing as cowardice does not rank among the possible things, and when a regiment yields from over-pressure, their brothers-in-arms in neighboring regiments would think it a crime to take advantage of the fact to fix upon them the cruel and indelible stain of cowardice. Their brothers-in-arms accept, as a matter of course, that when a regiment yields, it does so either to secure a better position for accomplishing the end in view, or because it is so punished as to render the holding of the position impossible. It may be that this kind of public crimination is inseparable to a young and green army; it is, however, none the less cruel and reprehensible.

abstract: The inquest in the case of the parties who died by the Grand-street catastrophe--an account of which we published in yesterday's TIMES--although appointed to be held at 11 o'clock A. M., yesterday, did not commence until 2 o'clock in the afternoon, owing to the delay in extricating one of the bodies from the ruins. From the time of the accident, which...
lead_paragraph: The inquest in the case of the parties who died by the Grand-street catastrophe -- an account of which we published in yesterday's TIMES -- although appointed to be held at 11 o'clock A.M., yesterday, did not commence until 2 o'clock in the afternoon, owing to the delay in extricating one of the bodies from the ruins. From the time of the accident, which occurred at 4 1/2 o'clock on Thursday evening, until 11 o'clock the same night, a large number of workmen were employed, under the superintendence of Capt. WILLIAMSON, of the Fourteenth Precinct Police, and JAMES M. MCGREGOR, Esq., "Inspector of Unsafe Buildings," in removing the bricks and other rubbish which had fallen upon the unfortunate men. Owing to the danger of further prosecuting the work in the night time, at about 11 o'clock Thursday night the work was suspended until an early hour yesterday morning. A large force of workmen was then put on, and worked diligently until about 12 o'clock yesterday, when the body of THOMAS WHITE was found buried about twenty feet beneath the ruins. It was immediately conveyed to the Fourteenth Precinct Station-house, where the body of THOMAS DODWELL had been previously deposited.

abstract: -- Col. Thomas Kilby Smith, of the Fifty-fourth Ohio Regiment, (Zouaves,) whose gallant bravery at the battles of Pittsburgh Landing has been highly mentioned in the war bulletins the commanding officer, and upon whom devolved the command of Stewart's Brigade after that officer had fallen dangerously wounded, has been appointed Commandant of Corinth. Col. Smith is a member of the Cincinnati Bar, and has at various times filled important State and United States offices, among which was that of Marshal for the Southern District of Ohio, his native State. His earlier education, which was both of a military and academic character, was supervised by that old hero, Gen. Mitchel. Brave as a lion -knowing no fear -- and noble and high toned in all his actions and sentiments and, moreover, as chivalrous as the word itself, he is immensely popular with his men, who have frequently been heard to declare that "with their Colonel to lead them they would follow him anywhere just out of love for him." Recently his numerous friends have united in a testimonial of appreciation, in the presentation of a most magnificient sword and necessary equipments. It is needless to prophecy that it will never be tarnished, nor sheathed while a foe remains to be vanquished.

abstract: THE WATER-STREET CASE.--The "terrible Waterstreet murder" will be very apt to prove but another instance of the certain results following a life of degradation and dissipation. HONNORA, upon being questioned, gave the following explanation ...
lead_paragraph: THE WATER-STREET CASE. -- The "terrible Water-street murder" will be very apt to prove but another instance of the certain results following a life of degradation and dissipation. HONNORA, upon being questioned, gave the following explanation of the affair, for the truth of which we, of course, do not vouch: The deceased and her comrades were of the lowest rank in life; their surroundings were filthy, their lives debauched, and their constant beverage "forty-yard whisky" and "poor-man's gin." The man, JAMES WINTHROP, formerly kept the deceased as a housekeeper and "boss" over several girls, from whose life of shame he reaped a reward. CATHERINE, the deceased, was a confirmed drunkard, and for gin would do anything or go anywhere. Her constant inebrity rendered her unprofitable to WINTHROP, and after a row they separated, and he took to his arms and her place the girl HONNORA MORRISON. After a little CATHARINE returned to her old haunt, but in a lower position, that is she became simply one of the girls. Her old habits were strong upon her however, and she again became a burden upon the hands of the establishment. During one of her [???] she went home and to bed, the proprietor and HONNORA being at the time away from the house. Returning they learned from another girl, (also under arrest,) that CATHERINE was sick and in the depths of the "horrors." [???] this girl HONNORA entered the room, when CATHERINE begged for some gin, which she would have given her, but WINTHROP objected. That night she continued to rave and cry terribly. In the morning HONNORA visited her, took her from one bed to another, while she made up the one in which she had slept, and finding that her clothing was in a most filthy state, went to the shop where CATHERINE had pawned her breastpin for a pint of gin, and her only other chemise for a sixpence worth of the same article, and redeemed the garment, that she might have something decent to wear. HONNORA says that CATHERINE died undoubtedly with the horrors. She gave her not only no fluid or camphene, but she gave her absolutely nothing.HONNORA is young Irishwoman, uneducated and friendless. That she is a bad woman there is no doubt, but that she committed this particular offence is really a matter of grave question. When she was arrested she was not permitted to take her clothing or her shawl, and when our reporter saw her, she was barefooted and illy-clad, at the Tombs. Mrs. FOSTER, upon a representation of these facts, sent a messenger for her things, and will do what she can to make her comfortable.

abstract: SCARCITY OF SUPPLIES AT RICHMOND. -- A special meeting of the Richmond City Council was held last Saturday, to devise some plan to supply the beleaguered City with provisions. The President of the Council, as reported in the Richmond Examiner, of Monday, said that "there was but one railroad (the Danville) upon which the city could rely for transportation, the others being in the hands, of the enemy; that upon that road it was impossible to get freight carried; and that, if some means of relieving the wants of the city were not devised, the poorer classes would suffer actual starvation." There were provisions near by, it was said, in the country; but they did not come forward, because of the passport system, one speaker thought; but probably as much on account of the shinplaster system. In order to lessen the draft upon the supplies in the city, one member proposed that the "multitude of strange young men, without visible means of support, who loafed about the corners of the principal streets," be invited to leave Richmond, and to remain away; but this resolution was killed, on the ground that "some negro would get hold of it, and carry it over to the Yankees, and they (the Yankees) would think we (the rebels) were starving to death."
lead_paragraph: SCARCITY OF SUPPLIES AT RICHMOND. -- A special meeting of the Richmond City Council was held last Saturday, to devise some plan to supply the beleaguered City with provisions. abstract: INDICTMENTS FOR THE VIOLATION OF THE SUNDAY LIQUOR LAW QUASHED. In the Court of General Sessions on Friday, before City Judge McCUNN, the Matter of the People vs. JOHN SHIELDS, THOS. ...
lead_paragraph: INDICTMENTS FOR THE VIOLATION OF THE SUNDAY LIQUOR LAW QUASHED. -- In the Court of General Sessions on Friday, before City Judge MCCUNN, the Matter of the People vs. JOHN SHIELDS, THOS. WHATSON and JOHN MCPATRIDGE indicted for publicly keeping intoxicating liquors on Sunday, came to again on the motion to quash the indictments. Mr. HALL appeared for the people, and said he was not prepared to argue the motion, on the ground that he had not received the points in the case from the counsel for the defendants, and which he was required, by the rules of this Court, to give with his notice of motion, and asked an adjournment until the next term, especially since he had argued the question before Recorder HOFFMAN on a demurrer to some of the same class of indictments with Mr. SMITH, counsel for the liquor-dealers.

abstract: This town is to be rendered more famous than ever before. History shall hereafter tell of such a thing as the siege of Richmond. Fourteen months ago we little thought, while endeavoring to terrify the municipality into the construction of batteries on the roads to the Peninsula and the fords of the Chickahominy ...
lead_paragraph: This town is to be rendered more famous than ever before. History shall hereafter tell of such a thing as the siege of Richmond. Fourteen months ago we little thought, while endeavoring to terrify the municipality into the construction of batteries on the roads to the Peninsula and the fords of the Chickahominy, to protect the place against a coup de main from Washington, that so long after the date when it was believed the Southern army would have crossed the Susquehanna, they would play a part in a gigantic military operation for the final possession of the city and the State. Yet, should any reliance be placed on appearances, affairs are quietly settling on a regular siege of this poor old town, if MCCLENNAN does not otherwise decide. He will probably prefer it to any other occupation. His troops like anything better than battles. Since the fighting in the swamps, regiments ordered to reinforce him here mutiny, and have to be fired into, rather than leave the delights of Norfolk for what they call "the slaughter pen of the Chicanominy." Of disease and natural death, the things they would have most to dread in a siege of Richmond, they have no such horror. MCCLELLAN himself is an engineer. The event of his life was his presence at the siege of Sebastopol. Richmond resembles that celebrated stronghold in more military points than most people suppose. He may have a strong inclination to prove that he understands his art better than his masters.

abstract: By an arrival from Gen. BEAUREGARD's army, we learn that the evacuation of Corinth had utterly discomfited Gen. HALLECK's plans. His fortifications raised for the reduction of the place covered an area of 27 miles, and were all rendered useless by the masterly retreat of Gen. BEAUREGARD's army, which had gone five days before it was known to HALLECK, who is said to have raved like a madman when he heard of it. -- Richmond Examiner, 16th.

abstract: Herrick, Edward C; treasurer of Yale
snippet: Herrick, Edward C; treasurer of Yale
lead_paragraph: EDWARD CLAUDIUS HERRICK, formerly Librarian and recently Treasurer of Yale College, died at his residence, in New-Haven, after a brief illness, Wednesday afternoon, June 11, 1862, aged 51 years. He was the youngest child of Rev. CLAUDIUS and Mrs. HANNAH (Pierpont) HERRIOK and was born in NewHaven, February 24, 1811. His father, a graduate of Yale College, in the Class of l798, was settled as a Minister of the Congregational Church in Woodbridge, and after his retirement from that office, taught for many years a large private school for young ladies, in New-Haven. His father died when young HERRICK was about twenty years old, and from that time his mother made him her main counsel and support. He rewarded her confidence with a filial devotion rarely surpassed, and remaining unmarried, he kept house with her and for her until she died, about three years ago.

abstract: The Senate only was in session yesterday, the House having adjourned over from Friday until Monday. Several petitions for a General Bankrupt Law were presented.
lead_paragraph: The Senate only was in session yesterday, the House having adjourned over from Friday until Monday. Several petitions for a General Bankrupt Law were presented. A bill was reported from the Naval Committee authorizing the Navy Department to accept the title of League Island, below Philadelphia. A bill opening Post-offices in the insurrectionary districts was passed. The House bill, establishing certain post-roads, and authorizing a bridge to be constructed across the Ohio River at Steubenville, was debated at considerable length, and was finally recommitted to the Post-office Committee. The Secretary of War was directed to transmit to the Senate so much of the report of Hon. JOSEPH HOLT and ROBERT DALE OWEN on the subject of ordnance, as relates to the gun contract of SHUBARTH. Consideration of the Confiscation bill was postponed until Monday. The House bill, prescribing the oath for all persons hereafter holding officeunder the Government, was considered until the adjournment.

abstract: Our Paris correspondent,  in his letter published yesterday, said, that as each battle takes place in America, the French become more and more bewildered on the subject of iron-plated vessels as opposed to fortifications, and kindred problems.
lead_paragraph: Our Paris correspondent, in his letter published yesterday, said, that as each battle takes place in America, the French become more and more bewildered on the subject of iron-plated vessels as opposed to fortifications, and kindred problems. First, a proposition is proven by us, and the French accept it as definitive; then the next battle disproves it, and reverses the decision. First, it is shown to the satisfaction of France, that one iron ship is immeasurably and overwhelmingly superior in battle to all wooden ones. Frenchman sees the proofs, and admits that the thing is indisputable. That very moment we are quite ready to prove that wooden ships, (or, as the gallant Capt. BOGGS phrased it, "iron hearts in wooden ships") are superior to even iron-cased batteries. We show that stone forts are worthless in a contest with iron ships, and, we also prove, that no iron ship, or fleet of iron ships, can stand against the fearful weight of metal we throw from the enormous guns we have mounted on forts. We demonstrate the superiority of rams, and we show how they can be dodged or destroyed. In fact, we no sooner prove any given point than we demonstrate its opposite; till finally the only thing that seems certain is, that whatever is isn't. We have had the merit of being the first to illustrate these variant facts in the science of war, and hence they have called forth the general notice of the world.

abstract: We have seen it stated in several of the Northern papers that after the surrender of the First Maryland (Yankee) Regiment at Front Royal, the fraternization between them and the members of the First Maryland (Confederate) Regiment was of the most affectionate character, and robbed the battle which resulted in their annihilation "of half of its horrors."
lead_paragraph: We have seen it stated in several of the Northern papers that after the surrender of the First Maryland (Yankee) Regiment at Front Royal, the fraternization between them and the members of the First Maryland (Confederate) Regiment was of the most affectionate character, and robbed the battle which resulted in their annihilation "of half of its horrors." According to the account, they rushed into each other -- not with bloody intent -- but into each other's arms, and fell to hugging and hand-shaking all around. A fouler libel upon the patriotism of any set of men was never conceived or perpetrated. The facts were indisputably to the contrary, and we have them from a member of the Confederate regiment, a participant in the battle, and a witness of the grounding of the arms of the Yankees. The contempt evinced for them by their captors was most marked and emphatic; the Maryland renegades hanging their heads like whipped curs caught in a dirty business. If words were exchanged with them on the Confederate side they were words of hissing, scorn, contempt, and loathing, not of affection and regard. True, many of the members of the opposing regiments were known to each other, but if there were any recollections of "Auld Lang Syne" they were those that challenged a death-struggle at sight. Among the captive crew were the very men who had aided to drive their betters from their homes, the rowdies who had hunted them through the streets with "billy," pistol and "slung-shot," and who now cringed and begged for mercy and protection.
