abstract: The officers of one of our gunboats which arrived here yesterday from the Gulf coast, bring the important intelligence that the rebels are determined to hold Mobile, and make the final struggle there. Their breastworks defending the city are protected by ditches thirty feet in width, and they give forth that these are the last ditches they will dig, and that in them they propose to die. So, after much pains and searching, the last ditch is discovered. It is located just where we always supposed it would be -- on the very verge of the Gulf of Mexico. The ditch is doubtless of the kind known in military classification as a wet ditch, and communicates directly with the waters of the Gulf. Near by the outlet of the ditch, or, probably, sailing in it, there is doubtless a very fast sailing-vessel -- probably the Nashville -- in which the rebel leaders will take refuge about the time they should, according to the programme, be dying, and sail off to some other country to see if there cannot be discovered a ditch which comes a short distance after the last. MILTON says that beneath the lowest deep, there is a lower depth; and why shouldn't there be a hundred ditches after the last? We are glad, however, that the rebels have given its exact information of the geography of the last ditch on this continent. It is at Mobile. That is the reason, probably, that BEAUREGARD is making tracks in that direction.

We are glad, however, that the rebels have given its exact information of the geography of the last ditch on this continent. It is at Mobile. That is the reason, probably, that BEAUREGARD is making tracks in that direction.

abstract: Editorial on British press views
snippet: Editorial on British press views
lead_paragraph: We all of us know the British Bunsby. Some of us have seen and talked with him, and heard from him, face to face, those marvelous opinions in which native good sense is so crushed out by prejudice and ignorance that pity mingles with our inward laughter. But we all know him upon paper. For he always distinguishes himself by the profundity and solemnity of his platitudes upon American topics; and therefore on the breaking out of the rebellion he was immediately engaged, at any price, to write for all the London papers. For all, with one or two exceptions; and we expected, may we venture to say that we hoped, that the London Examiner was one of these. But we were doomed to disappointment. That paper, long and justly celebrated for eschewing the Bunsbian productions upon general subjects, he has at last successfully selected as the victim of his crowning effort, -- a profound article upon "The American Combatants."

abstract: The journals of the North are boasting mightily over the gallant bayonet charge made by the troops in the battle of the 31st ult. and the 1st inst. One account says: "A bayonet charge was ordered, when the rebels broke and run, leaving twelve hundred of their dead and wounded on the field;" and MCCLELLAN reechoes the assertion in his official report, when he says, "several gallant bayonet charges during the day," &c. Now, we have been at some pains, by inquiries among the hospitals to ascertain the truth or falsity of these assertions. Of the many wounded, not one in one hundred received their wounds by a bayonet thrust, but in several instances wounds of this nature were received by our men from their own ranks in a charge upon the batteries. In fact, bayonet wounds in this war, on the Confederate side at least, are remarkably rare, as all the surgeons at the hospitals will attest. We think we have the secret of this oft-repeated (on paper) "bayonet charges," and their non-performance on the field. It is to inspire the Yankee troops to the attempting of a charge whenever opportunity offers, supplying them at the same time with the truly logical reasoning that "whatever has been done by man can be done again."

abstract: We learn that the Prince of Wales has recently presented to Ex-President BUCHANAN a splendid full-length portrait of himself, as a slight mark (he says) of his grateful recollection of the hospitable reception and his agreeable visit at the White House on the occasion of his tour in the ...
lead_paragraph: We learn that the Prince of Wales has recently presented to Ex-President BUCHANAN a splendid full-length portrait of himself, as a slight mark (he says) of his grateful recollection of the hospitable reception and his agreeable visit at the White House on the occasion of his tour in the United States. He adds that the cordial welcome which was then vouchsafed to him by the American people, and by the Ex-President as their Chief, can never be effaced from his memory.

abstract: "A NEGRO IN THE FENCE." The Kings County Medical Society, among whose members are to be found some of the most conservative, learned and dignified of the disciples of Esculapius, was recently thrown into as much commotion as if one of Commodore FARRAGUT'S 13-inch bombs had been dropped suddenly into their midst.
lead_paragraph: "A NEGRO IN THE FENCE." -- The Kings County Medical Society, among whose members are to be found some of the most conservative, learned and dignified of the disciples of Esculapius, was recently thrown into as much commotion as if one of Commodore FARRAGUT's 13-inch bombs had been dropped suddenly into their midst. At a recent meeting of the Society,Dr. NORTH, a member in good standing, practicing in the Eastern District, gravely proposed Dr. REA for membership. The proposition took the usual course, and was referred to the Censors, who, in due course of time, put a few questions to Dr. NORTH as to the character and standing of Dr. REA, and the questions all having been answered satisfactorily, they reported in favor of admitting the outside brother in the profession to all the honors to be conferred by a close communion with so distinguished an organization as the Society aforesaid. At the last monthly meeting, just as the members present were about going through with the stereotyped form of balloting on the proposition to admit "Dr. REA," the worthy Health-officer of the city, Dr. J.B. JONES, who, by reason of his official position, has a more extended knowledge of the practicing physicians in the city than "any other man," thought he "smelt a rat," and springing to his feet, stated, much to the astonishment of some, at least, of the members present, that he knew of but one practicing physician in the city, bearing the name of the candidate, and that was a negro! He put the question to Dr. NORTH, to know if that Dr. REA was the candidate he had proposed, and was promptly answered in the affirmative. The scene that followed, it is impossible to describe, because there was no impartial reporter present to record what was said and done, and those who were present are not inclined to say much about what did transpire; but one thing is certain, Dr. JONES made a motion to lay all the proceedings, so far as had, upon the table, and it was carried. The question is a new one for the Society to handle, and may result as disastrously to the organization as it has before in other organizations -- religious, political, and scientific. What adds to the embarrassment of those who oppose the admission of the candidate is, that they cannot discover any clause in the Constitution or by-laws of the Society which prevents a negro from being recognized as a man and a brother, and under the enforcement of which, any applicant who comes up to the standard of qualifications required, can be kept out. At the next meeting Dr. NORTH may possibly propose the following as a motto for the Society: "Nulli ugabimus, nulli differemus, Justitiam." If adopted, the whole question is at once settled.

abstract: -- The Colt's Arms Manufacturing Company have just completed a pair of pistols of Colt's patent ordered by the President as a present on his private account to the King of Denmark. They are of the style called the "old model improved," the barrels eight inches long and the stock of the riches: blank walnut, elegantly carved in relief. All the iron and steel is completely covered with gold inlaid in beautiful arabesques, with representations of the mechanic arts, agriculture and commerce elegantly designed and executed. The gold used in these inlayings alone cost over $100. The trimmings to the weapons are of solid silver, also elaborately engraved, and on a shield inserted in the handle is an inscription: "From the President of the united States to the King of Denmark." The weapons are contained in a rosewood case heavily trimmed with silver. The case contains also a number of cartridges, a bullet mould and the necessary appendages, all of the richest description. The whole cost of this beautiful present is not far from $900.

abstract: Editorial speculates on duration of war
snippet: Editorial speculates on duration of war
lead_paragraph: There are two sets of theorists whose notions respecting the duration of the war will be likely to prove as fallacious as they are antagonistic. These speculators are the Bulls and the Bears of the rebellion. One party is always finishing up affairs in "thirty" or "sixty" days, while the other, as persistently, protracts the strife to an indefinite period. The one can see in secession but a sort of exaggerated Astor-place riot, while the other finds in its looming proportions the signs of no briefer struggle than another Thirty Years' War. One will have it things are to be settled by the sharp and sudden action, which disperses a mob, and which leaves the municipal authorities undisturbed in the assertion of all they claim to enforce; the other believes it destined that the war shall drag on through weary years, until the exausted combatants mutually agree to put up with half of the whole they have struggled for, and patch up a new Peace of Westphalia.

abstract: EDS. ENQUIRER: Upon what slight things hang the destinies of nations! Some score of years ago, a young Yankee schoolmaster came South and spent a year in one of the country sites in Middle Georgia.
lead_paragraph: EDS. ENQUIRER: Upon what slight things hang the destinies of nations! Some score of years ago, a young Yankee schoolmaster came South and spent a year in one of the country sites in Middle Georgia. The consequence of that visit was a mulatto child -- its father, Senator SEWARD, now Secretary of State! The way this became known, the Secretary himself told it to a Dr. R -------, of Georgia, last Summer, stating that he regretted the embargo on correspondence, as it prevented his hearing from his daughter and sending her money, which he had done every year for years! He went on to speak in such a way as to convey the idea that he turned Abolitionist and brought on the war in order to liberate his beloved daughter from the thraldom of Slavery! Well did PAULDING say that he was a venomous reptile burrowing in the mud, whose poison and power was unknown till he struck!

abstract: Rumors obtained currency in this City and elsewhere yesterday that a severe battle was progressing before Richmond -- one account having it that our left wing had been defeated, and another that the city had been captured. Late inthe evening, however, warrant came from Washington for the denial of all such reports -- nothing more serious having occurred than the usual skirmishing of the pickets, and the fighting which ordinarily results from reconnoissances. Indeed, a dispatch from Gen. MCCLELLAN, received at the War Department in the afternoon, dated at 2 1/2 o'clock, states that things had been pretty quiet during the day. The Commanding General further states that his preparations were progressing well.
lead_paragraph: Rumors obtained currency in this City and elsewhere yesterday that a severe battle was progressing before Richmond -- one account having it that our left wing had been defeated, and another that the city had been captured. The Commanding General further states that his preparations were progressing well.

abstract: Is there not  danger that BEAUREGARD and his immense Corinthian army may turn up again as suddenly, unexpectedly and mysteriously as they disappeared? He left Corinth three weeks ago or more, carrying, according to the indirect statement of Gen. HALLECK in his official dispatch, 120,000 men with him, while twenty ...
lead_paragraph: -- Is there not danger that BEAUREGARD and his immense Corinthian army may turn up again as suddenly, unexpectedly and mysteriously as they disappeared? He left Corinth three weeks ago or more, carrying, according to the indirect statement of Gen. HALLECK in his official dispatch, 120,000 men with him, while twenty National Generals and a hundred thousand National troops were watching him, and not a troop nor a General of them knew all that he had gone, till the premises were accidentally discovered to be vacated; nor could any one of them tell where he went to, nor, after nearly a month's search, can they discover where he now really is. Now, if he could slip away thus softly and undiscovered, while the eyes of HALLECK and a hundred thousand men were on him, would it not be a very easy thing for him to Slip back again, now that Gen. HALLECK is said to have gone on a visit to St. Louis, now that Gen. POPE is on a visit to Washington, now that Gen. BUELL is in East Tennessee, Gen. MITCHEL near Chattanooga. Gen. WALLACE at Memphis, and now that our army is scattered at numerous points under subordinate commanders? It would certainly be a good thing for the Argus-eyed commander of our Western Department to look to.

abstract: Editorial on reasons why national credit is good and stocks are high; Editorial on why national credit is good and stocks are high; editorial on proposal
snippet: Editorial on reasons why national credit is good and stocks are high; Editorial on why national credit is good and stocks are high; editorial on proposal
lead_paragraph: The high state of credit, and the pervading tone of confidence now manifest in the United States, is a great marvel to the financiers and political philosophers of the Old World; and we have seen nowhere among our own political writers any attempt to set forth the palpable facts of such credit and confidence, and assign a reason sufficient to account for the phenomena. At the beginning of the revolt against the Union, the London Times, in its zealous hostility to our Government, made haste to warn European capitalists against lending us money to carry on war. Our defeat was confidently predicted; and whatever debt we might contract in conducting hostilities would inevitably be repudiated so soon as we retired ignominiously from the contest!

abstract: editorials on report Beauregard is on way to Richmond and on possibility of Halleck moving from Corinth to reinforce McClellan at Richmond
snippet: editorials on report Beauregard is on way to Richmond and on possibility of Halleck moving from Corinth to reinforce McClellan at Richmond
lead_paragraph: The whole country has been puzzling itself with the inquiry as to what has become of BEAUREGARD's army, so lately at Corinth. The anxiety springs chiefly out of the fear that it may turn up at Richmond suddenly, to increase still further the numerical superiority of the enemy over the forces under Gen. MCCLELLAN. This anxiety would be relieved at once, if we knew that the Union army of the West was being employed in any way to operate as reinforcements to MCCLELLAN, by taking a part in the general programme of movements against Richmond. We propose calling attention to some facts which suggest the strong probability, at least, that such a movement is being made by Gen. HALLECK.

lead_paragraph: at last given us information of the whereabouts of that mysterious humbug, BEAUREGARD. On Tuesday last, he was at Montgomery, en route for Richmond. He would arrive at the rebel citadel by Thursday or Friday, if he did not halt anywhere on the way. We suppose he will not take chief command of the rebel army at Richmond, for Gen. LEE has just been appointed to that position. It is likely he will step, or has stepped into the shoes of Gen. Jos. E. JOHNSTON, who, as we learn from a rebel letter, was so severely wounded at the Seven Pines as to be incapacitated for duty. There is quite a show of proof that a good part of his late army at Corinth preceded him to the rebel Capital -- such as the fact that our soldiers before Richmond have captured or killed individuals belonging to regiments of which other individuals were captured or killed by our soldiers before Corinth [???] ago. Of the remainder of [???] southwestern army, the bulk [???] to [???] him to Richmond, [???] only [???] of men in Central Mississippi [???] the [???] have [???] in these [???] that the censorship down there is not half as strict as it might be. It is not likely that our Western army will go down to Central Mississippi during the hot weather to drive out the rebel force left there under "invincible BRAGG," and if not, there will be but a small part of it needed for operations in the Gulf States this Summer. The remainder will doubtless be put to effective use elsewhere. Active operations, on an extended scale, are now confined to Virginia.

abstract: The last week closed Opera, we should presume until it may commence in the approaching Fall, and closed it with such a mass of attractions on the Wednesday, for its low price of admission, as may well render next season prospectively, for managers, an arduous if not a dubious attempt. Madame BORCHARD in "II Trovatore," with BRIGNOLI, Madame D'ANGRI and AMODIO, Madame HERRMANN in a scene...
lead_paragraph: The last week closed Opera, we should presume until it may commence in the approaching Fall, and closed it with such a mass of attractions on the Wednesday, for its low price of admission, as may well render next season prospectively, for managers, an arduous if not a dubious attempt. Madame BORCHARD in "Il Trovatore," with BRIGNOLI, Madame D'ANGRI and AMODIO, Madame HERRMANN in a scene from "L'Elisir d'Amore," and GOTTSCHALK at the piano, were enough for musical attraction; while HERRMANN displayed to the audience the means of doing one of his tricks, and offered those who were present what they seemed to consider the greatest attraction of the evening. But in showing them how it was done, he did not give them the skill to do it, and consequently we fear that innumerable brass rings will be manufactured to very little purpose, being a decided advantage to the workers in metal, but very little to amateur magicians. Madame HERRMANN confirmed the favorable opinion we have already expressed of her, and if, as is, we hear, her intention, she goes to Milan to study, we have little hesitation in prognosticating a brilliant future for her.

abstract: Sunday passed without a battle before Richmond, though the imminence of one will be seen on a perusal of our dispatches. The two armies are in close proximity. There was brisk skirmishing all day Saturday, and at night everything indicated that a general engagement was at hand.
lead_paragraph: Sunday passed without a battle before Richmond, though the imminence of one will be seen on a perusal of our dispatches. The two armies are in close proximity. There was brisk skirmishing all day Saturday, and at night everything indicated that a general engagement was at hand. The rebels advanced in strong force on our lines during the night, but being promptly met, soon retired again. They are evidently afraid to take the initiative again, as at Fair Oaks. They endeavored to feel our entire line on Friday by shelling, but did not accomplish anything -- most of their shells falling short, and eliciting no response from our batteries. They will ascertain their positions with sufficient certainty when the proper time arrives. Our dispatches state that the Richmond papers of Saturday announce the arrival of BEAUREGARD and his Staff at Montgomery, Ala., on the way to the rebel Capital, and that a large part of his army of the Southwest was expected to follow.

abstract: THE POLICE AMONG THE MILKMEN MORE ARRESTS. In yesterday's TIMES we published an account of the way in which the authorities are executing the law in New-York and Brooklyn relative to the sale of impure or adulterated milk.
lead_paragraph: THE POLICE AMONG THE MILKMEN -- MORE ARRESTS. -- In yesterday's TIMES we published an account of the way in which the authorities are executing the law in New-York and Brooklyn relative to the sale of impure or adulterated milk. At an early hour yesterday morning there were further arrests made in the up-town Wards. In most instances the prisoners were discharged with a reprimand, and an assurance on the part of the Magistrate that if they were caught in the act of violating the law a second time the most severe penalty which is prescribed in the act would be imposed upon them. In Justice KELLY's Court the delinquents invariably plead ignorance of the law. That official will not, however, permit the second offence to go unpunished, neither will he a second time listen to the convenient excuse that the offenders did not or could not comprehend the law. Those brought before him yesterday, namely: JAMES BROWN, HENRY KUHF and PHILIP BUSICK, were severely reprimanded. In the Thirteenth Precinct, Officers COLLARD and YOUNG arrested three men named EDWARD RAYENSBURG, HENRY MEHLIG and EDWARD BANYERS, for the same offence. Justice STEERS held BANYERS to bail in the sum of $300; the other two were committed to prison to await the action of the Grand Jury.

abstract: We shall come out of the present war with fat more accurate ideas than we have hitherto had as to the true relations of the State Governments and the National Government. It is not only the Southern people that have held false doctrines on this head, for we have all had loose notions about it, and have been strangely at sea this generation or two. During the war, however, the question of Sovereignty has often come up in a practical form, and the mode in which it has been decided cannot fail to draw far more rigidly than has yet been done, the lines between State Rights and the National authority. The latest and one of the most interesting practical elucidations of the question is furnished by the dispute between the Governor of the State of Kansas and the Secretary of War, touching the authority possessed by the former over the volunteers from that State, enlisted in the National service. The legal opinion on this point of Mr. BATES, Attorney-General of the United States, will be found in another column.
lead_paragraph: We shall come out of the present war with fat more accurate ideas than we have hitherto had as to the true relations of the State Governments and the National Government. abstract: Yesterday was a memorable day in this city, for on it was held the first meeting of the citizens in favor of the Union. Free speech being inaugurated, may it never occur again that it will be treason to speak in favor of the Constitution and the flag of the Union in New-Orleans.

abstract: THE CONEY ISLAND RAILROAD. The Coney Island and Brooklyn City Railroad Company are now running their cars regularly starting one every eight minutes from Fulton Ferry to a point on Fifteenthstreet beyond the city line, and near Windsor Terrace, ...
lead_paragraph: THE CONEY ISLAND RAILROAD. -- The Coney Island and Brooklyn City Railroad Company are now running their cars regularly -- starting one every eight minutes from Fulton Ferry -- to a point on Fifteenth-street beyond the city line, and near Windsor Terrace, a distance of something more than four and a half miles. By Sunday next cars will run the whole length of the road to Coney Island, a distance of eleven miles from the place of starting. The route of this road is as follows: Leaving Fulton Ferry, on Water-street to Main, on Main to York, York to Jay, through Jay, Smith, Mill, Ninth-streets, Tenth-avenue and Fifteenth-street. The track is one of the best that has yet been laid for horse cars, and the equipments of the road throughout are new and after the most approved plans. There are at present eleven cars on the road, light, airy and pleasant, and as soon as the road is open to Coney Island twenty cars will be operated, and during the warm weather, four large double-decked excursion cars, with four horses each, will be run, in addition to the regular number, to accommodate the public. Cars were first placed upon this road in May, since which time the trade has increased fifty per cent. This road will in time be one of the best, in a pecuniary point of view, in the city. A portion of it now passes through a densely populated section of the city, and opens up for improvement some of the most healthy and pleasant localities for residences in the suburbs. As a route for pleasure riding it is equaled by none. For the most part it is free from dust, and passes through streets in the outskirts of the city studded with pleasant villas and grass plots and meadows on either hand, the whole distance to Coney Island, the attractions of which for sea bathing are too well known to render it necessary to describe at this time. The Company will commence to erect to-day extensive and permanent staples on Fifteenth-street, between Eleventh-avenue and the city line. One building alone will be 140 by 200 feet, capable of accommodating two hundred horses. The fare on the road will be regulated according to the distance traveled -- to Coney Island, 11 miles, 20 cents for adults; children half price; five cents and three cents to the city line, and proportionate rates for intermediate distances between the city line and Coney Island. The officers of the Company are: President -- JAMES A. VAN BRUNT, the present popular Alderman of the Eighth Ward; Secretary -- FRANCIS, G. QUEREDO, formerly Alderman of the Fifth Ward; Superintendent -- AUGUSTUS IVINS, the well-known omnibus proprietor.

abstract: The Senate only was in session on Saturday, the House having adjourned over from Friday until to-day. Several petitions for a General Bankrupt Law were presented. A bill was reported from the Naval Committee authorizing the Navy Department to accept the title of League Island, below Philadelphia. A bill opening Post-offices in the insurrectionary districts was passed.
lead_paragraph: The Senate only was in session on Saturday, the House having adjourned over from Friday until to-day. Several petitions for a General Bankrupt Law were presented. A bill was reported from the Naval Committee authorizing the Navy Department to accept the title of League Island, below Philadelphia. A bill opening Post-offices in the insurrectionary districts was passed. The House bill, establishing certain post-roads, and authorizing a bridge to be constructed across the Ohio River at Steubenville, was debated at considerable length, and was finally recommitted to the Post-office Committee. The Secretary of War was directed to transmit to the Senate so much of the report of Hon. JOSEPH HOLT and ROBERT DALE OWEN on the subject of ordnance, as relates to the gun contract of SHUBARTH. Consideration of the Confiscation bill was postponed until Monday. The House bill, prescribing the oath for all persons hereafter holding office under the Government, was considered until the adjournment.

abstract: The steamship North Star arrived at this port yesterday from Aspinwall, with the mails, passengers and treasure from California. The treasure list foots up $612,461. She brings interesting intelligence from Panama, and the other Colombian States. MOSQUERA has at last concluded, it appears, to bring the Isthmus under his own control. On the 5th inst., as before announced, a schooner arrived at Aspinwall bringing 80 soldiers, and on the 7th on additional force of 130 arrived in another schooner, all under command of Col. SANTACOLOMA. According to his first announcement, these troops were only to proceed through Panama on their way to Buenaventura. But the Governor of Panama having information that their object was to take Panama, requested Col. TOTTEN, agent of the Panama Railroad, not to give the troops transit. He then issued a proclamation calling on the citizens to arm themselves, and erected barricades throughout the city. Col. SANTACOLOMA subsequently sent a schooner to Carthagena for instructions and more troops. The Governor, at last finding he would not be able to enforce his policy, and a negro outbreak threatening, entered into a compromise by which the troops were to go over to Panama on the 14th inst. Everything continued quiet at Bogota at last accounts. MOSQUERA continued at Ambalema. More fighting had taken place between the Government forces and the insurgents under ARBOLEDA, but with no definite results.

abstract: We would gladly regard as foundationless a rumor that the bill providing for the enlargement of the Erie Canal Locks does not secure the hearty support of the New-England members of Congress, while it incurs the sturdy opposition of the Pennsylvanians. The indifference and the opposition must alike result from an imperfect appreciation of the enterprise.
lead_paragraph: We would gladly regard as foundationless a rumor that the bill providing for the enlargement of the Erie Canal Locks does not secure the hearty support of the New-England members of Congress, while it incurs the sturdy opposition of the Pennsylvanians. The indifference and the opposition must alike result from an imperfect appreciation of the enterprise. The project is neither sectional or local. As a development of the national defences, it looks as directly to the protection of New-England and Pennsylvania as it does to the protection of New-York. As a commercial measure, it serves no one State or district in preference to another; while its advantage to the National resources in its enlargement of trade and in the augmented tribute it will bring to the National treasury, give it unquestional claims to the support and approval of the entire nation. These considerations have been strikingly presented in the memorial which Mr. S.B. RUGGLES, as agent of New-York, has submitted to the President. From that important paper we presented several highly interesting extracts several days ago. In another column will be found others, stating with much clearness the close commercial intimacy between the East and the West, and the political value of the active interchange between the grain of the prairie and the fabric of the New-England factory. Mr. RUGGLES asserts that while New-York raises enough wheat to last its population four months out of the twelve, New-England grows only enough for three weeks' consumption of its population. The deficit in either case has to be supplied by the West, and the West has to be paid in the productions of Eastern manufacturing industry. The circulation thus established is the secret of that political unity which cordially subsists between the two sections. And to encourage that tendency to unity, nothing is so efficacious as the development of those means of intercourse which shall bring the shop of Massachusetts nearer to the corn-field of Illinois.

abstract: The number of magnificent steamships constructed of late by the ship-builders of New-York and vicinity for the China trade, deserves more than a passing notice. The success which has invariably attended American steamers in the waters of that Empire, have won for our mechanics the warmest ecomiums. It would seem that science and art have extended their aid more particularly in the construction of these vessels than others from the hands of the same builders, and the appreciation of the fact that their models, and the skill and ingenuity manifested in their erection, are regarded as of a superior order, is practically shown by late advices from that region, to the effect that these vessels have vanished, as it were, from those waters, the old-style heavy-built English craft, so common there a few years since.

lead_paragraph: As affairs now stand before Richmond, there is nothing for us but to possess our souls in patience yet a while. We have no longer to look forward to special military moves that must be made before action can begin -- for the work of preparation is now complete. Gen. MCCLELLAN has, to-day, all the men and all the material he will receive, wherewith to strike the last great blow at the Rebellion. The hour-glass is set, and the nation in breathless expectancy watches the sands fast running out. The instruments are tuned and tried; the performers only await the signal to begin the awful symphony of battle, belched from brazen throats.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, after the presentation of petitions, a bill providing for the admission of the State of Western Virginia into the Union was reported from the Committee on Territories.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, after the presentation of petitions, a bill providing for the admission of the State of Western Virginia into the Union was reported from the Committee on Territories. A bill to establish certain National Arsenals was reported from the Military Committee. A bill for the organization of Army Corps and Staffs attached to Divisions, was introduced and referred to the Military Committee. The bill for the better government of the Navy was passed, after the adoption of several amendments. A resolution calling for information relative to the exchange of prisoners, was passed. The bill providing for an additional oath of office, was passed, with only five dissenting votes. The Committee of Conference on the Tax bill made a report which was concurred in by the Senate. The House Confiscation bill was taken up, and pending a motion to substitute the Senate bill, the Senate went into Executive Session, and afterward adjourned.

abstract: At last the Pacific Railroad bill is through the Senate. It passed to-day at 4 o'clock, with sundry amendments, but none that will endanger its final success. The House will either agree to these amendments, or the differences will be amicably adjusted by a Committee of Conference.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Friday evening, June 20, 1862.

abstract: A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening, Alderman FRANKS, of the Sixth Ward, in the Chair. A batch of vetoes was received from the Mayor, as follows: He vetoes the resolution ...
lead_paragraph: A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening, Alderman FRANKS, of the Sixth Ward, in the Chair. A batch of vetoes was received from the Mayor, as follows: He vetoes the resolution directing the purchase of 150 copies of the Brooklyn City Directory for 1862-3, at an expense of $350, first because it cannot legally be done, and secondly because not more than 100 copies are required; also, the resolution directing the purchase of the Odeon, in the, Eastern District, for an armory, because, in his opinion, the building is not suitable for that purpose; and, as there is money enough appropriated, he thinks a good and substantial structure should be erected; also the resolution fixing the assessment district for the opening of Grand-street, from Bushwick-avenue to Metropolitan-avenue, confirming the same to the width of half the block on each side of the line of improvement, because the district is not large enough and does not cover all the property which should come within the district of assessment. The vetoes were laid on the table and ordered published.

abstract: We are informed that the paragraph from the Petersburgh Express, relative to a Yankee spy having been seen in this city, copied by us yesterday, is true, except that the place at which he was seen was the Exchange, and not the American, and in the parlor, instead of at the dinner table. His name is DENNISON. At Washington he was SEWARD's chief detective. He was recognized by the little daughter of Mrs. GREENHOW, who has been instructed by her mother, while in Washington, to make herself familiar with the faces of such characters. The shrewd rascal, it seems, recognized the little girl, at the same time that she discovered him, and when she ran to give the intelligence to her mother, he disappeared. This fellow is remarkable for his cleverness and cunning, and has no doubt before this put MCCLELLAN in possession of much that he desired to know. The event should be on admonition to our own detectives and guards -- and to the people generally. Let all be on the qui vive, and let every person who has the least atmosphere of doubt about him be required to give an account of himself.

abstract: Gov. JOHNSON has had a very interesting con- ference with Dr. R.B.C. HOWELL, of the First Baptist Church; Rev. C.D. ELLIOTT, of the Fe- male School; Dr. SEHON, of the Methodist Church; Rev. Mr. FORD, of the Baptist Church; Dr. J.T. KENDRICK, of the First Presbyterian Church, and Rev. W.D.F. SAWRIE, of the Methodist Church, all contumacious clergymen at Nashville.
lead_paragraph: Gov. JOHNSON has had a very interesting conference with Dr. R.B.C. HOWELL, of the First Baptist Church; Rev. C.D. ELLIOTT, of the Female School; Dr. SEHON, of the Methodist Church; Rev. Mr. FORD, of the Baptist Church; Dr. J.T. KENDRICK, of the First Presbyterian Church, and Rev. W.D.F. SAWRIE, of the Methodist Church, all contumacious clergymen at Nashville. He announced to them that he had made up his mind that they must take the oath of allegiance, and proceeded to argue the question with them like a father. He told them that the Government had guaranteed to them religious liberty and the right to worship God according to the dictates of their own consciences. It was a privilege enjoyed in no other land. They were highly and peculiarly favored above their brethren. The Government had given them ample protection. But the time had come when this kind and liberal Government was compelled by traitors to fight for its existence, and it must know who were its friends and who were its foes. It was unreasonable to suppose that it would suffer rebels and disloyal men to occupy a position which offered so many opportunities for mischief to corrupt and designing men, as the pulpit. At the urgent request of the clergy, he gave them a few days for deliberation.

abstract: TOKENED. The Charleston Mercury of the 7th inst. informs us that its "Hoe press," on which it printed the vast number of 4,800 copies daily, beside a country edition 4,032 strong, has been removed from Charleston to ...
lead_paragraph: TOKENED. -- The Charleston Mercury of the 7th inst. informs us that its "Hoe press," on which it printed the vast number of 4,800 copies daily, beside a country edition 4,032 strong, has been removed from Charleston to Columbia, 130 miles in the interior. The cause of this movement of the Mercury is that there is a storm brewing near by, under the supervision of Gen. HUNTER, which is likely soon to break over the head of the devoted city -- in other words, as it says. "We must remove beyond the danger of bombardment." We are sorry that the Mercury has run away. Gen. HUNTER, if we mistake not, could even now drop a shell into the building in which it is printed; and if he had the range of the place, it would not be a bad thing to do for of all the malign agencies used to [???] the Southern heart, the Charleston Mercury was the chief. For the few day in which the paper is to [???] Charleston, it will be printed on a [???] which, we should thing would be[???] strike off the petty [???]which the [???] claims to have. It is [???] also means to die in defenced [???], the editor of the Mercury does [???], but we hope Gen. HUNTER will be quick enough to catch him before he escapes from the city. It is a great pity now that HUNTER has lost that "fast Hoe press."

abstract: Our Government has much more forecast than people suppose. While this very paper was urging the importance of providing clothing for the Fall and Winter campaigns, the Confederate authorities had already dispatched Maj. JAS. B. FERGUSON, of the Quartermaster's Department, amply supplied with funds, to various points in the South for the purpose of purchasing all the material for clothing that can be found. If our soldiers suffer for clothing, it will not be the fault of the Government -- unless, indeed, the Government neglect to stimulate and foster the production of material. Purchase, at liberal prices, is not enough. Every loom in the country should be set going, and they will be. The State authorities and the people will help their Government. Our soldiers must be clothed.

abstract: NIBLO'S GARDEN. For the first time during her present engagement Miss CAROLINE RICHINGS appeared as Marie, in the "Daughter of the Regiment."
lead_paragraph: NIBLO's GARDEN. -- For the first time during her present engagement Miss CAROLINE RICHINGS appeared as Marie, in the "Daughter of the Regiment." The piece, as brought out by her, is a drama, founded on the opera of the same name, but with nearly all the music -- save that of the heroine and a few choruses -- eliminated. There is no part of all her repertory in which Miss RICHINGS appears to so much advantage as in Marie. She acts in it with archness and piquancy, where archness and piquancy are required, and with a very natural shade of pathos in such scenes as border on the sentimental. She sings the music with the most finished grace and brilliancy, and she looks handsome enough to be the pet of any regiment in the world. It is rarely that the famous "Music Lesson," in the second act is given with finer effect, and when she breaks joyfully away from that into the recitative and cavatina "Salut a la France," her audience fairly became electrified into the wildest exhibitions of enthusiasm. In addition to the change of drama, a new ballet was produced, called "The Star of the Dance, wherein La Signorina GALLETTI executes some of her most complicated and attractive choregraphic evolutions, assisted by Mlle. KATRINA and a sufficient corps de bailet.

abstract: DEMANDED. The Senate has the project of a General Bankrupt law upon its calendar for consideration this week.
lead_paragraph: DEMANDED. -- The Senate has the project of a General Bankrupt law upon its calendar for consideration this week. The bill, we understand, has been discreetly framed so as to guard the creditor against disloyal and fraudulent debtors; while it affords the merchant, wrecked in the terrible breakers of this rebellion, the relief to which justice and mercy equally entitle him. No more righteous act of legislation than this can engage the remaining hours of Congress. It is demanded with singular unanimity by the entire business community. Creditors and debtors alike petition for it; for in the ability of the embarrassed business man to resume his traffic both creditor and debtor see the only chance for the payment of debts not otherwise payable, and the restoration of vigorous activity to trade. It is to be hoped the flippant disregard with which one branch of Congress has already dismissed the subject, will not be repeated. Let the bill be carefully considered, but let it surely be passed.

abstract: editorial on Lincoln policy
snippet: editorial on Lincoln policy
lead_paragraph: The reply made the other day by Mr. LINCOLN to the address of the "Progressive Friends," affords profound spiritual comfort to the Journal of Commerce and other prints of the Union-as-it-was confession. The President declined to meet the wishes of the Committee by issuing an immediate, indiscriminate and comprehensive decree of emancipation; therefore the President has strong antipathies for the radicals, refuses to identify himself with the moderate, conservative interest, and discloses his marked preference for those who would put Slavery back just where it was before it begot rebellion. In other words, deserting the party which raised him to office, and ignoring the common sentiment of the loyal North, Mr. LINCOLN has now filed a declaration of principles which distinctly identifies him with the Pro-Slavery reconstructionists.

abstract: editorial calls Vicksburg only obstacle in navigation of Mississippi River
snippet: editorial calls Vicksburg only obstacle in navigation of Mississippi River
lead_paragraph: rebel snag interfering now with the free navigation of the Mississippi River is the town of Vicksburgh. Our boats struck against it very unexpectedly, when they were dashing up the Father of Waters in the most triumphant style. The invincible fleet of Commodore FARRAGUT, which had blown to pieces all the rebel gunboats, fireships and forts near the mouth of the stream, and captured all the towns on the river as far up as Vicksburgh, was stopped short, and turned tail and went down the river again, after taking a look at this Mississippi town. The gun and mortarboats of Commodores FOOTE and DAVIS, which did such brave work at Island No. 10, at Fort Pillow, and above Memphis, and which, we were given to understand after the capture of Memphis, were not to pause in their victorious course down stream until they hailed the up-coming fleet from New-Orleans -- even they, it seems, have not thought it best to go to Vicksburgh. And so, from the mouth of the Arkansas to Vicksburgh, a distance of two hundred miles, the Mississippi River, which we all thought weeks ago was entirely ours, is still controlled by the rebels. We do not think, however, that Vicksburgh will be a very difficult snag to root out or to break down, and we do not imagine that the country will need to wait very long now for its reduction, and the consequent opening of the river. Our New-Orleans fleet only turned back from Vicksburgh that it might return to it again in such force as to compel it to succumb without making any ado about the matter; and of our up-river fleet, we learn that ELLET's rams have passed down to see if there is any butting needed near Vicksburgh. We suppose that some of FOOTE's old mortarboats have also gone down; and as part of PURTER's mortar fleet, lately at Mobile, has gone up, we shall doubtless soon see warm work at Vicksburgh, or else we shall behold, what the military commandant there said we never should behold, the surrender of another Mississippi town. Vicksburgh is the most important point in the State of Mississippi for us to hold. The possession of it will not only give us a clear sweep of the river, but will also put us within short railroad distance of Jackson, which is the Capital of the State, and the key to the very simple system of Mississippi railroads. It was wise not to attack it when the attack might cost us a good deal, if in a short time we could capture it at a cost probably of nothing.

abstract: At an early hour on Sunday morning last, a German named PETER GIEB, was brutally assaulted, knocked down, and afterward beaten to such an extent that he died of the injuries thus inflicted about 4 ...
lead_paragraph: At an early hour on Sunday morning last, a German named PETER GIEB, was brutally assaulted, knocked down, and afterward beaten to such an extent that he died of the injuries thus inflicted about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon. From all that could be learned at the Eleventh Precinct Station-house, and from persons in the immediate vicinity of the place where the outrage was committed, it appears that the deceased was standing quietly upon the sidewalk in front of the oyster-saloon of P. KELLAR, No. 252 Third-street, between 3 and 4 o'clock on Sunday morning, when three or four men came rushing out of the saloon. One of them was without a hat, and he, seeing the deceased standing on the walk, went up to him, and in a threatening manner demanded his hat. To this demand GIEB paid no attention, whereupon one of the parties struck him a violent blow on the forehead or temple, which, is not at present known. He was knocked down, and in falling, the buck and side of his head struck upon the sharp edge of the curbstone. It is also said that GIEB was beaten by one or two of the parties after he had fallen, but as to this we cannot speak positively. The unfortunate man man was soon after taken to his residence, No. 127 Willet-street, by the Eleventh Ward Police, and a physician called to attend him. An examination of the wounds showed that his skull was fractured in several places and that he was otherwise seriously injured; so much so, that his physicians, from the first, pronounced his case a hopeless one. He lingered in an insensible state, most of the time, until yesterday afternoon. His neighbors say that he was a quiet, inoffensive man, and was never known to be in difficulty with any one. He has left a wife and one child.

abstract: The Slave-trade has received another severe blow in the trial and conviction of APPLETON OAKSMITH, of this City, of fitting out a vessel for that traffic.
lead_paragraph: The Slave-trade has received another severe blow in the trial and conviction of APPLETON OAKSMITH, of this City, of fitting out a vessel for that traffic. It comes, too, in a direction where it was very much needed. The execution of GORDON was a stroke, the influence of which could not fail to be felt by all who were or might be engaged in the infamous traffic, as actual perpetrators. But these were not the only class whom it was desirable to reach. Desperate men might still be found who would put their lives in their hands for gain, and who would incur the hazards to themselves as long as others could be found who would furnish the money and run the risk of the loss of property. The vessels and their outfits had been generally furnished by parties who remained safely on shore themselves, and whom it was accordingly more difficult to connect with the enterprises. The outfits of vessels for the legal traffic to Africa differed so little from those of vessels bound for the slave markets, that unless a vessel actually took on board a cargo of negroes, it was very difficult to convict her, or the parties who fitted her out, of an illegal intent. But this very difficulty made it all the more important that the law should be able to reach some of these owners of slavers; and it is a fitting sequence to the trial and execution of GORDON, the slaver captain, that the owner of a slaver should in his turn expiate his offence by five years' imprisonment.

abstract: Gen. J.E.B. STUART rode into town Monday afternoon, and was paying his respects to the Governor, in a very quiet way, at the Executive mansion, when, it becoming known to the large crowd of strollers in the Capitol-square, who were looking on at the evolutions of the Second Class Militia, that the bold dragoon was near by, the building was immediately surrounded by an enthusiastic multitude vociferating for STUART. The gallant General in a few minutes made his appearance upon the portico and acknowledged the compliment paid him in a few remarks full of spirit and good cheer. Among other things he said he had been to the Chickahominy to visit some of his old friends of the U.S. army, but they very uncivilly turned their backs upon him. Seeing a manifest desire on the part of the crowd to make for him an ovation, the General then mounted his charger and galloped off amid the shouts of the crowd, which by this time had increased to more than a thousand persons.

abstract: a-dozen rebel Generals caged in Fort Warren now, and the number will in a day or two be raised to seven. At the fight last week on the White River, in Arkansas, HINDMAN, of that State. Gen. HINDMAN, the Commander- ...
lead_paragraph: a-dozen rebel Generals caged in Fort Warren now, and the number will in a day or two be raised to seven. At the fight last week on the White River, in Arkansas, HINDMAN, of that State, -- Gen. HINDMAN, the Commander-in-Chief of the forces of Arkansas -- he who but a few days ago issued a proclamation, directed against the army of Gen. CURTIS, which breathed forth threatenings and slaughter in a style that would have astonished the unconverted Paul, and in whichhe threatened that he would make the war in Arkansas a war of extermination -- this ferocious rebel was taken captive. So far as he personally was concerned, it seems, he did not care about lighting till he was exterminated. After this we do not see how he can consistently call on other Arkansians to fight till they are exterminated; we do not see that he can prohibit them from surrendering when they cannot help themselves. HINDMAN is the only Arkansas General who has [???] at all in the war; and he has not figured very prominently.

abstract: EXHIBITION OF STRAWBERRIES. Of the twenty contributors, only about half brought their fruits in on Monday morning, and the award of premiums being made at 11 o'clock, the large collections which came ...
lead_paragraph: EXHIBITION OF STRAWBERRIES. -- Of the twenty contributors, only about half brought their fruits in on Monday morning, and the award of premiums being made at 11 o'clock, the large collections which came in the afternoon had no change for competition. Messrs. HEINS, MARSHALL, WILLIAMS, GOLDSMITH, FULLER and some others were in time, and of these MARSHALL had the largest collection; but the greatest, comprising seventy-two varieties, from PRINCE & Co., of Flushing, and some others, did not arrive till 4 P.M. In the Marshall collection were the Wilson, Prince's Magnate and Climax, River's Eliza, Triomphe de Gand and longer-known McAvoy's Red, Coles Prolific, Black Prince, Brighton Pine, Genessee, Gen. Havelock, Duc de Bralant, Willey, Jenney's Seedling, Delices d'Antonine, Early Scarlet, Ohio Mammoth, Fillbasket, Walker, Ward's Favorite, Charlton's Prolific, Monroe Scarlet, Scott's Seedling and Bicton Pine, with scarlet fruit. Messrs. BURGESS and HEINS had a number of varieties of large size. PARSONS & Co. exhibited Cutter's Seedling and Triomphe de Gand. Mr. FULLER had Trollope's Victoria, Triomphe de Gand and several other large varieties. PRINCE's collection comprised the Margueritte, Oscar, Le Baron, Ambrosia, Victorine, Wizard of the North, La Constante, Empress, Emma. Triomphe de Gand, La Sullane, Duc de Malakoff, Austin, Orb, Lenning's White, Scarlet Magnate, Welcome, Lucas and a number of very superior seedlings, eight varieties of the A pine Monthly and Hautbois, with a host of others. Rev. L.M. PEASE exhibited some of the finest berries, but too late for premiums. This exhibition is a great success. The Patent-office Agricultural Report will contain descriptions of all the finest varities.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday petitions for the immediate passage of a Bankrupt law were presented. A resolution was adopted instructing the Judiciary Committee to inquire into the statements, evidence, , of JOSEPH WEBB and ROBERT DALE OWEN in regard to arms contracts.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday petitions for the immediate passage of a Bankrupt law were presented. A resolution was adopted instructing the Judiciary Committee to inquire into the statements, evidence, &c., of JOSEPH WEBB and ROBERT DALE OWEN in regard to arms contracts. A bill making an appropriation for the payment of bounties to the volunteer force was reported from the Finance Committee, but is consideration was postponed until to-day. Mr. GRIMES, of Iowa, made a speech in favor of establishing a Naval depot on League Island, below Philadelphia. The Confiscation measures were then debated until the adjournment. During the debate the Vice-President laid before the Senate; message from the President, vetoing the bill authorizing the issue of small notes in the District of Columbia.

abstract: Stanly speaks, Washington, NC, urging peace
snippet: Stanly speaks, Washington, NC, urging peace
lead_paragraph: The speech of Gov. STANLY, which was delivered at Washington, N.C., on the 17th inst., before the great Union Mass-meeting, was full of moderation and eloquence, and it may be pronounced one of the finest productions of the day. It was received with the atmost satisfaction by both the Federal troops and the citizens of the Old North State, who were present from seventeen counties.

abstract: The new commander of the United States troops in and around Washington, Gen. SAMUEL D. STURGIS, is one of the ablest disciplinarians in the army, and it is for this specialty he was probably appointed to his present position.
lead_paragraph: The new commander of the United States troops in and around Washington, Gen. SAMUEL D. STURGIS, is one of the ablest disciplinarians in the army, and it is for this specialty he was probably appointed to his present position. He is a graduateof West Point, and after completing his studies at that institution, in 1846, was admitted to the rank of the Second Dragoons, as a Second Lieutenant, by brevet. His promotion was rapid. He became a First Lieutenant, Captain and Major successively, the last in May, 1861, since which time he has risen to be a Colonel and a "General," by brevet, of course Gen. STURGIS is a native of Pennsylvania, and has never interfered in politics.

abstract: cision of Judge SMALLEY's, in the United States District Court, which is of interest to importers and to all parties who have business to transact at the Custom-house. It appears that Mr. LULING, of this City, entered sugars at the Custom-house for warehouse, and afterwards offered an export entry of them. This was refused at the Custom-house because, as it was claimed, the goods had been fraudulently undervalued in the previous entry. The goods were thereupon seized by the Collector, and a suit was instituted to forfeit them for the undervaluation. The claimant then proposed to give bonds to the Court for the value of the goods. Judge BETTS decided, on motion, that the amount of the bonds should be the value of the goods, without the duties and bonds to this amount were given, and a renewed application was made to enter them for export; but it was again refused, the Collector taking the ground that the goods were still in custody of the Court, because, although bonds had been given for their value, yet it was necessary, in order to their discharge, that the claimant should file a certificate that the duties had been "paid or secured to be paid," which certificate he declined to give to the claimant. The claimant then procured a certificate to be signed by a Deputy-Collector, at the Custom-house, which contained these words, and filing it with the Court, obtained an absolute order of discharge, and the Marshal thereupon discharged the goods from custody, so that the reason given by the Collector for refusing the export entry no longer existed. But it was claimed that the the Deputy-Collector, when he signed the certificate, did so inadvertently, thinking it was to be used for a different purpose,and thus that it was unauthorized, and thereupon this motion was made on behalf of the United States to take that certificate off from the files as improperly given, and to set aside the order of discharge.

abstract: of Gen. BEAUREGARD has been one of the most pleasing and intricate problems of the war. At no given time has it been possible to fix the place of that volatile warrior. He is no sooner reported at Richmond than he turns up at Atlanta, and at the date of his latest general order at Corinth, is known, technically speaking, to be at Charleston. He has barely assumed command of a powerful army somewhere, when he is found at the head of a powerful army somewhere else. At no moment can the most observant place a metaphorical linger upon him. The attempt only proves that he is not there.
lead_paragraph: of Gen. BEAUREGARD has been one of the most pleasing and intricate problems of the war. At no given time has it been possible to fix the place of that volatile warrior. abstract: A LARGE FIRE IN THE EIGHTH-AVENUE SEVERAL DWELLINGS BURNED LOSS ABOUT $10,000. About  1 o'clock, yesterday morning, a fire was discovered in the cellar of the two-story frame-house, No. Eighth-avenue, which building was soon consumed. From this the flames extended each way to the adjoining buildings, until all of the houses, from No. 631 to No. 645, both inclusive, were burned to the...
lead_paragraph: A LARGE FIRE IN THE EIGHTH-AVENUE -- SEVERAL DWELLINGS BURNED -- LOSS ABOUT $10,000. -- About 1 o'clock, yesterday morning, a fire was discovered in the cellar of the two-story frame-house, No. [???] Eighth-avenue, which building was soon consumed. From this the flames extended each way to the adjoining buildings, until all of the houses, from No. 631 to No. 645, both inclusive, were burned to the ground. The houses were principally of wood, and owing to the combustible nature of the contents there was no staying the progress of the fire, notwithstanding the fact that a large number of firemen were early on the ground. Nos. 635, 637, and 639 were owned by GEORGE HERRICK, as a grocery store and dwelling. His loss is about $1,500. He is insured for $2,000 in the New Amsterdam Insurance Company. CATHARINE HOGAN occupied a portion of No. 635 as a millinery store. Her estimated loss is from $300 to $460. She is insured for $1,200 in the Brevoort and Brooklyn Insurance Companies. Nos. 631 and 633 were occupied by A.P. SMITH. His damage is, perhaps, $300. He is insured for $1,000 in the Brevoort Insurance Company. Buildings No. 641, 643, and 645 were owned by Alderman IRA E. ALLEN. One of the occupants of the latter building, named GEORGE MCCORD, was much damaged -- to what extent could not be ascertained. He is insured in the Fireman's Insurance Company for about $6,000. Mr. N.W. GUINNEVAN occupied No. 639 as a furniture store. His damage to stock was about $800. He is insured for $1,000 in the Rutger's Insurance Company. Mr. LOUIS EADENBECKER occupied No. 641 as a confectionery store. His loss on stock and furniture will amount $600, upon which he has no insurance. HENRY BEHEMANN occupied No. 643 1/2. His goods were very much damaged. He has an insurance of $300. Mr. WILLET MCCORD, of No. 645, had his stock of clothing damaged to the extent of about $300. He is insured for $800 in the Gebhard Insurance Company. DANIEL DEMPREY occupied the upper part of several of the buildings. He lost considerable of his stock and furniture, upon which he has an insurance for $260 in the Rutger's insurance Company. There are quite a number of other tradesmen, whose names we could not obtain, who suffered considerably by this fire. The second floors, of nearly all the burned buildings, where occupied by poor families who lost the most of their little property, and barely escaped with their lives, from the fact that the fire occurred at a time when all were in their beds. Owing to the efforts of the firemen, and the vigilance of the Twenty-second Precinct Police, a large amount of valuable property was saved, though some of it in a damaged condition, both from fire and water. The estimated total loss is about $10,000.

abstract: By the arrival of the Arabia at Halifax, and the Etna at this port, we have advices from Europe to the 15th inst., eight days later than previously received. The news is important. Questions had been put in both Houses of Parliament relative to the rumors of mediation in America, and Goa. BUTLER'S proclamation regarding the ladies of New-Orleans. Earl RUSSELL and Lord PALMERSTON said the mediation rumors were unfounded.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the Arabia at Halifax, and the Etna at this port, we have advices from Europe to the 15th inst., eight days later than previously received. The news is important. Questions had been put in both Houses of Parliament relative to the rumors of mediation in America, and Gen. BUTLER's proclamation regarding the ladies of New-Orleans. Earl RUSSELL and Lord PALMERSTON said the mediation rumors were unfounded. No propositions on the subject had been made, and there were no present intentions of such a step. Gen. BUTLER's proclamation was denounced, and the hope expressed that the United States Government would disavow it. The cotton market was buoyant, and prices 1/4d.@3/8d. higher. Sales of the week, 84,000 bales. Friday's sales were 7,000 bales, closing at the advance above noted. Breadstuff's were firmer and a trifle higher on Friday. Provisions were firmer. Consols 91 3/8@91 3/4. The bullion in the Bank of England had decreased £450,000. The first intimation of the defeat of the French troops before Puebla had been received, and it was semi-officially announced that reinforcements were to be sent to Mexico immediately.

abstract: French and British press observations
snippet: French and British press observations
lead_paragraph: Battles -- great battles -- are about to be fought in America, and perhaps have been fought already, at the very moment we are writing. It is impossible, in fact, for the armies of the North, and the armies of the South, in presence of each other at Corinth and at Richmond, not to come to blows. Deluges of blood will be shed, and, what is more sad to contemplate, whatever the issue may be, these terrible encounters do not promise a solution to the actual crisis, either for America or for Europe. The victory, no matter on what side, will not be attended with any final result.

abstract: editorial expresses surprise, questions reason for visit
snippet: editorial expresses surprise, questions reason for visit
lead_paragraph: The announcement of President LINCOLN's passage through New-York, on the way to West Point, occasioned yesterday a, profound feeling of surprise. Ingenuity was utterly defeated in the effort to interpret the object of the sudden journey -- a general impression that it was to borrow the military counsel of Gen. SCOTT that the President seized this moment to leave Washington, affording the only probable solution of the mystery. Gen. SCOTT is rusticating in the shadow of the Highlands. His health is too seriously shaken to admit of a trip to the Capital, there to afford the Government the results of his invaluable experience and calm sagacity; and the obvious alternative is for the Government to wait upon the veteran. Here, for the present, must be the limit of guess-work, touching this unexpected and obscure Presidential progress.

abstract: The British Government has once more, through its official spokesmen, in each House of Parliament, made solemn and emphatic renewal of its determination to preserve a strict neutrality between the contestants in the great struggle on the American Continent.
lead_paragraph: The British Government has once more, through its official spokesmen, in each House of Parliament, made solemn and emphatic renewal of its determination to preserve a strict neutrality between the contestants in the great struggle on the American Continent. These mile-stones by the way are useful and reassuring, and never more so than at the present moment. Rumors of intervention, in the form of mediation, have, of late, been again rife -- a flock of "noisome and timorous birds, prognosticating a day of sects and schisms." What availed it that great successes over the whole field of war gave pledge of its speedy termination in the crushing of the rebellion and the restoration of the Union, if foreign jealousy would see in this all the more reason for stepping in and baulking a result it fears? It is not to be denied, the conviction is not altogether baseless that the moment of the greatest danger of interference from abroad is precisely that when plainly our triumph draws nigh. If there exist in the breasts of European statesmen a desire to secure the permanent division of the United States -- and without doubt this desire forms one of the elements in the complex web of wishes, hopes and fears entering into the Old World statesman's calculation -- now is the moment when it must press with the greatest weight.

abstract: THE STRAWBERRY CARNIVAL. The strawberry carnival was at its height last week, and would have continued through the present, weather permitting. At no time within the memory of the oldest inhabitant, has the delicious strawberry been so abundant or so cheap as during the present season. The number of distinct varieties, too, is remarkable, and all have, as a general rule, reached the market in good condition.
lead_paragraph: THE STRAWBERRY CARNIVAL. -- The strawberry carnival was at its height last week, and would have continued through the present, weather permitting. At no time within the memory of the oldest inhabitant, has the delicious strawberry been so abundant or so cheap as during the present season. The number of distinct varieties, too, is remarkable, and all have, as a general rule, reached the market in good condition. Of course, this being the fact, all classes have had their fill of the fruit, and it has been for ten days past one continous strawberry carnival. People not satisfied with eating a quart each at home for supper must needs spend their spare change to visit some public entertainment in the evening, where the chief [???] presented to tempt the appetite, would be the inevitable strawberry, the dishes dressed off with a little cream and a piece of cake. Strawberries here, strawberries there, strawberries everywhere. Festivals to do homage to strawberries, were given in the churches, festivals were inaugurated at the Academy of Music; festivals were interpolated into the school exercises, and even the eleemosynary establishments have not escaped the deluging shower of strawberries and cream. The [???] looked on in despair, while their meats were spoiling on the hooks for the want of purchasers. There was nobody to eat, nobody to buy meat. It was all strawberry -- strawberries in the mouth, strawberries in the eye, strawberries in the ear, strawberries to the smell, touch and to handle. Strawberries were uppermost in the mind upon retiring to rest and the first thought that shot through the brain at the dawn of day. Some people had laid themselves out extensively to continue the carnival, but the rain has set in, fortunately, so as to give the people a breathing spell. By many this is considered a providential interposition

abstract: Editorial compares material condition of North and South
snippet: Editorial compares material condition of North and South
lead_paragraph: There is hardly any point in which a comparison between the North and the South is devoid of interest, or where the results of a comparison do not show abundantly how utterly foolish was this rebellion. If we look at the number of soldiers only, this will be so; but even numbers are not of the first importance. In the sinews of war, in munitions, in artillery, in supplies of every kind, there is hardly any comparison to be instituted between the two sections. So, too, in the effects which the war has produced. One traveling through the North finds but little token of an impaired prosperity. He finds the laborer in the fields and the cities, as bustling and noisy with trade as ever. Some signs of war he sees in the number of uniforms which he meets everywhere, and the columns of the newspapers show that the war is the paramount object of interest. But the people are cheerful and happy; they bear the burdens and the anxieties which the war brings upon them lightly. The feeling of public calamity necessarily connected with war is swallowed up in love of country and of the cause. How is it at tho South? Universal testimony tells us that the case is exactly reversed. Through large tracts of country the lands are going to waste for lack of labor. A National Captain who was taken at Bull Run and sent South, than brought back to Richmond, and then sent to Salisbury, N.C., writes, that on this trip the crowds at the stations "were dull and silent. Every one that spoke said 'I wish the war was over.' It begins to look dark to them." A Union man, who escaped through Tennessee some months ago, said that the people there had come to speak universally in suppressed tones, and not a hopeful man was to be seen. abstract: Proceedings; Commencement
snippet: Proceedings; Commencement
lead_paragraph: The Commencement exercises of Nassau Hall, the third oldest College in America, are in progress this week. Yesterday, at 11 A.M., the members of the Whig and Cliosophic Societies met in the Chapel of the College, and proceeded to the First Presbyterian Church, where the exercises were held. The President of the College, Rev. Dr. JOHN MACLEAN, D.D., presided, and introduced the orator of the day, Rev. T.L. CUYLER, a graduate of the College and a member of the Cliosophic Society, which, by rule, was entitled to the orator of the day.

abstract: mond Dispatch of last Saturday, in noticing the impatience of the rebel army for the combat, remarks: "Our men (the rebels) are burning to distinguish themselves. They treat the foe with profound contempt in any and every arm of the service." And further on, the same journal says that the "Federal troops feel in no hurry to attempt the capture of Richmond, for they are aware that the best blood of the South is ready to be shed in its defence." In these statements is undoubtedly to be discovered the whole secret of the recent movements of the rebels, which have so mystified mankind. It was the profound contempt of the "best blood" which flowed in the veins of the enormous rebel host under BEAUREGARD which led it to march contemptuously away from the region polluted by the presence of our Western troops. The flight of Gen. LOVELL and his high-blooded rebels from New-Orleans was only an indication of their contempt for the plebeian, Gen. BUTLER. The evacuation of Memphis by the rich-blooded rebels who lately occupied it, was only because they would not deign to walk the streets trodden by our soldiers. Gen. HINDMAN, of Arkansas, surrendered to Col. FITCH last week, either because he had too profound a contempt for the Ex-Senator to [???] his blade with Yankee blood, or else because he was not willing to lose any of his own precious liquor. And so in a hundred other recent cases of rebel manoeuvering and skedaddling; they were all out of contempt for us. It would not astonish us if the already profound contempt of the rebels at Richmond grow so very profound ere long that they could not think of fighting our troops at all,but should withdraw in a dignified and contemptuous manner to a more airy situation. We had thought that the contempt for Northern soldiers was pretty well extracted from the rebels by this time. But it seems that it is strong as ever; and that all past lessons have taught them nothing. We venture to say that if they remain at Richmond much longer, the element of profound contempt will he effectually and finally extracted from their best blood. Not till that is done, will they become good democratic citizens.

abstract: Editorial on health of troops throughout country and effects of seasons and geographic locations
snippet: Editorial on health of troops throughout country and effects of seasons and geographic locations
lead_paragraph: of which during the last half year have been about as bad as could be, will rapidly improve, notwithstanding the advent of the hot weather, now that it has been removed from the unwholesome region around Corinth -- the malarious river bottoms of Southern Tennessee. That part of it stationed at Memphis will be in a fine, high, healthy region, which our troops in the deadly swamps of Cairo last Summer greatly longed to occupy. The column which has gone to East Tennessee will be in the very healthiest region of America -- among the hills and life-giving breezes of that romantic section; and if it pushes forward into Southwestern Virginia, it will find much the same conditions and climate. The troops required to Summer along the line of Northern Alabama and Mississippi, can now select positions with good sanitary conditions -- and there are plenty of such -- where the health of the men will be maintained and improved. The rebels fled from Corinth at a most opportune moment, in this point of view, for our army. Since it encamped in Southern Tennessee, five months ago, it lost five by disease to one by the enemy. But now neither the enemy nor malaria are likely to give it much more trouble.

abstract: THE ELEVENTH WARD HOMICIDE. The Coroner commenced the taking of testimony in this case yesterday afternoon. Officer ADEL D. HUNT, of the Eleventh Precinct, who made the arrest of MICHAEL MORAN, one of the parties suspected of having aided in the commission of the homicide, was examined at length by Coroner NAUMANN.
lead_paragraph: THE ELEVENTH WARD HOMICIDE. -- The Coroner commenced the taking of testimony in this case yesterday afternoon. Officer ABEL D. HUNT, of the Eleventh Precinct, who made the arrest of MICHAEL MORAN, one of the parties suspected of having aided in the commission of the homicide, was examined at length by Coroner NAUMANN. In addition to what has already been reported, Officer [???] testified "that when he took his prisoner before Justice STEERS on Sunday morning, he told the justice that he considered the man who had been knocked down, to be in a very dangerous condition, as he had not spoken since the affair occurred. A man named TRACY then stepped up to the Judge and said that the German who was struck had open in Court that morning. The Justice immediately sent an officer of the Court around to see if the man was seriously injured. When the Court officer returned, he reported to the Justice that he had seen the man said to be injured, and also the doctor who was attending him. The Court officer further stated to Justice STEERS that the doctor said the blow might have been caused by a club, or a fall, but that he did not think it anything more than a flesh wound. The justice then discharged my man, Dr. FREDERICK ROESLER. The physician who attended the deceased from the time of the occurrence till his death, then testified, among other things, that the man was insensible all the time; that his skull was seriously fractured, and that he took out a part of it. The Doctor further testified: "No one spoke to me about the condition of the man; at least, no officer of a Court." The inquest, not being concluded at a late hour last evening, it was further adjourned over till to-day, at the same place. The excitement in regard to the homicide, instead of abating, seemed rather to increase yesterday throughout the Eleventh Ward, and especially among those who are the same countrymen as the deceased.

abstract: Commencement
snippet: Commencement
lead_paragraph: Who originated the highly approved custom of College Commencements taking place in the floral season, we are not informed. The practice is, however, highly approved among the schools of learning, and the successful aspirants are not only crowned with wreathes of bay and laurel, but smothered in roses, pecked with pinks, showered with lilies, and hailed in a double sense with all the most delightful contributions of the conservatory. The Academy of Music therefore bloomed, blossomed and radiated pleasant fragrance, yesterday, on the occasion of the One Hundred and Eighth Commencement of Columbia College. Seldom have those classic halls contained a more brilliant audience, or rescended with sweether sounds than the music of the excellent orchestra which Mr. HELMSMULLER directed throughout the day. The stage was tastefully decorated with the national colors, and at 10 o'clock precisely the Committee of Arrangements conducted to their seats the President, Faculty, Trustees and invited guests. Among rehersed note were President King. Professors Lieber, Nairne, Davies, Peek, McVickar, Drisler, Schmidt and Anderson, Chancellor Ferris, of the New-York University, Bishop DeLancey, Rev. Drs.
