abstract: Our advices from Gen. McCLELLAN'S army this morning are highly important. Dispatches from the General to the War Department announce that our pickets on the left were advanced considerably yesterday, under sharp resistance on the part ...
lead_paragraph: Our advices from Gen. MCCLELLAN's army this morning are highly important. Dispatches from the General to the War Department announce that our pickets on the left were advanced considerably yesterday, under sharp resistance on the part of the enemy. The movement, we judge, commenced about noon. At 3 o'clock Gen. McCLELLAN telegraphed that the picket lines of Gen. KEARNEY and one-half those of Gen. HOOKER were where he desired them to be, and that he hoped soon to accomplish all he aimed at for the day. At 5 o'clock he telegraphed that the affair was over, and that he had gained his point fully, and with but little loss, notwithstanding the strong opposition. The enemy was driven out of his camps in front, and all was quiet. While this important movement was being made on the left, Gen. FITZ-JOHN PORTER, further to the right, succeeded in silencing the enemy's batteries in his front. Gen. McCLELLAN has now gained an advantage which will undoubtedly prove most fatal to the enemy. The troops engaged -- those of HOOKER and KEARNEY -- are spoken of as having behaved most handsomely.

abstract: The British "guardians of civilization" are again made perfectly happy. Since the stone blockade has fallen through they have had a most lamentable lack of opportunity to void their rheum on America. Gen. BUTLER'S ...
lead_paragraph: The British "guardians of civilization" are again made perfectly happy. Since the stone blockade has fallen through they have had a most lamentable lack of opportunity to void their rheum on America. Gen. BUTLER's order, regarding the women of New-Orleans, therefore, comes like a godsend to them; and the subject has been taken up in both Houses of Parliament, and exploited by the British Bunsby with a gusto quickened by the fact that he has not before had half so good an opportunity of giving voice to some of the choicest qualities of the Cockney heart and head. We knew at the time the order was made that it was a capital tub to catch just such a whale as John Bull. We did not suppose, however, that English "indignation" would take any other form that a little more than the usual quantum of thunder and lightning (of the sheet-iron and tin-pan style) from the Times, Saturday Review, etc. We did not suppose, after the lessons they have had, that insular impertinence would go so far as to make this affair a matter of adjudication before Lords and Commons.

abstract: We are  now in regular receipt of Union newspapers from North Carolina, South Carolina and Florida from New-Orleans, Memphis, Nashville, and many points in Tennessee from all parts of Kentucky, Missouri and Western Virginia  from Norfolk, Alexandria, and other places in Eastern Virginia; in fact, they come to us from more than half of the region lately held by the late rebel Confederacy.
lead_paragraph: We are now in regular receipt of Union newspapers from North Carolina, South Carolina and Florida -- from New-Orleans, Memphis, Nashville, and many points in Tennessee -- from all parts of Kentucky, Missouri and Western Virginia -- from Norfolk, Alexandria, and other places in Eastern Virginia; in fact, they come to us from more than half of the region lately held by the late rebel Confederacy. Why Gen. MITCHEL has not issued an organ at Huntsville, during the occupancy of that pleasant Alabama town, we do not know; but probably because he and his men have been too busy to spare time for the editing of it. We have most likely a Union organ by this time at Baton Rouge, as our forces have been in possession of that Capital for over a month; and we shall doubtless at once have one at Little Rock. Richmond, too, will soon doubtless enjoy the blessings of a loyal Press; and we expect that even the Charleston Mercury will ere long, under the able editorship of Gen. HUNTER, be showing forth the blessings of Union and Freedom, which the Carolinians have not had preached to them for, lo! these many years. These presses undoubtedly are doing, and will continue to do, a great deal of good. It was by the falsehoods of the rebel Press that the rebellion was stimulated and brought to a headway, and is now sustained; and it must be largely through the efforts of a loyal Press that the power and love of the Union will be restored.

abstract: Mr. SIMMONS, of Rhode Island, who has not heretofore enjoyed a reputation for that spotless purity which should adorn the senatorial toga, but who has thus far escaped any very marked exposure, has at last been brought fairly to the bar of public opinion.
lead_paragraph: Mr. SIMMONS, of Rhode Island, who has not heretofore enjoyed a reputation for that spotless purity which should adorn the senatorial toga, but who has thus far escaped any very marked exposure, has at last been brought fairly to the bar of public opinion. There were contracts for arms to be awarded. As a Senator and the Chairman of one important Committee, and a member of others, Mr. SIMMONS was able to exert high influence at the War Department, and did exert it. The result was the allotment of a very profitable contract for Springfield muskets to a friend of the Senator, for which the friend was charged by the Senator a commission of $50,000, and the commission was paid. The facts brought out by the Contract Investigating Committee, Mr. SIMMONS admits to be correct; so the case is in all respects agreeably snug and complete.

abstract: The clerk of the weather, possibly sorry for the grevious disappointments which he had inflicted on the hundreds of ladies who look forward to Commencement Day as the acme of their annual enjoyment, shut up the water gates, and granted a glorious day for "Commencement," which was thankfully acknowledged.
lead_paragraph: The clerk of the weather, possibly sorry for the grevious disappointments which he had inflicted on the hundreds of ladies who look forward to Commencement Day as the acme of their annual enjoyment, shut up the water gates, and granted a glorious day for "Commencement," which was thankfully acknowledged. The "Mansion House," the headquartersof the students, and therefore most sought by mothers and sisters, was crowded to overflowing by parties from all parts of the State, and from other States, each anxious to share in the triumph of some particular favorite.

abstract: Business at the Custom-house has been very active for the past few days. Importers have been for a long time looking with anxiety for the introduction of the new Tariff bill, which, it was supposed, would have been introduced much sooner than it was. The unexpected delay in the passage of the Tax bill was the cause of the non-introduction of the Tariff at an earlier date, as the two measures were intended to go together, the rates of duty on foreign goods imposed by the latter being arranged to accord with those of internal duty levied by the former.
lead_paragraph: Business at the Custom-house has been very active for the past few days. Importers have been for a long time looking with anxiety for the introduction of the new Tariff bill, which, it was supposed, would have been introduced much sooner than it was. The unexpected delay in the passage of the Tax bill was the cause of the non-introduction of the Tariff at an earlier date, as the two measures were intended to go together, the rates of duty on foreign goods imposed by the latter being arranged to accord with those of internal duty levied by the former.

abstract: The story of the capitula  tion of the French army in Mexico, which we received yesterday by way of the Pacific coast, is undoubtedly untrue. We have already published news from our own corre  spondent at the City of Mexico, two days later than the date of the alleged capitulation, and no mention was made of so vitally important as occurrence.
lead_paragraph: -- The story of the capitulation of the French army in Mexico, which we received yesterday by way of the Pacific coast, is undoubtedly untrue. We have already published news from our own correspondent at the City of Mexico, two days later than the date of the alleged capitulation, and no mention was made of so vitally important as occurrence. The story probably had its foundation in the news of the defeat of the French at Puebla, which, as it traveled westward to the Pacific and northward to San Francisco, got changed into the shape and magnified into the proportion in which it now comes to us. This is the second stupendous fiction we have lately received by this route, and the public will hereafter be cautious of accepting Mexican news when it comes by way of California.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the House bill for the appointment of an Indian agent in Colorado Territory was passed. Petitions were presented in favor of a Bankrupt law.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the House bill for the appointment of an Indian agent in Colorado Territory was passed. Petitions were presented in favor of a Bankrupt law. A resolution that the several departments of the Government publish in the daily papers in Washington, once a week, a list of contracts which may have been solicited or proposed during the preceding week, was introduced and laid over. Notice was given of a bill to repeal the act creating an Agricultural Department. The Judiciary Committee reported back the General Bankrupt bill, with a recommendation that it be postponed until next December. The subject will be considered to-day. At the expiration of the morning hour the Confiscation bill was taken up, and debated until the adjournment.

abstract: Our letters from New  Orleans this morning, and the extracts from the Press of that city, will be found deeply interesting. The condition of this Southern metropolis, as it slowly rises from the slough of rebellion into the clear atmosphere of loyalty, furnishes a most instructive subject to the political philosopher, as well as to every patriot who looks to the final pacification of the South, and the unification of the whole Republic.
lead_paragraph: -- Our letters from New-Orleans this morning, and the extracts from the Press of that city, will be found deeply interesting. The condition of this Southern metropolis, as it slowly rises from the slough of rebellion into the clear atmosphere of loyalty, furnishes a most instructive subject to the political philosopher, as well as to every patriot who looks to the final pacification of the South, and the unification of the whole Republic. Slowly the deeply-rooted prejudices of the past are wearing away; rapidly the inhabitants of the city are coming to appreciate the necessities of the case, and their own interests. Gen. BUTLER's rule is characterized by an unflinching energy, by a severity which, if it sometimes seems extreme, is impartial, and appears to be demanded by circumstances, by a [???] toward the [???] which gives the lie to rebel and British falsehoods, by a general ability which seems to master at once every new situation. The most intricate legal cases he resolves; the most minute details of local affairs he supervises; the largest practical questions he fearlessly grapples with. As a study in the general subject of rebel pacification, New-Orleans furnishes the finest field, and for it our columns this morning furnish admirable material.

abstract: POPULAR EXCITA  BILTY. Whatever mystery attended the visit of the President to West Point is sufficiently cleared up. The Republic is not in danger, Washington is safe, Gen. McCLELLAN is neither dead or defeated, JACKSON has not gobbled up FREMONT.
lead_paragraph: -- POPULAR EXCITABILTY. -- Whatever mystery attended the visit of the President to West Point is sufficiently cleared up. The Republic is not in danger, Washington is safe, Gen. MCCLELLAN is neither dead or defeated, JACKSON has not gobbled up FREMONT. There is no apprehension of any of these calamities occurring within the next forty-eight hours. The whole secret is that the President, entertaining, with becoming modesty, doubts as to certain knotty points in the "strategy" of the campaign he is directing with so much military skill and success, naturally desired to consult an authority wiser than himself, and therefore thrust a clean shirt and his map of Virginia into a carpet-bag, and repaired to the Summer quarters of the late General-in-Chief. What points were presented, discussed and solved at this kindly and cordial interview, who shall tell? Let it suffice that it ended with entire satisfaction on both sides, each interlocutor expressing his confidence in the success of the army and the cause; and Gen. SCOTT confessing that a very serious burden of anxiety had, by the Presidential confidences, been displaced from his loyal old heart.

abstract: We suppose that, by an attentive perusal of our daily budget of correspondence and telegrams from our army in front of Richmond, the reader will obtain as correct an idea of the situation and prospects there as it is in the power of words to give.
lead_paragraph: We suppose that, by an attentive perusal of our daily budget of correspondence and telegrams from our army in front of Richmond, the reader will obtain as correct an idea of the situation and prospects there as it is in the power of words to give. It is briefly this: -- that affairs are in an exceedingly critical condition; that any hour may bring on a conflict which will rage along the entire line, and that that conflict is very likely to decide the fate of Richmond; that our army is in fine condition, morally, physically, and militarily, for the battle; that it is prepared, and quite ready for it; that it has been largely reinforced; that daily, though slowly yet surely, it is planting itself in more favorable positions, and making headway, ceaselessly, toward the rebel capital; and an official dispatch from Gen. MCCLELLAN, published this morning, announces that yesterday, after a brisk skirmish, he gained a point on the enemy's right, whose importance, though we cannot here precisely indicate it, is such that it will enable him to operate directly upon the rebel works whenever it may suit his convenience. On the other hand, it is seen that, as in many another critical case, so here, the crisis may for sometime be delayed; that while the breaking of a cloud and the consequent shower of rain may be the means of bringing on a battle, (as in the recent instance of the engagements at Seven Pines and Fair Oaks,) so a hundred circumstances, as little under mortal control as this, may be means of indefinitely postponing it; and that though it is not in the power of Gen. MCCLELLAN to prevent a general engagement, it may not be his plan to precipitate it at the present moment. The public are apt to become so excited by the daily rumors, canards, bulletins and signs of battle, that they think it impossible each morning that another twenty-four hours can pass away without witnessing the decisive combat; while to suggest that a week or a fortnight may transpire before such an event, is considered the height of absurdity. Yet, from day to day, under just suck a flock of rumors, did Gen. HALLECK work his way toward the rebel stronghold at Corinth, till finally he produced what, we now know from the rebels themselves, was little less than a rout of their army, and its virtual dissolution, without a battle having been fought at all. It is not likely -- nor, for that matter, is it unlikely either -- that the rebel army at Richmond will come to as disgraceful an end; and that the great rebellion will fizzle out as meanly and contemptibly as it opened. But at the same time, in speculating upon the present and future, it is well not to lose sight of the events of the recent past.

abstract: SEMI-MONTHLY MEETING OF THE HORTICULTURAL SOCIETY. On Tuesday evening the semi-monthly conversational meeting of the Brooklyn Horticultural Society was held in the Academy of Music. Notwithstanding the disagreeable weather, there was a large attendance of both ladies and gentlemen, and a fine display of flowers upon the President's table. The President, J.W. DEGRAW, Esq., occupied the chair.
lead_paragraph: SEMI-MONTHLY MEETING OF THE HORTICULTURAL SOCIETY. -- On Tuesday evening the semi-monthly conversational meeting of the Brooklyn Horticultural Society was held in the Academy of Music. Notwithstanding the disagreeable weather, there was a large attendance of both ladies and gentlemen, and a fine display of flowers upon the President's table. The President, J.W. DEGRAW, Esq., occupied the chair. A communication was received, asking the Society to recommend a plan of E. WEBBE for expelling worms from the city. If by his plan all the worms are not expelled by 1864 he desires no pay. The subject was referred to a Special Committee, of which Dr. J.B. JONES was made Chairman. S.B. BROPHY, Esq., read a communication from L. BRANDEIS, on the Anacharis Alsinostrum, a fresh water plant of wonderful powers of increase, not known among botanists to have flower-bearing plants. He has had the plant flower in his aquarium, and regards the discovery of great interest to botany. The special subject for discussion -- "The Neglected Fruits and Flowers of America," was considered at considerable length, and was laid on the table to be taken up at the next regular meeting.

abstract: Parliament discusses war; Observations from France
snippet: Parliament discusses war; Observations from France
lead_paragraph: In the House of Lords, on the 13th inst., the Earl of Carnavon said: I wish to put a question to the noble Earl, the Secretary for Foreign Affairs in reference to the proclamation said to have been issued by Gen. BUTLER, the commander of the Federal forces at New-Orleans. That proclamation states that any woman who shall by word, look or gesture, insult any officer or soldier, shall be treated as a woman of the town and dealt with accordingly. I will not insult the House by commenting upon such a proclamation as this, but it must be perfectly obvious to your Lordships that one of two things must be meant. Either it is intended as a reality or a menace. If it was a menace it was one of the grossest, most brutal, and most unmanly insults to every woman in New-Orleans, since it was notorious that there was not a woman in the city who was not devoted to the Confederate cause. On the other hand, if the proclamation be intended to have a practical effect, I beg your Lordships to observe that, by the terms in which it is couched, it gives more unlimited powers to the Federal soldiers than have ever been given to any soldiers upon the earth. The proclamation is absolutely without precedent. We have heard of towns taken by storm, and subjected to all the violence of the troops who have taken them, but that such a proclamation as this should be issued in a large and prosperous commercial town which has capitulated, and of which they have been for some time in peaceful occupation, has never before come to my knowledge. I will do the Northern States the justice to say that I do not believe they are in any sense identified with this proclamation of Gen. BUTLER's, and I trust that they will repudiate it. It, however, this is to be the principle upon which the war in America is to be carried on, it will be a war of extermination. The question I wish to ask is, whether Her Majesty's Government have received any information as to the authenticity of this proclamation. I wishalso to put another question to the noble Lord. There has been for sonic days a report current of the proposal made by the Government of France to Her Majesty's Government for concerting jointly terms of mediation between the belligerents in this war. It is quite obvious that the value of any such mediation must depend on the terms in which it is concerted, on its general character, and on the spirit in which it is received. But assuming that the mediation is such as is consistent with our self-respect and with the material interests of this country, I trust that Her Majesty's Government will give the propositions their most earnest and most favorable consideration.

abstract: The country will be rejoiced this morning to learn that President LINCOLN has at last, by a word, brought order and unity out of the confused and discreditable condition of army affairs that has so long existed in the Valley of the Shenandoah and on the Rappahannock.
lead_paragraph: The country will be rejoiced this morning to learn that President LINCOLN has at last, by a word, brought order and unity out of the confused and discreditable condition of army affairs that has so long existed in the Valley of the Shenandoah and on the Rappahannock. The forces under FREMONT and BANKS in the Valley, and those under MCDOWELL at Fredericksburgh and elsewhere, are consolidated into one army, divided into three corps, and the whole of them put under the command of Gen. POPE. The first work of the new Commander will of course be to take in hand that audacious rebel marauder, Stonewall JACKSON, (and in this business of rebel catching, he has had more experience than any man in the field,) and drive him finally out of the region which he has so long ravaged -- or, what would be still better, and more accordant with POPE's antecedents, "bag" or destroy him and his entire command.

abstract: The Press is generally commenting upon the Franco-Mexican imbroglio, as though the full news of the defeat of the French, near Puebla, had reached France. We believe we are entirely correct in stating that nothing more than the rumor of the defeat of the French.
lead_paragraph: The Press is generally commenting upon the Franco-Mexican imbroglio, as though the full news of the defeat of the French, near Puebla, had reached France. We believe we are entirely correct in stating that nothing more than the rumor of the defeat of the French, which we received several weeks ago, by way of California, and very soon after through Key West, has been received in Paris. This is what the French and English Press are now commenting upon. Some suppose it may be true, while others deny the possibility of its truth, and give their reasons in full.

abstract: SPENCE, that fast friend of the rebels, in his latest editorial letter in the London Times, declares that one effect of the continuance of the American war will be to send shoals of paupers over to suffering Europe. A bright idea, truly, Mr. SPENCE; owe you one! Americans roaming European cities, and extending the mendicant palm, is a pleasant picture in the mind's eye. Perhaps, however, Mr. SPENCE is thinking of the number of rebel poor relations they are likely to have on their hands before long. It is indeed more than probable that a lot of the traitor crew, whom the United States will be quite too hot to hold, will seek an asylum on European soil. But we had hardly supposed John Bull would suffer these dear friends of his to become paupers. That's the most unkindest cut of all.

abstract: A highly important change is announced this morning in the disposition of the forces in Virginia, which have recently been acting independently of Gen. McCLELLAN's command. The armies under Gens.FREMONT, BANKS and McDOWELL have been consolidated, and will be known as the Army of Virginia, to be divided into...
lead_paragraph: A highly important change is announced this morning in the disposition of the forces in Virginia, which have recently been acting independently of Gen. MCCLELLAN's command. The armies under Gens. FREMONT, BANKS and MCDOWELL have been consolidated, and will be known as the Army of Virginia, to be divided into three corps, under command of the three Generals named respectively -- the whole under command of Gen. POPE, the great rebel-catcher of the West. Gen. POPE will undoubtedly immediately turn his attention to "bagging" JACKSON and his peripatetic ragamuffins.

lead_paragraph: With the decision of the Cabinet there will be no disposition to quarrel. An offer of mediation at the present time can amount only to an expression of opinion on the probable issue of the war. As we have before said, there is not the smallest chance that it would be accepted by the Federals, who, flushed with their successes in Tennessee and Louisiana, and proud of their vast levies and buoyant currency, still look upon the conquest of the South as merely the work of a month or two. The endurance, the courage, and the bitter animosity of their enemy are facts which only a few among them are beginning to appreciate. We may, then, look on an angry refusal from the Washington Government and an outburst of denunciation from the Northern public generally, as certain to follow any advice of ours. The readiness of England to take advantage of their troubles, and her baseness in drawing France with her into an interference with American affairs, would be the theme of every tongue and pen in the United States. Something would, indeed, be gained by such a course, inasmuch as we should place on record our willingness to join in preventing the further shedding of blood. But, considering the jealousy of our every action which prevails through the States, it is, perhaps, better that England should not take the initiative even in tendering good offices. If the Emperor of the French thinks the moment opportune for telling the Northern people that in his opinion the subjugation of several millions of their own race is an enterprise beyond their strength, and that the attempt is causing intolerable suffering to Europe, he is at perfect liberty to do so, and Englishmen will be glad to sec good advice offered by a personage who is far more likely to be listened to than any of our statesmen. We should desire nothing better than that NAPOLEON or the Czar, who are two most popular Sovereigns across the Atlantic, should, either separately or conjointly, press on the Americans the counsels which would be indignantly rejected if offered by us. European mediation had better begin on the Continent. All that we can say now has already been said by our politicians and by the Press. The speeches of two or three Cabinet Ministers and the well-known opinions of almost every man of note in either House are equivalent to anything that the French Emperor can disclose to the Americans by a formal offer of mediation. The North knows well the opinions of this country, and, without further official communication, will feel assured that we give a tacit assent to any recommendations which other Powers may make in the interests of peace.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, petitions were presented in favor of a ship canal from Lake Michigan to the Mississippi, and of a bankrupt law. A bill for the relief of the widow of Gen. C.F. SMITH was reported from the Committee on Pensions. The bill to grant the proceeds of certain public lands to aid in the construction of the Northern Pacific Railroad was passed.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, petitions were presented in favor of a ship canal from Lake Michigan to the Mississippi, and of a bankrupt law. A bill for the relief of the widow of Gen. C.F. SMITH was reported from the Committee on Pensions. The bill to grant the proceeds of certain public lands to aid in the construction of the Northern Pacific Railroad was passed. The bill to increase the compensation of Surveyors of Customs in the Northern District of this State was passed. The bill to carry into effect the treaty with Great Britain for the suppression of the Slave-trade was passed, with only four dissenting votes. The bill for the admission of Western Virginia was taken up, but pending its consideration the Senate resolved itself into a High Court of Impeachment, for the trial of WEST H. HUMPHREYS, of Tennessee. The galleries of the Senate were densely crowded to witness the proceedings. The members of the House of Representatives came in and filled the seats of the Senators, who were arranged upon a platform specially constructed for the purpose. The witnesses, including Col. POLK, PARSON BROWNLOW and BAILIE PEYTON, occupied settees on the outer circle. Two tables were placed in the area fronting the Secretary's desk, one of which was surrounded by the managers on the part of the House to prosecute the case, while the other was unused -- the accused with his counsel not being present. The proceedings were conducted with all the dignity becoming a High Court of Impeachment. The accused was found guilty on the first article of impeachment by a unanimous vote of the thirty-eight Senators present. He was also found guilty on all the other articles but one -- that which charged a confiscation of the property of citizens of the United States. The judgment of the Court was, that Judge HUMPHREYS be removed from his office, and forever disqualified from holding or enjoying any office of honor, trust or profit under the United States. The Court and the Senate then adjourned.

abstract: The decision rendered by Recorder HOFFMAN, in interpretation of the Metropolitan Police act of 1860, appears to be impeccable, and in all respects sound law. The act in question does not, as has been heretofore believed, make the exposure of liquor for sale on Sunday a criminal offence. It simply exposes the dealer to be sued for a penalty, which, when recovered, shall go to swell the Police Insurance fund; and instead of arresting the seller flagrante delicto, and bearing him away to the station-house, he must be waited upon by a Deputy Sheriff with a summons, and indulged with all the tediousness the law will bestow upon him. The rumseller then is not a culprit in the dook, but the highly respectable, and doubtless the exceedingly obstinate, defendant of a civil suit. How the act in question came to be thus drafted to defeat the intention of the lovers of public order and morality, we do not happen to know. The framers must have been plentifully devoid of law, or they must have deliberately concerted a fraud upon the Legislature and the people.

abstract: Editorial on European discussions of mediation
snippet: Editorial on European discussions of mediation
lead_paragraph: Our French and English critics now begin to see, in spite of themselves, that the military problem of this rebellion will very soon be solved, notwithstanding their stereotyped prophesies of its impossibility. The flag of the Republic has already been victoriously borne over more than one-half of the rebellious South, whose very vastness was urged as a main reason why it could never be conquered. The arms of the Union have already triumphed over at least a half of the great host, which a year ago, or half a year ago, the rebels had in the field, though that rebel army was declared to be too powerful to be overthrown. The so-called Confederacy, as a military Power, is seen to be already on its last legs, though it was thought that its vitality would be coexistent with that of the Union; and foreign observers cannot help seeing that after the pending battle -- and, we may say, our pending victory -- at Richmond, the Confederacy, as a political Power, will be numbered among the shadows of the past -- the shortest-lived Empire of all time. All these things the European Powers are beginning to comprehend; and therefore they know that intervention between the National Government and the rebels, in behalf of the latter, would be absolutely futile.

abstract: CLOSING EXERCISES AT MLLE. ROSTAN'S YOUNG LADIES' SCHOOL IN TWENTY-FIFTH-STREET. A brilliant audience, composed largely of our French families, mingled with native personages, crowded the elegant reception rooms of Mlle. ROSTAN on Wednesday evening, to witness the closing entertainment offered their friends by her accomplished students.
lead_paragraph: CLOSING EXERCISES AT MLLE. ROSTAN's YOUNG LADIES' SCHOOL IN TWENTY-FIFTH-STREET. -- A brilliant audience, composed largely of our French families, mingled with native personages, crowded the elegant reception rooms of Mlle. ROSTAN on Wednesday evening, to witness the closing entertainment offered their friends by her accomplished students. An opening chorus by the members of the singing class was followed by an appropriate address by Rev. Dr. GILLETTE, wherein he defined his position rather pointedly in saying, that as every rose had its thorn he now represented that essential but offending offset; and often as he had escaped Mile's authority he was upon this occasion fairly constrained, and would, therefore, meet his honorable duty.

abstract: The Count DE GASPARIN, in his latest work on the position of the United States before Europe, says that "from the beginning of the troubles Europe arrogated to herself a sort of benevolent patronage over divided America; she viewed them as minors infants who...
lead_paragraph: The Count DE GASPARIN, in his latest work on the position of the United States before Europe, says that "from the beginning of the troubles Europe arrogated to herself a sort of benevolent patronage over divided America; she viewed them as minors -- infants who needed to be directed by maturer minds." With one modification, this remark is perfectly true. This patronizing air has been assumed almost wholly toward the North, toward the United States. The rebels have generally been treated as not only full grown, but even as prodigies of wisdom and virtue. It is remarkable that any one in Europe could have taken so just a view as this of GASPARIN's. We hardly know any one but him from whom it could have been expected. And what makes it yet more remarkable, is that it was written before the most palpable instance of this feeling was brought to light in the debate in the British Parliament upon Gen. BUTLER's order about the women of New-Orleans, of which we give a detailed report in another column.

abstract: John Purchase vs. The New-York Exchange Bank. -- This action was brought to recover damages for a refusal on the part of the defendant to transfer to the plaintiff on the books of the bank, five shares of its stock, which the plaintiff claimed to have obtained from one Erastus Wheaton on the 28th of January, 1856. The demand of transfer was made on the 23d of January, 1857. The defence was, that during the intervening year, and prior to the alleged demand, a judgment had been recovered by a third party against the said Wheaton, and proceedings supplementary to execution had been taken pursuant thereto; that a receiver of Wheaton's property had been appointed by the Court, and the said stock sold and the proceeds applied toward the satisfaction of the said judgment; and further, that the stock then stood in Wheaton's name, on the books of the Bank, and its officers had no notice prior to the said demand, of any ownership or interest therein on the part of the plaintiff.
lead_paragraph: John Purchase vs. The New-York Exchange Bank. -- This action was brought to recover damages for a refusal on the part of the defendant to transfer to the plaintiff on the books of the bank, five shares of its stock, which the plaintiff claimed to have obtained from one Erastus Wheaton on the 28th of January, 1856. abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the President was requested, if not incompatible with the public interest, to transmit to the Senate the report of JOSEPH HOLT and ROBERT DALE OWEN on contracts. A bill to establish a National Foundry in ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the President was requested, if not incompatible with the public interest, to transmit to the Senate the report of JOSEPH HOLT and ROBERT DALE OWEN on contracts. A bill to establish a National Foundry in the Hanging Rock iron and coal districts of Ohio, was referred to the Military Committee. The bill to prevent members of Congress, or any officers of the Government, from taking any consideration for procuring contracts, office or place, was passed. A report from the Conference Committee on the bill to reorganize the Navy Department, was agreed to. The Confiscation bill was then taken up, and debated until the adjournment.

abstract: The extreme penalty of the law was yesterday inflicted upon WILLIAM H. HAWKINS the colored steward of the ship Lammergeyer, for murdering the Captain of the vessel on the high seas. A good deal of sympathy has ...
lead_paragraph: The extreme penalty of the law was yesterday inflicted upon WILLIAM H. HAWKINS the colored steward of the ship Lammergeyer, for murdering the Captain of the vessel on the high seas. A good deal of sympathy has been expressed for this man, and so far as his boldness in view of the near approach of death is concerned, it has not been without reason. But it is difficult to see why the man should have escaped the death penalty, if it is ever to be inflicted upon any murderer. He was conclusively proved to be a murderer. In the silence of the night he stole unobserved to the bed where his victim lay asleep, unguarded and unsuspecting, and deliberately took his life. It was not in a scuffle; it was not under the sharp spur of immediate and gross provocation. He had been injured, as he thought, but his wrath had had hours to cool, and his deed was a deed of cold-blooded revenge. There never was a murder which more perfectly filled out all the elements required to constitute the crime.

lead_paragraph: The United States transport Ericsson, Capt. LOWDER from Tortugas 16th inst., Key West 18th and Port Royal 23d, arrived here yesterday morning. She brings a large mail from all the above places, and has 181 passengers, among whom is Gen. BENHAM and Staff. She has also on board 57 wounded soldiers, who were wounded in the late engagement on James Island, S.C. They are in charge of Surgeons CRAVEN and SCHOLL. She brought from Key West four Companies of the Fortieth New-York State Volunteers, and landed them at Port Royal, also the Seventh New-Hampshire and four companies First United States Artillery, regulars.

abstract: SUICIDE IN THE JERSEY CITY PRISON. -- On Wednesday evening, a man giving his name as JOHN DAVIS, and stating he was born in England, and was 35 years of age, applied at the Police station in Jersey City for lodging. It being evident from his strange manner that he was insane, or suffering from the delerium tremens, it was thought best to lock him up, and he was therefore placed in a cell. At 1 o'clock yesterday morning, a groan attracted the attention of Chief REILY, when, upon going to the cell, he found the man in the last agonies of death, and lying in a pool of blood, he having committed suicide by severing the arteries of his left arm. The weapon used to commit the fatal deed was the blade of a shoemaker's knife, which the man had managed to secrete about his person, so as to escape detection when searched before being placed in his cell. Coroner GAFFNEY held an inquest upon the body. A verdict was rendered in accordance with the above facts. The deceased was a stranger in Jersey City, and nothing was found upon his person by which any information could be derived concerning him.

abstract: The Charleston Press is to receive credit for the general correctness of its reports of what happened near Secessionville on the 16th inst. The story, as told by our own fellows, ...
lead_paragraph: The Charleston Press is to receive credit for the general correctness of its reports of what happened near Secessionville on the 16th inst. The story, as told by our own fellows, is pretty much to the same purpose. There were intrenched rebels, with batteries heavy and light, rifle-pits in abundance, flanked by woods filled with sharpshooters. There were swamps to protect them, and embarrass the enemy. Upon these formidable defences the Union troops were flung without preparation, half of them with leadless muskets, the rest with guns uncapped; there was some unequal artillery play, wherein our boys, completely unsheltered, came by the worse; and a charge or two marked by the exhibition of reckless gallantly, which extracted praise even from the enemy. The assault was desperate, but it failed. All the men could do was done. They actually forced their way into the enemy's works; struck down the artillerists at their guns; and only retired when the lack of support proved the hopelessness of the conflict, and then with the steadiness of men retiring from a parade-ground rather than from a battlefield. No want of pluck and nerve was chargeable to officers or men. They did their part; but through some blunder, only 2,000 of our forces were brought into action against 10,000 intrenched and secure rebels, and the odds were too tremendous. They retired as the 600 retired from the Russian batteries at Balaklava.

abstract: The affair near the Seven Pines, on Wednesday last, grows in magnitude with time, like all our battles on the Peninsula and before Richmond. Gen. MCCLELLAN, in his official report. said it was "not a battle, merely an affair of HEINTZELMAN's Corps, supported by KEYES," and this, of course, was strictly correct; but still the affair was of much more consequence than our first accounts would seem to indicate, and the loss, it appears, was much heavier than first reported. Our correspondent furnishes this morning a list of two hundred killed and wounded, while the whole number of our men lost in the engagement amounted to at least three times those figures, and probably even more. The number of killed, however, in comparison with the wounded, as will be seen from our list, is extraordinarily and unusually small, which arose in great measure from the character and circumstances of the fighting. Of the rebel loss we have no accurate estimate, but there is little doubt that it was heavier than our own. All accounts, official and unofficial, concur in representing the bearing and behavior of our troops in the action as being -- to use the word of Gen. MCCLELLAN -- "splended."

abstract: --Though Gen. FREMONT has, at his own request, been relieved from the command of the first Army Corps of the newly constituted Army of Virginia, it does not necessarily follow that he will not accept of any other command, or that he will leave the field. Whether he does so or not, depends upon himself and the will of the Commander-in-Chief. It was reported before his appointment to the command of the Department of the Mountains, that he announced himself willing to resign his Major-Generalship, and accept the Colonelcy of a regiment, or even to enlist as a private soldier, that he might serve his country. It is very doubtful, however, considering all the circumstances, whether he will again take any prominent command during the war.

abstract: Let our possessions be what they may - marble palaces, broad lands, magnificent plate, or caskets of "precious stones" -- they all sink in the balance as against Heaven's great boon, HEALTH, and they cannot be enjoyed without it. The language of nature attests that whoever would enjoy the pleasures of food, the beauties of flowers and landscapes, the joys of companionship, the richness of literature, or the honors of station and renown, must preserve their health. And yet how little is it valued, and how carelessly preserved. The stomach is the receptacle of all nourishment, and the fountain from which all parts of the body derive their sustenance. When foul, injurious food enters the stomach, acute sympathy disorganizes all other organs, and disease more or less painful must follow. The laws of nature cannot be violated with impunity. Night revelry, luxurious living, irregularity of meals, and a disordered appetite, will gradually destroy the power and activity of the stomach. How many ladies and gentlemen eat and drink disease at late suppers, and arise in the morning with headache, loss of appetite, feeling languid, unrefreshed, feverish, low spirited, weak and incapacitated to perform any mental or physical duty, and dream not this is the beginning of that horrid disease.

abstract: At the third day's racing, to-day, there were between three and four thousand spectators. The weather was beautiful, and the track, considering the late heavy rains, in good condition. The first race was a single dash of one mile, and was won by JOHN HUNTER'S Miss Jessie, beating Lexington, filly, and Erolite half a length, in 1.46 .

abstract: Our streets just now are thronged with army officers, who sport their shoulder-straps on the fashionable promenades, or clink their spurs in the festive barroom. Do these soldiers not see that silent rebuke darts from the eyes of every sensible man and woman they pass that they should thus be away from the post of duty on the field? The sympathy and admiration evoked by the spectacle of the maimed and wounded heroes who have suffered in the entire of their country is only equalled by the contempt felt for those idle soldiers who parade their indolence on the public thoroughfares. It has been authoritatively stated that no more furloughs are to be granted on any pretext whatever: but why not immediately summon these dilectanti soldiers to duty. We have seen it intimated several times that the Secretary of War was about to order every man to his post, and dismiss those who did not obey. We should like to see it done, not merely talked about. The services of every man are imperatively wanted, and the country expects the Secretary to do his duty in the matter promptly and efficiently.

abstract: A FEW STATISTICS DEVELOPED BY THE CHRISTIAN ALLIANCE OF NEW-YORK. -- The present interest attaching to the alliance of all the different denominations is, their labor in behalf of our soldiers. The members of it began to preach to the volunteers when the earliest volunteering excitement seized upon our citizens -- when, some twelve months ago, Broadway and other less noted thoroughfares were dotted at every few paces with eager bands of recruits; and to these net alone upon the Sabbath, but dining the week did messengers repair with attractive reading matter and good advice from the Alliance. The daily journals of the City and such of the weeklies as could be recommended, were freely distributed among them, till the "boys," at them leave-takings, would bear a regretful memory of these (to many of them) unusual privileges, and would call out to the missionaries "Mind you don't for get to send us our papers." They were promised, and the promise has been more than fulfilled; for not only papers but books such as they could not help being interested in perusing have been plentifully furnished them. Already have sixty-five million duodecimo pages been printed and sent to our volunteers. Mr. GOSS, one of the active missionaries of the Society, has lately visited the camps, and says that he has of discovered that just such matter as we love to read at home our brave boys love to get on the battle-field. He observed a bushel basket of tracts sitting upon a drum-head, which, although remaining for a long, weary day, was never approached or touched by the men, who are sick of unmeaning philosophy, but eagerly long for that which instructs and revives, as does with unvarying certainty the spirit of true religion as his presented to the cultivated perceptions by a thousand channels in the beautiful processes of nature and developments of the day. A rainy day in camp or the submitted surroundings of the hospital are found to be chosen occasions for the brotherly undertaking of the Alliance messengers, and the workers steadily gaining in power and results.

abstract: THE DEATH OF COL. JAMES H. PERRY. -- The sudden announcement yesterday, of the death of Col. JAMES H. PERRY, of the Forty-eighth (Brooklyn) Regiment, who died at Fort Pulaski on the 18th inst. of apoplexy, caused a gloom to hang over the whole people, such as has not been felt before since the war began. The deceased was not only an accomplished officer, but he was a Christain gentleman and a patriot in the broadest sense. Having for many years, as a minister of the Gospel, occupied the pulpits of several of the most prominent churches of the Methodist persuasion, in this city, he had endeared himself to a very large circle of friends who now deeply feel his loss. When the slaveholders first sounded the tocsin of war, Col. PERRY was among the first to offer his services to the Government. He was at that time pastor of the Pacific-street Methodist Episcopal Church, and in announcing the determination he had arrived at to his congregation, he feelingly said that he owed his services to the country, for "I received my education from her, and I owe her all my education will enable me to do." He received authority to enlist a regiment, and raised the "Continental Guard," or Forty-eighth Regiment New-York Volunteers, and proceeded to the seat of war on the 17th of September last. His command was at the taking of Port Royal, took an active part, in the battle on Daufuskie Island, and rendered important service in the preliminary arrangements made to reduce Fort Pulaski. Col. PERRY was about fifty-two years old at the time of his death, having been born in Ulster County, New-York, in 1811. He graduated at West Point in 1836 with high honors, and there being no active service for him, he resigned his position in the army soon after. About this time, the young Republic of Texas needed military assistance, and Col. PERRY accepted a position under Gen. HOUSTON -- then at the zenith of his glory. Under that distinguished man, be acted as aid at the bloody battle of San Jacinto, and participated in many of the subsequent struggles of the Taxans in establishing their independence. The object for which he entered the service of the "Lone Star State" having been accomplished -- its independence -- he resigned the commission he held and [???] his way northward. We next hour of him preparing for the ministry, and soon afterward he was ordained as a minister of the Methodist Episcopal Church. His first charge was at Newfield, Conn.; and after that he was stationed at Madison, Conn.; Milburn, N.Y.; Sag Harbor, N.Y.; Bridgeport and Southport, Conn.; Mariner's Church, Cherry-street, New-York; Carleton-avenue Church, Brooklyn; Fleet-street Church, Waterbury, Conn.; Hansom-place, Brooklyn, and lastly the Pacific-street Church, Brooklyn. Seven years of his ministerial life were passed in this City. Two sons of deceased early gave their advices to their country. One perished at Bull Run, and the other is now an officer in the Forty-eighth Regiment. Col. PERRY was a man of fine presence and not only deserved but commanded respect. The members of his own regiment almost idolized him and yet he was one of the strictest disciplinarians in the whole army. His remains will be brought to this city for interment at an early day. As soon as his death was announced yesterday, the flags throughout the city were lowered to half-mast in token of the loss the public has sustained in his death. Col. PERRY's family reside at No. 281 Dean-street, this city.

abstract: Editorial on French and British distortions of war news
snippet: Editorial on French and British distortions of war news
lead_paragraph: The European eye has a notorious habit of looking at things American through the wrong end of the lorgnette. It is not enough that we are far off; we must be artificially belittled. Only when our faults are to be observed, is the glass used normally, and made to maganify instead of to diminish. If, now and then, some close and candid observer like a STUART MILL, or a DE GASPARIN, ventures to outrage the reigning style by giving his countrymen a salvo of facts, uncolored and lucid, about our Republic, he is assailed with volleys of imprecations and refutations. His blind countrymen don't wish to be enlightened; they prefer their good old, half-blundering, half-malicious way; they will use their glasses in the manner which best suits them, and as for the daring innovator, his telescopes are bad, or something is the matter with his eyes.

abstract: The People vs. Joseph Hart. -- A statement of this case in a former proceeding was published in the TIMES of the 27th. At that date the Court decided that an injunction would not issue to restrain the police authorities from rearresting Hart, he having been before arrested, and discharged on habeas corpus. Hence on the night of the day of the decision, the Police Superintendent, by one of his officers, caused the present, arrest, the defendant being charged with the violation of the Concert Saloon Act, in vending lager bier to the audience at Volk's Garten, (of which defendant is proprietor.) during the performance there on that night.

abstract: CONTRIBUTIONS TO OUR WOUNDED SOLDIERS BY PUBLIC SCHOOL No.48. While Churches and association are providing for the wounded in our hospitals, and the benevolent of both sexes are giving their time and means in alleviating the sufferings of the noble defenders of our country, the teachers and pupils of some of the New-York Public Schools are doing  "what they can" for the cause. Ward School No. 48.
lead_paragraph: CONTRIBUTIONS TO OUR WOUNDED SOLDIERS BY PUBLIC SCHOOL NO. 48. -- While Churches and associations are providing for the wounded in our hospitals, and the benevolent of both sexes are giving their time and means in alleviating the sufferings of the noble defenders of our country, the teachers and pupils of some of the New-York Public Schools are doing "what they can" for the cause. Ward School No. 48, under the charge of JAS. H. PARTRIDGE, Esq., recently made its first contribution to the wounded soldiers. The sufferers in the hospital corner of Fifty-first-street and Lexington-avenue were the glad recipients of this donation. Three large wagons were required to forward the packages of hospital shirts, linen lint, garments of every description, liniments, tea, coffee, larina, sugar, jellies, &c., &c., which were so generously supplied by the patriotic teachers and the boys and girls of this school. A large sum of money was also collected from the same source, and placed in the hands of the kind managers of the hospital. When the children visited the sufferers -- saw some of the terrible realities of war, and received the thanks of those noble sons of Union -- they exclaimed, with tearful eyes, truly, "it is more blessed to give than to receive."

abstract: Our pickets, yesterday, missing the usual fire of their rebel opponents, pushed somewhat further forward than their old posts, and for some miles along the lines were unable to discover the picket force of the enemy. abstract: further accounts of battle
snippet: further accounts of battle
lead_paragraph: The glorious victory achieved on James Island, on Monday, 10th inst., has one great lesson and result of encouragement and significance, apart from its practical and direct effects. It has proved -- what some abroad denied and gone at home timidly doubted -- that the people of Soul Carolina and Charleston can and will fight for their metropolis and their homes. It may be regarded as a providential enforcement of this lesson that the comparatively small force actually engaged represented all classes of our population in blood and in religious affinities.

abstract: The second  cargo of sugar from New-Orleans, since the raising of the blockade, consisting of 278 hogsheads, arrived in this port yesterday. The prospects are, that, whether or not cotton comes forward from the South this Summer, we are likely to get a respectable supply ...
lead_paragraph: -- The second cargo of sugar from New-Orleans, since the raising of the blockade, consisting of 278 hogsheads, arrived in this port yesterday. The prospects are, that, whether or not cotton comes forward from the South this Summer, we are likely to get a respectable supply of sugar and molasses. A good part of the sugar raising region of Louisiana is already under control of our army and navy, and the planters are said to be not averse to exchanging for gold, their supplies of the saccharine staple -- though it is true that nearly all we have yet received was from stores on hand in New-Orleans. From the mouth of the Mississippi to Baton Rouge, there are many thousands of hogsheads of last year's [???] still on hand, and but very little of it has been destroyed; while the crops this year have been planted and cultivated, and will be gathered and undoubtedly sent to market as usual. Trade generally in the city, as we learn from our files received yesterday, is looking up. Quite a number of vessels were in port; nearly all the closed stores are reopened; and the curious fact is mentioned --it is a fact, not a joke -- that the laborers employed by Gen. BUTLER have succeeded in rooting out all the grass growing in the principal business streets. It will be a long time yet before the Crescent City attains to anything like the commercial prosperity it enjoyed before secession times; but we are glad to see that, as its loyalty is growing, so its trade and commerce also are gradually awaking from the torpor and death into which they have been plunged.

abstract: FOURTH OF JULY IN JERSEY CITY. -- Preparations are being made, by the Common Council of Jersey City, for an appropriate celebration on the Fourth. The First Presbyterian Church, corner of Washington and Sussex streets, has been secured for the delivery of an oration, the reading of the Declaration of Independence, and other suitable exercises, and arrangements are in progress for a parade of the Continentals and the firing of salutes. In the evening, a public exhibition of fireworks will be given at Van Vorst-square.

abstract: Letters received in this city, yesterday, front a New-Bedford man on board the U.S. bark Kingfisher, of the blockading squadron off St. Marks, Fla., of date 3d,4th and 6th inst., give an account of the capture of the crews of two of the cutters of the bark in the Ocilla River. On the 2d inst. the first and second cutters left the ship to proceed some fifteen miles up the Ocilla River to procure water. Soon after, the pilot, with one man to accompany him, left in his boat and followed the cutters, [???] had about twenty minutes the start. On arriving in the river the pilot discovered something suspicious on shore, and landing, found that the rebels had built three batteries, rudely constructed of logs. One of the boats was capsized, and the other was carried off. The men were not seen. Returning to the ship, and giving this information, the third cutter was manned and left for the river to search for the [???]. They discovered nothing but a large grave, recently covered. This they opened, and were engaged in taking out one of the bodies it contained, when, claimed by the approach of the rebels, they took to their boat and returned to the ship.

abstract: One of the gentlemen connected with the Examiner went to all the hospitals to see if there was any person therein who received his wounds from the bayonet. This happened nearly a fortnight since, and we do not know that we precisely recollect the issue of the investigation as stated in the paper. We are under the impression, however, that only one or two were found thus wounded, and that they were accidentally hurt by some of their own comrades in the hurry of the conflict. This statement agrees with all we have heard from other quarters. We have examined many persons -- officers and men -- with regard to the matter, and they all say the Yankees made no bayonet charge, either at Williamsburgh or at Chickahominy. Indeed, they all asseverate the direct reverse. They say that our men repeatedly charged, and that in no instance did the Yankees stand long enough to repeat the shock. MCCLELLAN's statement, in his official dispatch with regard to a charge made upon EARLY'S brigade at Williamsburgh, was so notoriously false, that Gen. EARLY felt himself constrained to give it the lie direct, under his own hand, in the newspapers. His statements about Yankee charges at Chickahominy are given the lie just as direct by every General in the field. But it is not wonderful. A man who can descend to lie as he did about that battle in other respects, will descend to anything.

abstract: -- The English Parliament appears to be greatly exercised in relation to the proceedings of Gen. BUTLER in New-Orleans. The attack in Parliament relative to his order respecting the women has naturally provoked much comment and no little feeling in this country. We cannot understand by what right the English Parliament assumes a tone so arrogant and dictatorial, relative to the measures of one of the United States commanding Generals as military commander of one of our rebel cities. We recommend Lord PALMERSTON particularly to call to mind the historical fact that less than 50 years ago, the war-cry of the British invading army, under PACKHENHAM, on the very spot now commanded by Gen. BUTLER, was "Beauty and Booty." We think it would be in better taste, therefore, for our English friends to use less violent and more modest language relative to Gen. BUTLER's order restraining the women of New-Orleans, which order, all accounts agree in stating, has been productive of nothing but good.

abstract: Now that the British Parliament has disposed of that "infamous " order of Gen. BUTLER, if it has net exhausted all its sympathy over those ill-treated rebel women, who are not allowed to spit at, throw filth upon, and infamously insult Union soldiers, we should...
lead_paragraph: Now that the British Parliament has disposed of that "infamous" order of Gen. BUTLER, if it has net exhausted all its sympathy over those ill-treated rebel women, who are not allowed to spit at, throw filth upon, and infamously insult Union soldiers, we should like to ask for a little of its indignation in another direction. We would ask for one small vial of wrath to be uncorked over those assassins who fired upon the scalded and drowning seamen of the Mound City, and the boats which put off to rescue them from their horrible fate, but we recollect that this was the act of rebels, and as the cockneys have fully determined already that the rebels are conducting the war in all respects like a high-minded and chivalrous nation, they will doubtless greatly admire the deed. But we have learned of an outrage which is just in their line, and we cannot doubt that if it was properly brought before Parliament, representations would be at once made to our Government protesting against the act as "unworthy the civilization of the Nineteenth Century." We refer to the "infamous" act of our Government in seizing the Erie Canal for military purposes.

abstract: The truth, with regard to the lose of the Yankees at Chickahominy, begins to come out, in spite of all MCCLELLAN's attempts to suppress It. At first it was stated, roughly, at 3,000 men killed, wounded, and missing. We knew that was an underestimate, for intelligence received from within their lines made it, by their own confession, amount to at least 4,000 in wounded. Next came the statement of the New-York Herald, which gave 800 killed and 4,000 wounded, besides a number of missing. Knowing the Yankee propensity to lie, we then expressed our conviction that they had lost at least 10,000 men. In the meantime, out came MCCLELLAN's report, in which, after claiming a great victory, he acknowledged a loss of 5,724. Week before last, a lady arrived in this city from beyond the enemy's [???], who had heard their officers say, in the cars, that they were badly beaten, and that their loss was at least 10,000. Now, the correspondent of the New-York Tribune lets out the whole secret, and there can be no further doubt. The loss was at least 10,000. The correspondent is apprehensive that, when the truth is [???] told, it will have been found to be greatly more.

abstract: Editorial opposes moving New Orleans Branch Mint to St. Louis as proposed in Congress; Editorial opposes removing New Orleans branch mint to St. Louis as proposed in Congress
snippet: Editorial opposes moving New Orleans Branch Mint to St. Louis as proposed in Congress; Editorial opposes removing New Orleans branch mint to St. Louis as proposed in Congress
lead_paragraph: A resolution looking to the transfer of the Branch Mint of the United States from New-Orleans to St. Louis, was entertained by the House of Representatives a short time ago. The proposition, with our present light upon the subject, seems neither wise nor politic. On its face it looks like a demand for vindictive legislation against New-Orleans, to punish it for its late disloyalty; but Congress will scarcely sanction it upon any such grounds, after having settled its policy against similar legislation, by its recent action virtually restoring the Naval School to Annapolis. If the proposed removal of the New-Orleans Mint, then, is to be justified on any proper grounds, we must look for such justification in considerations of commercial convenience or financial economy. Let us see whether such reasons are at command.
headline: {'main': 'The Mint at New-Orleans.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Mint at New-Orleans.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: "Gen. Pillow, the military maniac and parvenue charlatan commander, has fallen into general disgrace with the Secessionists. He is now living near Oxford, Miss., terribly awakened from his dreams of martial glory; knowing that he is a butt and jest even with the people he declared himself determined to save from Northern invasion. He recently paid a visit to Beauregard at Okolona, and the former was so disgusted with Pillow that he refused to see him. Gideon foamed and raved, and talked of challenging Beauregard, but did not; and returned to his place of residence full of oaths and mortifications."
lead_paragraph: "Gen. Pillow, the military maniac and parvenue charlatan commander, has fallen into general disgrace with the Secessionists. He is now living near Oxford, Miss., terribly awakened from his dreams of martial glory; knowing that he is a butt and jest even with the people he declared himself determined to save from Northern invasion. He recently paid a visit to Beauregard at Okolona, and the former was so disgusted with Pillow that he refused to see him. Gideon foamed and raved, and talked of challenging Beauregard, but did not; and returned to his place of residence full of oaths and mortifications."

abstract: Editorial on problems of illegal sale of rum, NYC
snippet: Editorial on problems of illegal sale of rum, NYC
lead_paragraph: FERDINAND I., of Naples, (the grandfather of BOMBA II.,) said that "the world was governed by three Fs -- Festa, Farina, Forca;" Holidays, Flour and the Gallows. It may not be a particularly palatable truth to our citizens -- just awakened from their siesta by the din of civil war to the consciousness of rights and duties so long ignored -- to learn that their municipal affairs are under regime compared with which the rule of FERDINAND would be provident and decent. It is the "Festa" and "Forca" -- without the "Farina." It givesus a judiciary with no certainty of justice; fills the City Hall with jobbers and the Departments with plunderers, and sends its instruments to the Legislative Halls with the one errand to protect the liquor trade. It regards the City as its own -- a good place for the manufacture and sale of rum; and it asserts and maintains the right to do this without respect to law and against law -- withholding from the Treasury the prescribed fees for license, and burdening our tax-list with the cost of supporting its victims in the prisons, almshouses and hospitals, when they have passed through the Police, Courts and Juries, sustained and multiplied mainly to finish up the work of the dram-shop.

abstract: -- This tune, which has been played so persistently and loudly by the rebels in the South, and which is now harped upon by the rebel sympathizers and harpists in Europe, will, it is to be feared, soon have to be changed for something else. Not only are thousands of citizens in those parts of the South conquered by our arms coming forward to swear their loyalty, but thousands of rebel soldiers from the repossessed States and cities of the South and Southwest, are returning to their homes, and voluntarily accepting the terms of clemency offered them. In New-Orleans, where uniformed rebels are permitted to return home on condition of giving their parole that they will not take up arms against the Government of the United States, and will not furnish any information nor afford any aid or comfort to its enemies or opposers until released from parole or exchanged, it is found that unexpectedly large numbers are anxious to take advantage of this leniency. The order of the Military Commandant of New-Orleans, giving this privilege to Confederate troops, was Order No. 13, and the fact that a subsequent order in the following terms had to be issued, shows better the present temper of the rebels than any amount of declamation from the rebel Press, here and abroad:

abstract: Editorial says Civil War developments so far have not solved problem of supplying European demands; Editorial says war has not yet solved problem of supplying European demands for cotton
snippet: Editorial says Civil War developments so far have not solved problem of supplying European demands; Editorial says war has not yet solved problem of supplying European demands for cotton
lead_paragraph: The present war has settled many questions that were considered very doubtful at the time of its breaking out. It has settled that there shall be no extension of Slavery in the territory of the United States. It has settled that gradual emancipation is an accepted policy of the National Government in its dealings with Slaveholding States. It has settled that the Union is stronger than any property-interest, however gigantic, that is protected under it. And it has settled that the American Government is a self-existing, self-protecting power among the nations, that can hold its own against millions of traitors, and defy a world in arms.

abstract: War Dept. issues report on changes in Union Army since Dec. 5, 1861; excerpts
snippet: War Dept. issues report on changes in Union Army since Dec. 5, 1861; excerpts
lead_paragraph: A General Order, extending over 52 pages, and containing a list of appointments, promotions, & c., & c., in the army of the United States, made by the President, by and with the consent and advice of the Senate, since the publication of General Orders No. 106, of Dec. 5, 1861, has just been issued by the War Department. This order has been anxiously expected for some time by those officers of the regular army who stand pretty well up in their respective grades, and whose advancement is accelerated by every casualty among those in the grades above them. The list of promotions, however, is necessarily incomplete, although it is supposed to contain all alterations up to the date of its publication. Since it was compiled from the army register kept in the Adjutant-General's Office, several changes have occurred, among which maybe noticed the promotion of Lieut.-Col. WILLIAM HOFFMAN, of the Eighth Infantry, to the Colonelcy of the Third Infantry, in the room of Maj.-Gen. CHARLES F. SMITH, deceased. (Col. HOFFMAN is now Commissary-General of Prisoners, and in his absence, Maj. NATHAN B. ROSSELL commands the Third, which is with Gen. MCCLELLAN.) This, with other promotions, waits confirmation by the Senate before being published.

abstract: The United States brig-of-war Bainbridge, Commander WASHER, arrived at this port yesterday, from Key West and Fortress Monroe. She brings news of the health of Commodore DUPONT'S fleet, and has mails but no late intelligence from the Chesapeake She will be surveyed at the Brook'yn Navy-yard at once, and repaired, her officers and crew getting a temporary furlough. The Bainbridge belongs to the old navy, and was in Brazil with Alvarado HUNTER before the outbreak of the rebellion. Annexed is a list of her officers: T.M. WASHER, Commander; Geo. P. Rogers. Executive Officer; F. Hopkins, Jr., Acting Master; John Willson, Assistant-Surgeon; Wm. H. Weldon. Assistant-Paymaster; E.C. Burt and J.F. Baldwin, Master's Mates; J.E. Parkman, Captain's Clerk.

abstract: One of the most important of the great measures before Congress seems likely to be left among the last to be acted upon this session. abstract: The Atlanta (Ga.) Southern Confederacy, of the 10th inst., learns from a gentleman who arrived in that city on the 9th inst., from Nashville, that ANDY JOHNSON was actually killed on Thursday last by ex-Gov. NEIL S. BROWN. BROWN was arrested by ANDY's order sometime ago, to be sent to a Lincoln Bastile up North, but was paroled for a few days to attend to some business. The gentleman says BROWN was arraigned before ANDY last Thursday, when, for some provocation, BROWN drew a revolver and shot him several times, ending the life of the scoundrel on the spot, and that BROWN was hung half an hour thereafter -- all of which, we hear the gentleman says he witnessed.

BROWN, in order that the Secretary's directions may reach as soon as possible, those enrolling officers who, at a distance, may not have received instructions from their superior officer to cease the enrollment of these State officers. Our columns are so crowded to-day that we are forced to postpone comments upon this correspondence to a future day.

abstract: AUGUSTA, June 23. -- A dispatch from Chattanooga dated 21st inst., says Col. DAVIS, of the Second Florida Regiment, with his command, crossed the river this morning at the Narrows. Sharp skirmishing ensued. The result was, that the Yankees were driven back with considerable loss. SCOTT's Cavalry, Col. FORREST commanding, also engaged the enemy. The expedition was commanded by Gen. LEADBETTER. Our loss was one mortally and three slightly wounded. Capt. GURLY, of Alabama, and his partisan corps, brought in to-day a Captain and two Lieutenants of the Nineteenth Illinois Regiment, who were captured twelve miles from Huntsville. Maj. COFFER, captured by MORGAN, is to be exchanged for Lieut.-Col. WOOD. -----
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, June 23. -- A dispatch from Chattanooga dated 21st inst., says Col. DAVIS, of the Second Florida Regiment, with his command, crossed the river this morning at the Narrows. abstract: It was generally expected that a fierce and general engagement would have taken place at our lines yesterday, and, from every indication and preparation, the surmise seemed to be well founded: but, although all were on the tiptoe of expectation, yesterday passed, like many others, without the realization of the much looked- ...
lead_paragraph: It was generally expected that a fierce and general engagement would have taken place at our lines yesterday, and, from every indication and preparation, the surmise seemed to be well founded: but, although all were on the tiptoe of expectation, yesterday passed, like many others, without the realization of the much looked-for and desired event. Early in the day, cannonading, both from our own and the enemy's positions, took place from the right, left and centre, but on the two latter points operations were nothing more than a fierce and artistic artillery duello, in which the enemy were decidedly worsted. Their artillery bearing upon GARNETT's and CHRISTIAN's farms were particularly active, and seemed anxious for a response. This was not long in forthcoming, and they were accordingly shelled from their several positions with much ease and with evident loss.
headline: {'main': "REBEL ACCOUNT OF WEDNESDAY'S FIGHT.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "REBEL ACCOUNT OF WEDNESDAY'S FIGHT.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Editorial again urges passage bankruptcy bill
snippet: Editorial again urges passage bankruptcy bill
lead_paragraph: Miss MARTINEAU has contributed to the June number of Macmillan's Magazine an article which will be read with much interest on both sides of the Atlantic, not only because it embodies the views of a very clever woman on the causes and impending consequences of the Southern rebellion, but also because it reproduces the opinions of some of our greatest celebrities on the same subject. The authoress seems to have been inspired to her task by the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia; and, believing that the significance of this act has not been fully appreciated in England, she essays to show that all the most eminent men of the Republic have foreseen the present state of affairs, and that it would be a serious falsification of history to regard it as either unnecessary or unexpected. She says:

abstract: The first train on the Memphis and Charleston Railroad for Corinth, with a number of teams, wagons, and one company of the Fifty-sixth. Ohio Regiment, besides several officers, was attacked by a large force of rebel cavalry yesterday, about twelve miles from this city. The rebels destroyed the locomotive, burned the cars, killed ten of our men, and captured several officers, including Col. KINNEY, Majors PRIDE and SHARPE.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS, Saturday, June 26.

abstract: As year by year the United States increased in power, certain European countries abated their pretensions of interfering directly in the affairs of this continent. Of these was Spain. Since 1846, however, the idea of a Spanish Monarchy in Mexico has been secretly agitated, principally by a few bigoted ecclesiastics of that country -- generally Spanish born -- some of the scions of the aristocratic Mexican families, educated in Europe and dazzled by the glitter of court, and here and there a desperate and disappointed Mexican politician or army officer.

abstract: On Friday last, two Federal gunboats came up James River to the neighborhood of Drury's Bluff, and commenced shelling the woods on the Chesterfield side. The boats were opened upon by Capt. FRENCH's Battery, from Stafford County, and a spirited engagement was kept up for two hours or more. It is believed that the boats sustained considerable damage, for they finally gave up the contest and started off down the river. The only injury sustained on our side was the bursting of a gun, which seriously wounded WM. D. JACKSON, of Stafford.

abstract: A SERIOUS AFFRAY. At a pic-nic during the last week, two men, named JAMES MARTIN and JOHN HUGHES, had a quarrel and a fight, when the former got the worst of it in the affray. To obtain " satisfaction," he " laid " for his opponent, and with a party of friends fell upon him as he was passing.
lead_paragraph: A SERIOUS AFFRAY. -- At a pic-nic during the last week, two men, named JAMES MARTIN and JOHN HUGHES, had a quarrel and a fight, when the former got the worst of it in the affray. To obtain " satisfaction," he "laid" for his opponent, and with a party of friends fell upon him as he was passing through Carroll-street, South Brooklyn, on Friday evening, and was inflicting a severe punishment. HUGHES, It appear had prepared himself for just such a rencontre, by placing a revolver in his pocket, and when in the contest against large odds, he found that they were likely to pay him off with interest for the punishment he had administered before, he drew the revolver, it is alleged, and fired, the shot lodging in one of MARTIN's arms, inflicting a severe, but not a dangerous wound. HUGHES has been arrested, and, at the proper time, the case will be investigated.
