abstract: Seven bridge-burners were executed at Atlanta, Ga., on the 18th inst. Arrangements had been made for them all to be swung off at the same time; but two of the ropes breaking, the men fell to the ground instead of into eternity. But these two were quickly brought to their feet, new ropes adjusted to their necks, and an end at once put to their earthly career.

abstract: A few days ago we alluded to the immense frauds and villainy being carried on in this city in buying and selling substitutes by men who make a regular business of the nefarious trade. Although frequently spoken of and condemned by this paper and others, the evil still continues, and, if anything, is rather on the increase. It should be put a stop to by the authorities, and some of the swindlers, both the men who furnish them, and the substitutes themselves, who sell their service with the deliberate intention of deserting as soon as the purchase-money is safely in their pockets, summarily punished. Too strong terms cannot be used in condemnation of this pernicious practice. It has a bad influence upon the army, for if these rascals can elude the service, and desert when they please without doing punished, why cannot others do the same? Another case has come to our knowledge. A few days ago a man by the name of LEVASSEUR went to the Third Alabama Regiment and bargained to furnish a substitute for a man then in service. The price fixed upon was $800, the dealer in substitutes receiving $300 for his services. The man's name was BYRNES, who came with a certificate from the British Consul and recommendations from others; but as soon as the bargain was concluded, the substitute absconded, returning, probably, to the person who originally brought him to be sold over to other parties. Within the last three weeks seven men from this one regiment alone have been purchased, all of whom have since deserted. Such conduct is no more or less than stealing, and it is time due check should be put upon such operations by the Police. The morale of such conduct is bad, and, and, if allowed to go on, army will be reduced very materially.
lead_paragraph: A few days ago we alluded to the immense frauds and villainy being carried on in this city in buying and selling substitutes by men who make a regular business of the nefarious trade. Although frequently spoken of and condemned by this paper and others, the evil still continues, and, if anything, is rather on the increase. It should be put a stop to by the authorities, and some of the swindlers, both the men who furnish them, and the substitutes themselves, who sell their service with the deliberate intention of deserting as soon as the purchase-money is safely in their pockets, summarily punished. Too strong terms cannot be used in condemnation of this pernicious practice. It has a bad influence upon the army, for if these rascals can elude the service, and desert when they please without doing punished, why cannot others do the same? Another case has come to our knowledge. A few days ago a man by the name of LEVASSEUR went to the Third Alabama Regiment and bargained to furnish a substitute for a man then in service. The price fixed upon was $800, the dealer in substitutes receiving $300 for his services. The man's name was BYRNES, who came with a certificate from the British Consul and recommendations from others; but as soon as the bargain was concluded, the substitute absconded, returning, probably, to the person who originally brought him to be sold over to other parties. Within the last three weeks seven men from this one regiment alone have been purchased, all of whom have since deserted. Such conduct is no more or less than stealing, and it is time due check should be put upon such operations by the Police. The morale of such conduct is bad, and, and, if allowed to go on, army will be reduced very materially.

abstract: We have received a copy of the Christian Banner, published at Fredericksburgh, Va., by JAMES W. HUNNICUTT. Mr. HUNNICUTT, in a long article headed "Rebellion and Stubborness," sets himself right on the secession question. He says that a faction of "ill-natured politicians," whose motto was " rule or ruin." attempted to usurp the reins of Government.
lead_paragraph: We have received a copy of the Christian Banner, published at Fredericksburgh, Va., by JAMES W. HUNNICUTT. Mr. HUNNICUTT, in a long article headed "Rebellion and Stubborness," sets himself right on the secession question. He says that a faction of "ill-natured politicians," whose motto was "rule or ruin," attempted to usurp the reins of Government. Then he sketches at length the history of the secession movement in Virginia, and charges that the State was carried into the rebel Confederacy by fraud, inas much as it was affirmed that but five or six member of the State Convention bad voted against the secession ordinance, whereas the official records shower that no less than fifty had done so. Mr. HUNNIOUTT then alludes to the efforts which he made personally to check the movement, and the odium which he incurred in consequence. In conclusion he says;

abstract: Official information has been received at this office that the Minister of Marine at Madrid has given notice, that on and after the 31st day of March, 1862,a light would be exhibited from a light-house recently erected on Cape Silleiro, the south point of entrance to Vigo Bay, on the west coast of Spain. The light is a fixed white light, placed at an elevation of 72 feet above the [???] level of the sea, and should he seen in clear weather from a distance of 17 miles. The illuminating apparatus is dioptric, or by lenses of the fourth order. The tower is 38 feet high, of light-colored granite, and stands about 30 yards from the water's edge. The first story is square, the two upper octagonal, and it is joined to the keeper's dwelling. It is in lat. 426 5 N., lon 8 52 38 west of Greenwich. By order.

abstract: Les Miserables, Part I, Fantine reviewed; V Hugo's Les Miserables, Part I, Fantine, reviewed
snippet: Les Miserables, Part I, Fantine reviewed; V Hugo's Les Miserables, Part I, Fantine, reviewed
lead_paragraph: The reputation alone of Maj. BARNARD as an officer of the highest ability in his arm of the military profession, identified with so many of the finest engineering achievements, of the country, would secure to him a large, audience for any utterance he might wish to give in that direction. What he has to say on a topic of such universal interest as the repulse of the National forces in front of the rebel works at Manassas, will be listened to with the utmost attention. What Maj. BARNARD here presents was, he tells us in his preface, commenced in February in a letter to a friend in England, through whom alone he expected it to reach publicity. That style of composition he found it impossible to maintain as he proceeded with the task, and hence he varies it, retaining the epistolary form, however, to the end.

abstract: Just sixty-five years ago yesterday, the corner-stone of the Duane-street Methodist Episcopal Church was laid, by Rev. GEORGE ROBERTS. So far as known, but two who were present at the time are now living. The occasion was celebrated with appropriate exercises in the church yesterday?Methodists from all parts of the City flocking to participate.
lead_paragraph: Just sixty-five years ago yesterday, the corner-stone of the Duane-street Methodist Episcopal Church was laid, by Rev. GEORGE ROBERTS. So far as known, but two who were present at the time are now living. The occasion was celebrated with appropriate exercises in the church yesterday -- Methodists from all parts of the City flocking to participate. The church is the only edifice now standing erected by the Methodists in this City during the last century. The Society was the third of that denomination -- the John-street and Forsyth-street having preceded it. The morning services yesterday were conducted by Rev. Bishop JANES, the afternoon by Rev. J.B. WAKELY, and the evening by some of the old pastors, Rev. Mr. VAN DUZEN, Rev. Mr. DE VINNE, Rev. Mr. BATES and others. The afternoon and evening services were mainly a reunion of the old members and pastors. The entire exercises of the day were highly interesting, and the contributions realized over $500 in aid of the church, which is somewhat in debt, although its property is estimated to be worth about $100,000. The present pastor is Rev. Mr. LEWIS, who officiated in that capacity seven years since. He was last year located in Dutchess County. The present number of communicants is 240. The list has been as high as 800, but owing to the up-town exodus, many of the members and congregation have been obliged to connect themselves with other churches. Among the oldest communicants are Mrs. GEO. SHOTWELL, who joined in 1812, and J.B. OAKLEY, who joined in 1807. The latter gentleman -- the oldest male communicant -- was present yesterday.

abstract: Editorial decries Confederate practice of burning cotton rather than risk confiscation
snippet: Editorial decries Confederate practice of burning cotton rather than risk confiscation
lead_paragraph: Though it is impossible to say how mucy cotton has been destroyed by the rebels, there can now be little doubt that the quantity is very considerable. The work of burning began in South Carolina at the time of the possession of the Sea Islands by the United States forces; it has been continued since at every point in the cotton region penetrated by the National armies, and almost every day we have reports of new acts of incremation. An extract from a private letter from New-Orleans, published in our columns yesterday, stated that "almost every bale of cotton in Louisiana and Mississippi is so placed that the torch can be and will be applied, if found necessary to save it from the hands of the 'enemy.'" "You may calculate safely," adds the writer, "that if no more is destroyed, the growing crop will hardly more than equal the amount already burnt; and if hostilities cease, the coming Fall would find cotton only equal to one crop."

abstract: The great South Gate-house of the new Reservoir, at Eighty-sixth-street, in the Central Park, is now nearly completed, and the public is invited to inspect the work on Monday next. We have heretofore...
lead_paragraph: The great South Gate-house of the new Reservoir, at Eighty-sixth-street, in the Central Park, is now nearly completed, and the public is invited to inspect the work on Monday next. We have heretofore at various times described the Reservoir and appurtenances, but, in view of the near completion of the work, may recapitulate a few details. Our new Reservoir is one of the largest (if not the largest) natural ponds in the world. It is estimated to hold a thousand millions, or a billion, gallons of water -- enough to supply the entire City, at the present rate of consumption, for about a month. The amount of ground covered is about 106 acres, and the water surface 96 acres. It will vary in depth from 32 to 38 feet -- the shallowest part being the rock bottom. The lake extends from Eighty-5fth to Ninety-seventh streets, and from Fifth to Eighth avenues, the distance round it being over a mile and a half. The entire time of construction will be about three years, and the cost, including ground, (at an unprofessional guess) bill approximate $2,000,000. The Reservoir is divided into two equal portions by a stupendous wall traversing the entire length, so that either half may be used independent of the other -- when the greatest depth is attained, however, the centre wall will be covered, so that the lake will present an unbroken expanse. Even the empty bed, as it may at present be seen, affords a sight of really imposing grandeur. So much for the general details of the great work.

abstract: Coalitions, like misery, make people acquainted with strange bedfellows. Generally speaking, they are the devices of faction to foist upon a nation a policy which it does not approve. As a consequence, coalitions, though often successful, are commonly shortlived.
lead_paragraph: Coalitions, like misery, make people acquainted with strange bedfellows. Generally speaking, they are the devices of faction to foist upon a nation a policy which it does not approve. As a consequence, coalitions, though often successful, are commonly short-lived. It is in their nature, too, to bring into contact, and compel to work in the same political traces, men of diametrically opposite opinions, tastes and prejudices. Thus we have seen High Tories and Radicals unite their strength to pull Earl DERBY into the Premiership of Great Britain; and that his tenure of office was short, and the late effort to renew it abortive, -- notwithstanding the artful manoeuvres of that two-edged sword, Mr. DISRAELI, -- is to afford another illustration of the inherent weakness of coalitions, and the jealousy with which they are regarded by the people.
headline: {'main': 'Coalitions and Their Consequences.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Coalitions and Their Consequences.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: News from Confederate States
snippet: News from Confederate States
lead_paragraph: On Monday night signal rockets were frequently seen to ascend from our extreme left, important omens of future events, and from preparations everywhere visible, we were led to suppose that transactions of a momentous character would have transpired yesterday; but, despite every conjecture, nothing whatever occurred of vital importance. Sharp skirmishing is of daily occurrence on our extreme left, but the results have not yet been fully developed. Several wounded in these affairs have arrived in the city, and report the enemy unwontedly pugnacious in that direction, although, from every indication, we are led to believe that their increasing appetite for slaughter will be more than fully satisfied ere many hours shall have passed over us. A few prisoners were brought into our lines yesterday and Monday, and from their reports it would seem that no preparations are yet perfected by the Federals for any "onward to Richmond" movement. It is possible LIBBY's warehouse will soon be honored by the arrival of a few hundred of the blue-coated gentry, and their greeting be far otherwise than as conquerors. From the interior of the enemy's lines we learn from recent arrivals that the depredations of the foe have been frequent, their bearing remarkably imperious and overbearing -- violent hands being laid upon every species of property, while aged inhabitants are daily subjected to harsh language and ill manners. Since Gen. STUART's visit to their rear the rancor and ill-breeding of LINCOLN's hirelings have been more than usually oppressive, their threats and taunts are increasing as to blackguardism, while the unprotected have no resort but patience and silent endurance. Indeed, Federal cavalry have been particularly active in and around Charles City, we hear; squads are patroling all the country in search of rebels and the disloyal; but up to the present their anxiety and industry have been of no avail, for the mounted rebels have thus far cleverly eluded all traps and search.

abstract: The paroxysm of heat to which the weather has suddenly risen, does not tend to increase public patronage of dramatic amusements; but managers are the most hopeful and enterprising of speculative mortals and never allow a theatre to remain unoccupied, if money or promises will avail to open it and get together a sufficient number of performers to make a working company. At this present juncture there are more theatres in operation here than the City has ever known before; and though competition and the weather necessarily interfere with their chances of prosperity, it is evident they must be paying expenses or they would certainly not keep ontempting fortune. It is wise to wish them all success; for the more of them there are the [???] it undoubtedly is for both urban resident and [???] visitor, and the better is New-York's metropolitan dignity preserved.

abstract: Only the Senate was in session Saturday -- the House having adjourned over from Friday until Monday. The official reports of the battle of Pittsburgh Landing -- 160 in number -- were laid before the Senate. The House bill for the relief of the Panama Railroad Company, appropriating $7,475 for transportation, was passed. The bill to establish certain National arsenals was considered until the expiration of the morning hour, when the Confiscation bill was taken up. It was finally voted to substitute the bill of the Senate Committee for the House bill -- 21 to 17, and it was passed. The Senate then went into Executive session, and subsequently adjourned.
lead_paragraph: Only the Senate was in session Saturday -- the House having adjourned over from Friday until Monday. abstract: Col. LOOMIS, the commandant of the headquarters of the (regular army) recruiting service for the Department of the East, has been removed. He will be relieved probably during the present week, Col. LOOMIS has only one senior in the United States army, Gen. SCOTT. Even Gen. WOOL is his junior. Unlike the two distinguished men named, he is a graduate of West Point, and is the oldest "Academy officer" in the service. He entered "the rank" at the foot of the ladder, as a second Lieutenant in the Second Artillery, in 1811. Every important duty performed by the old "18,000 strong" was shared by him, and after 40 years of the most loyal and devoted service he became a full Colonel, and got a splendid regiment -- the Fifth Infantry. He led it for over eight years, whenever the Secretary of War ordered him, and being considered too old, was retired when or before the present war broke out But he would not be idle, insisted on working, and succeeded the gallant HEINTSELMAN in this vicinity. His removal is regretted by all. Col. LOOMIS is perhaps over 70 years of age, but does not consider himself "superfluous on the stage yet."
